professors.name: Paul Carter
professors.bio: I am particularly interested in the use of technology in education. Specifically I have been involved in the development of web-based materials that not only present learners with raw information, but also present an opportunity to learn in an interactive manner through the use of multimedia. As a graduate student of Uri Ascher's I worked on the application of multigrid techniques to the shape from shading problem in computer vision. The problem was modelled by a singularly perturbed elliptic partial differential equation. I continue to be interested in scientific computation, particularly in the numerical solution of differential equations.           I directed the new Bachelor of Computer Science (Integrated Computer Science) / BCS(ICS) program during its first two years in operation. This unique second degree program provides students with the opportunity to combine their existing skills with a solid foundation in computer science. The first cohort of students was admitted in September 2004. Students entering the program have very diverse backgrounds and experience. This intense program assumes no prior knowledge in computer science, yet provides students with the opportunity to graduate with a Bachelor of Computer Science in only two years.

professors.name: Ron Garcia
professors.bio: I am interested in many aspects of programming language semantics, design, and implementation, including language support for library-centric and modular software development, generic and generative programming, and domain specific languages and libraries.

courses.description: Continuation of BUSI 441.

courses.name: MINE 547 Industrial Expert Systems
courses.description: The use of artificial intelligence to solve complex problems in industry. Topics include knowledge acquisition, knowledge representation, knowledge accumulation, and conflict resolution. Credit will be granted for only one of MINE 547 or MINE 578.

courses.name: POLI 347A Law and Political Theory - LAW & POLI THRY
courses.description: An examination of law and political theory that considers topics such as sovereignty, constitutionalism, civil disobedience, rights and the political role of judges.

courses.name: PHIL 560A Philosophy of Science - PHIL OF SCIENCE
NURS 690C Directed Studies in Nursing - DIR STDS NURSING
JRNL 100A New Media and Society - NEW MEDIA&SOCI

courses.prerequisites: One of BIOC 203, BIOL 201 and either (a) one of CHEM 204, CHEM 213 or (b) all of CHEM 205, CHEM 233.

courses.name: FRST 449D Directed Studies in Forestry - DIRECTED STUDIES
courses.description: In special cases and with the approval of the instructor concerned, a student may carry on directed studies of specific problems in forestry.

courses.name: BUSI 493 Strategic Management in Business
courses.description: A conceptual and practical introduction to the major areas of busness strategy with an integrative perspective on managing a business.  Includes the analysis of a business and its environment, the development and evaluation of strategic alternatives, and implementation of change.

courses.description: Perceptual phenomena and their underlying brain mechanisms.

courses.name: EMBA 587B Executive Project - EXECUTIV PROJECT
courses.description: Restricted to Executive M.B.A. students.

courses.name: BIOL 112 Biology of the Cell

courses.prerequisites: One of CHEM 12, CHEM 111 and one of BIOL 11, BIOL 12, BIOL 111.

courses.name: ARTH 227 Art and the Visual Environment in the Modern and Post-modern Periods
courses.description: A selective survey of visual art, architecture and other visual media since 1900.

courses.name: MATH 423 Topics in Algebra
courses.description: Commutative algebra, algebraic geometry, algebraic number theory, Lie theory, homological algebra and category theory, or some other advanced topic in algebra.

courses.name: EPSE 403 Education of Students with Developmental Disabilities in Inclusive Settings

courses.name: ASIA 326 Critical Approaches to Manga and Anime
courses.description: A critical introduction to Japanese manga and anime in the 20th and 21st centuries.

courses.name: CNPS 699 Doctoral Dissertation
courses.description: Pass/Fail.

courses.name: MINE 590E Special Advanced Topics - GEOTHML EXPL&DRL
courses.description: A special advanced course may be arranged upon the approval of the department head.

courses.name: CHBE 481 Bioprocess Engineering II

courses.name: CLST 334 Roman Religion

courses.name: LING 300 Studies in Grammar
courses.description: Introduction to syntactic analysis and theory, with emphasis on description and analysis of data from a wide variety of languages.

courses.name: CHEM 329 Research Ethics and Data Analysis Skills
courses.description: Research ethics; data analysis skills for chemical research. Restricted to Honours students with third year standing and, with permission of the department Head, to Major students with satisfactory third year standing.

courses.name: PHIL 320A Symbolic Logic 2 - SYMBOLC LOGIC II
courses.description: Continuation of PHIL 220. A system of deduction for predicate logic is selected for further study. Completeness of this system and other metatheoretic results are proved. Other topics include computability, recursive function theory, incompleteness and decidability.

courses.name: SOCI 473A Sociology of Mental Illness - MENTAL ILLNESS
courses.description: A sociological approach to the meaning of mental illness; the organization of psychiatric treatment; problems in the explanation of the distribution of mental illness in a population.

courses.name: MINE 698 Seminar
courses.description: Topics in mining and mineral processing for Ph.D. students.

courses.name: JAPN 314 Japanese for Professional Life I

courses.name: MUSC 169A Intensive Chamber Ensemble - INT CHMB ENS
courses.description: Intensive coaching in chamber ensemble for advanced players. Performance of works prepared is expected.

courses.name: ANAT 504 Cell Structure and Function
courses.description: Seminar discussions of current topics in vertebrate cell biology.

courses.name: BIOC 203 Fundamentals of Biochemistry
courses.description: Amino acids and proteins. Enzymes and enzymology. Human metabolic pathways. Structure, function and metabolism of carbohydrates including glycogen storage and gluconeogenesis. Restricted to students in Biochemistry specializations.

courses.name: ELEC 413 Semiconductor Lasers
courses.description: An introduction to lasers and applications. Theory, modeling, fabrication and performance of semiconductor lasers. Optical communications links.

courses.name: MINE 501A Topics for Engineers in the Mining Industry - MINING&MNRL PROC

courses.description: Clinical education experiences with the preventative and therapeutic midwifery care of normal pregnancy, labour, birth, and puerperium with an emphasis on the intrapartum period and assessment and management skills.  A clinical practicum in locations around the provice.  Pass/Fail.

courses.name: GPP 508 Philosophical and Ethical Foundations for Public Policy

courses.name: MINE 403 Rock Mechanics Design

courses.name: FIST 534B Seminar in Film Studies - SEM FILM STUDIES
courses.description: Topics to be arranged.

courses.name: MECH 596 CAD/CAM Principles and Practice

courses.name: EPSE 683 Hierarchical Linear Modeling, Growth and Change

courses.description: Introduction to legal research and writing skills and the use of legal databases.

Parallel algorithms including reduce, scan, and sorting networks.  Reasoning about the correctness of parallel programs.  Performance analysis and measurement for parallel programs.
courses.prerequisites: One of CPSC 261, CPSC 313, EECE 476, CPEN 411 and one of CPSC 320, EECE 320.

courses.name: SPPH 516 Methods for Systematic Reviews in Health Research

courses.name: CAPS 449 Graduating Essay

courses.name: MATH 399 Co-operative Work Placement II

courses.name: BUSI 453 Advanced Financial Accounting
courses.description: An examination of advanced financial accounting topics.

courses.name: FRST 556 Land Information Acquisition and Analysis
courses.description: Principles and application of data acquisition and use.

courses.name: BAMA 590A Directed Studies in Marketing - DIR ST MARKETING

courses.name: PHYS 555F Directed Studies in Physics - DIRECTED STUDIES

Dynamics: Lagrange-Euler formulations, Newton-Euler formulation. Control: methods of control, robot control hierarchy, control of single joint and multiple link manipulators, advanced control methods.

courses.name: LLED 602 Critical Analysis of Issues and Methodology in Language and Literacy Education
courses.prerequisites: (Admission to the Ph.D. program in LLED.)

courses.name: LAW 467D Topics in Corporate Law - TPCS CORP LAW

courses.name: APBI 265 Sustainable Agriculture and Food Systems
courses.description: Principles and practices necessary to understand practical concerns of sustainable food systems.  Credit will be given for only one of APBI 265 or APBI 260.

courses.name: KIN 489A Seminar - SEMINAR
courses.description: Current topics and research in specific areas.
courses.prerequisites: (Fourth-year standing. Consult with Advisor for specific prerequisites.)

courses.name: COMM 434 Land Law
courses.description: Legal principles and concepts relating to real estate and land development.

courses.name: MUSC 167 Introduction to Piano Chamber Music
courses.description: A survey of repertoire and performance issues.

courses.name: MUSC 569C Intensive Specialized Chamber Ensemble - INT SPC CHMB ENS
courses.description: Intensive coaching.

courses.description: Basic principles in the study of microorganisms and their relation to human health for dental hygiene students.

courses.description: Methods for determining the behaviour of large scale industrial systems and their application to the design and analysis of such systems.

courses.name: APBI 401 Soil Processes

courses.name: FIPR 433 Motion Picture Production II

courses.description: Study of the historical development, theoretical basis, practical knowledge, accountability of, and issues regarding curriculum process and teaching in nursing education or practice.

courses.name: LLED 492B Supervised Study in Reading - SPR ST IN READ

courses.name: CRWR 301A Intermediate Writing Poetry - INTRMD POETRY

courses.description: Elements of theory and of Canadian policy and institutions concerning the economics of markets and market behaviour, prices and costs, exchange and trade, competition and monopoly, distribution of income.

courses.name: ARTH 338 Visual Culture in the Age of Enlightenment and Revolution (1715-1830)
courses.description: Art, architecture, and social space in Europe and America: redefining gender, identity and nation in the era of industrialization and political change.

courses.name: MINE 590Q Special Advanced Topics - ADV MIN WSTEMGMT
courses.description: A special advanced course may be arranged upon the approval of the department head.

courses.name: ARST 575R Topics in the Management of Records - TPCS MGMT RECRDS

courses.name: MUSC 107C Composition I - COMPOSITION I

courses.name: STAT 547H Topics in Statistics - TOPICS IN STAT

courses.name: PHAR 503M Graduate Clinical Clerkship - GRAD CLIN CLRKSP

Students will be assigned to clinicians in the selected specialty who are members of either the Faculty of Medicine or Pharmaceutical Sciences and who are appointed as clinical instructors for this course. Rotations will take place at the site(s) where the majority of the clinician's practice is conducted.

courses.name: SPPH 524 Core Biological Concepts of Public Health Practice

courses.name: PSYC 448B Directed Studies in Biopsychology - DIR STUD BIOPSYC
courses.description: Directed investigation of an experimental problem requiring a written report of the findings.
courses.prerequisites: (At least a 72% average in the preceding 30 credits and permission of a faculty member who is prepared to supervise the investigation.)

courses.name: MATH 592B Topics in Automorphic Forms - AUTOMORPHIC FORM
PHAR 503R Graduate Clinical Clerkship - GRAD CLIN CLRKSP
courses.description: This course will consist of clinical rotations of 4-6 weeks' duration (20-40 hours per week, 2 credit/rotation) in selected specialty areas in medicine and clinical pharmacy. Students will be assigned to clinicians in the selected specialty who are members of either the Faculty of Medicine or Pharmaceutical Sciences and who are appointed as clinical instructors for this course. Rotations will take place at the site(s) where the majority of the clinician's practice is conducted.

courses.name: MATH 603D Topics in Topology - TOPICS TOPOLOGY

courses.name: MTRL 350 Metallurgical Thermodynamics II

courses.name: VISA 331 Intermediate Painting II

courses.name: ECED 585A Advanced Seminar on Research in Early Childhood Education - RES EARLY CHLDHD
PHAR 352 Therapeutics II
courses.description: Rational drug therapy, management of patient-specific drug-related problems and therapeutic monitoring of selected disease states.

courses.name: ASIA 453 Japanese Travel Literature
courses.description: Japanese travel literature (myths, legends, poetry, tales, diaries, illustrated guides, satiric sermons, haiku, comic fiction, colonial reporting, and ethnography) from the 8th century to present.

courses.name: EOSC 498 Co-operative Work Placement III

Normally taken in the Summer Session (Terms 1 and 2) following third year. Technical report required. courses.name: CCFI 590A Graduating Paper - GRADUATING PAPER

courses.prerequisites: COMM 292 and one of COMM 203, COMM 392.

courses.name: GREK 501B Greek Prose - GREEK PROSE
courses.description: History, philosophy and/or oratory.  Credit will not be given for both GREK 401 and GREK 501.

courses.name: SOCI 328 Social Statistics I
courses.description: The testing of sociological theories using quantitative data analysis techniques on numerical data from social surveys, experiments and official statistics.

courses.name: BA 530A Study Abroad and Exchange - STUDY ABR'D&EXCH
courses.description: Restricted to students in one of the following programs: M.B.A., LL.B./M.B.A., M.Sc.B., Ph.D. with B.A.D.M. specialization, or M.M. with either ECMS or ECMJ. M.M. ECMS or ECMJ students are limited to a maximum of 12 credits in this course.

courses.name: SOCI 201A Ethnic Relations - ETHNIC RELATIONS
courses.description: An introduction to the study of the relations between ethnic groups and of the interplay between ethnicity and other social factors. The course examines such concepts as: ethnicity, racism, prejudice, discrimination, assimilation, and multiculturalism. Ordinarily the course deals with ethnic groups in British Columbia, and students are expected to carry out elementary research projects.

courses.name: AUDI 547D Directed Reading in Audiology and Speech Sciences - DIR READ AUDI&SP
courses.description: May be taken more than once.

courses.name: APBI 499 Undergraduate Thesis
courses.description: Design and execution of an experimental/analytical research project leading to the preparation of a thesis.
courses.prerequisites: (Approval of a program adviser; consult before the end of classes in third year.)

courses.name: COMM 450 Financial Accounting - Intermediate II
courses.description: Intermediate II. Continuation of the examination of accounting as a means of measurement and as an information system for external reporting purposes.

courses.name: CONS 504C Directed Studies in Conservation - DIR STD CONSERV
MECH 360 Mechanics of Materials
courses.description: Beam deflections, singularity functions; use of tabulated solutions; column buckling; Castigliano's theorem, statically indeterminate beams, bending of beams with asymmetric cross-sections, shear centre; principal stresses and stress invariants in three dimensions.

courses.name: CHEM 540A Seminar in Chemistry - PHYSICAL SEMINAR
courses.description: Compulsory for all graduate students in Chemistry. Pass/Fail.

courses.name: MEDI 535 Research Seminar
courses.description: Reviews of research in selected areas of experimental medicine, including presentation of student's own research results.

courses.name: MECH 305 Data Analysis and Mechanical Engineering Laboratories
courses.description: The use of probability and statistical methods for engineering applications. Mechanics of materials, heat transfer, and fluid dynamics. Instrumentation, data acquisition, and data manipulation using modern computational tools.
courses.prerequisites: All of MECH 220, MECH 223, MECH 224, MECH 225.

courses.name: CRWR 306A Intermediate Writing for the Screen - INTMD WRT SCREEN
courses.description: An exploration of and practice in writing for the screen, focusing on how a writer employs the technical elements of the craft of screenwriting. Manuscript submission is not required for admission.

courses.name: PSYC 361 Motivation
courses.description: Experimental analysis of hunger, thirst, exploratory and curiosity behaviour, maternal and reproductive behaviour, fixed action patterns, and complex processes involved in social motivation with emphasis on the biological basis of motivation.
courses.prerequisites: Either (a) all of PSYC 101, PSYC 102 or (b) one of PSYC 100, PSYC 260, PSYC 304, PSYC 360.

courses.name: SOWK 337 Culture and Race in Social Work Practice
courses.description: Issues and problems inherent in practising social work in diverse cultural settings.

courses.name: GRSJ 224B Gender, Race, Sexuality, and Social Justice in Literature - GRSJ IN LIT
courses.description: Techniques of literary study, with emphasis on intersectionality and the ways in which gender is represented in literature and contributions of feminism and gender studies to literary studies.

courses.name: BIOC 530 Seminar in Biochemistry
courses.description: Attendance is required of all graduate students in Biochemistry. Normally students will make a presentation once per year on a topic approved by their research advisor or committee or on the results of their research.

courses.name: CHEM 445C Projects in Experimental Chemistry - PROJCTS EXP CHEM
courses.description: Principles of experimental design, practice and problem solving in chemistry, including the opportunity to pursue projects in a research setting.
courses.prerequisites: CHEM 345. (or CHEM 335 and fourth-year standing in a Chemistry Combined Major specialization.)

courses.name: COMM 386B Topics in Business III - FIRST NTN JNTVEN
WRIT 098 Preparation for University Writing and the LPI
ARTH 102 Crisis and Contradiction in Art and the Built Environment
courses.description: Concepts and issues critical to the understanding of art and its histories in a global context.

courses.name: PCTH 302 Introductory Pharmacology Laboratory
courses.description: A series of experimental demonstrations and individual laboratory experiments illustrating the basic principles of pharmacology.

courses.name: COMM 365 Market Research
courses.description: The process of marketing research including topics such as problem/opportunity formulation, research objectives, data sources, research instrument design, sampling, data collection and processing and methods of data analysis.
courses.prerequisites: All of COMM 290, COMM 291 and either (a) COMM 296 or (b) COMM 396;  and one of COMM 295, ECON 201, ECON 301.

courses.name: PHTH 521 Pathology for Physical Therapy II
MICB 418 Industrial Microbiology and Biotechnology
courses.description: Exploitation of microbial and animal cells for the industrial production of chemicals ranging from alcohol to therapeutic proteins. Genetic manipulation of cellular characteristics, fermentation methods, patenting and governmental approval processes.

courses.name: STAT 536B Statistical Theory for the Design and Analysis of Clinical Studies - STAT THRY DSG&AN
ENGL 525A Studies in the Eighteenth Century - STUDIES 18TH C
ARST 573 Archival Systems and the Profession
FOPR 262 Forest Access and Transportation
courses.description: Introduction to the physical attributes of forest access and transportation and how they best integrate with the objectives of resource sustainability.

courses.name: FREN 215 Oral French Practice
courses.description: Course designed to provide opportunities for students already well-grounded in grammar to improve their oral skills. Credit will not be given for both FREN 215 and FREN 224 or FREN 225.

courses.name: PLAN 548C Current Issues in Planning - CLIMATE CHANGE
courses.description: Each year the school may offer one or more courses on a topical issue covering recent advances in the field.

courses.name: BIOC 404 Biochemical Methods
courses.description: Theory and application of classical and emerging technologies in biochemical research.  Emphasis on using primary literature and oral presentation skills.  Restricted to Honours students in Biochemistry or others with permission of the instructor.

courses.name: LARC 542 Aesthetics and Sustainability
courses.description: Analysis and planning of landscapes to communicate sustainability and to inform public awareness and design by exploring the relationship between aesthetics and sustainability.

courses.name: LAW 340 Comparative Law
courses.description: Basic theory of comparative law and the differences between the civil law tradition and the common law tradition.

courses.name: STAT 499 Co-operative Work Placement IV
courses.description: Work experience in an industrial research setting. Normally taken during Term 1 of Winter Session of fifth year. Restricted to students admitted to the Co-operative Education Program in Statistics.

courses.name: LLED 526 Second Language Assessment: Conceptual and Empirical Approaches
HIST 370 Europe Since 1950
courses.description: Europe since the middle of the twentieth century. Themes include the Cold War, the development of separate social and political systems in Western and Eastern Europe, the emergence of the welfare state, and the problems of European integration.

courses.name: MTRL 562 Finite Elements in Heat Transfer
courses.description: Application of the finite element method to heat transfer and solidification; steady state and transient heat conduction; latent heat evolution and radiation.

courses.name: PHAR 592B Fundamentals of the Pharmaceutical Sciences Disciplines - FNDMNTL PHAR SCI
BIOL 111 Introduction to Modern Biology
courses.description: Concepts fundamental to biological issues, such as the genetic basis of biological variation, evolution, infectious diseases, causes of cancer, population growth, and human effects on ecosystems.  Not open to students who have credit for Biology 12 (including AP, IB).

courses.name: GEOG 423 Development of Environmental Thought
courses.description: An examination of how attitudes toward human nature and non-human nature have changed from Mesolithic times to the present in Western society.

courses.name: PHRM 131 Study Design and Interpretation I
courses.description: Principles of clinical study design, focusing on biostatistical foundations, randomized controlled trials, and systematic review of randomized controlled trials.

courses.name: FNH 474 Sport Nutrition
courses.description: Nutritional needs of athletes, including energy, carbohydrate and protein; hydration; pre-and post-event nutrition, weight management and body composition issues; ergogenic aids; sports-specific guidelines; and special athlete populations.

courses.name: GERM 110 Beginners' German II
courses.description: Introduction to the language. Ability to communicate accurately in a variety of everyday situations, speak about past events and express ideas and hypotheses in German. See also GERM 433.

courses.name: SPAN 405E Topics in Peninsular and Latin-American Culture - TPCS PNS<N-A C
courses.prerequisites: One of SPAN 220, SPAN 221 and SPAN 302.

courses.name: SOWK 532A Social Work Practice with the Family - THE FAMILY
HEBR 479A Supervised Study in Classical Hebrew - CLASSICAL HEBREW
CENS 404 Gender and Nation: Women's State in Modern Central, Eastern and Northern European Literatures and Cultures
courses.description: Cultural and social discourses of gender in literary works written in Central, Eastern and Northern Europe roughly between 1850 - 1930.

courses.name: POLI 421A Advanced Topics in Comparative Politics: Non-Western - COMPARATIVE POLI
courses.description: A seminar devoted to comparative analysis of politics in non-western states. For specific content in a given year, consult the departmental website.
courses.prerequisites: Two of POLI 220, POLI 320, POLI 321, POLI 322, POLI 323, POLI 324, POLI 325, POLI 326, POLI 327, POLI 328, POLI 329, POLI 330, POLI 331, POLI 332, POLI 333, POLI 350, POLI 351.

courses.name: PERS 104 Persian Reading and Writing for Persian-Speaking Students
courses.description: Reading and writing of standard Tehran Persian; lexical and syntactic differences between written and spoken Persian.  This course prepares students for PERS 300.
courses.prerequisites: (Basic knowledge of spoken Persian and consent of instructor.)

courses.name: EOSC 548B Graduating Paper for Masters Candidates without Thesis - MSC GRAD PAPER
CRWR 511E Advanced Writing for Lyric Forms I - ADV LYRIC FORM I
CIVL 418 Engineering Hydrology
courses.description: Hydrologic processes - weather, precipitation, infiltration, evaporation, snowmelt and runoff generation. Emphasis on quantitative techniques including: hydrograph analysis, reservoir and channel routing, statistical methods and design floods, hydrologic modelling.

courses.name: THTR 356 Costume Construction
courses.description: Advanced assembly and specialized construction methods for producing costume for stage and screen.

courses.name: AUDI 685B Seminar in Language Development - SEM LANG DEVELOP
CRWR 205 Introduction to Writing Creative Nonfiction
courses.description: An exploration of and practice in the writing of creative nonfiction, focusing on how a writer employs the technical elements of the craft of creative nonfiction. Manuscript submission not required for admission.

courses.name: ENGL 340 Introduction to Old English
courses.description: Old English grammar, with readings in the prose of the period.

courses.name: LLED 489A Applied Linguistics for Teachers - APPL LING TEACH
BASM 530 International Trading Environment
courses.description: Credit will not be granted for both BASM 530 and BAIM 500.

courses.name: ARCL 419 The Archaeology of Death
courses.description: A survey of methods, theory, and case-studies in mortuary archaeology.

courses.name: RHSC 505 Measurement for Assessment, Planning, and Evaluation
LIBE 494C Supervised Study in Teacher Librarianship - SUPR ST TCH LIBR
HGSE 359 Ecosystem-Based Management Seminar
courses.description: History, definitions, and applications of EBM; challenges of achieving both economic and environmental well-being with a focus on resource use and management on Haida Gwaii.  Part of the Haida Gwaii Fall Semester.
courses.corequisites: All of HGSE 355, HGSE 356, HGSE 357, HGSE 358.

courses.name: MATH 121 Honours Integral Calculus
courses.description: Definite integrals and the Fundamental Theorem of Calculus, techniques and applications of integration, infinite series. Please consult the Faculty of Science Credit Exclusion List: www.students.ubc.ca/calendar/index.cfm?tree=12,215,410,414.
courses.prerequisites: Either (a) a score of 68% or higher in MATH 120 or (b) a score of 80% or higher in one of MATH 100, MATH 102, MATH 104, MATH 180, MATH 184. (or (c) a score of 5 in AP Calculus AB.)

courses.name: SOCI 364 Built Environments
courses.description: Physical, social, and economic aspects of built environments, including housing and community planning.

courses.name: INDE 443 Senior Clerkship
courses.description: A senior clinical elective for fourth year students. Students will participate in all relevant clinical and academic activities associated with the particular rotation.

courses.name: EPSE 536 Foundations of Education for Students with Visual Impairments
courses.description: Online course.

courses.name: EPSE 604B Advanced Topics in Human Development, Learning, and Culture - ADV TPCS HMN DEV
BUSI 399 Logistics and Operations Management
courses.description: The design and management of systems to make products, provide services and deliver them to the end user.

courses.name: CNPS 535 Perspectives on Adult Psychopathology in Counselling
COMM 486F Special Topics in Business - SUSTAIN MARKETNG
APBI 244 Introduction to Biometeorology
courses.description: Basic principles and processes of climatology. Energy and water balance concepts. Weather systems and climate change, microclimate of soils, crops, forests, and animals.

courses.name: FRST 304 The Science Underlying Forestry Issues
courses.description: Examination of current forestry issues with specific reference to their scientific basis. Not available for credit to undergraduate students in the Faculty of Forestry.

courses.name: CRWR 401V Writing Poetry I - WRITING POETRY I
courses.description: A workshop class in the writing of poetry. Admission is restricted to B.F.A. Majors in Creative Writing.

courses.name: FIST 531A Seminar: Styles in Film - SEM: STYLES FILM
courses.description: Studies in styles or film genres such as narrative, documentary, ethnographic, experimental, etc. Topics will vary from year to year.

courses.name: CIVL 598E Topics in Civil Engineering - UNCRTNTY&RISK
courses.description: Seminar or lecture.

courses.name: MEDG 548B Directed Studies - DIRECTED STUDIES
courses.description: A series of laboratory sessions, directed readings and directed counselling interviews related to selected areas of Medical Genetics. This advanced course may be taken upon approval of the department head.

courses.name: FMED 402 Cardiovascular
courses.description: An introduction to human cardiovascular anatomy, physiology and relevant biochemistry and genetics. Disordered function of the system will be taught by integration of discussion with the normal. As appropriate, pharmacological and other therapeutic and preventative modalities will be taught.

courses.name: FNH 415 Business Concepts in Food, Nutrition, and Health
courses.description: Introduction to and application of business activities in food, nutrition, and health settings. Credit will only be granted for only one of FNH 415, FOOD 515, or FRE 515.
courses.prerequisites: (At least third-year standing in the Faculty of Land and Food Systems.)

courses.name: PHAR 405B Problems in Clinical Pharmacy - PROB CLINCL PHAR
courses.description: Individual assignments involving library and clinical investigation of specific problems relating to drug utilization and information topics.

courses.name: COMM 445 Maritime and International Transportation
courses.description: The characteristics of shipping services and the role of shipping services in the design and management of international logistics systems.

courses.name: ENVR 410 Energy, Environment, and Society
courses.description: The role of energy in human societies throughout history and the environmental and social implications of energy use.  Coverage of both the science and policy of energy use.  Energy supply and demand, energy transitions, analytical tools, impacts, and alternatives.
courses.prerequisites: (Fourth-year standing in B.Sc., B.A.Sc. or related programs.)

courses.name: LLED 372 Teaching French Language and Literacy: Secondary
courses.description: Language of instruction is French. Pass/Fail for B.Ed. students. Non-B.Ed. students are eligible for percentage grading or Credit/D/Fail grading.

courses.name: FIPR 436A Documentary Development and Production - DOCMNTY DEV&PROD
courses.description: Documentary concept development, essential production techniques, and marketing.

courses.name: LIBR 582 Digital Image and Text Collections
BIOF 548A Directed Studies - DIRECTED STUDIES
courses.description: Advanced study under the direction of a faculty member composed of laboratory sessions and directed readings related to selected areas of bioinformatics. Students must get permission to register in this course.

courses.name: ENGL 304A Advanced Composition - ADV COMPOSITION
courses.description: Special emphasis on rhetoric, with a focus on audience, authorial voice, and range of style.
courses.prerequisites: (3rd year standing and 6 credits of first-year English, or Arts One, or 6 credits of ASTU 100 from CAP or 3 credits of first-year English and 3 credits of ASTU 150)

courses.name: CHEM 448C Directed Studies in Chemistry - DST CHEMISTRY
courses.description: Students will undertake an investigation of a specific topic as agreed upon by the student and the faculty supervisor. Open to third- and fourth-year chemistry students.

courses.name: APPP 505 Analytics and Interpretation for Applied Sciences
courses.description: Relevant measurable metrics of a project; data interpretation techniques; introduction to data visualization; overview of big data and predictive analytics; strategies related to metrics and data, ethical and privacy concerns. Collaboratively delivered with the Faculty of Commerce and Business Administration.

courses.name: FNH 342 Critical Perspectives on Consumer Food Practices
courses.description: Personal, collective, and policy factors affecting food choices, including perceptions of healthy eating, gender, identity, family structures, and economic, sociocultural, and political forces.

courses.name: COMM 446 Transportation Economics
courses.description: Economic characteristics of passenger and freight transportation services; market structure of the transportation industry; economic impact of public regulation and promotion and the role of economic analysis in resolving problems of Canadian policy. Credit may be obtained for only one of COMM 446, ECON 480.
courses.prerequisites: One of COMM 295, ECON 201, ECON 301, ECON 206.

courses.name: APSC 173 Engineering Analysis II
courses.description: Integrals and transcendental functions, techniques of integration, applications of integration, polar coordinates, infinite sequences and series, vectors and the geometry of space, and partial derivatives.

courses.name: CPSC 448B Directed Studies in Computer Science - DIRECTED STUDIES
courses.description: Open ordinarily to students in Computer Science with at least a 72% average and the permission of the head of the department or designate. The course may consist of supervised reading, participation in a seminar, and one or more programming projects.

courses.name: LLED 580D Problems in Education - PROB IN EDUC
courses.description: Investigation and report of a problem.

courses.name: ANTH 516 Qualitative Methods in Anthropology
courses.description: A discussion of selected methods used to observe, describe, and interpret cultural phenomena and social organization, including participant observation, interviewing, ethnographic semantics, life histories, componential analysis, and photography. Attention will also be given to ethics in anthropological research and writing and to such analytic matters as the nature of description, conceptualization, generalization, and content analysis.

courses.name: PHYL 522 Advanced Topics in Cardiovascular Physiology
GEOB 307 Biogeography and Global Change
courses.description: Biogeographic concepts in understanding responses in ecosystems to environmental change at global, regional, and local scales. Conservation issues such as the loss of biodiversity and endangered species.

courses.name: HIST 202B Gateway to the Middle Ages - MIDDLE AGES
courses.description: Problems and themes of medieval European History through the close study of the people and cultures that produced them.

courses.name: FNH 403 Food Laws, Regulations and Quality Assurance
courses.description: Canadian and international laws governing food composition, grading, quality and safety; hazard analysis critical control points; statistical quality assurance.

courses.name: EOSC 449 Thesis
courses.description: Original research work under the direction of a faculty member. Required of all honours students. Open to major students with a satisfactory standing, appropriate background courses and permission of the course instructor and the directing faculty member.

courses.name: ARCH 543 Seminar: Contemporary Practice
courses.description: Topics across a range of practice related subject matter.

courses.name: ETEC 533 Technology in the Mathematics and Science Classroom
ARCL 318 Archaeology of Hunter-Gatherer-Forager-Societies
courses.description: Early hunter-gatherer-forager societies, spanning the period from the emergence of the first tool-using hominins to the origins of agriculture.

courses.name: CPSC 410 Advanced Software Engineering
courses.description: Specification, design, construction and validation of multi-version software systems.
courses.prerequisites: Either (a) CPSC 310 or (b) one of EECE 310, CPEN 321 and one of EECE 315, CPEN 331.

courses.name: ECON 590A Special Advanced Course - SPEC ADV CRSE
CPSC 302 Numerical Computation for Algebraic Problems
courses.description: Numerical techniques for basic mathematical processes involving no discretization, and their analysis. Solution of linear systems, including analysis of round-off errors; norms and condition number; introduction to iterative techniques in linear algebra, including eigenvalue problems; solution to nonlinear equations.
courses.prerequisites: One of CPSC 110, CPSC 111, CPSC 260 and one of MATH 101, MATH 103, MATH 105, MATH 121 and one of MATH 152, MATH 221, MATH 223.

courses.name: EPSE 687C Doctoral Practicum In School or Counselling Psychology - SCH CNS PSY PRAC
courses.description: Pass/Fail
courses.prerequisites: (Admission to the School Psychology or Counselling Psychology Ph.D. Program.)

courses.name: ASIA 388 Buddhist, Brahamanical and Jain Philosophers in Interaction
courses.description: Debates on issues of epistemology, language and ontology among the philosophical schools or systems of classical India Nagarjuna, Bhartrhari, Uma-svati, Sankara and others.

courses.name: MINE 520 Advanced Coal Preparation
courses.description: Thermal and metallurgical coals. Desulphurization Theory of coal beneficiation. Dense media separation. Coal surface properties and their effect on fine coal processing by flotation and oil agglomeration; coal/water/slurries. Plant performance testing and instrumentation. Credit will be granted for only one of MINE 520 or MINE 566.

courses.name: MUSC 169C Intensive Chamber Ensemble - INT CHMB ENS
courses.description: Intensive coaching in chamber ensemble for advanced players. Performance of works prepared is expected.

courses.name: ELEC 493 Nanotechnology and Microsystems Capstone Design Project
courses.description: Design, analysis, and implementation of solutions in response to a real world nanotechnology and microsystems engineering problem.  Projects are provided by industry, research laboratories, or other suitable entities.  Includes coverage of topics such as project management.

courses.name: ANTH 304A Ethnography of the Northwest Coast - ETHNOG NW COAST
courses.description: Specialized study of ethnographic and theoretical problems of the region.

courses.name: HIST 104 Topics in World History
courses.description: Thematically-organized topics will explore global aspects of human experience across time. Each section will examine a single theme. Check with the department for course offerings.

courses.name: MUSC 103 Introduction to the Theory of Music
courses.description: Concepts of rhythm, pitch, timbre, and texture. Notation and aural recognition of rhythmic and pitch patterns. Basic principles of melody and form. This course is not applicable to the B.Mus.

courses.name: VISA 311 Intermediate Digital Arts II
courses.description: Investigation of issues and topics in digital media and visual culture through the production of contemporary video art. Technical instruction in video manipulation software. Individual and/or group projects.

courses.name: CIVL 402 Engineering Law and Contracts in Civil Engineering
courses.description: Contract documents; preparation of specifications; torts and independent contractor; companies and partnerships; mechanics liens; agency; evidence; expert witness; Engineers Act and Code of Ethics; industrial design and trade secrets; employment law including occupational health and safety; liability; equity considerations.

courses.name: PHIL 212A Greek Philosophy II - GREEK PHIL II
courses.description: Plato; Aristotle; selections from Hellenistic Philosophy. Recommended as preparation for PHIL 310.

courses.name: EDUC 452B Inquiry Seminar III - INQUIRY SEMNR 3
courses.description: Pass/Fail.

courses.name: LIBR 533 Legal Information Sources and Services
KIN 382 Meaning and Values in Sport
courses.description: An analysis of the experience of sports activities.

courses.name: EECE 571D Electrical Engineering Seminar and Special Problems - PWR SYSTM DYNMC
EOSC 433 Geotechnical Engineering Practice
courses.description: Application of rock/soil engineering principles and techniques used in geotechnical design. Influence of geological factors, design of ground support, and use of geotechnical instrumentation and numerical analyses for tunneling and slope stability projects. Case histories.

courses.name: ANTH 449A Honours Tutorial - HONOURS TUTORIAL
courses.description: Will usually require the presentation of at least one research paper.

courses.name: THTR 448A Directed Studies in Theatre Theory and Practice - DIR ST THTR THRY
OBST 502 Physiology of the Mother, Fetus and Newborn
courses.description: Functional development of the placenta and major organ systems in the fetal and newborn period in man and animals.

courses.name: LLED 360 Classroom Discourses and Teaching English Language Learners: Secondary
courses.description: Pass/Fail.

courses.name: ENGL 354A Milton and the Seventeenth Century - MILTON&17TH CENT
courses.prerequisites: (3rd year standing and 6 credits of first-year English, or Arts One, or 6 credits of ASTU 100 from CAP or 3 credits of first-year English and 3 credits of ASTU 150)

courses.name: MATH 562 Mathematical Electrophysiology
courses.description: Formulation and analysis of models of excitable media.  FitzHugh-Nagumo model, ionic models of membrane excitability (e.g., Hodgkin-Huxley), calcium excitability, bursting phenomena.

courses.name: MUSC 106 Aural Skills II
courses.description: Continuation of MUSC 105. Restricted to B.Mus. students.

courses.name: KORN 440B Supervised Study in the Korean Language - SPRV STDY KORN
courses.description: Primarily for students in Asian Studies and Linguistics.

courses.name: PHAR 458 Pharmacotherapy in Oncology
courses.description: Common oncological diseases and their drug treatment.

courses.name: LING 447D Topics in Linguistics - TOPICS IN LING
courses.description: A capstone course for Linguistics and Speech Sciences majors, normally taken after three years of study.  Individual sections will differ substantially; see online Course List for detailed descriptions and prerequisites. May be repeated for credit when content is different.

courses.name: ECON 451 Economics of Public Expenditures
courses.description: The role of government in the economy; efficiency and economic justice. Theory of public goods; applications to topics such as education, medical care and social services. Pricing and investment rules for public enterprises.

courses.name: COMM 395 Business Communications
courses.description: Understanding non-written communications in day-to-day business.

courses.name: CCFI 508A Review of Research in Educational Methods - REV RES ED MTHDS
courses.description: Studies are made of recent research bearing on educational practice.
courses.prerequisites: (Appropriate senior undergraduate introductory or methods course is required.)

courses.name: ANTH 506A Current Research in Anthropology - CURRENT RES ANTH
courses.description: The relationship between current theoretical issues and research methods.

courses.name: CIVL 415 Water Resource Engineering
courses.description: An introduction to the planning and design of water resource systems, stream systems, and municipal and hydropower engineering.

courses.name: SOCI 220 Sociology of Indigenous Peoples
courses.description: Sociological perspective of Indigenous peoples and issues both internationally and within Canada.

courses.name: VISA 110 Studio Three: Digital Media
courses.description: Foundation instruction in techniques and approaches to digital practice. The nature of digital technologies and their role in contemporary culture will be examined. (This course is open to all UBC students, regardless of prior experience.)

courses.name: BUSI 300 Urban and Real Estate Economics
courses.description: Comprehensive treatment of urban and real estate economics; introduction to study of cities and real estate market; analytical microeconomic principles.

courses.name: CIVL 300 Construction Engineering and Management
courses.description: Project delivery systems: traditional; construction management; turnkey; project management. Network planning methods. Activity planning, including construction methods selection. Estimating, bidding and bonding. Project control tools and procedures. Human resources, including equity considerations; occupational health and safety and quality control.

courses.name: PCTH 548B Directed Studies in Pharmacology - DIRECTED STUDIES
courses.description: In special cases, with the approval of the department head, advanced courses may be arranged.

courses.name: GEOG 122 Geography, Modernity and Globalization
courses.description: The human geography of the modern world since 1945: global interdependence in economic geography, geopolitics, and cultural geography; consequences of modernization, including demography, urbanization and environmental effects; regional case studies; reactions to modernization.

courses.name: MEDG 560 Genetic Counselling Seminar
courses.description: Medical and genetic interviewing and family history taking; decision making; family dynamics; impact of congenital defects, genetic disease, and chronic disease on individuals and families; support groups and other community resources; computer resources; cross-cultural issues.

courses.name: CHEM 569 Advanced Bioorganic Chemistry
courses.description: Credit will be given for only one of CHEM 569, CHEM 413, or BIOC 403.

courses.name: EOSC 320 Sedimentology
courses.description: Origin, diagenesis and geochemistry of sediments and sedimentary rocks.
courses.prerequisites: EOSC 221 and one of EOSC 210, EOSC 222.

courses.name: CHBE 366 Chemical Engineering Laboratory
courses.description: Experiments to illustrate and use material presented in 300-level CHBE process option courses. Field trips may be required.

courses.name: GEOG 250 Cities
courses.description: An interdisciplinary introduction to the city in the context of contemporary globalization. Analysis of urban patterns and processes from the theoretical perspectives of various disciplines and methodologies.

courses.name: MINE 497P Directed Studies - ADV MINERAL PROC
courses.description: Requires approval of the department head.

courses.name: BIOL 448B Directed Studies in Biology - DIRECTED STUDIES
courses.description: A course designed to allow students to undertake an investigation on a specific topic as agreed upon by the faculty member and the student. Permission of the supervisor required. No more than six credits of BIOL 448 may be taken with the same supervisor.

courses.name: FNIS 100 Indigenous Foundations
courses.description: The historical, cultural, political, economic and legal issues that inform the experiences of Indigenous peoples in Canada, examined from both Indigenous and non-Indigenous perspectives. Credit will be granted for only one of FNIS 100, FNSP 100, or FNSP 200.

courses.name: LAW 457 Real Estate Development
courses.description: A study of the legal aspects of the development of real estate projects such as shopping centres, sports centres and condominiums. Not offered each year, consult Faculty.

courses.name: MATH 301 Applied Analysis
courses.description: Integrals involving multi-valued functions, conformal mapping and applications, analytic continuation, Laplace and Fourier transforms.
courses.prerequisites: One of MATH 300, MATH 305 and one of MATH 215, MATH 255, MATH 256, MATH 265.

courses.name: POLI 446A Multiculturalism and Identity Politics - MULTICULT&POLITC
courses.description: Seminar will examines how "identity" is theorized in contemporary political thought, beginning with the role that identity plays in the "western" canon and proceeding to examine feminist, multicultural, queer, and post-colonial theories of citizenship along with their critics.

courses.name: SOWK 320 Introduction to Social Work Research
courses.description: Introduction to theory and conduct of social research as applied to social welfare and social work practice. The focus is on development of social work research questions and design of studies. Enrolment is limited to students in the B.S.W. program, except by permission of the school.

courses.name: CNPS 545 Family Counselling - Interventions and Research
courses.description: Main theoretical and therapeutic approaches of contemporary family counselling with emphasis on intervention and critical research issues in educational and other counselling settings.

courses.name: LIBR 610 Theoretical and Research Foundations of Library and Information Studies
FRST 339 Forest Level Measurement and Productivity
courses.description: Obtaining and forecasting information for stands and forests.

courses.name: CONS 425 Sustainable Energy: Policy and Governance
courses.description: Energy as a policy problem; governance framework for energy policy; prominent controversies in Western Canadian energy policy; the politics and policy of energy alternatives.

courses.name: FIPR 533C Advanced Problems in Directing - ADV PROB FILM PR
courses.description: Problems in directing narrative film. Explores problems in scripting, performance, shot design, and editing through seminars, workshops with acting students, and production exercises.

courses.name: EPSE 431 Programming for Children with Specific Learning Disabilities
courses.description: Methods and programs for learning disabilities are reviewed. Practical experience in the development and execution of a remedial program is required.

courses.name: FREN 425A Studies in French Autobiography - STDY FRN AUTOBIO
courses.prerequisites: One of FREN 320, FREN 321, FREN 328, FREN 329, FREN 330.

courses.name: MUSC 565B Asian Music Ensemble - BALINSE GAMLN EN
courses.description: Study of Asian music, to include practical training in instrumental techniques and ensemble performance. The music of one major Asian civilization, often Chinese, will be emphasized.

courses.name: GRS 397A Regional Directed Field Studies - REG DIR FLD STUD
courses.description: Participating students may be assessed a fee.

courses.name: PHAR 540C Topics in Pharmacology - TOPICS IN PHARM
courses.description: Lectures and supervised studies in selected areas of pharmacology. Enrolment restricted.

courses.name: CRWR 514U Advanced Writing for Television I - ADV WRIT TV I
CNPS 580B Problems in Education - PROB IN EDUC 2
courses.description: Investigation and report of a problem.

courses.name: FRST 436 Growth and Yield
courses.description: Techniques of growth and yield projection and discussion of modelling approaches. Exploration of stand dynamics, quantitative implications of management treatments and environmental limitations to tree and stand growth.

courses.name: MECH 598 Research Seminar
courses.description: Current topics in mechanical engineering research for M.A.Sc. students.

courses.name: FRE 503 Policy Analysis for Food, Environment and Resources
VISA 321 Intermediate Drawing II
courses.description: Investigation of drawing as a discipline in the context of contemporary art and theory. Emphasis on self-directed projects in consultation with the instructor.

courses.name: ECON 531 Economic History of Modern Europe
BUSI 497 Guided Case Study in Agricultural Real Estate
courses.description: An agriculturally-focused version of BUSI 499.
courses.prerequisites: All of BUSI 330, BUSI 331, BUSI 442, BUSI 452.

courses.name: PHYS 109 Enriched Experimental Physics
courses.description: A laboratory course accompanying PHYS 108 with emphasis on data collection and analysis and experimental techniques.

courses.name: ANTH 418 Anthropological Statistics
courses.description: Applications of statistical techniques to quantitative and qualitative data in Anthropology.

courses.name: EDUC 495G Practicum (Elementary) for Previously Certified Teachers - TEACH PRACT ELEM
courses.description: Pass/Fail.
courses.prerequisites: (Completion of recent elementary teaching methods courses in the subjects to be taught.)

courses.name: MEDI 430 Medicine - Clinical Clerkship
courses.description: Clinical activities including examination, diagnosis, on-going management and discharge planning of patients and participation in academic half-days, consisting of seminars and patient-related discussions.

courses.name: ENGL 409K Modern Critical Theories - MDN CRIT THRIES
courses.prerequisites: (3rd year standing and 6 credits of first-year English, or Arts One, or 6 credits of ASTU 100 from CAP or 3 credits of first-year English and 3 credits of ASTU 150)

courses.name: BIOL 331 Developmental Biology
courses.description: Animal development and its underlying causal principles; introductory embryology.
courses.prerequisites: Either (a) BIOL 201 or (b) all of BIOL 200, BIOL 260 and one of BIOL 233, BIOL 234.

courses.name: PHIL 414A Topics in the History of Modern Philosophy - EARLY MOD PHIL
courses.description: Intensive study of a major philosopher or school such as Descartes, Hume, Empiricism, Rationalism, or the British utilitarians.

courses.name: MECH 326 Mechanical Design II
courses.description: Design and application of mechanisms, linkages, and cams. Fatigue and fracture considerations in design: failure types, failure under static and dynamic loading, fatigue failure, crack initiation, and propagation. Introduction to the FEM in mechanical design.
courses.corequisites: All of MECH 325, MECH 360 and one of MECH 328, ENPH 253, IGEN 330.

courses.name: APBI 311 Animal Physiology I
courses.description: Physiological principles in animals, including vital life support systems, cellular communication, growth and development.

courses.name: MINE 590D Special Advanced Topics - NUM MODEL ROCK
courses.description: A special advanced course may be arranged upon the approval of the department head.

courses.name: EOSC 448C Directed Studies - DIRECTED STUDIES
courses.description: Investigation of a topic to be agreed upon by a member of the faculty and the student. Permission of an undergraduate advisor and of the supervising faculty member is required before registration.

courses.name: MTRL 579 Physics of Microfabrication: Front End Processing
courses.description: Practical aspects, physical models, and simulations of Si-based nanofabrication processes such as oxidation, diffusion, ion implantation, chemical vapor deposition, etching, stress techniques. Semiconductor device physic basics will also be discussed.

courses.name: URST 400 Seminar in Urban Studies
courses.description: A seminar for senior students who wish to explore some common topics of importance to urban studies from the viewpoints of several disciplines.

courses.name: SOCI 369A Sociology of Sexualities - SOCIO OF SEXUAL
courses.description: Historical and social construction of sexual identities, desires, communities, and politics in the twentieth century.

courses.name: CLST 317 Classical Tragedy
courses.description: The plays of the Greek and Roman tragic dramatists, in translation.

courses.name: FIPR 533A Advanced Problems in Directing - ADV PROB FILM PR
courses.description: Problems in directing narrative film. Explores problems in scripting, performance, shot design, and editing through seminars, workshops with acting students, and production exercises.

courses.name: LAW 251 Public Law
courses.description: An overview of the constitutional and statutory law governing the legislative, executive, and judicial branches of government in Canada, including an introduction to statutory construction and analysis and the administration of law in Canada.

courses.name: GERM 400 Advanced German I
courses.description: Near-native competence and thorough understanding of critical contemporary topics in a limited number of areas fostering study skills. All skills will be fostered but the course focuses on accurate writing and conversation in particular.

courses.name: FRST 399 Introduction to Research Methods
courses.description: Lectures and seminars in research philosophies and the scientific method, with special emphasis on field research.

courses.name: MUSC 561A Piano Chamber Ensembles - PIANO CHAMB ENS
courses.description: Open only to graduate students.

courses.name: FOPR 388 Analytical Methods in Forest Hydrology
courses.description: Analytical methods in forest hydrology and their applications in the planning of forest operations with a focus on the hydrologic and hydraulic design procedures for stream crossings.

courses.name: MTRL 582 Advanced Ceramics
courses.description: Complex silicate structures; ion exchange in silicates; kinetics of solid state reactions; kinetics of high temperature processes.

courses.name: ENGL 539A Studies in the Twentieth Century - STUDIES 20TH C
DENT 528 Prosthodontic Treatment Planning and Outcomes Seminars II
ASIA 475 Documenting Punjabi Canada
courses.description: Exploration of the history of the Punjabi Canadian community through traditional text-based methods and oral history collection (in English or Punjabi).

courses.name: ARBC 102 Introduction to the Grammar and Vocabulary of Classic Arabic II
EDUC 450B Inquiry Seminar I - INQUIRY SEMNR 1
courses.description: Pass/Fail.

courses.name: ADHE 328 Institutions of Adult Education
courses.description: The history, roles, and activities of institutions in the field of adult education.  Institutions in Canada, Great Britain, and the United States are emphasized, and some experiences in other countries are examined.

courses.name: MTRL 592B Advanced Topics in Materials Engineering - ADVANCED TOPICS
courses.description: May be arranged on approval of the department head.

courses.name: PSYC 547D Reading and Conference - READG & CONFRNCE
ASIA 699 Doctoral Dissertation
courses.description: In Chinese, Japanese, or South Asian Studies only.

courses.name: SPPH 300 Working in International Health
courses.description: This is a tutored, web based Interprofessional Health and Human Service (IHHS) course on planning/preparing for work in a developing country. Causes of ill health amongst populations living in poverty; analysis of available solutions. Health Science background not essential. Credit will be granted for only one of SPPH 300 or IHHS 300.

courses.name: CHBE 402 Chemical Pulping Technology
courses.description: Process and unit operations in the conversion of wood chips to pulp, principles and practice of kraft pulping, oxygen delignification, pulp bleaching, chemical recovery and related unit operations. Economic and environmental issues are considered.

courses.name: LIBE 580B Problems in Education - PROB IN EDUC 2
courses.description: Investigation and report of a problem.

courses.name: SOWK 201 Introduction to Social Work Practice
courses.description: An introduction to the knowledge, skills and values of social work practice in its many forms, emphasizing different ways of understanding the context of social and personal problems.

courses.name: FRST 558 Landscape-Level Forest Land Management
courses.description: Preparation of landscape-level sustainable forest management plans that integrate ecological, social, and economic components.

courses.name: SOWK 440I Integrative Seminars in Social Work - INTGRTV SEM SOWK
courses.description: A series of seminars offered during the final term of studies which address salient issues in social policy and social work practice and draw upon combined knowledge from social work and related disciplines.

courses.name: EDCP 304 Textile Design and Pedagogical Approaches: Art Education
courses.prerequisites: (6 credits of introductory art studio or art history courses.)

courses.name: MECH 325 Mechanical Design I
courses.description: Introduction to manufacturing operations. Design for manufacturing and assembly. Design and selection of shafts, bearings, springs, seals and packing, and couplings. Design of bolted joints and power screws. Design and selection of gears, gear trains, brakes and clutches.
courses.corequisites: MECH 360 and one of MECH 328, ENPH 253, IGEN 330.

courses.name: CHEM 427 Chemistry of Materials
courses.description: Introduction to the chemistry, theory and applications of contemporary materials.  Credit will not be given for both CHEM 427 and CHEM 527.
courses.prerequisites: One of CHEM 201, CHEM 205, CHEM 251 and one of CHEM 202, CHEM 250 and one of CHEM 204, CHEM 213, CHEM 233, CHEM 260.

courses.name: SPHA 510 Canadian Health Policy and the Healthcare System
courses.description: Analysis of topical Canadian health policy issues including an historical overview of the health care system, health care funding, public / private financing, health care personnel and pharmaceutical policy challenges.

courses.name: SOCI 495B Advanced Studies in Sociology - ADV STUDIES SOCI
courses.description: An intensive examination of selected topics in Sociology. Consult the department for this year's offerings.

courses.name: PHAR 526 Pharmaceutical Research Techniques II
courses.description: Immunological assays, capillary and gel electrophoresis, radioisotope techniques, PET, peptide analysis and receptor binding studies.

courses.name: CHEM 529 Structural Methods in Inorganic Chemistry
courses.description: NMR, ESR, mass spectrometry, photoelectron spectroscopy (Auger, UV, X-Ray), Mossbauer spectroscopy, electrochemistry.

courses.name: CNPS 532A Psychological Assessment in Counselling - PSYC ASSESS CNSL
courses.description: The use of standardized measures of mental ability, achievement, aptitude, interest and personality.

courses.name: ECON 365 Topics in Canadian Industrial Organization and Regulation Policy
courses.description: Current topics in industrial organization and regulation with emphasis on Canadian federal and provincial policy. The content will differ from year to year. Possible subjects include the regulation of transportation and communications, environmental regulation, marketing boards and other forms of agricultural regulation, competition and anti-combines policy, industrial organization and trade policy, and issues in consumer protection.

courses.name: RELG 206 Introduction to Judaism and its Texts
courses.description: What is Judaism? An overview of the key texts that have defined the Jewish religion, from the Hebrew Bible through works of contemporary thinkers. Recommended as a basis for upper-level courses in religious studies.

courses.name: BIOL 306 Advanced Ecology
courses.description: Ecology of populations, communities and ecosystems. Tests of ecological theory with experiments and application to environmental issues. Labs meet once a month. Please consult the Faculty of Science Credit Exclusion Lists: www.students.ubc.ca/calendar/index.cfm?tree=12,215,410,414.
courses.prerequisites: One of BIOL 230, BIOL 302, BIOL 303, BIOL 304.

courses.name: ARCH 533 Environmental Systems and Controls II
courses.description: Mechanical and electrical services of buildings and their integration with architectural form and fabric.

courses.name: PHYS 535 Radiotherapy Physics II
courses.description: A continuation of PHYS 534, including an extension of the topics discussed in that course.

courses.name: CHIN 201 Intermediate Chinese I: Part 1 (Non-Heritage)
courses.description: Skills in listening, speaking, reading, and writing, and understanding of Chinese culture.

courses.name: FRST 513 Biotechnology in Tree Improvement
courses.description: Advanced research topics and their application to forest genetics. Emphasis on molecular genetics and experimental protocols.

courses.name: MINE 488 Heavy Oil Sand Mining and Processing
courses.description: Life cycle of the production of Oil Sands resources, including mining, bitumen extraction, and reclamation.

courses.name: POLI 515A State and Society in the Developing World - STATE&SOC DV WLD
MINE 310 Surface Mining and Design
courses.description: Surface mining methods, production planning and scheduling; slope design and drainage; wall control; materials handling and equipment selection; production control and automation, waste disposal and closure.

courses.name: WOOD 487 Wood Composites
courses.description: Physical, chemical and mechanical variables involved in adhesive bonding of composite wood products; characteristics of adhesives; plywood, composite wood panels, hardboard, medium density fibreboard, laminated wood and engineered lumber composites manufacturing processes; important physical and chemical properties of products.

courses.name: FRST 449B Directed Studies in Forestry - DIRECTED STUDIES
courses.description: In special cases and with the approval of the instructor concerned, a student may carry on directed studies of specific problems in forestry.

courses.name: EOSC 454 Applied Geophysics
courses.description: Using geophysics to characterize the Earth's subsurface for resource exploration, engineering, or environmental applications. Data acquisition, processing, and interpretation of geophysical surveys. Inversion examples drawn from potential (electrical, magnetic, gravity) or wave field (seismic, ground penetrating radar) surveys.
courses.prerequisites: All of EOSC 352, EOSC 353, EOSC 450 and one of PHYS 301, PHYS 354.

courses.name: NURS 341 Relational Nursing Practice as Praxis
courses.description: Critical analysis of the enactment of relational practice toward promotion of health and wellbeing at multiple levels.
courses.prerequisites: All of NURS 302, NURS 303, NURS 304, NURS 305, NURS 306, NURS 338.

courses.name: LLED 493C Supervised Study in Modern Languages Education - SPR ST MDN LANG
LAW 413D Tax Administration and Dispute Resolution - TAX ADMN & DISPU
courses.description: Not offered each year, consult Faculty. Credit will be granted for only one of LAW 413 or LAW 567.

courses.name: DENT 420 Dentistry II
courses.description: Continued exposure to clinical dentistry and supporting science; at UBC and in the community. In problem-based tutorials, clinical and classroom settings, students are introduced to diagnostic sciences;  prosthodontics; pediatric dentistry; psychomotor skills; operative dentistry; geriatrics; while continuing to engage in professionalism and community service learning activities.

courses.name: ANAT 527 Muscle Biophysics
courses.description: Selected topics in muscle contraction at an advanced level Permission of Head required.

courses.name: EECE 579 Advanced Topics in VLSI Design
courses.description: A course in VLSI design with an emphasis on new methodologies in digital IC design. Top-down design and CAD tools are illustrated through a class project. EECE 479 and EECE 481 are recommended.

courses.name: EOSC 222 Geological Time and Stratigraphy
courses.description: Measuring geological time and understanding Earth history using stratigraphic principles, paleontology and radioactive decay. Please consult the Faculty of Science Credit Exclusion List: www.students.ubc.ca/calendar/index.cfm?tree=12,215,410,414.
courses.prerequisites: (Second-year standing in Science. One of EOSC 1**, EOSC 210, GEOB 103 is recommended.)

courses.name: GEOG 345 Theory and Practice in Human Geography
courses.description: A consideration of major intellectual issues and debates in the development of contemporary human geography, in relation to developments in other fields and changes in politics, culture and society.

courses.name: PSYC 305A Personality Psychology - PERSONALITY PSYC
courses.description: Theory and research on individual differences in motivation, emotion, and social behaviour.
courses.prerequisites: Either (a) PSYC 100 or (b) all of PSYC 101, PSYC 102. (or (c) 6 credits of 200-level Psychology (but not 205 or 263).)

courses.name: INDE 410 Introductory Clinical Skills and Systems I
courses.description: Small group sessions may be supplemented by self-study resources. Students will be introduced to communication skills, components of health history, and the physical exam, and will develop basic skills of examination of the cardiovascular, respiratory and genito-urinary systems.

courses.name: POLI 220 Introduction to Comparative Politics
courses.description: A comparative analysis of foreign governments. Specific countries to be covered will vary according to section; consult the brochure issued by the Department.

courses.name: KIN 373 Research Methods in Kinesiology
courses.description: Critical evaluation of research studies and methods with emphasis on the physical activity context.

courses.name: STS 597 Master's Colloquium in Science and Technology Studies
ARCH 561 Seminar: History and Theory
courses.description: Topics across a range of history/theory-based subject matter.
courses.prerequisites: All of ARCH 504, ARCH 505, ARCH 523, ARCH 568.

courses.name: CRWR 359B Intermediate Fiction Workshop - INTRMD FICTION
courses.description: An intermediate level workshop class in writing of fiction. Manuscript submission is not required for admission.

courses.name: THTR 440A Topics in Theatre - TOPICS IN THTR
courses.description: An examination in depth of a selected area of theatre history, theory or practice. Topics will change from year to year. May be repeated for credit when topics differ.
courses.prerequisites: (6 credits of THTR at the 300-level or above.)

courses.name: LAW 397 Oil and Gas Law
courses.description: Legal regimes for the disposition of interests in petroleum; government regulation. Not offered each year, consult Faculty.

courses.name: EOSC 399 Co-operative Work Placement II
courses.description: Approved and supervised technical work experience in an industrial, university or government setting for a minimum of 14 weeks. Normally taken in Winter Session (Term 1) in third year. Technical report required. Restricted to students admitted to the Co-operative Education Option in Earth, Ocean and Atmospheric Sciences.

courses.name: PHYS 490 Student Directed Seminar
courses.description: Self-directed, collaborative studies, in a group-learning environment, initiated and coordinated by senior undergraduate students with the supervision of a faculty advisor. Course structure, enrolment, and delivery methods will comply with the "Handbook for Student Directed Seminars".  Cannot be used as a specialization requirement in any PHYS and/or ASTR specialization.

courses.name: CRWR 403W Writing for Children and Young Adults I - CHILD & YOUNG I
courses.description: A workshop class in writing for Children and Young Adults. Admission is restricted to B.F.A. Majors in Creative Writing.

courses.name: PHYS 447A Advanced Topics in Physics - ADV TPCS PHYS
courses.description: Directed studies available to students in Honours Physics with approval from the Head of the Department.

courses.name: ARCH 538C Study of Architecture Abroad - ARCH ABROAD
courses.description: More than one section may be taken concurrently.

courses.name: KIN 215B Performance Analysis of Selected Team Sports and Activities - PERF ANYL STS&A
courses.description: Specific topics to be announced each year. KIN 115 and 215 can be taken in any order.

courses.name: WOOD 482 CAD/CAM
courses.description: Introduction to computer assisted design and manufacturing with a focus on the fundamental issues of geometry and machine tools including an understanding of standard computer tools. Applications to secondary wood products manufacturing.

courses.name: ELEC 457 Optimization of Power System Operation
courses.description: Application of linear and nonlinear optimization methods in power systems; constrained optimization; optimal power flow; economic dispatch; electricity market; local prices for active and reactive power; security-constrained OPF; state estimation, reliability analysis.

courses.name: BUSI 433 Real Estate Business
courses.description: General business skills for real estate practitioners.

courses.name: ARTH 351B Islamic Art and Archaeology - ISLAM ARCH ART
courses.description: A study of the artifacts of Islam as an expression of Islamic beliefs.

courses.name: LING 222 Language Acquisition
courses.description: Audition and speech perception, phonological organization, word learning, syntax, and pragmatics.

courses.name: FRST 498 B.Sc. Thesis in Forestry
courses.description: An independent study or research project of a subject of special interest to the student under the direction of a staff member. The subject must be appropriate to the student's area of concentration.

courses.name: ENGL 470A Canadian Studies - CANADIAN STUDIES
courses.prerequisites: (3rd year standing and 6 credits of first-year English, or Arts One, or 6 credits of ASTU 100 from CAP or 3 credits of first-year English and 3 credits of ASTU 150)

courses.name: MUSC 162E Wind and Percussion Chamber Ensembles - WIND CHAM ENS PC
courses.description: May be repeated for credit in accordance with program requirements for B.Mus. or B.A. in Music. Open to other students by audition, with credit, as stipulated by their faculties.

courses.name: CHIN 204 Intensive Intermediate Chinese I (Non-Heritage)
courses.description: Skills in listening, speaking, reading, and writing, and better understanding of Chinese culture.

courses.name: GERM 410 Advanced German II
courses.description: Development of capabilities to deal with a variety of authentic texts from and about Germany, Austria and Switzerland; fostering of communicative skills, cross-cultural analysis and critical thinking; effective and accurate communication in both spoken and written German.

courses.name: STAT 302 Introduction to Probability
courses.description: Basic notions of probability, random variables, expectation and conditional expectation, limit theorems. (Consult the Credit Exclusion list within the Faculty of Science section in the Calendar.)

courses.name: BIOL 440 Plant Genomics
courses.description: Concepts, principles, applications, and recent discoveries in genome structure, genetics, and comparative genomics in plants with a focus on economically important plants.

courses.name: KIN 115A Performance Analysis of Selected Individual Sports and Activities - PERF ANYL SPORTS
courses.description: Specific topics to be announced each year. KIN 115 and 215 can be taken in any order.

courses.name: EDCP 585B Special Course in Curriculum and Pedagogy - SPECIAL CURR&PED
ASTR 403 Cosmology
courses.description: Introduction to the study of the Universe as a whole. Foundations of the Hot Big Bang model, the early Universe, nucleosynthesis, the cosmic microwave background, large-scale structure, galaxy formation and quasars.
courses.prerequisites: One of PHYS 200, PHYS 250. (ASTR 300 is recommended.)

courses.name: FNIS 401O Special Topics - SPECIAL TOPICS
courses.description: Topics will vary from year to year. Consult the departmental website: http://fnsp.arts.ubc.ca.
courses.prerequisites: One of FNSP 200, FNIS 210, FNSP 210, FNIS 220, FNSP 220. (or third-year standing.)

courses.name: MEDI 590 Molecular Regulation of Cell Growth and Differentiation
courses.description: Cytokines and signal transduction mechanisms in the growth and differentiation of germ line, haemopoietic and other eukaryotic cells; actions of oncogene and tumor-suppressor gene products; molecular concepts derived from experimental model systems; molecular strategies of cytokine therapy.
courses.prerequisites: One of MICB 302, BIOC 402, BIOC 403. (Permission of course coordinator is also acceptable.)

courses.name: RELG 312 Jews and Judaism in Canada
courses.description: The history of the Jewish community in Canada, from New France to the present. Emphasis on the relationship between immigration and religious transformation, Jewish-Christian relations, the development of community structures.

courses.name: FRST 311 Plant Physiology I
courses.description: Mechanisms and regulation of functional processes contributing to the assimilation, transport and utilization of water, mineral nutrients and carbon by plants. CHEM 230 is recommended.

courses.name: BRDG 690 Internship
courses.description: 8 months for Ph.D. students.

courses.name: FNH 330 Introduction to Wine Science 1
courses.description: Principles of viticulture, enology, and wine microbiology and chemistry; marketing, regulation and classification of wines from selected regions of the world; social, economic and health aspects of wine consumption; wine appreciation.

courses.name: DHYG 406 Guided Study in Dental Hygiene
courses.description: Conduct an in-depth investigation of a health promotion issue.
courses.prerequisites: All of DHYG 400, DHYG 401, DHYG 461. (And Faculty approval.)

courses.name: MIDW 105 Introduction to Midwifery Theory and Practice
courses.description: Normal pregnancy, labour, birth, the newborn, and puerperium with an emphasis on prenatal and postnatal midwifery care.  A series of lectures and lab practice sessions.

courses.name: APSC 496C Interdisciplinary Engineering Design Project - INTER ENG PRJECT
courses.description: Projects involving students from several departments.

courses.name: FIST 547A Directed Studies in Film - DIRECTED ST FILM
MICB 405 Bioinformatics
courses.description: Computational methods to analyze genome and protein sequences to derive structural and functional information. Related topics in functional genomics.
courses.prerequisites: One of MICB 301, MICB 325, BIOC 302, BIOC 303, BIOL 335, BIOT 380.

courses.name: HIST 235 History of Canada: Moments that Matter
courses.description: An introduction to major turning points in Canadian history.  Exploration of the social, political, cultural, and environmental transformations/revolutions that have shaped Canada from early European colonialism to the twenty-first century.

courses.name: PCTH 548F Directed Studies in Pharmacology - DIRECTED STUDIES
courses.description: In special cases, with the approval of the department head, advanced courses may be arranged.

courses.name: LAW 490 Clinical Criminal Law
courses.description: Dealing with criminal files under the supervision of experienced lawyers. Credit will be granted for only one of LAW 488, LAW 490, or LAW 491. Pass/Fail.
courses.prerequisites: One of LAW  260, LAW  400 and one of LAW  280, LAW  476.

courses.name: SOIL 514A Biometeorology - BIOMETEOROLOGY
courses.description: Energy and mass exchange in the biosphere with emphasis on the interfaces between the atmosphere and soils, plants and animals. Offered in alternate years.

courses.name: PSYC 460 Behavioural Neuroendocrinology
courses.description: Detailed examination of the interaction between hormones and neural control of reproductive and non-reproductive behaviours; emphasis on gonadal and adrenal hormone effects on learning and memory in the brain.

courses.name: BIOL 320 Survey of Algae
courses.description: A survey of the algae, considering their morphology, life history, classification, and ecology.

courses.name: SOCI 328A Social Statistics I - SOCIAL STATS I
