courses.description: The testing of sociological theories using quantitative data analysis techniques on numerical data from social surveys, experiments and official statistics.

courses.name: THTR 372 Intermediate B.F.A. Acting II
courses.description: Open only to B.F.A. Acting students.

courses.name: NRSC 501 Neuroscience II
courses.description: Continuation of NRSC 500 with emphasis on the integrative functions of the brain, behaviour, and selected neural disorders. Permission of Neuroscience Chair is required. Normally to be taken in conjunction with NRSC 500.

courses.name: WOOD 373 Wood Adhesives and Coatings
courses.description: Introduction to structure and properties of polymers and wood finishes; chemistry of adhesives and preservatives.

courses.name: SPHA 542 Operations and Logistics
courses.description: The application of management tools and principles to production and allocation problems.

courses.name: INDE 455 Senior Clerkship
courses.description: A senior clinical elective for fourth year students. Students will participate in all relevant clinical and academic activities associated with the particular rotation.

courses.name: ENPH 479 Engineering Physics Project II
courses.description: Projects designed to give students research development and design experience. Projects are provided by research faculty in Science and Engineering and from local industry.

courses.name: FNEL 201 Intermediate Salish Language I
courses.description: Emphasis on increasing fluency in conversational ability, enhancing pronunciation and comprehension skills, expanding vocabulary, extending literacy and grammatical understanding, and further study of oral traditions in their cultural context.

courses.name: GREK 352 Intermediate Ancient Greek: Verse
courses.description: Readings in the major authors in Greek Verse.

courses.name: COMM 377 International Financial Markets and Institutions
courses.description: Structure, nature and institutions of foreign exchange markets, including spot, forward, futures, options, and offshore currency markets. Factors affecting exchange rates are also discussed. Credit will be granted for only one of COMM 377 or COEC 377.

courses.name: ENGL 520A Studies in the Seventeenth Century - STUDIES 17TH C
CRWR 515A Advanced Workshop in Literary Translation I - WK LIT TRANSL I
courses.prerequisites: (Proficiency in a language other than English.)

courses.name: PHYS 402 Applications of Quantum Mechanics
courses.description: Spin and angular momentum addition, perturbation methods, and applications in the fields of Atomic, Molecular, Nuclear, and Solid State Physics.

courses.name: LARC 501 Landscape Architecture Design Studio I
courses.description: Landscape design methods and processes. Restricted to M.L.A. students.

courses.name: COMM 459 Financial Statement Analysis
courses.description: An examination of financial statement information from the perspective of decision makers external to the firm, e.g., investors and financial institutions.
courses.prerequisites: COMM 293 and one of COMM 297, COMM 298 and one of COMM 370, COMM 397.

courses.name: CIVL 201 Civil Engineering I
courses.description: Sustainable development, design process, project planning, and modeling with sketches, spreadsheets, and other tools.
courses.prerequisites: One of APSC 176, ENGL 110, ENGL 111, ENGL 112, ENGL 120, ENGL 121.

courses.name: HIST 363 Europe in the Early Middle Ages
courses.description: A survey of the development of institutions, ideas and the economy in Europe from about 400 through about 1000 CE.

courses.name: FRST 424 Sustainable Forest Management
courses.description: Integration of biophysical and socio-economic components of forest management.
courses.prerequisites: (Fourth year standing in the B.S.F. program.)

courses.name: ECED 508A Review of Research in Early Childhood Education - REV RES IN ECED
ARCH 538A Study of Architecture Abroad - ARCH ABROAD
courses.description: More than one section may be taken concurrently.

courses.name: CHIN 303 Advanced Chinese Reading and Writing II (Non-Heritage)
courses.description: Continuation of CHIN 301. Can be taken concurrently with CHIN 307.

courses.name: BIOL 418 Evolutionary Ecology
courses.description: Ecological adaptation and evolutionary processes in contemporary populations; natural selection, variation, optimization, foraging theory, coevolution, arms races; life history theory, evolution of sex, sexual selection, evolution in managed populations.
courses.prerequisites: BIOL 336 and one of BIOL 230, BIOL 303, BIOL 304.

courses.name: MUSC 410 Introduction to Schenkerian Analysis
courses.description: The key concepts of Schenker's theory of tonality. Applications to the analysis of short pieces in various tonal styles, emphasizing clear and correct graphing. Issues of interpretive scope.

courses.name: PHYS 405 Radiation Biophysics
courses.description: Physical and chemical interactions of ionizing radiations and their biological effects at the cellular, tissue and whole-animal levels. Credit will be given for only one of PHYS 405, 536. See the Faculty of Science Credit Exclusion Lists: www.calendar.ubc.ca/vancouver/index.cfm?tree=12,215,410,414.
courses.prerequisites: One of PHYS 102, PHYS 108, PHYS 153, SCIE 001. (and third year standing in Science or Applied Science.)

courses.name: APBI 210 Vascular Plants
courses.description: A comparative study of pteridophytes, gymnosperms and angiosperms, integrating form, function, and ecology.
courses.prerequisites: Either (a) all of BIOL 121, BIOL 140 or (b) all of SCIE 001, BIOL 140. (Or (c) 7 credits of first-year biology.)

courses.name: MUSC 532C Advanced Studies in Music History and Musicology - SONG INTERP
CRWR 401W Writing Poetry I - WRITING POETRY I
courses.description: A workshop class in the writing of poetry. Admission is restricted to B.F.A. Majors in Creative Writing.

courses.name: PHYS 350 Applications of Classical Mechanics
courses.description: Review of principles. Particle mechanics: Euler's equations, tops and gyroscopes, motion of the Earth, Lagrangian and Hamiltonian methods. Variational principles in optics and mechanics, Liouville's theorem and statistical mechanics. The relationship between classical and quantum mechanics.

courses.name: COMM 453 Financial Accounting-Advanced
courses.description: An examination of advanced financial accounting.

courses.name: EPSE 310B Assessment and Learning in the Classroom - ASMNT&LRN IN CLS
courses.description: Pass/Fail.

courses.name: EOSC 543 Topics in Solid Earth Sciences
GRSJ 320 Feminist Anti-Racist Pedagogies
courses.description: Feminist pedagogies and feminist debates about pedagogy in formal, nonformal, and informal educational settings.
courses.prerequisites: Either (a) all of GRSJ 101, GRSJ 102 or (b) all of WMST 101, WMST 102. (or third-year standing.)

courses.name: FRST 446 Co-operative Work Placement.
courses.description: Supervised work experience in an approved organization for a minimum of 15 weeks. Restricted to students in the Co-operative Education Program in the Faculty of Forestry. Final work term report required.

courses.name: POLI 100 Introduction to Politics
courses.description: Political issues and case studies, drawn from Canadian and international contexts, will be used to introduce students to central debates and concepts of politics and political analysis.

courses.name: BIOL 501 Quantitative Methods in Ecology and Evolution
courses.prerequisites: (BIOL 300 or equivalent and graduate student standing.)

courses.name: ARTH 341 20th Century Art and Culture: The Postmodern
courses.description: A critical examination of international visual art and culture from the 1950s to the present;  the role of art in consumerist society and the emergence of postmodernism.

courses.name: ELEC 321 Stochastic Signals and Systems
courses.description: Stochastic behaviour of signals and systems; discrete and continuous probability; random processes; modeling and identification of linear time-invariant systems; binary hypothesis testing and decision making.

courses.name: MUSC 694B Music Performance (Major) - VOICE
courses.description: Private instruction, vocal or instrumental.

courses.name: FRST 545 Technical Communication Skills II
courses.description: Theory and practice of technical communication necessary for preparation of effective scientific reports, reviews, grant proposals, journal articles and theses.

courses.name: LAW 464 Competition Policy
courses.description: The law and policy relating to the regulation of competition in Canada and other jurisdictions. Not offered each year, consult Faculty. Credit will be granted for only one of LAW 414 or LAW 464.

courses.name: EOSC 118 Earth's Treasures: Gold and Gems
courses.description: Origin, properties, valuation, prospecting and geology of gold, platinum, silver, diamonds, rubies, emeralds, and other precious metals and gems.

courses.name: HIST 260 Science and Society in the Contemporary World
courses.description: An introduction to the historical development, conceptual foundations, and cultural significance of contemporary science. Themes will vary from year to year.

courses.name: MIDW 221 Clinical Skills
courses.description: Online situation-based learning tutorials occurring simultaneously with MIDW 220 clinical placement.

courses.name: APBI 428 Integrated Pest Management
courses.description: Development and implementation of multi-disciplinary pest management programs in agricultural crops.

courses.name: VISA 360 Intermediate Sculpture I
courses.description: Investigation of contemporary practices in sculpture and the use of scale. Emphasis on public sculpture.
courses.prerequisites: One of VISA 260, VISA 285, VISA 286, FINA 285, FINA 286.

courses.name: FIPR 547B Directed Studies in Film Production - DIR ST FILM PROD
LAW 560 Seminar in Topics in Common Law Theory and Practice
courses.description: Completion of an upper-level 300- or 400-level J.D. seminar or workshop course 4 credit minimum, completion of a substantial research paper consisting of an advanced analysis relating to the subject matter of the particular seminar or workshop.

courses.name: GPP 503 Measurement and Data Analysis for Policy
courses.description: Fundamental quantitative tools for policy analysis and program evaluation, including measurement, data visualization, and regression analysis. Introduction of skills for the design and implementation of quantitative policy analysis.

courses.name: LLED 580A Problems in Education - PROB IN EDUC
courses.description: Investigation and report of a problem.

courses.name: EMBA 598A Topics in Strategy and Economics - TPCS STRAT&ECON
courses.description: Restricted to Executive M.B.A. students.

courses.name: CLST 319 The Roman Army
courses.description: Rome's military from the early Republic to the Imperial period. Topics range from those of a military nature such as equipment and strategy to social topics such as policing and marriage of soldiers.

courses.name: GREK 402A Greek Verse - GREEK VERSE
courses.description: Studies in epic, tragedy and/or comedy.

courses.name: CRWR 353A Intermediate Children and Young Adult Writing Workshop - INTRMD CHLDRN
courses.description: An intermediate level workshop class in writing for children and young adults. Manuscript submission is not required for admission.

courses.name: ATSC 406 Operational Meteorology
courses.description: Introduction to meteorological prediction, meteorological data analysis, prognosis of weather systems, motion and development, satellite imagery, Doppler radar, numerical weather prediction, synoptic and mesoscale forecasting, applied laboratory exercises.

courses.name: SURG 548B Seminar in Surgery - SEM IN SURGERY
EDUC 323A School-based Orientation Practicum: Middle Years - SCL PRACT MID YR
courses.description: Pass/Fail.

courses.name: CIVL 445 Engineering Design and Analysis I
courses.description: Integration and application of previously acquired knowledge and skills to find design solutions.  Focus on conceptual designs.

courses.name: CNPS 580A Problems in Education - PROB IN EDUC 1
courses.description: Investigation and report of a problem.

courses.name: SOWK 506 Directed Field Studies in Social Work I
courses.description: Pass/Fail.

courses.name: SPPH 521 Approaches to Enquiry in Population and Public Health
courses.description: Research approaches in the area of population and public health; focus on developing research questions and the centrality of research questions in conducting research.

courses.name: LFS 501 Approaches to the Integration of Knowledge
GRSJ 311 African/Black Women in the Americas
courses.description: An interdisciplinary survey of gender studies and histories of African/Black women in the Americas from the beginning of the slave trade to the present.
courses.prerequisites: Either (a) all of GRSJ 101, GRSJ 102 or (b) all of WMST 101, WMST 102. (or third-year standing.)

courses.name: MDVL 310A Topics in Medieval Studies - TPCS MDVL STUDI
courses.description: Interdisciplinary approaches to selected topics in medieval history, literature, and the arts; topics vary from year to year; interested students should consult the Medieval Studies advisor.

courses.name: CONS 370 Aboriginal Forestry
courses.description: Issues the may be encountered in professional natural resources work with or for Aboriginal communities and organization, including contemporary issues of Aboriginal rights and title, traditional uses, and self-government.

courses.name: PHIL 363A History and Philosophy of Economics from Ricardo to Keynes - HIST/PHIL ECON2
courses.description: The development of economic thought from David Ricardo up to the present, including such figures as Malthus, Mill, Jevons, and Keynes, focusing primarily on the conceptual foundations of economics, particularly the problems of value, distribution and growth.

courses.name: PHYL 548C Advanced Topics in Human Physiology - ADV HUMAN PHYL
GEOB 200 Atmospheric Environments
courses.description: Physical principles underlying weather and climates. Thermal, moisture and wind climates at scales from valleys to the globe. Daily weather, air pollution, global change. Credit will be given for one only of GEOB 200, 204, GEOG 200, 204, AGRO 244.
courses.prerequisites: One of GEOG 102, GEOB 102. (or first-year science.)

courses.name: FRST 310 Soil Biology
courses.description: The diversity and interactions of soil organisms (bacteria, protozoa, fungi, animals, plants) in natural and managed ecosystems; roles in primary production, nutrient cycling, decomposition and reclamation; responses to environmental change.

courses.name: EDST 508B Review of Research in Educational Studies - REV RES ED STUDS
SOCI 210A Canadian Social Structure - CAN SOCIAL STRUC
courses.description: Descriptive and analytic survey of such features as demographic characteristics, class structure, ethnicity, and regional variation in Canadian society as a basis for understanding current social issues.

courses.name: CHIN 215 Intermediate Chinese II: Part I (Heritage)
courses.description: Integrated skills in modern Chinese. Focus on reading, writing, and better understanding of Chinese culture.

courses.name: ARCH 568 Research Methods
courses.description: Contemporary concerns and issues associated with research in architecture and landscape architecture.

courses.name: CRWR 570B Advanced Special Projects in Creative Writing - ADV PROJCTS CRWR
COMM 336 Introduction to e-Business
courses.description: Fundamental concepts for moving into e-Business including: technology infrastructure; security; electronic payment systems; business-to-consumer and business-to business e-commerce; business models; strategy, behavioral and interface issues; legal and privacy concerns cases.

courses.name: ECON 317 Poverty and Inequality
courses.description: Economic inequality in Canada and other countries; measurement and causes. Inequality in the distribution of wealth; redistribution of income and wealth; notions of distributive justice.

courses.name: MTRL 280 Materials in Design
courses.description: The process of materials selection for different design criteria; the importance of shape and processing variables; the use of computer software in the selection process.

courses.name: DHYG 462 Literature Review II
courses.description: A continuation of DHYG 461.

courses.name: ARCH 504 Architectural History 1A
courses.description: Origins of contemporary architectural thought. A survey of the theories, technological and social changes which have influenced architecture and related fields since the 18th century.

courses.name: ASTU 400M Interdisciplinary Studies in Arts - LIFE POL SELF
courses.description: For upper-division students in the Faculty of Arts. Topics announced annually.

courses.name: CHEM 413 Bioorganic Chemistry
courses.description: Enzyme catalysis; mechanistic enzymology; chemistry of cofactors; biosynthetic transformations; natural product biosynthesis; topics in chemical biology. Credit will be given for only one of CHEM 413, CHEM 569, or BIOC 403.

courses.name: LAW 231 Property Law
courses.description: The legal concept of ownership and its changing nature and application, including equitable principles, the acquisition and transfer of interests, the regulation of use, Aboriginal title, and statute-based systems for registering interests in land.

courses.name: JRNL 520F Special Topics in Contemporary Journalism - SPEC TOP IN JRNL
EDCP 580B Problems in Education - PROB IN EDUC
courses.description: Directed Studies and Major Essay in the diverse disciplines and topics of curriculum and pedagogy.

courses.name: MINE 482 Maintenance Engineering
courses.description: Analytical foundation for maintenance of industrial plant equipment and mobile equipment in various production environments; maintenance planning and management, life cycle analysis, reliability theory, total quality maintenance, condition monitoring.

courses.name: BUSI 446 Real Estate Development II
courses.description: Analysis of real estate development process with an examination of economic feasibility studies, approval processes, project financing, construction, project management, and marketing phases.

courses.name: ASTR 349 Directed Research Project in Astronomy
courses.description: A research project, undertaken under the direction of a faculty member, culminating in a written report.  Requires approval of the course instructor and program advisor in the Department of Physics and Astronomy.

courses.name: CHEM 566 Advanced Organic Synthesis
courses.description: Discussion of modern synthetic methods and applications to the synthesis of complex organic molecules. Credit will not be given for both CHEM 566 and CHEM 411.

courses.name: PSYC 350A Psychological Aspects of Human Sexuality - PSYC ASP HM SEXL
courses.description: Human sexuality from a biopsychological, behavioural, and psychosocial perspective.
courses.prerequisites: Either (a) PSYC 100 or (b) all of PSYC 101, PSYC 102. (or (c) 6 credits of 200-level Psychology (but not 205 or 263).)

courses.name: PHIL 349A Philosophy of Religion - PHIL OF RELIGION
courses.description: A critical and analytical examination of arguments for and arguments against the existence of God, and other related topics.

courses.name: INDS 502C Interdisciplinary Studies: Thematic Seminars - HIST MEM&SCL REC
courses.description: Seminars, lectures, and discussions of topics involving several faculties. Contact the Interdisciplinary Studies Program for specific topics (www.isgp.ubc.ca).

courses.name: KIN 365 Foundations of Coaching
courses.description: Methods of athletic conditioning, planning the program, psychology of training and coaching, athletic evaluation.

courses.name: FRST 201 Forest Ecology
courses.description: The structure and function of forest ecosystems, including: energetics; productivity; nutrient, carbon and water cycling; soils; the physical environment; population and community ecology; disturbance ecology; ecological succession; biological diversity and ecological resilience.

courses.name: BIOC 460 Advanced Techniques in Biochemistry
courses.description: Theoretical basis and practical applications of a selection of advanced techniques currently used in biochemical research. Topics will vary.
courses.prerequisites: One of BIOC 303, BIOT 380 and all of BIOC 402, BIOC 410.

courses.name: CIVL 304 Introduction to Environmental Engineering
courses.description: Environmental engineering issues and projects; application of scientific and engineering principles to addressing these; soil, water and air pollution, and remediation.

courses.name: MUSC 694C Music Performance (Major) - STRING INST'S
courses.description: Private instruction, vocal or instrumental.

courses.name: EMER 430 Emergency Medicine
courses.description: This course covers the principles of Emergency Medicine.  The seminar series is case based and interactive.  Teaching resuscitative skills is emphasized.

courses.name: MUSC 402A Special Projects - SPECIAL PROJECTS
courses.description: For fourth-year students who receive permission of the Director of the School of Music to do advanced studies in their major field.

courses.name: NAME 501 Advanced Ship Structures
courses.description: Pressure hull design; finite element analysis applications; classification rules; ice and ice loads; dynamic loads including slamming, risk and reliability.

courses.name: ASIA 532B Topics in Traditional Japanese Literature - TRAD JAPN LIT
APBI 442 Grapevine and Berry Crop Biology
courses.description: Grapevine genetics, morphology, and physiology and major biological features of other important berry crops for British Columbia such as blueberry, cranberry, and raspberry. Credit will be granted for only one of APBI 442 or PLNT 542.
courses.prerequisites: One of APBI 210, BIOL 210 and BIOL 234. (BIOL 260 recommended.)

courses.name: PHIL 102 Introduction to Philosophy II
courses.description: Basic problems and methods of philosophy. Topics such as morality, personal identity, free will and determinism, and the meaning of life. Credit will not be given for both PHIL 100 and 102.

courses.name: SOWK 440P Integrative Seminars in Social Work - INTGRTV SEM SOWK
courses.description: A series of seminars offered during the final term of studies which address salient issues in social policy and social work practice and draw upon combined knowledge from social work and related disciplines.

courses.name: PATH 502 Current Topics in Pathology Research
courses.description: General principles of etiology, pathogenesis, disordered physiology, and anatomic pathology of common disease processes.

courses.name: MATH 549B Thesis for Master's Degree - MASTERS THESIS
WOOD 475 Wood Properties, Identification and Uses
courses.description: Elementary chemical, physical and mechanical properties of wood and their variations in relation to structure; identification by hand lens features; manufacture of lumber, pulp and composite wood products. Not available for credit to Wood Products Processing students.

courses.name: BOTA 546D Topics in Botany - TOPICS IN BOTANY
URST 200 Cities
courses.description: An interdisciplinary introduction to the city in the context of contemporary globalization.  Analysis of urban patterns and processes from the theoretical perspectives of various disciplines and methodologies.

courses.name: PATH 451 Clerkship in Laboratory Medicine and Infection Prevention and Control
courses.description: May involve attendance at an approved institution and/or a project assigned by the instructor(s). Instructor permission required. Enrolment may be limited.

courses.name: LAW 482D Topics in Procedure and Evidence - TPCS PROC & EVID
courses.description: Not offered each year, consult Faculty.

courses.name: FMPR 428 Rural and Underserved Community Practice
courses.description: A 4 week full time course that allows medical students in Phase III of the undergraduate program to apprentice with family physicians in rural and underserved community practices. This course is the start of year 3 clerkships and takes place at the end of second year.

courses.name: KIN 303 High Performance Conditioning in Physical Activity and Sport
courses.description: Conditioning methods, exercise techniques and appraisal methods for fitness in high performance physical activity and sport.

courses.name: EOSC 330 Principles of Geomorphology
courses.description: Landform development; morphological and historical analysis of landforms; applications in engineering and resource development. Please consult the Faculty of Science Credit Exclusion List: www.students.ubc.ca/calendar/index.cfm?tree=12,215,410,414.

courses.name: SPPH 515 Surveillance and Monitoring in Public Health
courses.prerequisites: Either (a) all of HCEP 400, HCEP 502 or (b) all of SPPH 400, SPPH 502.

courses.name: LAW 530 Advanced Legal Research and Writing
PHIL 490A Honours Tutorial - HONOURS 4TH YEAR
courses.description: For students in fourth-year Honours.

courses.name: MATH 120 Honours Differential Calculus
courses.description: Limits, derivatives, Mean Value Theorem and applications, elementary functions, optimization, Taylor series, approximation. Please consult the Faculty of Science Credit Exclusion List: www.students.ubc.ca/calendar/index.cfm?tree=12,215,410,414.
courses.prerequisites: (High-school calculus and one of (a) a score of 95% or higher in BC Principles of Mathematics 12 or Pre-calculus 12; or (b) permission from the Mathematics Department Head.)

courses.name: MECH 491 Computer-Aided Manufacturing
courses.description: NC programming and machining with interactive CAD/CAM systems. Curve and surface geometry for tool-path generation. Tool-path generation methodologies. Geometric modeling techniques for simulation and verification of manufacturing processes. Introduction to Computer-Aided Process Planning. Supplementary tutorial laboratory experiments.

courses.name: CNRS 502A Studies in Law and Society - STUDIES LAW
NURS 337 Professional Nursing Practice with Adults, Older Adults, and their Families
courses.description: Analysis and application of theories, concepts, evidence, and competencies guiding professional nursing practice with older adults and their families in a variety of practice settings and contexts.
courses.prerequisites: All of NURS 302, NURS 303, NURS 304, NURS 305, NURS 306.
courses.corequisites: Either (a) all of NURS 338, NURS 339, NURS 340 or (b) all of NURS 341, NURS 342, NURS 343.  (Depends on sequencing of NURS 337 with other professional practice courses.)

courses.name: APSC 201 Technical Communication
courses.description: Written and oral communication in engineering. Report preparation, business correspondence, and oral presentation of technical material. Credit will be granted for only one of ELEC 281, CPEN 281, or APSC 201.
courses.prerequisites: One of APSC 176, ENGL 110, ENGL 111, ENGL 112, ENGL 120, ENGL 121.

courses.name: MUSC 403E Selected Topics in Music - ANALYSIS & PERF
courses.description: See School of Music schedule for description and prerequisites. Restricted to B. Mus. and B.A. in Music students.

courses.name: PHYS 555C Directed Studies in Physics - DIRECTED STUDIES
courses.description: With approval of the department head, advanced studies under the direction of a staff member may be arranged in special cases.

courses.name: FOPR 264 Geomatics, Forest Access and Transportation
courses.description: Geomatics, the physical attributes of forest access and transportation and how they best integrate with the objectives of resource sustainability.

courses.name: LARC 532 Landscape Technologies II
courses.description: Hard landscape materials.

courses.name: HIST 403J Seminar in the History of International Relations - INTRNATNL RELTNS
courses.description: Selected topics in the history of international relations. Priority for registration will be given to fourth-year majors in the International Relations and History programs.

courses.name: EDUC 172 Language and the Curriculum
courses.description: For Dadaab, Kenya teacher education students.

courses.name: FREN 111 Intermediate French I
courses.description: Not available for credit to students with FREN 12, FREN 112 or equivalent.

courses.name: KIN 489E Seminar - SEMINAR
courses.description: Current topics and research in specific areas.
courses.prerequisites: (Fourth-year standing. Consult with Advisor for specific prerequisites.)

courses.name: AUDI 548 Graduating Paper
courses.description: Pass/Fail.

courses.name: CRWR 530 Preparation for a Career in Writing
courses.description: Credit will be granted for only one of CRWR 430 or CRWR 530.

courses.name: CHIN 211 Intermediate Chinese I: Part 1 (Heritage)
courses.description: Integrated skills in modern Chinese. Focus on reading, writing, and better understanding of Chinese culture.

courses.name: PHTH 576 Clinical Decision Making V
courses.description: Pass/fail.

courses.name: ARTH 448 Seminar in North American Architecture
LATN 351 Latin Literature of the Classical Period (Verse)
courses.description: Readings in Latin Verse.

courses.name: CHBE 346 Chemical and Biological Engineering Thermodynamics
courses.description: Volumetric and thermodynamic properties of fluids; equations of state; heat effects; ideal and non-ideal mixtures; fugacities and activity coefficients; vapor-liquid and liquid-liquid phase equilibrium; solubility of gases and solids in liquids; chemical reaction equilibrium; equilibrium partitioning of pollutants.

courses.name: CRWR 504A Advanced Writing for Radio I - ADV WRIT RADIO I
MUSC 221 History of Music IV
courses.description: The development of Western music from circa 1900; an introduction to jazz and popular music and to music of selected non-Western societies.
courses.prerequisites: MUSC 220 and one of MUSC 100, MUSC 110.

courses.name: THTR 308 Sound Design
courses.description: Audio design and production for theatre and other performance forms.

courses.name: SOCI 484A Sociology of Health and Illness - HEALTH & ILLNESS
courses.description: Sociological perspectives on health, illness, and health care as represented in classic and contemporary sociological studies of selected topics such as illness experience, social aspects of the practice of health professionals, training of health professionals, and the social organization of health delivery systems.

courses.name: PSYC 307 Cultural Psychology
courses.description: Cultural influences on human thought and behaviour; interactions of culture and self; multicultural experiences; intercultural relations; methodological issues.
courses.prerequisites: Either (a) PSYC 100 or (b) all of PSYC 101, PSYC 102. (Or (c) 6 credits of 200-level PSYC (but not 205 or 263).)

courses.name: COMM 467 Brand Management
courses.description: Issues and challenges commonly faced by brand managers, including: assessing brand meaning, evaluating brand health, assessing a brand?s leverage potential, evaluating brand extensions, managing brands through a crisis, and assessing brand value.

courses.name: PHIL 340A Knowledge and Reality II - KNOW&REALITY II
courses.description: Topics in metaphysics and epistemology such as induction, the mind/body problem, free will, and action theory. Readings from classic and contemporary texts.

courses.name: ECON 472 Economics of Renewable Resources
courses.description: Application of economic analysis to the management of renewable resources. Special attention is given to criteria for the optimal use of depleting resources such as forests and water. Other topics include public policy with regard to environmental quality, conservation, and outdoor recreation.

courses.name: ARST 520 Selection and Acquisition of Archival Documents
LAW 453 Equitable Remedies
courses.description: The history and development of equitable remedies such as specific performance, injunctions, declarations, relief against forfeiture, and tracing.

courses.name: ASIA 318 Premodern India
courses.description: A survey of the history and culture of India from the earliest historic period to 1200 and the coming of Islam, with emphasis on the evolution of classical Hindu civilization.

courses.name: PHYS 449 Honours Thesis
courses.description: A research project, undertaken under the direction of a faculty member, culminating in a thesis.

courses.name: STAT 251 Elementary Statistics
courses.description: Probability, discrete and continuous random variables, joint probability distributions, estimation, hypothesis testing, regression, analysis of variance, goodness of fit. (Consult the Credit Exclusion list within the Faculty of Science section of the Calendar).
courses.prerequisites: One of MATH 200, MATH 217, MATH 226, MATH 253, MATH 263.

courses.name: ECED 585F Advanced Seminar on Research in Early Childhood Education - RES EARLY CHLDHD
SLAV 307A Literature and Film in Eastern Europe - LIT&FLM EAST EUR
courses.description: Films and translated literature by Slavic writers with emphasis on the interaction between politics and literature.

courses.name: ENGL 491A Senior Honours Seminar - SR HONORS SEMNR1
courses.description: Offerings in literary theory.

courses.name: PHAR 361 Non-Prescription Products and Self-Care of the Patient I
courses.description: The use of non-prescription drugs for selected conditions.

courses.name: FMED 403 Pulmonary
courses.description: An introduction to human respiratory medicine. The relevant anatomy, physiology, biochemistry and genetics will be taught. Instruction in disordered function of the system will be taught by integration of discussion with the normal. As appropriate, pharmacological, therapeutic and other preventative modalities will be introduced.

courses.name: STAT 460 Statistical Inference I
courses.description: A detailed theoretical development. Statistical models, exponential families, sufficiency, completeness, and detailed properties of point estimation. Intended for Honours students.

courses.name: SOWK 425 First Nations Social Issues
courses.description: Contemporary social issues facing First Nations peoples and communities examined in the context of the history of Euro-Canadian/First Nations relations; the impact of Euro-Canadian institutions upon First Nations peoples; implications for social policy and social work practice.

courses.name: CNPS 433 The Personal and Social Development of the Adult
courses.description: Personal and social adjustment issues for professional counsellors; basic skills necessary for effective group counselling.

courses.name: LAW 440 Insurance Law
courses.description: The general legal principles of life, automobile, fire and other types of insurance; the regulation of the insurance industry.

courses.name: MUSC 560E String Chamber Ensembles - GUITAR CHMBR ENS
courses.description: Open only to graduate students.

courses.name: BIOL 327 Introduction to Entomology
courses.description: A survey of the structure, classification and biology of insects; ecology, life-histories and insect-plant relations.

courses.name: APBI 360 Agroecology II
courses.description: Animals and Plants as Components of Agricultural Ecosystems. A systems approach is used to investigate the functions and interactions of plants and animals in agricultural systems. Field trips for assessment of existing agroecosystems.

courses.name: DENT 774A Interdisciplinary Care in Orthodontics and Dentofacial Orthopedics I - INTD ORTH&DNT I
courses.description: Continues in second year.

courses.name: RELG 317 The Origins of Christianity: Social, Religious, and Political Milieux
courses.description: The origins of Christianity as reflected in early Christian literature of the first and early second centuries (including the New Testament).

courses.name: LAW 416 Labour Law
courses.description: Union-management relations; the collective bargaining process; the collective agreement, arbitration and conciliation procedure. The relationship between the union and its membership. Credit will be granted for only one of LAW 415 or LAW 416.

courses.name: GEOG 485 Geography of China
courses.description: An introduction to the changing cultural, social and economic geography of China. Normally alternates with GEOG 425.

courses.name: ENGL 358 Studies in an Eighteenth-Century Genre
courses.prerequisites: (3rd year standing and 6 credits of first-year English, or Arts One, or 6 credits of ASTU 100 from CAP or 3 credits of first-year English and 3 credits of ASTU 150)

courses.name: ECED 400 Introduction to Early Childhood Education and Care
PCTH 325 Rational Basis of Drug Therapy
courses.description: The principles and applications underlying the action and disposition of therapeutic agents (including alternative medicines) in the body.  Use of drugs as tools in experimental research.
courses.prerequisites: One of BIOL 201, BIOC 202, BIOC 203, BIOC 300.

courses.name: KIN 475 Pulmonary Physiology of Exercise
courses.description: Operation of the lungs, chest wall, and ventilatory control mechanisms during dynamic whole-body exercise.

courses.name: POLI 460A Foreign Policy Analysis - FRGN POLICY ANLY
courses.description: A seminar devoted to the analysis of the foreign policies of one or more states, as well as to the study of literature pertaining to foreign policy analysis. For specific content in a given year, consult the departmental website.
courses.prerequisites: Two of POLI 260, POLI 360, POLI 361, POLI 362, POLI 363, POLI 364, POLI 365, POLI 366, POLI 367, POLI 368, POLI 369, POLI 370.

courses.name: LING 311 Studies in Phonology
courses.description: Introduction to phonological analysis and theory, with a strong emphasis on description and analysis of data from a wide variety of languages.

courses.name: EPSE 505 Foundations in Human Development: Infancy to Adulthood
BUSI 335 Information Systems
courses.description: Introduction to information technology related to business use: design, implementation, and application of information systems.

courses.name: KIN 115B Performance Analysis of Selected Individual Sports and Activities - PERF ANYL SPORTS
courses.description: Specific topics to be announced each year. KIN 115 and 215 can be taken in any order.

courses.name: PLAN 517 Theory and Methods of Urban Design
courses.description: Application of urban design theory to a neighbourhood design.

courses.name: PLAN 548F Current Issues in Planning - CULTURAL PLAN
courses.description: Each year the school may offer one or more courses on a topical issue covering recent advances in the field.

courses.name: LAW 447A Topics in Commercial Law - TPCS COMCL LAW
courses.description: Not offered each year, consult Faculty.

courses.name: LAW 472 Advanced Trial Advocacy
courses.description: Skills-training in all aspects of civil and criminal trial advocacy.
courses.prerequisites: One of LAW  270, LAW  469. (LAW 280 or LAW 476 is also recommended.)

courses.name: ENGL 331 The Structure of Modern English: Sentences and Their Uses
courses.description: An introduction to syntax, pragmatics, and sentence semantics.

courses.name: EDUC 496D Practicum (Secondary) for Previously Certified Teachers - TEACH PRACT SECD
courses.description: Pass/Fail.
courses.prerequisites: (Recent completion of secondary teaching methods courses in the subjects to be taught.)

courses.name: STAT 357 Stochastic Signals and Systems
courses.description: Stochastic behaviour of signals and systems (e.g., communication systems); discrete and continuous probability; random processes; modeling and identification of linear time-invariant systems; binary hypothesis testing and decision making.

courses.name: CHBE 598 Seminar
courses.description: Current topics in chemical and biological engineering research. A required seminar for all thesis graduate students (M.Sc., M.A.Sc., and Ph.D.) in the Department of Chemical and Biological Engineering.

courses.name: MECH 468 Modern Control Engineering
courses.description: Introduction to state space control methods for linear systems including modal control, controllability, observability, linear quadratic regulators, optimal control.

courses.name: ARCH 404 Architectural History I
courses.description: Architecture from 1400 to 1900 and the design theory and practice that have shaped it.  Restricted to B.En.D. students.  Credit will be given for only one of  ARCH 405 or ARCH 505.

courses.name: THTR 120 Introduction to Theatre
courses.description: Theory and practice of the theatrical arts. Attendance at plays is required.

courses.name: BAMS 504 Advanced Simulation for Decision Making
NEST 500A Studies in Near Eastern Archaeology in the Bronze Age - STD NE ARCH BRNZ
JRNL 503B Journalism Practice and Standards - NWSRM PRCT STDRD
LAW 430 Advanced Legal Research
courses.description: Research using electronic databases, information systems, and non-legal databases relevant to the resolution of legal issues.

courses.name: ELEC 453 Power System Analysis
courses.description: Transmission and distribution; phasors, complex power; balanced/unbalanced three-phase operation; symmetrical components, sequence networks; voltage regulation; short circuit capacity; circuit breakers; transmission lines, series/shunt impedance; short, medium, and long line models.
courses.prerequisites: One of EECE 373, ELEC 342 and one of ELEC 352, EECE 392.

courses.name: MIDW 125 Pharmacology for Maternity Care Providers
courses.description: An overview of basic concepts in pharmacology, pharmacy, and therapeutics relevant to the practice of midwifery in Canada.

courses.name: FNH 498 Undergraduate Essay
courses.description: Preparation of a comprehensive and analytical review of an approved topic under the supervision of a faculty member. Consultation with a program advisor is required.

courses.name: LIBR 505 Research Methods in Information Organizations
CONS 503C Topics in Conservation - TPS CONSERVATION
SPPH 535 Principles of Occupational and Environmental Hygiene
courses.description: Scientific basis for the recognition, evaluation, and control of chemical, physical, and biological, exposures; standard setting; exposure monitoring methods.

courses.name: ANAT 513 Functional Human Anatomy of the Respiratory, Cardiovascular and Gastrointestinal Systems of the Thorax and Abdomen
SOCI 312A Gender Relations - GENDER RELATIONS
courses.description: The nature of gender relations, their social and cultural expression, and theories of gender inequality.

courses.name: MUSC 349 Keyboard Harmony and Transposition
courses.description: Designed for the keyboard performance major and keyboard concentrator in General Studies.

courses.name: LAW 387 Environmental Law
courses.description: A foundation course dealing with the regulatory and policy framework for the protection of the environment in Canada, such as pollution control and biodiversity conservation.

courses.name: MEDG 419 Developmental Origin of Human Disorders
courses.description: Genetic and epigenetic determinants of development from conception to birth. Topics include development of the neural tube, face, heart, endoderm, blastocyst, embryonic stem cells, gastrulation, genomic imprinting, placental complications, chromosomal abnormalities and prenatal diagnosis. Discussions based on published research articles.
courses.prerequisites: One of BIOL 234, BIOL 334 and one of BIOL 331, BIOL 335. (A standing of 'B' or higher recommended.)

courses.name: MEDG 548D Directed Studies - DIRECTED STUDIES
courses.description: A series of laboratory sessions, directed readings and directed counselling interviews related to selected areas of Medical Genetics. This advanced course may be taken upon approval of the department head.

courses.name: ELEC 465 Microsystems Design
courses.description: Structured modeling and design practices; multiphysics at microscales; physical limitations in MEMS; interface with electronics; behavioural modeling languages for mixed analog-digital system design. Credit will only be given for one of EECE 489, ELEC 465, or EECE 581.

courses.name: FREN 342 French Practice for Non-Specialists I
courses.description: The program of FREN 222, for students not specializing in French. Credit will not be granted for both FREN 222 and FREN 342.

courses.name: STAT 547M Topics in Statistics - TOPICS IN STAT
courses.description: Students should consult the Statistics Department for the particular advanced topics offered in a given year.

courses.name: POLI 552A Political Psychology and Public Opinion - PSYC & PUBL OPIN
LLED 353 Teaching and Learning English as an Additional Language: Elementary
courses.description: Pass/Fail.

courses.name: BIOL 446 History and Philosophy of Biology
courses.description: The nature of science, this history of evolutionary and molecular biology, philosophical questions about scientific methods and fundamental conclusions of biology.
courses.prerequisites: (Fourth-year standing in any degree program is required.)

courses.name: ELEC 315 Electronic Materials and Devices
courses.description: Fundamental aspects of electronic materials such as: semiconductors, metals, dielectrics, piezoelectrics, magnetic materials, and their applications in devices such as diodes, transistors, and transducers.

courses.name: PLAN 508 Foundations of Planning Theory and History
FRST 385 Watershed Hydrology
courses.description: Measurement and analysis of hydrological processes in response to forest management activities.

courses.name: CHBE 419 Industrial Biotechnology Laboratory
courses.description: Modern bioreactor technology, upstream and downstream processing of biotechnology products. Restricted to students in the Joint Degree in Biotechnology.

courses.name: FNH 497B Directed Studies in Food, Nutrition and Health - DST FOOD,NTR HLT
WOOD 412 Co-operative Work Placement V
courses.description: Approved and supervised work experience with a public or private organization for minimum of 13 weeks full-time. Final work term assignment required. Restricted to students in the Co-operative Education Program in Wood Products Processing.

courses.name: PHYS 309 Electrical Laboratory
courses.description: Selected experiments in electromagnetism and electronics; computer data acquisition; advanced data analysis and simulation.

courses.name: MEDG 448C Directed Studies - DIRECTED STUDIES
courses.description: A supervised individual program of study of a topic to be agreed upon by a member of faculty and the student. Permission of the appropriate supervisor and the department head is required.

courses.name: MEDG 505 Genome Analysis
courses.description: Investigation of genetic information as it is organized within genomes, genetic and physical map construction, sequencing technologies, gene identification, database accessing and integration, functional organization of genomes from contemporary, historic and evolutionary perspectives.

courses.name: CPSC 422 Intelligent Systems
courses.description: Principles and techniques underlying the design, implementation and evaluation of intelligent computational systems. Applications of artificial intelligence to natural language understanding, image understanding and computer-based expert and advisor systems. Advanced symbolic programming methodology.

courses.name: GRSJ 503E Special Topics in Feminist Studies - TPC FEMNST STDYS
MICB 502 Advanced Immunogenetics
courses.description: Consult the Credit Exclusion List in the Faculty of Science section of the Calendar.

courses.name: LARC 551 Professional Practice
courses.description: Ethical, legal and business context of professional practice, including contracts, project management.

courses.name: ATSC 499 Co-operative Work Placement IV
courses.description: Approved and supervised technical work experience in an industrial, university or government setting for a minimum of 14 weeks. Normally taken in Winter Session (Term 1) of the fifth year. Technical report required. Restricted to students admitted to the Co-operative Education Program in Atmospheric Science.

courses.name: ARTH 376 Arts of the Northwest Coast Peoples: The North
courses.description: The histories, historiography and cultural diversity of the Northern Northwest Coast region; persistence and innovation in the arts in communities, and in cross-cultural and market spheres.

courses.name: PSYC 308A Social Psychology - SOCIAL PSYC
courses.description: Theory and research of individual social behaviour; social motivation; attitudes; group interaction; socialization; prejudice.
courses.prerequisites: Either (a) PSYC 100 or (b) all of PSYC 101, PSYC 102. (or (c) 6 credits of 200-level Psychology (but not 205 or 263).)

courses.name: VISA 320 Intermediate Drawing I
courses.description: Investigation of drawing as a discipline in the context of contemporary art. Emphasis on expanding definitions of the drawing practice while focusing on technical and conceptual development.

courses.name: SOCI 382 Sociological Methods: Qualitative Research
courses.description: Examination of the different traditions of qualitative sociological inquiry and the associated methodological features used to study the interpretive practices and meanings in the everyday lives of individuals.

courses.name: CIVL 432 Advanced Structural Steel Design
courses.description: Design of steel structures to resist vertical and lateral loads. Floor and roof systems including conceptual layout, floor deck, beams, joists, trusses, and columns. Stability issues and limit states design. Connections and construction aspects. Seismic design.

courses.name: GRSJ 450C Directed Studies - DIRECTED STUDIES
courses.description: General reading and/or a research undertaking, with the agreement, and under supervision of, a faculty member selected by the student and approved by the GRSJ Undergraduate Advisor. A written paper or equivalent will be required. Open to GRSJ majors or minors.

courses.name: ANTH 210 Eating Culture
courses.description: An anthropological exploration of how the collection, cultivation and consumption of food shapes human society and culture.

courses.name: ASIA 341 Classical Chinese Literature in Translation
courses.description: Poetry, historical and philosophic prose writings and the earliest genres of fiction in classical Chinese (ca. 1100 BC ? ca. 750 AD).

courses.name: BIOT 380 Advanced Biotechnology
courses.description: Block registration for the microbiology, molecular genetics, biochemistry, management and regulatory affairs, process systems, analytical chemistry and communication courses taken in the BCIT/UBC Joint Degree in Biotechnology.  Credit limited to students in the Joint Degree Program.

courses.name: POLI 547B Topics in Political Theory - TPCS POLI THEORY
ENGL 541A Studies in American Literature Since 1890 - AMER LIT 1890 ON
COMM 386A Topics in Business III - BUSI ETHCS LDSHP
LLED 492C Supervised Study in Reading - SPR ST IN READ
MTRL 381 Structure and Properties Laboratory
courses.description: Structure and properties of ferrous and non-ferrous metals; heat treatment; hardenability; metallography; age hardening.

courses.name: MICB 425 Microbial Ecological Genomics
courses.description: Intrinsic and extrinsic forces driving prokaryotic genome evolution.  Gene transfer; microbial species concepts; community genome structure, function and dynamics; ecological impacts of microbial genome diversity.  Emphasis on problem solving and experimental design.
courses.prerequisites: One of BIOL 335, MICB 325. (One of MICB 201 or MICB 301 is recommended.)

courses.name: MINE 434 Processing Precious Metal Ores
courses.description: Process alternatives and mineralogical considerations; physical and chemical recovery technologies; environmental protection; flowsheet studies.

courses.name: HEBR 201 Intermediate Biblical Hebrew I
courses.description: The second year of Biblical Hebrew with emphasis on rapid reading of poetry and prose along with grammar.

courses.name: ASIA 342 Chinese Literature in Translation: The Vernacular Tradition
courses.description: Readings in drama and fiction, 800 to 1800 AD. The emergence of vernacular genres as distinct from and sometimes opposed to the existing classical genres.

courses.name: SPAN 222 Introduction to the Analysis of Hispanic Cultural Texts
courses.description: Critical analysis of different cultural genres such as music, cinema, art, photography, through the study of selected Iberian and Latin American cultural texts.  Not available for credit toward the Major or Minor in Spanish.  Taught in Spanish.

courses.name: GEOG 547A Directed Reading in Human Geography - HUMAN GEO DR RDG
MATH 405 Numerical Methods for Differential Equations
courses.description: Interpolation, numerical integration, numerical solution of ordinary and partial differential equations. Practical computational methods emphasized and basic theory developed through simple models. See Faculty of Science credit exclusion list: http://www.calendar.ubc.ca/vancouver/index.cfm?tree=12,215,410,414.

courses.name: BIOL 260 Fundamentals of Physiology
courses.description: Principles of cellular and organismal physiology illustrated with examples from unicellular organisms, plants and animals, focusing on transport processes, water balance, nutrient acquisition and communication.
courses.prerequisites: Either (a) all of BIOL 112, BIOL 121 or (b) SCIE 001. (or (c) 8 transfer credits of 1st year BIOL and 6 credits of 1st year chemistry.)

courses.name: SPAN 101 Beginners' Spanish I
courses.description: Grammar, composition, translation, oral practice.

courses.name: PHAR 472 Pathophysiology III
courses.description: Pathophysiology of selected disease states.

courses.name: LING 546A Directed Reading in Topics related to Linguistics - DIRECTED READING
LAIS 605 Seminar in Advanced Research Methods
CHEM 402 Diffraction Methods
courses.description: Crystal structures; point and space groups; X-ray diffraction, neutron diffraction, electron diffraction of gases and surfaces. Credit will be given for only one of CHEM 402 and 514.

courses.name: SOWK 621 Social Theory, Ideology and Ethics
courses.description: Critical analysis of major social theories, differentiating competing approaches to understanding human behaviour; social theory, social ideology, and social ethics.

courses.name: ECED 406 Early Learning Curriculum in the Pre-School Years
courses.description: The development of pre-kindergarten programs with reference to recent research, theories of early learning, and curriculum trends and practices.

courses.name: AUDI 527 Introduction to Dysphagia
courses.description: Pass/Fail.

courses.name: MINE 592B Mining Industry Internship - MINE INTERNSHIP
courses.description: Mining or mineral processing engineering internship in which concepts, theory and practice of mining and mineral processing engineering are applied by working with industry on appropriate technical projects. Pass/fail.

courses.name: POLI 464F Problems in International Relations - PROB INTRL RELTN
courses.description: Content varies from year to year. Consult the departmental website. One section (of 3 credits) is reserved for fourth-year students in the Major program in International Relations.

courses.name: ECON 309 Intermediate Open Economy Macroeconomics
courses.description: The aggregate economy with emphasis on macroeconomic policy and international economic growth, money and inflation, unemployment, business cycles, and macroeconomic stabilization policy under fixed and flexible exchange rates. Registration restricted to students in the Bachelor of International Economics Program. Credit will be granted for only one of ECON 302, 305, or 309.
courses.prerequisites: All of ECON 101, ECON 102, MATH 105 and one of MATH 104, MATH 184.

courses.name: BA 530J Study Abroad and Exchange - STUDY ABR'D&EXCH
courses.description: Restricted to students in one of the following programs: M.B.A., LL.B./M.B.A., M.Sc.B., Ph.D. with B.A.D.M. specialization, or M.M. with either ECMS or ECMJ. M.M. ECMS or ECMJ students are limited to a maximum of 12 credits in this course.

courses.name: IGEN 330 Intermediate Engineering Design
courses.description: Intermediate level engineering design projects involving material in the curriculum of the Integrated Engineering program.
courses.prerequisites: (Third-year standing in the Integrated Engineering program.)

courses.name: PATH 437 Viral Infections in Humans
courses.description: Interactions between viruses and humans; pathogenesis; prompt virological diagnosis; rationale for antiviral chemotherapy and prophylaxis.

courses.name: EECE 571B Electrical Engineering Seminar and Special Problems - BIG DATA SYSTEMS
CIVL 230 Solid Mechanics I
courses.description: Stress and strain, Hooke's law, axially loaded members, torsion, shear forces and bending moments in beams, bending of beams, shear stresses in beams, shear centre, composite members, introduction to elasto-plastic and statically indeterminate problems.

courses.name: PHIL 101 Introduction to Philosophy
courses.description: Basic problems and methods of philosophy. Topics such as the nature and scope of human knowledge, the existence of God, and the relationship between mind and body. Credit will not be given for both PHIL 100 and 101.

courses.name: ELEC 454 Power System Analysis II
courses.description: Power system monitoring/control; large networks; automatic generation control; optimum power flow calculations; traveling wave transmission lines; EMTP and MATLAB programs for transients, short-circuit, and transient stability analysis.

courses.name: FISH 504 Quantitative Analysis of Fisheries I
OBST 501 Reproductive Endocrinology I
courses.description: Neuroendocrine regulation of reproduction, regulation of the ovarian and testicular function.

courses.name: THTR 547C Directed Studies in Theatre and Drama and Film/Television - DIRECTED STUDIES
PHAR 542 Central Nervous System Pharmacology
courses.description: A course comprised of lectures, assigned readings and reports on selected topics dealing with drug actions in the central nervous system. Given in alternate years. Permission of instructor required.

courses.name: PCTH 499 Co-operative Work Placement IV
courses.description: Approved and supervised technical work experience in an industrial research setting for a minimum of 3.5 months. Normally taken during the summer after fourth year. Technical report required. Restricted to students admitted to the Co-operative Education Program in Pharmacology.

courses.name: PSYC 398 Cooperative Work Placement I
courses.description: Approved and supervised relevant work experience in an industrial, academic, or government setting for a minimum of 13 weeks, full-time. Normally taken in Summer Session after third year. Work term report required. Restricted to students admitted to the Co-op Program in Psychology (B.Sc.).

courses.name: ARCH 512 Structures I
courses.description: Quantitative and qualitative means for understanding of statics, materials and flow of force through a structure.

courses.name: CDST 350A Canadian Studies - CDN STUDIES
courses.description: An interdisciplinary introduction to Canadian studies. Required of all majors.

courses.name: PORT 101 First-Year Portuguese I
courses.description: Grammar, composition, translation, oral practice. Credit will be granted for only one of PORT 101 or PORT 110.

courses.name: PHYS 341 Physics of Music
courses.description: An introduction to the physical principles important to the production, transmission and perception of musical sounds. The treatment will be non-mathematical; with emphasis on demonstrations. Topics may include the description of sound waves, resonances, scales, physics of hearing, examination of specific musical instruments, etc. Not for credit in the Faculties of Science and Applied Science.

courses.name: ENGL 319 History of the English Language: Later History
courses.description: Principles of language change. The development and spread of the English language from the Norman Conquest to the Modern English period.
courses.prerequisites: (Third-year standing. Knowledge of the International Phonetic Alphabet. ENGL 318 or ENGL 330 or the equivalent is recommended.)

courses.name: CHEM 205 Physical Chemistry
courses.description: Chemical kinetics and thermodynamics and spectroscopy useful in biological, medical, agricultural, earth, and related sciences. Credit will be given for only one of CHEM 201 and 205.
courses.prerequisites: Either (a) SCIE 001 or (b) one of MATH 100, MATH 102, MATH 104, MATH 110, MATH 120, MATH 180, MATH 184 and one of CHEM 113, CHEM 123, CHEM 154.

courses.name: BIOL 412 Phytogeography
courses.description: Description and interpretation of present and past floristic vegetational patterns; integration of evolutionary, ecological, and phytogeographical concepts. Terrestrial and aquatic plants are considered. Restricted to students of third and fourth years.

courses.name: HIST 103 World History Since 1900
courses.description: International relations; changes in the nation-state system; the emergence and impact of major political ideologies; genocide; decolonization; the globalization of trade; and the dynamics of economic, social, cultural, and environmental change in a global context.

courses.name: SOWK 200 Introduction to Social Welfare
courses.description: An introduction to the perspectives, concepts and theoretical foundations of social welfare, including an analysis of the institutional structures of social welfare in the modern state.

courses.name: MATH 450 Asymptotic and Perturbation Methods
courses.description: Asymptotic expansions. Asymptotic evaluation of integrals; WKBJ methods. Regular and singular expansions. Boundary layer theory; matched asymptotic expansions. Multiple scale techniques.

courses.name: EPSE 436 Survey of Behaviour Disorders in Children and Adolescents
PHYS 502 Condensed Matter Physics I
courses.description: One-electron theory of solids, energy bands, lattice vibration, transport theory.
courses.prerequisites: (A background in undergraduate solid state physics such as covered in PHYS 474 is highly recommended.)

courses.name: EDCP 375A Business Education I - Secondary: Curriculum and Pedagogy - BUS ED I SEC C&P
courses.description: Pass/Fail.

courses.name: ISCI 448J Directed Studies - DIR STUDIES
courses.description: Permission of the Director is required.

courses.name: MUSC 442C Song Interpretation - SONG INTERPRET
courses.description: Survey of the literature for voice with keyboard accompaniment, with emphasis on performance problems. Open to piano and voice majors, and to others by permission of instructor. May be repeated once for credit.

courses.name: COMM 604 Advanced Topics in Urban Land Economics I
ARTH 480 Visual and Digital Media Theory
courses.description: A thematic examination of key arguments in visual and digital media theory, focusing on developments in lens-based and digital media in relationship to twentieth-century and contemporary artistic practice.

courses.name: DENT 596 Endodontic Case Review and Treatment Planning III
courses.description: Student case presentations, treatment choice, and evaluation of prognosis.

courses.name: HIST 368 Europe in the 19th Century
courses.description: An investigation of main themes in European history from the French Revolution to the beginning of the 20th century. Topics of particular importance are: domestic politics; the interaction of states; the formation of new states; social and economic transformations affecting the whole civilization; major cultural expressions of the century.

courses.name: COMM 590B Topics in Business Administration - TOPICS BUS ADMIN
PLAN 550A Directed Studies - DIRECTED STUDIES
courses.description: In special cases and with the approval of the Director of the school, a student may study an advanced topic under the direction of a faculty member.

courses.name: BIOC 449C Honours Thesis - HONOURS THESIS
courses.description: A research problem under the direction of a faculty member. Restricted to Honours students.

courses.name: MINE 480 Mine Waste Management
courses.description: Basic geotechnical, hydrological, and water management aspects of mine waste management.

courses.name: ECON 350 Public Finance Policy Topics
courses.description: Examination of two or three selected policy problems from areas of taxation, income security, and public expenditures. Topics to be selected each year from areas of current or recent policy debate. Examples include public pension policy, privatization and public services, income tax or sales tax reform, federal-provincial cost sharing programs, tax incentives versus direct expenditures, welfare reform.

courses.name: MECH 506 Linear Vibrations
courses.description: Transient and steady state vibration analysis of continuous and discrete mechanical systems. Lagrange's equation and Hamilton's Principle. Measurement of vibration. Machinery health monitoring. Frequency domain analysis. Experimental modal analysis. Vibration of rotating machinery.

courses.name: WOOD 276 Mechanics of Wood Products
courses.description: Introduction to the strength of materials with emphasis on the elastic properties and ultimate strength of wood and wood products.
courses.prerequisites: One of PHYS 101, PHYS 170 and one of MATH 101, MATH 103, MATH 105, MATH 121.

courses.name: ELEC 455 Power Systems Protection
courses.description: Analysis of disturbances, security of power systems, cascading and blackouts; role and impact of protection; transducers and measuring elements; protection of transmission and distribution systems; protection of generators, substation equipment, special protection systems and relays.
courses.prerequisites: One of EECE 458, ELEC 453 and one of EECE 373, ELEC 342, EECE 374.

courses.name: EECE 580 Emerging Electronic Materials and Devices
courses.description: The physics, fabrication and characterization of organic and carbon nanotube based capacitors, transistors, batteries, electrochromic windows, active displays, chemical sensors, photo-detectors, strain gauges, actuators and single molecule devices.

courses.name: STAT 560 Statistical Theory I
courses.description: Credit will not be given for both STAT 460 and STAT 560.

courses.name: EOSC 329 Groundwater Hydrology
courses.description: Introduction to theory of groundwater flow; flow nets; regional groundwater resource evaluation; well hydraulics; role of groundwater in geologic processes.
courses.prerequisites: One of MATH 101, MATH 103, MATH 105, MATH 121, SCIE 001.

courses.name: FRE 340 International Agricultural Development
courses.description: Characteristics, processes and sources of economic growth, role of agricultural and resource sectors in economic growth, analysis of output and input markets in those sectors, policy failures, tools for empirical analysis of rural markets, growth, and the environment.

courses.name: ARCL 232 Ancient Latin America
courses.description: The archaeology of ancient Mexico, Central and South America, highlighting recent discoveries about the emergence and growth of civilizations such as the Aztecs, Maya, Zapotec, Inca, Chimor and their ancestors.

courses.name: MEDG 550 Concepts in Clinical Genetics for Genetic Counselling
courses.description: Practical applications, theories, and principles of medical genetics as they apply to genetic counselling.

courses.name: PSYC 367 Sensory Systems
courses.description: Anatomy and physiology of the sensory pathways and their relation to perception.
courses.prerequisites: Either (a) PSYC 100 or (b) all of PSYC 101, PSYC 102. (or (c) 6 credits of 200-level Psychology (but not 205 or 263).)

courses.name: AUDI 550A Advanced Topics in Audiology - ADV TPCS AUDI
courses.description: May be taken more than once for credit.

courses.name: MEDI 501 Molecular and Cellular Biology of Experimental Medicine
courses.description: Cell and molecular function in normal tissues and in specific disease processes, including, genetic, viral, bacterial, immune, and physiological disorders.

courses.name: HIST 318 Early Twentieth-Century Britain
courses.description: British society and politics in the era of the two world wars: the liberal reforms before the Great War, war experiences, the Great Depression, and the impact of new political movements.

courses.name: ELEC 415 Semiconductor Devices: Physics, Design and Analysis
courses.description: Physics of operation, and design and analysis of semiconductor devices of topical interest, e.g., solar cells, LEDs, high-speed MOSFETs, high-frequency HBTs, low-noise HEMTs.

courses.name: EPSE 550 Professional, Ethical and Legal Issues in School Psychology
MINE 506 Mining Methods
courses.description: A more advanced study of some aspects of mining methods. Credit will be granted for only one of MINE 506 or MINE 550.

courses.name: ANTH 517 Archaeological Methods
courses.description: A discussion of selected basic data-gathering methods in their relation to the development of ideas about the archaeological record.

courses.name: MIDW 360 Global Maternal Infant Health
courses.description: Social and economic determinants of maternal and fetal health worldwide, innovative public health strategies to reducing maternal and infant mortality and morbidity, and the impact of conflict on the health of mothers and babies.  Ethical considerations related to global clinical placements and medical tourism.  Theoretical course in preparation for global clinical placement.  Pass/Fail.

courses.name: LAW 325 Conflict of Laws
courses.description: A study of the private legal problems arising in cases in which the relevant facts cut across provincial or national boundaries. Recommended to be taken in third year.

courses.name: BIOL 233 Genetics for Life
courses.description: How genetic differences determine individual characteristics, and how they are inherited, analyzed, and modified. Emphasis on genetic diversity, human ancestry, personal genomics, and cancer genetics.
courses.prerequisites: Either (a) all of BIOL 112, BIOL 121 or (b) SCIE 001. (; or (c) a corequisite of CHEM 203 and one of BIOL 112 or BIOL 121.)

courses.name: MTRL 594 Advanced Composite Materials
courses.description: Processing and properties of advanced polymer based composite materials with emphasis on analysis, design, and manufacturing. Credit will only be given for one of MTRL 494, 594.

courses.name: LAW 395 Forest Law
courses.description: Acquisition of timber interests; development, financing and organization of timber companies; regulation of exploitation industry interests; management taxation. Not offered each year; consult Faculty.

courses.name: CPSC 340 Machine Learning and Data Mining
courses.description: Models of algorithms for dimensionality reduction, nonlinear regression, classification, clustering and unsupervised learning; applications to computer graphics, computer games, bio-informatics, information retrieval, e-commerce, databases, computer vision and artificial intelligence.
courses.prerequisites: One of MATH 152, MATH 221, MATH 223 and one of STAT 200, STAT 203, STAT 241, STAT 251, MATH 302, STAT 302, MATH 318, BIOL 300;  and either (a) CPSC 221 or (b) all of CPSC 260, EECE 320 and one of CPSC 210, EECE 210, EECE 309.

courses.name: MICB 448A Directed Research - DIRECTED RESRCH
courses.description: A library (3 credits) or laboratory (3 or 6 credits) project. Requires permission of the Undergraduate Advisor. The results are presented in a written report to be reviewed by oral examination.
courses.prerequisites: Either (a) MICB 323 or (b) all of MICB 322, MICB 399.

courses.name: CHEM 211 Introduction to Chemical Analysis
courses.description: Quantitative chemical analysis; chemical and physical principles of spectrophotometry, potentiometry, and chromatography.

courses.name: ANTH 451 Conservation of Organic Materials
courses.description: Conservation of organic materials within a museum environment; the nature of materials, mechanisms of deterioration and principles of preventive conservation. Recommended for students intending to work with cultural materials.

courses.name: MUSC 565D Asian Music Ensemble - AFRICAN MUS/DANC
courses.description: Study of Asian music, to include practical training in instrumental techniques and ensemble performance. The music of one major Asian civilization, often Chinese, will be emphasized.

courses.name: KORN 200 Intermediate Korean
courses.description: Reading and writing of modern colloquial Korean at an intermediate level. As of 2011W, credit will be granted for only one of KORN 201/202 or KORN 200.

courses.name: ARCH 548 Graduate Project Part I
courses.description: Preparation of a graduation design project including literature review.

courses.name: ANTH 315 Japanese Culture and Society
courses.description: Japanese culture and society: patterns of organization, value systems, family, education, work, minorities and diversity, harmony and conflict, urban/rural differences, gender, sexuality, youth, tradition, continuity, change, and future prospects.

courses.name: EOSC 442 Climate Measurement and Analysis
courses.description: Local climate time series collection and analysis. Retrieval and analysis of on-line climate data and model output.
courses.prerequisites: EOSC 340 and one of CPSC 110, CPSC 111, CPSC 301, EOSC 211, MATH 210, PHYS 210 and one of STAT 200, STAT 241, BIOL 300.

courses.name: JAPN 406 Readings in Modern Japanese Essays
courses.description: An advanced course in the reading and analysis of scholarly texts in modern Japanese drawn from history, sociology, economics, etc. Advanced conversation, composition, and practice in the use of standard reference tools as preparation for independent research in Japanese.
courses.prerequisites: JAPN 301. (It is recommended that students complete JAPN 303 prior to taking JAPN 406.)

courses.name: EDST 502A Growing Up in History: Critical Approaches to Children and Youth - HISTORY CHLD YTH
ASIA 532A Topics in Traditional Japanese Literature - TRAD JAPN LIT
CHEM 325 Integrated Chemistry Laboratory I
courses.description: Principles and techniques of modern chemistry applied by integrating experiments chosen from organic, inorganic, physical, and analytical chemistry. Open only to students in Chemistry specializations.
courses.prerequisites: All of CHEM 211, CHEM 213, CHEM 245 and either (a) all of CHEM 201, CHEM 202 or (b) CHEM 208.

courses.name: MUSC 159A University Chamber Strings - UNIV CHMBR STRNG
courses.description: May be repeated for credit in accordance with program requirements for B.Mus. or B.A. in Music. Open to other students by audition, with credit, as stipulated by their faculties.

courses.name: BIOL 437 Laboratory in Animal Cell Molecular Biology
courses.description: The use of recombinant DNA techniques to explore problems in animal developmental biology.
courses.prerequisites: All of BIOL 331, BIOL 335 and one of BIOL 201, BIOC 300, BIOC 302, BIOC 303. (Permission of the department head is also required.)

courses.name: BIOL 406 Plant Ecology I
courses.description: Plant community ecology including a consideration of the major approaches to sampling, analyzing and interpreting vegetation patterns. Instruction given in field work and computer analysis of field data.
courses.prerequisites: One of BIOL 230, BIOL 302, BIOL 304. (BIOL 324 is recommended.)

courses.name: BIOC 403 Enzymology
courses.description: Kinetic analysis, catalytic mechanisms, transition state stabilization and regulation of activity, strategies for active site characterization and case studies of well-documented enzyme systems. Credit given for only one of BIOC 403, CHEM 413 or CHEM 569.
courses.prerequisites: BIOC 402. (A minimum standing of 65% is recommended.)

courses.name: ADHE 330 The Community Practice of Adult Education
courses.description: Community based adult education with particular emphasis on the application of knowledge of the social, economic, cultural and political environment in developing and conducting adult education programs with an for individuals and groups.

courses.name: ADHE 412 An Overview of Adult Education
courses.description: Survey of adult education theory and practice in Canada and the world. The focus is on the purpose and participation in, adult education, characteristics of learners, and the training of adult educators.

courses.name: ASIA 305 Asian Horror Cinema: National Nightmares and Specters of Trauma
courses.description: Engaging with the ideologies, industrial histories, socio-cultural contexts, and aesthetics of horror films - and the genre itself - from various Asian cinemas.

courses.name: POLI 377 Nuclear Weapons and Arms Control
courses.description: Evolution and contemporary significance of nuclear weapons and arms control policy and technology from the perspective of the physical and life sciences and the social sciences and humanities.
courses.prerequisites: (Third-year standing in B.A. or B.Sc. progrm, or second-year standing in B.A.Sc. program)

courses.name: ECON 336 Economic History of Canada
courses.description: The growth of the Canadian economy in relation to development of natural resources, changing markets, industrialism, communications, and technology.

courses.name: ARTH 540B Studies in 20th Century Art - 20TH CENT ART
CIVL 524 Legal Aspects of Project and Construction Management
courses.description: Legal issues of construction contracts, bidding processes, negligence, insurance, bonding, liens, and labour law.

courses.name: PHIL 125 Introduction to Scientific Reasoning
courses.description: Historical and logical analysis of various types of scientific hypotheses and the data that support or undermine them. This course is restricted to students with fewer than 90 credits.

courses.name: PHYS 438 Zoological Physics
courses.description: Animal systems viewed from a physicist's perspective. Topics include sensory systems, energy budgets, locomotion, internal flows, physical advantages of grouping.
courses.prerequisites: One of PHYS 101, PHYS 107, PHYS 153, PHYS 157, SCIE 001. (BIOL 325 is recommended.)

courses.name: MECH 484 Aircraft Design: Aerodynamics
courses.description: Aircraft performance, stability and control, loading and air worthiness. Detailed example.

courses.name: MINE 508 Integrated Mining and Processing Systems
courses.description: Methods and systems for integrated mining and processing, conceptual model development, simulation, economic and technical evaluation. Credit will be granted for only one of MINE 508 or MINE 557.

courses.name: GRSJ 520B M.A. Thesis - M.A. THESIS
courses.description: Pass/Fail.

courses.name: HINU 102 Introductory Hindi-Urdu
courses.description: Spoken Hindi and Urdu, and written Hindi. As of 2011W, credit will be granted for only one of HINU 100/101 or HINU 102.

courses.name: FREN 357 Translation I
courses.description: Comparative study of French and English through translation.

courses.name: MINE 590J Special Advanced Topics - FLOT FDMT & APPL
courses.description: A special advanced course may be arranged upon the approval of the department head.

courses.name: EDUC 495A Practicum (Elementary) for Previously Certified Teachers - TEACH PRACT ELEM
courses.description: Pass/Fail.
courses.prerequisites: (Completion of recent elementary teaching methods courses in the subjects to be taught.)

courses.name: WOOD 311 Co-operative Work Placement II
courses.description: Approved and supervised work experience with a public or private organization for a minimum of 13 weeks full-time. Final work term assignment required. Restricted to students in the Co-operative Education Program in Wood Products Processing.

courses.name: MECH 582 Experimental Fluid Mechanics
