courses.description: Modelling Test facilities. Wind tunnel force measurement. Theory of conventional and modern manometry. Classical velocimetry. Hotwire anemometry. Theory and application of laser Doppler velocimetry. Particle image velocimetry. Flow visualization techniques. Thermometry. Credit will not be given for both MECH 489 and MECH 582.

courses.name: CRWR 416A Writing for Television I - WRT TELEVISION 1
courses.description: A workshop class in writing for television. Admission is restricted to B.F.A. Majors in Creative Writing.

courses.name: HIST 378 History of Early China
courses.description: History of China from the earliest times to the disintegration of the Tang Empire. Students will acquire the analytical skills and tools to understand the origins and foundations of Chinese society.

courses.name: THTR 405 Scenery Design II
courses.description: Exploration of complex scenery design and development of design portfolio.

courses.name: PLAN 548R Current Issues in Planning - RESEARCH DESIGN
courses.description: Each year the school may offer one or more courses on a topical issue covering recent advances in the field.

courses.name: COMM 480 Co-operative Work Placement III
courses.description: Approved and supervised work experience for a minimum of 35 months. Normally taken during the summer term of the fourth year. Technical report required. Restricted to students admitted to the Co-operative. Education Program in Commerce.

courses.name: KIN 461 Prevention of Sports Injuries I
courses.description: Training and safety strategies for the prevention of injuries to the musculoskeletal system and sense organs.
courses.prerequisites: One of KIN  361, HKIN 361. (and third-year standing.)

courses.name: CNPS 426 The Role of the Teacher in Guidance
courses.description: This course is designed to assist the teacher in understanding and using guidance techniques for day-to-day use in the classroom. The emphasis will be on techniques for working with people towards better self-understanding and better perspectives of alternatives.

courses.name: CRWR 415A Workshop in Literary Translation I - WK LIT TRANS I
courses.description: Where a language department is regularly consulted on a project, the language adviser may assign marks equal to 3 credits of the course.
courses.prerequisites: (Proficiency in a language other than English.)

courses.name: MTRL 557 Separation Science in Aqueous Metal Processing
courses.description: The theory of solvent extraction and ion exchange, membrane separations, chemical precipitation, electrochemical separations and other techniques for aqueous metal processing, applications from the metal processing literature.

courses.name: APSC 450 Professional Engineering Practice
courses.description: Legislation affecting the practice of engineering; ethical principles and responsibilities. Management of engineering enterprises; labour relations, safety and environmental legislation. Restricted to engineering undergraduate students in the final year of their program.

courses.name: PHYL 548B Advanced Topics in Human Physiology - ADV HUMAN PHYL
PSYC 461 Neuroplasticity and Behaviour
courses.description: Experimental findings and theory documenting the plasticity of the brain and its relationship to behaviour: emphasis on gene regulation, neurogenesis and cell morphology changes in relation to learning and experience.

courses.name: CHBE 474 Process Control Engineering
courses.description: Frequency response analysis; advanced control techniques; multivariable control systems; mathematical tools for computer control systems; design of computer control systems; engineering design of industrial control applications; plant wide control concepts; distributed control systems concepts.

courses.name: DENT 713 Clinical Periodontics and Implant Surgery III
courses.description: Pass/Fail.

courses.name: NURS 334 Professional Nursing Practice with Infants, Children, Youth, and their Families
courses.description: Analysis and application of theories concepts, evidence and competencies guiding professional nursing practice with infants, children, youth, and their families through childhood and adolescence in a variety of practice setting and contexts.
courses.prerequisites: All of NURS 302, NURS 303, NURS 304, NURS 305, NURS 306.
courses.corequisites: Either (a) all of NURS 338, NURS 339, NURS 340 or (b) all of NURS 341, NURS 342, NURS 343.  (Depends on sequencing of NURS 334 with other professional practice courses.)

courses.name: MECH 368 Engineering Measurements and Instrumentation
courses.description: Industrial measurement needs including: architecture of electronic instrumentation systems; electrical representation of physical quantities; sensors and actuators; analog signal processing using linear and non-linear circuits; computer based readout including programming for user-interface and data acquisition.
courses.prerequisites: Either (a) two of MECH 220, MECH 224, ELEC 203 or (b) two of MECH 220, MECH 224, EECE 263.

courses.name: EPSE 348 Family-Centred Practice for Children with Special Needs
CPSC 445 Algorithms in Bioinformatics
courses.description: Sequence alignment, phylogenetic tree reconstruction, prediction of RNA and protein structure, gene finding and sequence annotation, gene expression, and biomolecular computing.
courses.prerequisites: CPSC 320. (and six credits of BIOL beyond BIOL 111.)

courses.name: CRWR 407Y Writing of Drama for the Stage I - STAGE DRAMA I
courses.description: A workshop class in writing of drama for the stage. Studio work is required, and some plays may be given a live stage production in Brave New Play Rites (adjudication process involved). Admission is restricted to B.F.A. Majors in Creative Writing.

courses.name: MATH 217 Multivariable and Vector Calculus
courses.description: Partial differentiation, extreme values, multiple integration, vector fields, line and surface integrals, the divergence theorem, Green's and Stokes' theorems.  Intended for students in Honours Physics and Engineering Physics. Please consult the Faculty of Science Credit Exclusion List: www.students.ubc.ca/calendar/index.cfm?tree=12,215,410,414.
courses.prerequisites: A score of 68% or higher in one of PHYS 101, PHYS 107, PHYS 153, SCIE 001 and a score of 68% or higher in one of PHYS 102, PHYS 108, PHYS 153, SCIE 001 and a score of 68% or higher in one of MATH 101, MATH 103, MATH 105, MATH 121, SCIE 001.

courses.name: CHIN 471 Later Classical Chinese Poetry (Tang)
courses.description: Readings in classical poetry from the time of Du Fu (712-770) to the end of the Tang Dynasty, at an advanced level. Not to be taken concurrently with any CHIN courses lower than 400-level. Credit will be granted for only one of CHIN 471 or 474.
courses.prerequisites: One of CHIN 313, CHIN 314, CHIN 317, CHIN 318, CHIN 323.

courses.name: MUSC 164 Jazz Ensemble
courses.description: Performance techniques and repertoire. May be repeated for credit in accordance with program requirements for B.Mus. or B.A. in Music.

courses.name: MIDW 220 Introduction to Midwifery Clinical Care
courses.description: Clinical care of women experiencing normal pregnancy, labour, birth, and puerperium.  Clinical education experiences in preventative and therapeutic midwifery care with emphasis on prenatal and postnatal midwifery care.  Clinical practice education opportunities within the province.  Pass/Fail.

courses.name: LAW 473 Appellate Advocacy
courses.description: Issues relating to advocacy before appellate courts; techniques of appellate advocacy. Not offered each year, consult Faculty.

courses.name: WOOD 494 Principles of Wood Cutting and Tooling
courses.description: Wood cutting fundamentals, chip formation, cutting conditions, cutting edge maintenance, sawing, planing and molding, veneer cutting, chipping, turning.

courses.name: PHAR 330 Pharmacogenomics: Genetics and Drug Action
courses.description: Application of genetic information to drug therapy.

courses.name: EDCP 377 Design and Technology II - Secondary: Curriculum and Pedagogy
FNH 301 Food Chemistry I
courses.description: Constituents of food and related chemical physical properties including water, carbohydrates, proteins, lipids, minerals, and vitamins.
courses.prerequisites: Either (a) CHEM 201 or (b) CHEM 205;  and either (a) CHEM 203 or (b) CHEM 233.

courses.name: EOSC 584B Topics in Biological Oceanography - BIOL OCEANOGRPHY
LLED 459 Trends and Issues in Literacy Instruction
courses.prerequisites: (An introductory-level reading or language arts education course.)

courses.name: CAPS 426 Physiological Basis of Central Nervous System Functions
courses.description: An integrated study of the structural and functional organization of the central nervous system with special emphasis on neurophysiological mechanisms.
courses.prerequisites: (A cumulative average of 75% over at least 90 credits attempted in the first three years of a student's program and a minimum mark of 75% in CAPS 301 or PHYL 301. Permission of the course director is also required.)

courses.name: HIST 402B Problems in International Relations - PRBS INTRNL RELN
courses.description: Selected topics such as trade, migration, diplomacy, war, migration, colonialism, and post- colonialism. Priority for registration to majors in History or International Relations.

courses.name: PHYS 203 Thermal Physics I
courses.description: Fundamentals of thermodynamics and statistical physics; entropy, laws of thermodynamics, heat engines, free energy, phase transitions, Boltzmann statistics, quantum statistics.
courses.prerequisites: One of PHYS 102, PHYS 108, PHYS 118, PHYS 158, PHYS 153, SCIE 001.
courses.corequisites: One of MATH 217, MATH 200, MATH 226, MATH 253, MATH 263.

courses.name: ASTU 412A Co-operative Work Placement V - COOP PLACEMENT V
courses.description: Optional extra work placement. Approved and supervised work experience with a public or private organization for a minimum of 13 weeks full-time. Final work term report.

courses.name: PHIL 415A The Philosophy of Immanuel Kant - PHLSPHY I. KANT
courses.description: Study of Kant's critical philosophy.

courses.name: MUSC 506 Readings in Orchestral Repertoire
courses.description: Standard repertoire for orchestral instrumentalists.

courses.name: COMM 389 Creativity in Business
courses.description: The role and importance of creativity in developing successful business solutions.

courses.name: STAT 599 Co-operative Work Placement II
courses.description: Restricted to students admitted to the Co-operative M.Sc. Education Program in Statistics.

courses.name: SPHA 553 Program Planning and Evaluation
courses.description: Basic concepts and principles underlying program planning and evaluation in health services.

courses.name: FREN 470B Studies in Modern French Linguistics - MODRN FR LING
courses.corequisites: (FREN 370 may be taken concurrently with the permission of the instructor of FREN 470.)

courses.name: EECE 553 Advanced Power Systems Analysis
courses.description: Computer-oriented analysis of electric power systems with regard to multiphase line constants, steady-state analysis of single and parallel circuits, lightning and switching surges; large-scale solution of power-flow problems; optimal real and reactive power flow.

courses.name: COEC 126 Data: Description, Display, and Inference
courses.description: Use of data and statistics to convey information on important issues of the world economy. Credit will be granted for only one of COEC 126 or COMM 126.

courses.name: EDCP 331 Social Studies - Elementary: Curriculum and Pedagogy
courses.description: Pass/Fail.

courses.name: LARC 504 Landscape Architecture Design Studio IV
PATH 548C Directed Studies - GRAD STUD - DST
POLI 240 Currents of Political Thought
courses.description: A critical introduction to some major ideologies and traditions of Western political thought that examines their philosophical origins as well as their implications for political life.

courses.name: NURS 410F Exploring Avenues of Nursing Practice - EXPL AVE NURS PR
courses.description: A specific avenue is selected from a number of options in consultation with faculty.  For post-RN students only.

courses.name: COMM 286V Topics in Business II - INTR CAPTL MRKTS
THTR 205A Graphics for Theatre and Film Design - GRAPHICS: T&F D
THTR 507 Scenery Design Studio II
courses.description: Complex scenery design for opera, dance, theatre, and other performance forms.

courses.name: PLNT 540 Plant Molecular Biology Laboratory
courses.description: Techniques of purification, cloning, sequencing, restriction-hybridization analysis of plant nucleic acids, in vitro labelling of plant nucleic acids and proteins, and electrophoresis and immunodetection of plant proteins. Offered by the Biotechnology Teaching Laboratory in cooperation with Plant Science. Admissions to the course is limited and requires recommendation from the Program Coordinator.

courses.name: HIST 468A Topics in Comparative Indigenous History  - COMP INDIG HIST
courses.description: Comparative  interdisciplinary analysis of selected topics in Indigenous history in North America and beyong. HIST 302 or other background in the field is recommended.

courses.name: PSYC 440B Directed Studies in Psychology - DIRECTED STUDIES
courses.description: Directed investigation of an experimental problem, requiring a written report of the findings.
courses.prerequisites: (At least 72% average in the preceding 30 credits and permission of a faculty member who is prepared to supervise the investigation.)

courses.name: PHIL 385A Existentialism - EXISTENTIALISM
courses.description: Meaning, identity and alienation as explored in the works for example of Kierkegaard, Dostoyevsky, Tolstoy, Sartre, and Camus.

courses.name: ASTU 412 Co-operative Work Placement V
courses.description: Optional extra work placement. Approved and supervised work experience with a public or private organization for a minimum of 13 weeks full-time. Final work term report.

courses.name: LLED 478C Introduction to Teaching English as a Second Language - INTRO TO TESL
courses.prerequisites: (For TESL Certificate, 6 credits of LLED 489, ENGL 329, LING 420, LING 200, LING 201 taken within the last five years or taken as corequisite with consent of instructor. For B.Ed. TESL, LLED 315.)

courses.name: LARC 570A Co-op Work Placement - COOP WORK PLCMNT
courses.description: A mechanism for students to earn academic credit for relevant work experience outside the university. Open only to M.L.A. students.

courses.name: MUSC 121 History of Music II
courses.description: The development of Western music from circa 1600 to circa 1800.

courses.name: AUDI 545 Issues in Clinical Practice
courses.description: Ethics, service delivery systems, practice considerations specific to the work place.

courses.name: EDUC 421E School-based Extended Practicum: Secondary - EXT PRACT SECD
courses.prerequisites: (Normally all requirements set to precede this practicum.)

courses.name: WOOD 461 Globalization and Sustainability
courses.description: Examination of globalization and its impact on sustainability, including social, economic, and environmental aspects.

courses.name: COMM 100 Introduction to Business
courses.description: An overview of all functional areas of business. Students will be introduced to the computer and internet tools commonly used in business. For non-Commerce students only.

courses.name: LAW 343D Topics in Public Law - TPCS PUBLIC LAW
courses.description: Not offered each year, consult Faculty.

courses.name: PSYT 430 Psychiatry Clinical Clerkship
courses.description: Supervised treatment of adult inpatients and outpatients within a multi-disciplinary team. Assessment and treatment of a child and family as well as seminars on selected topics.

courses.name: LAW 211 Contracts
courses.description: Historical development; formation and enforceability of contracts; parties; contractual terms; changes of circumstances; remedies for breach.

courses.name: CHBE 583 Energy Engineering
courses.description: Supply and use of conventional and alternative fuels and energy. Design and operation of unit operations for processing of fossil fuels, biomass, and other energy sources. Environmental considerations of energy use.

courses.name: INDE 430 Professional Dimensions in Medicine
courses.description: Ethics, jurisprudence, medical office procedures, physician well-being in relation to professional practice of medicine. Introduction to clinical procedures.

courses.name: BIOF 540 Statistical Methods for High Dimensional Biology
COHR 405 Managing the Family Business
courses.description: Managing and working in a family business presents unique challenges: family issues can conflict with business issues. This course examines governance structures and tools to manage the interface between the family and the business.
courses.prerequisites: COMM 292 and one of COMM 203, COMM 392.

courses.name: GEOG 395 Introduction to the Changing Landscapes of Latin America
courses.description: Culture and environment in 1491; Spanish colonialism and biological imperialism; commodity production and exchange; neo-liberalism; and environmental justice movements.

courses.name: EPSE 575 Seminar in Instructional Methods for Persons with Significant Learning Challenges
NURS 580 The Philosophy of Evidence
courses.description: Students not enrolled in the doctoral program require permission of instructor.

courses.name: ECON 319 History and Philosophy of Economics from Ricardo to Keynes
courses.description: The development of economic thought from David Ricardo up to the present including such figures as Malthus, Mill, Jevons, and Keynes, focusing on the conceptual foundations of economics, particularly the problems of value, distribution and growth.

courses.name: FRST 430 Advanced Biometrics
courses.description: Analysis of variance, multiple regression and analysis of covariance. Design and analysis of experiments.

courses.name: UFOR 100 Greening the City
courses.description: Roles played by urban forestry and greenspace systems in a rapidly changing world; topics include urban ecology, urban forest conservation, urban forest management, climate change, society and human well-being, design and planning, urban/rural interface issues, and urban forest policy.

courses.name: GERM 325 German Translation
courses.description: Theory, methodology, and practice of translation from German into English.

courses.name: BMEG 456 Clinical and Industrial Biomedical Engineering
courses.description: Principles of clinical practice, Canadian healthcare system, medical approach to diagnosis, ethics and regulations for clinical trials, medical technology management, medical device development and standards, biostatistics. Restricted to students in EECE and MECH Biomedical Engineering options. Credit will be granted for only one of APSC 456, APSC 556, BMEG 456, or BMEG 556.

courses.name: SCIE 113 First-Year Seminar in Science
courses.description: Small-group experience where students study science in society, scientific process, and how to communicate scientific concepts.  Enrollment limited to students with first-year standing in the B. Sc. program in Science.

courses.name: PHYS 348 Frontiers in Physics and Astronomy
courses.description: Current research topics in physics and astronomy are investigated and explored. Technical communication and research skills are studied and developed via oral presentations and written scientific reports on these current research topics.
courses.prerequisites: (Third-year standing in a physics honours program or fourth-year standing in a physics or astronomy major program.)

courses.name: SPPH 581Q Selected Topics - ADV ECONMIC EVAL
courses.description: By seminar and directed readings, certain topics of current interest are explored in depth.

courses.name: PSYC 534B Clinical Psychology Practicum - CLIN PSYC PRACTM
LAW 401D Penal Policy - PENAL POLICY
courses.description: Selected legal policy issues relating to punishment for crime. Not offered each year, consult Faculty.

courses.name: GEOG 312 Climate Change: Science and Society
courses.description: Climates over the geological, historical and instrument periods. Theories of climatic change. Monitoring and modelling the climate system. Impacts of change on environmental and socio-economic systems.
courses.prerequisites: One of GEOG 102, GEOB 102, GEOG 200, GEOB 200, GEOG 204, GEOB 204, ATSC 201, EOSC 112. (3rd year standing.)

courses.name: MUSC 120 History of Music I
courses.description: An overview of Western music from antiquity through the Middle Ages and Renaissance, providing a framework for understanding musical styles and practices, and examining selected compositions in greater analytical and historical depth.

courses.name: JAPN 315 Japanese for Professional Life II
courses.description: Continuation of JAPN 314.

courses.name: GEOG 426 Historical Geography of British Columbia, I
courses.description: Colonialism, resistance, and land use in early British Columbia.

courses.name: FRST 302 Forest Genetics
courses.description: Population genetics and conservation of genetic resources; principles of genetics and their application to forestry.

courses.name: PSYC 302 Infancy
courses.description: Human cognition, perception, motor, social, emotional needs, brain development and their interactions from birth until the emergence of language.
courses.prerequisites: Either (a) PSYC 100 or (b) all of PSYC 101, PSYC 102. (or (c) 6 credits of 200-level Psychology (but not 205 or 263).)

courses.name: AUDI 540 Approaches to Audiology and Speech-Language Pathology for People of First Nations, M?tis or Inuit Heritage
RMES 500B Resource and Environmental Workshop - DIRECTED STUDIES
courses.description: Faculty and students from different disciplines act as an interdisciplinary team studying specific resource problems with ecological, economic, demographic and social dimensions. Techniques and methods are emphasized to show their value in integrating knowledge, defining policy and facilitating communication. Several sections with different emphasis offered each year.

courses.name: FRST 307 Biotic Disturbances
courses.description: Concepts of disturbance ecology with special reference to insects and diseases in the forests of British Columbia; forest health problems in the biogeoclamatic zones of BC; present management strategies and future potentials in a scenario of climate change.

courses.name: GEOB 507A Directed Studies in Physical Geography - DIR ST PHYS GEOG
EOSC 514 Introduction to Geological Fluid Mechanics
MECH 221 Engineering Science I
courses.description: Rigid body kinetics and kinematics, basic electrical circuits, work and power, stress and strain, torsion, bending, engineering materials, probability and statistics. This course includes the content of ELEC 203.
courses.prerequisites: All of MATH 101, MATH 152, PHYS 170 and either (a) PHYS 153 or (b) all of PHYS 157, PHYS 158, PHYS 159.
courses.corequisites: All of MECH 220, MECH 224 and one of ENGL 112, APSC 176.

courses.name: ETEC 540 Text Technologies: The Changing Spaces of Reading and Writing
MECH 550P Special Advanced Courses - ADV SOLID MECH
courses.description: Special advanced lecture courses may be arranged for graduate students upon the approval of the department head. There will not be more than 6 credits in any one such course.

courses.name: PHAR 460 Natural Health Products in Pharmacy Practice
courses.description: An evidence-based analysis of the efficacy and safety of natural health products used in pharmacy practice.

courses.name: NAME 502 Advanced Ship Hydrodynamics
courses.description: Advanced ship resistance; boundary layers; propeller design; numerical methods in hydrodynamics; advanced marine vehicles; ocean waves; cavitation; ship vibration. Includes a laboratory component involving a wave/towing tank and computational fluid dynamics project.

courses.name: ANTH 312 Introduction to the Anthropology of Gender
courses.description: Theoretical approaches to, and the ethnographic study of, gender in cross-cultural contexts.

courses.name: ENGL 472A American Studies - AMERICAN STUDIES
courses.prerequisites: (3rd year standing and 6 credits of first-year English, or Arts One, or 6 credits of ASTU 100 from CAP or 3 credits of first-year English and 3 credits of ASTU 150)

courses.name: ELEC 474 Biophotonics
courses.description: Lens theory, light sources and detectors, image resolution and contrast, tissue absorption and scattering, fluorescence, microscopy, spectroscopy, optical imaging systems, and their applications to life sciences and medicine.

courses.name: PHIL 378 Philosophical Wisdom of Early India
courses.description: Epistemological and ontological thought from the Vedic Period to the period of the rise of philosophical schools or systems.  Philosophy in the Mahabharata, Gita; early Buddhist and Jain views on knowledge and reality; views on language.

courses.name: EDST 590 Graduating Paper
courses.description: Pass/Fail.

courses.name: RUSS 102 Basic Russian II
courses.description: Continuation of RUSS 101.

courses.name: LLED 352 Introduction to Teaching and Learning French: Elementary
courses.description: Pass/Fail.

courses.name: HIST 105 Contemporary Global Issues in Historical Perspective
courses.description: Places issues and problems of current relevance such as disease, terrorism, drugs, or ethnic conflict in historical perspective. Each section will explore a single theme. Check with department for course offerings.

courses.name: VISA 401D Advanced Open Studio - ADV OPEN STUDIO
courses.description: Research-based studio with thematic or disciplinary focus.  Intended for senior Visual Art undergraduate students.
courses.prerequisites: Three of VISA 310, VISA 311, VISA 320, VISA 321, VISA 330, VISA 331, VISA 340, VISA 341, VISA 350, VISA 351, VISA 360, VISA 361, VISA 370, VISA 390.

courses.name: FREN 102 Beginners' French II
courses.description: Grammar, composition, reading and oral practice.  Not available to students with prerequisite for FREN 111.

courses.name: ELEC 464 Nanotechnology and Nature
courses.description: Examples of nature's fabrication methods, sensors, actuators, energy harvesting, signaling and information processing, and comparisons with artificial methods.

courses.name: FMED 422 Integument
courses.description: A one-week block covering the basic science and common clinical issues of skin, hair, nails, and accessible mucosae. Normal anatomy and physiology, common clinical and pathophysiological changes and dysfunction, and psychosocial relevance of integumentary diseases are the three principal areas explored.

courses.name: BUSI 444 Computer Aided Mass Property Assessment

courses.name: SOCI 350A Sociological Theories: Classical and Contemporary Approaches - SOCI THEORIES
courses.description: An examination of selected traditions, conceptual problems, and current topics in the field of sociological theory.

courses.name: MATH 105 Integral Calculus with Applications to Commerce and Social Sciences
courses.description: Antiderivatives, the definite integral, techniques of integration, infinite series, partial derivatives, maxima and minima with constraints, discrete and continuous random variables. Please consult the Faculty of Science Credit Exclusion List: www.students.ubc.ca/calendar/index.cfm?tree=12,215,410,414.
courses.prerequisites: One of MATH 100, MATH 102, MATH 104, MATH 110, MATH 111, MATH 120, MATH 180, MATH 184.

courses.name: LING 445 Sociolinguistics
courses.description: The systematic study of language as a social phenomenon.

courses.name: HIST 392 Scientific Revolution: Circulation of Knowledge in the Early Modern World
courses.description: The profound transformation of knowledge about the world in the context of the first global encounter of civilizations between 1450 and 1800. Explores the foundations for modern science.

courses.name: MATH 200 Calculus III
courses.description: Analytic geometry in 2 and 3 dimensions, partial and directional derivatives, chain rule, maxima and minima, second derivative test, Lagrange multipliers, multiple integrals with applications. Please consult the Faculty of Science Credit Exclusion List: www.students.ubc.ca/calendar/index.cfm?tree=12,215,410,414.
courses.prerequisites: One of MATH 101, MATH 103, MATH 105, MATH 121, SCIE 001.

courses.name: BA 550 Business Immersion
courses.description: This course is restricted to students in the MM Program.

courses.name: COMM 363 Marketing Analysis
courses.description: Analytical methods applicable to marketing management decision making; attention to strategic considerations linking analysis of consumer data, corporate data, environmental factors, and competitive response. The course makes extensive use of micro computers.

courses.name: MATH 427 Topics in Topology
courses.description: Homology theory, homotopy theory, manifolds, and other topics chosen by the instructor.

courses.name: LFS 400 Audio Storytelling
courses.description: Adopts a journalistic framework to communicate powerful stories and present academic content in new ways through the use of audio technology.

courses.name: CIVL 574 Experimental Soil Mechanics
courses.description: Field and laboratory experimental studies of advanced aspects of soil behaviour; compressibility; shear strength; pore water pressure; dynamic tests; advanced instrumentation and measurement techniques; research reports required.

courses.name: KIN 161 Leisure and Sport in Society
courses.description: Introduction to the political, economic and social basis of leisure and sport; concepts, theories and problems.

courses.name: EDUC 496F Practicum (Secondary) for Previously Certified Teachers - TEACH PRACT SECD
courses.description: Pass/Fail.
courses.prerequisites: (Recent completion of secondary teaching methods courses in the subjects to be taught.)

courses.name: PHRM 170 Community Service Learning I
courses.description: Service learning activities with external community partner sites and members. Pass/Fail.

courses.name: POLI 327 European Integration
courses.description: Post-1945 integration of Europe, comparison of national politics and attitudes to integration, and the history and institutions of the European Union.

courses.name: EOSC 425 Paleontology
courses.description: Paleobiogeography in the context of plate tectonics. Mass extinction events. Fossilization and biases in the fossil record. Species concepts in paleontology. Biostratigraphy. Paleontological evidence for early life; the colonization of oceanic and terrestrial environments and; the evolution of the primates.

courses.name: SOWK 570 Directed Studies in Social Work
FRST 318 Forest and Conservation Economics
courses.description: Practical problem solving of economic issues related to forestry and conservation, touching on investment analysis, capital budgeting, non-timber economics, ecosystem services, and forest certification. Completion of FRST 232 or intermediate knowledge of MS Excel essential.

courses.name: HIST 350 The Soviet Union

courses.name: BUSI 486B Special Topics in Business - INTL LEADERSHIP

courses.name: PHAR 591 Scholarly Integrity and Research Ethics
JAPN 302 Advanced Modern Japanese: Conversation and Composition I

courses.name: BMEG 510 Anatomy and Physiology with Applications to Biomedical Devices
courses.description: Anatomical structures and physiological principles of major body systems.  Functional connections to operation of diagnostic and therapeutic equipment.  Exploration of recent advances. Credit will be given for only one of BMEG 410 or BMEG 510.

courses.name: MECH 592 Machine Tool Structures and Vibrations
courses.description: Review of metal cutting mechanics, milling, static deformations of machine tools. Machine tool vibrations, forced and self excited vibrations in machining, chatter, stability. Sensors for machine tool monitoring and adaptive control. Sensor assisted intelligent machining techniques.

courses.name: JAPN 103 Beginning Japanese II B
courses.description: Continuation of JAPN 102 (Non-intensive).

courses.name: BIOL 364 Animal Physiology
courses.description: Cardiovascular, respiratory, and osmoregulatory physiology. Preference will be given to students who are in Biology, Nutritional Sciences, and Honours Biophysics.
courses.prerequisites: BIOL 204 and one of BIOL 260, BIOL 361.

courses.name: COMM 291 Application of Statistics in Business
courses.description: Methods and applications of statistics in business; data analysis, descriptive regression; data generation; sampling distributions; hypothesis testing; confidence intervals; two sample problems; inference in regression.

courses.name: SOWK 570M Directed Studies in Social Work - DIRECTED STUDY
ECON 495 Honours Seminar
courses.description: Reports and group discussions of selected topics for fourth-year Honours students.

courses.name: EPSE 576 Assessment and Positive Behaviour Support in School and Community Settings
PSYC 594 Psychoneuroendocrinology
courses.description: Not offered each year; consult Department of Psychology.

courses.name: HGSE 354 Diversifying Resource-Dependent Communities
courses.description: Examination of the forces that restructure local economies, both historically and contemporarily; link between rural economic development and the legacy of resource development in Aboriginal communities across British Columbia.  A core element of the Haida Gwaii Semester.

courses.name: CPEN 400A Topics in Computer Engineering - BLDG MDRN WEBAPP
courses.description: Lectures or projects on subjects of current interest.

courses.name: COGS 300 Understanding and Designing Cognitive Systems
courses.description: Theory and methods for integrating diverse disciplinary content in cognitive systems.

courses.name: SOCI 514 Analyzing Quantitative Data in Sociology
courses.prerequisites: (SOCI 502 is a prerequisite for Sociology graduate students. A background in material such as that covered in SOCI 502 is highly recommended for all others.)

courses.name: ANAT 511 Fundamentals of Body Design: Basic Principles in Human Anatomy as Illustrated by the Organization of the Back and Upper Limb

courses.description: Introduction to methodologies and evidence concerning the structure and operation of security markets and the valuation of financial securities including stocks, bonds, options and futures contracts; portfolio management, corporate finance and investment decisions.

courses.name: PHIL 551A Philosophy of Mind - PHIL OF MIND

courses.description: Modern bioreactor technology, upstream and downstream processing of biotechnology products. Credit will not be given for both CHBE 564 and MICB 419.

courses.name: VANT 148 UBC Vantage College Projects
courses.description: Projects linked to topics explored in the UBC Vantage College International Program curricula.

courses.name: EPSE 406 Typical and Atypical Development in Infants and Children

courses.description: The construction of gender ideologies and gendered and sexual identities, including masculine, feminine, and transgendered, in modern Latin America.

courses.name: CHEM 535A Topics in Analytical Chemistry - TPCS ANALYT CHEM

courses.name: LATN 501C Latin Prose - LATIN PROSE

courses.name: MTRL 592E Advanced Topics in Materials Engineering - ADVANCED TOPICS
courses.description: May be arranged on approval of the department head.

courses.name: DENT 592 Endodontic Case Management II
courses.description: Modern endodontic technology and clinical endodontics. Lectures, seminars, and simulation training.

courses.name: PATH 304 Normal Human Histology

courses.name: THTR 408A Advanced Study in Design and Scenography - ADV STDY DSGN

courses.name: SPAN 207 Conversational Spanish II

courses.name: PHAR 461 Non-Prescription Drugs and Self-Care of the Patient III

courses.name: PSYC 440E Directed Studies in Psychology - DIRECTED STUDIES
courses.description: Directed investigation of an experimental problem, requiring a written report of the findings.

courses.name: ENDS 401 Environmental Design Studio III

courses.prerequisites: One of EECE 210, CPEN 221, EECE 309, EECE 310, CPEN 321, CPSC 210, CPSC 310.

courses.name: MUSC 593D Music Performance (Major) - WIND,BRASS&PERC
courses.description: Private instruction, vocal or instrumental. May be repeated for credit, in accordance with program requirements.

courses.name: MUSC 694D Music Performance (Major) - WIND,BRASS&PERC
courses.description: Private instruction, vocal or instrumental.

courses.name: EOSC 510 Data Analysis in Atmospheric, Earth and Ocean Sciences

courses.description: Pass/Fail.

courses.name: ASTU 400R Interdisciplinary Studies in Arts - WRITTEN AND ORAL

courses.name: CHBE 365 Biological Engineering  Laboratory

courses.name: LAW 305 Law, Society and State

courses.name: CHIN 217 Intermediate Chinese II: Part 2 (Heritage)

courses.name: HGSE 351 History and Politics of Resource Management

courses.name: EDST 540A Locating Oneself in Global Learning - GLOB LEARN

MUSC 156B Vocal Chamber Ensembles - MEN'S CHOIR

courses.name: DENT 565 Biomechanics of Craniofacial Orthopedics and Orthodontics I
courses.description: Continues in second year.

courses.name: MECH 575J Directed Studies in Mechanical Engineering - SINUSDAL TRJCTRY
MUSC 695D Music Performance (Major) - WIND,BRASS&PERC
courses.description: Private instruction, vocal or instrumental.

courses.name: FRST 508 Forest Insect Ecology

courses.description: Management responsibilities in quantity food production with emphasis on menu planning, purchasing and service. Includes planning and equipping food services. courses.name: ASIA 499 Honours Thesis
courses.description: Restricted to fourth-year students admitted to the Honours Program in Asian Studies.

courses.name: BIOC 501A Advanced Biochemistry Laboratory - ADV BIOC LAB
courses.description: Practical applications of advanced biochemical techniques. Admission is limited and is by permission of the department head.

courses.name: PHAR 498 Cases in Pharmaceutical Sciences III

courses.name: SOWK 310 Interviewing Skills

courses.name: CHIN 103 Basic Chinese I: Part 2 (Non-Heritage)

courses.name: BIOF 520 Problem-Based Learning In Bioinformatics
courses.description: Develops the student's ability to exchange ideas in small groups focused on real but simplified problems in bioinformatics. Problems are carefully selected to cover all aspects of Bioinformatics research.  Required of students in the Bioinformatics graduate program.  Students not registered in the Bioinformatics graduate program must get permission to register in this course.

courses.name: FIPR 339 Post-Production Techniques I
courses.description: Open only to students in the Film Production BFA Program.

courses.name: FMED 421 Blood and Lymphatics
courses.description: Blood and lymphatic system; anatomy, physiology and relevant biochemistry; normal and disordered function; pharmacological and other therapeutic and preventative modalities.

courses.name: ECED 401 Supporting Young Children's Health and Well-Being in Early Childhood Settings
EDUC 495H Practicum (Elementary) for Previously Certified Teachers - TEACH PRACT ELEM
courses.description: Pass/Fail.
courses.prerequisites: (Completion of recent elementary teaching methods courses in the subjects to be taught.)

courses.name: MECH 552 Electro-Mechanical System Design Project II
courses.description: The full assembly, instrumentation, computer and electronic interfacing, and testing of a dynamic machine.

courses.name: PSYC 363 Principles of Animal Learning
courses.description: Introduction to basic theories of non-associative learning, classical and operant conditioning. Experimental findings from behavioural and biological analyses with animals and humans.

courses.name: CPEN 331 Operating Systems
courses.description: Operating systems, their design and their implementation. Process concurrency, synchronization, communication and scheduling. Device drivers, memory management, virtual memory, file systems, networking and security.
courses.prerequisites: CPSC 261 and one of EECE 210, CPEN 221, EECE 309.

courses.name: EPSE 411 Augmentative and Alternative Communication for Individuals with Severe Speech and/or Physical Impairments
ENDS 281 Architecture in Context and Across Cultures: A History
courses.description: A world survey of architecture, from prehistory to postmodernity, which relates architecture to landscape and city, design principles and cultural values, formal and vernacular practices. It explores the different ways in which history has been conveyed and the purposes it serves.

courses.name: THTR 299B Production I - PRODUCTION I
courses.description: Assigned projects in theatre production.

courses.name: ECON 456 International Macroeconomics and Finance
courses.description: Balance of payments; market for foreign exchange; mechanism for adjusting the balance of payments; internal vs. external stability; current problems and issues.

courses.name: BIOC 304 Contemporary Biochemical Research
courses.description: Exploration of the breadth and importance of biochemical research to present day challenges in medicine and biotechnology. Detailed experimental research case studies of novel biochemical methods used to address pressing and ongoing biochemical issues.

courses.name: RSOT 513 Health, Illness and Occupation I
PHAR 533A Clinical Clerkships I - CLIN CLERKSHP I
courses.description: Required clinical rotations of four weeks' duration in selected specialty areas in medicine and clinical pharmacy.

courses.name: EDCP 354 Biological Sciences - Secondary: Curriculum and Pedagogy
courses.description: Pass/Fail.
courses.prerequisites: (A completed concentration in biological sciences or permission of the Head.)

courses.name: CNPS 688 Supervision of Counselling Practice
courses.description: Supervision requires both knowledge of supervision models and practices, and skills to implement them. This course involves a seminar and practicum to integrate the two requirements of the subject. (For those on the Doctoral program.) Pass/Fail.

courses.name: SCAN 335 Vikings and Norse Mythology (in English)
courses.description: History, literature, and mythology of early Scandinavian societies.

courses.name: ANTH 433A Directed Studies - DIRECTED STUDIES
courses.description: General reading and/or a research undertaking, with the agreement, and under the supervision, of a Department faculty member selected by the student. No more than six credits of Directed Studies may be taken for credit toward the Major or Honours program.

courses.name: ASTU 400W Interdisciplinary Studies in Arts - COG NEURO
courses.description: For upper-division students in the Faculty of Arts. Topics announced annually.

courses.name: BIOL 317 Weed Science
courses.description: Importance, identification, dissemination and biology of weeds; preventative, cultural, biological and chemical methods of control.

courses.name: EDUC 451A Inquiry Seminar II - INQUIRY SEMNR 2
courses.description: Pass/Fail.

courses.name: CRWR 506A Advanced Writing of Drama for Screen I - ADV DRAM SCRN I
IAR 515F Topics in Asia Pacific Policy Studies - CO TREATY HUM RT
EPSE 502 Cognition, Language and Literacy Processes in Education
JAPN 101 Beginning Japanese I
courses.description: Continuation of JAPN 100 (Non-intensive). Not available for credit to students with JAPN 12.

courses.name: WOOD 244 Quantitative Methods in the Wood Industry
courses.description: Solving practical problems in the wood industry using computer-based mathematical tools including spreadsheets, visual basic programming and relational database systems.
courses.prerequisites: One of MATH 101, MATH 103, MATH 105, MATH 121.

courses.name: FNEL 202 Intermediate Salish Language II
courses.description: Continued focus on the diverse range of language learning skills that advance competency in conversational fluency, pronunciation, comprehension, vocabulary, oral traditions, literacy, grammatical understanding, and the cultural contextualization of language use.

courses.name: ASTU 202 Canada, Japan and the Pacific: Political, Economic and Geographical Perspectives
courses.description: An interdisciplinary introduction to political, economic and geographical interactions between Japan and Canada, the links between these countries and other Pacific Rim nations, and the historical origins of these connections. Specific topics will vary from year to year, but will include themes such as economic integration in the Pacific region; the role of resource economies such as Canada's; security relations in the Pacific; the role of Japanese investment in the Asia-Pacific region.

courses.name: CHEM 311 Instrumental Analytical Chemistry
courses.description: Theory, design, and application of instrumental methods of chemical analysis including spectroscopy, mass spectrometry, electroanalysis, and chemical separations..

courses.name: PHAR 457 Pharmaceutical Care in Aboriginal Health
courses.description: Aboriginal health in Canada and the role a culturally-competent pharmacist can have in collaborating with other health professionals and Aboriginal communities in providing care and healing.

courses.name: DENT 577B Advanced Topics in Restorative Therapy - ADV TPCS RST DNT
MTRL 358 Hydrometallurgy I
courses.description: Aqueous extraction of metals from ores and concentrates.

courses.name: POLI 464C Problems in International Relations - PROB INTRL RELTN
courses.description: Content varies from year to year. Consult the departmental website. One section (of 3 credits) is reserved for fourth-year students in the Major program in International Relations.

courses.name: COMM 474 Fixed Income Markets and Management
courses.description: Fixed income instruments and derivatives. Risk profiles and their use in establishing fixed income investment portfolios. Performance attribution techniques.

courses.name: ARCH 544S Seminar in Architecture - URB DSG CSE STDY
courses.description: An exploration of selected topics in architecture. Enrolment is limited to facilitate discussion.

courses.name: FIPR 436B Documentary Development and Production - DOCMNTY DEV&PROD
courses.description: Documentary concept development, essential production techniques, and marketing.

courses.name: NURS 338 Relational Nursing Practice Across Diverse Health Experiences
courses.description: Exploration and analysis of opportunities and challenges of relational practice across multiple diverse health experiences and sites of health care.
courses.prerequisites: All of NURS 302, NURS 303, NURS 304, NURS 305, NURS 306.

courses.name: BAEN 502 Growing and Exiting a Venture
MUSC 165C World Music Ensembles - KOREAN DRUMMING
courses.description: Training on traditional instruments and their techniques, with emphasis on ensemble performance. Different sections focus on the music of different cultures, e.g., Bali, China, Ghana, Korea. May be repeated for credit in accordance with program requirements for B.Mus. or B.A. in Music, or when permitted in other programs.

courses.name: ORPA 719 Orthopaedic Surgical Anatomy
courses.description: A course in clinical anatomy as applied to orthopaedics. A regional approach involving surgical dissections in cadavers. Each session lasts two hours. Emphasis is on surgical anatomical approach.

courses.name: ENGL 311 History and Theory of Rhetoric: The Later Theory
courses.description: Rhetorical theory from Augustine to the 21st century, emphasizing questions of persuasion in everyday life.

courses.name: PATH 635 Seminar
courses.description: Attendance required for all Ph.D. candidates in the department.

courses.name: IGEN 430 Advanced Engineering Design Projects
courses.description: Projects involving all material in the curriculum of the Integrated Engineering Program. Students will be expected to propose a project and complete the design and construction of a prototype. Restricted to students in the fourth year of the Integrated Engineering program.

courses.name: EPSE 590 Graduating Paper/Seminar
courses.description: Pass/Fail.

courses.name: SPPH 537 Perinatal Epidemiology
courses.description: Indicators of maternal/newborn well-being across population subgroups, changing trends in obstetrical intervention, perinatal morbidity, and the analysis of perinatal data.

courses.name: CIVL 430 Design of Concrete Structures
courses.description: Non-linear response of reinforced concrete members subjected to axial load, bending and shear; design of simple one-way members including beams, columns, slabs and footings.

courses.name: MECH 306 Data Analysis and Mechatronics Laboratories
courses.description: The use of probability and statistical methods for engineering applications. Mechanics of materials and heat transfer. Instrumentation, data acquisition, and data manipulation using modern computational tools. Common mechanical devices. For students in the Mechatronics Option only.
courses.prerequisites: All of MECH 220, MECH 223, MECH 224, MECH 225.

courses.name: ECON 307 Honours Intermediate Macroeconomics II
courses.description: Theories of economic growth and the business cycle. Intended primarily for prospective honours and other qualified students.
courses.prerequisites: A score of 68% or higher in ECON 305. (Or permission of the School.)

courses.name: PHIL 316 Philosophy After 1800
courses.description: Survey of 19th and 20th century philosophy. May include Hegel, Schopenhauer, Nietzsche, Mill, Meinong, Brentano, the British Idealists, Russell, and Moore. Social and political currents in 19th century philosophical thought.

courses.name: FRE 585 Quantitative Methods for Business and Natural Resource Management
INDE 440 Senior Clerkship
courses.description: A senior clinical elective for fourth-year students. Students will participate in all relevant clinical and academic activities associated with the particular rotation.

courses.name: SOWK 453 Disability and Justice
courses.description: This Interprofessional Health and Human Service (IHHS) course considers how health and human service professionals can effectively practice with people with disabilities from a social justice perspective. Social and personal context and practice responses are examined. Offered as IHHS 407 prior to September 2015. Credit will be granted for only one of SOWK 453 or IHHS 407.

courses.name: WOOD 356 Machine Components
courses.description: Machines used for wood products manufacturing, design, maintenance, purchasing. Selection of components including drives, bearings, brakes, clutches, fasteners, springs.

courses.name: BIOL 449 Directed Biological Research
courses.description: A course designed to allow students to undertake a research project in selected fields. Open only to Honours students in Biology, with permission of the supervisor. Presentation of a thesis and an oral examination are required.

courses.name: MATH 550 Methods of Asymptotic Analysis
courses.prerequisites: (Applied complex analysis (MATH 301 or equivalent) and ordinary and partial differential equations (MATH 400 or equivalent).)

courses.name: ARTH 432 Seminar in the Art of the Middle Ages
MUSC 157A Early Music Ensemble - EARLY MUSIC ENS
courses.description: Performance of early Western instrumental and vocal ensemble music. May be repeated for credit in accordance with program requirements for B.Mus. or B.A. in Music. Open to other students by audition, with credit, as stipulated by their faculties.

courses.name: CHIN 307 Advanced Chinese Speaking and Writing II (Non-Heritage)
courses.description: Continuation of CHIN 305. Can be taken concurrently with CHIN 303.

courses.name: LLED 557 Family Literacy: Issues and Perspectives
MUSC 339C Opera Workshop I - OPERA WORKSHOP 1
courses.description: Participation in performances by the School. Open also to students outside Music without credit, after audition.

courses.name: RMES 517 Agricultural Watershed Management
courses.description: Intensive and extensive agriculture with a focus on water needs, water use and impacts on water resources.  Non-point sources of pollution, nutrient modeling, soil and land degradation, protection and rehabilitation of watersheds including buffer zones, wetlands, and best management practices.  Credit will be granted for only one of SOIL 520 or RMES 517.

courses.name: CIVL 447 Environmental Engineering Design and Analysis
courses.description: Integration and application of previously acquired knowledge and skills to find design solutions.  Extends the conceptual design of CIVL 445 into detailed environmental design projects.

courses.name: PSYC 404 Psychology of Religion
courses.description: Cognitive, emotional, and motivational underpinnings of religious behaviour; supernatural beliefs, magical thinking, ritual, sacrifice; religion's role in morality, prosociality, health, violence, and intergroup relations.
courses.prerequisites: Either (a) all of PSYC 217, PSYC 218 or (b) PSYC 366 and one of PSYC 307, PSYC 308.

courses.name: FIST 210 Early Cinema
courses.description: Aesthetics, economics, history, and technological characteristics of international early film.

courses.name: FMED 428 Nutrition, Growth and Development
courses.description: Physiology of growth, neurodevelopmental maturation, antenatal testing, neonatal physiology, child behaviour, cognitive and pubertal development, principles of nutrition, the role of nutrition in growth, development, and disease.

courses.name: RELG 305 Prophecy and Kingship in Ancient Israel
courses.description: An examination of Israelite prophecy and prophetic writings in their historical context.

courses.name: COMM 381 Co-operative Work Placement II
courses.description: Approved and supervised work experience for a minimum of 3.5 months. Normally taken during the summer term of the third year. Technical report required. Restricted to students admitted to the Co-operative Education Program in Commerce.

courses.name: DENT 776A Interdisciplinary Care in Orthodontics and Dentofacial Orthopedics III - INTD ORTH&DN III
ANAT 514 Functional Human Anatomy of the Urogenital Systems: Pelvis and Perineum

courses.description: Introduction to the law of contracts, with particular reference to contracts for sale of goods and related law of personal property; principles of agency, partnerships and company law.

courses.name: FRST 562 Directed Study in International Forestry
courses.description: Contemporary and emerging issues in international forestry.

courses.name: MINE 541 Environmental Technologies and Issues in Mining
courses.description: Advanced topics related to mining environment selected in consultation with the instructor. Credit will be granted for only one of MINE 541 or MINE 581.

courses.name: ECON 356 Introduction to International Finance
courses.description: Exchange rate policy regimes; international financial organizations; the interaction between monetary policy and exchange rate regimes; financial crises.

courses.name: GEOB 103 Our Changing Environment: Water and Landscapes
courses.description: Physical processes acting at the Earth's surface; water cycle; landforms; human impacts. Please consult the Faculty of Science Credit Exclusion Lists: www.students.ubc.ca/calendar/index.cfm?tree=12,215,410,414.

courses.name: PHIL 338A Philosophy of Law - PHIL OF LAW
courses.description: Concepts of law, constitution and sovereignty; law and morality; natural law theories and legal positivism; obligation, responsibility, and punishment.

courses.name: EDST 401 Education, School, and Social Institutions
courses.description: Pass/Fail.

courses.name: HIST 310 The British Empire to 1850
courses.description: Rise of the British imperial system within a global context from its beginnings to 1850. Focuses on economic and social themes with emphasis on settlements in the southern hemisphere as well as the West Indies.

courses.name: SOWK 305 Social Work Practice I
courses.description: An examination of the foundation, knowledge and competencies underlying generalist social work practice. Enrolment is limited to students in the B.S.W. program.

courses.name: CHIN 313 Advanced Chinese Reading and Writing II (Heritage)
courses.description: Continuation of CHIN 311. Can be taken concurrently with CHIN 317, CHIN 323.

courses.name: MUSC 165E World Music Ensembles - KOREAN DRUMMING
courses.description: Training on traditional instruments and their techniques, with emphasis on ensemble performance. Different sections focus on the music of different cultures, e.g., Bali, China, Ghana, Korea. May be repeated for credit in accordance with program requirements for B.Mus. or B.A. in Music, or when permitted in other programs.

courses.name: MATH 227 Advanced Calculus II
courses.description: Parametrization of curves and surfaces; line and surface integrals; theorems of Green, Gauss, Stokes; applications to physics and/or introduction to differential forms. Please consult the Faculty of Science Credit Exclusion List: www.students.ubc.ca/calendar/index.cfm?tree=12,215,410,414.
courses.prerequisites: A score of 68% or higher in MATH 226.

courses.name: KIN 361 Introduction to Athletic Training
courses.description: Recognition, prevention, and first aid treatment of common sports injuries. Laboratory sessions emphasize principles and techniques of basic protective taping and strapping.

courses.name: EOSC 333 Elemental and Isotopic Geochemistry
courses.description: Analytical methods in geochemistry, major and trace element geochemistry, radiogenic isotopes, geochemistry of seawater, the mantle, basalts, subduction zones, sedimentary rocks, continental crust.

courses.name: PCTH 448E Directed Studies in Pharmacology - DST PHARMACOLOGY
courses.description: Advanced investigation of a specific topic in Pharmacology.

courses.name: ARTH 363 Art in Japan: The Problem with Painting
courses.description: Key debates in the history of painting and its institutionalization.

courses.name: CHBE 494 Thesis-Environmental Topic
courses.description: Environmental engineering research topic.

courses.name: NURS 343 Leadership, Ethics, and Policy in Nursing Practice
courses.description: Critical analysis of the enactment of nursing leadership, ethics, and policy in practice.
courses.prerequisites: All of NURS 302, NURS 303, NURS 304, NURS 305, NURS 306, NURS 340.

courses.name: POLI 445A Critical Theory: Policitical Theory and the Problems of Race - POLI THRY & RACE
courses.description: Traditions of critical social theory, broadly construed, to examine the modern politics of 'race,' racism, and racialized identities.

courses.name: CHIN 484 Intensive Modern Chinese Literature (Heritage)
courses.description: A combination of CHIN 481 and 483. Selected readings from the May Fourth Era to the present. Not to be taken concurrently with any CHIN courses lower than 400-level. Credit will be granted for only one of CHIN 381, 383, 384 or 484.
courses.prerequisites: One of CHIN 313, CHIN 314, CHIN 317, CHIN 318, CHIN 323.

courses.name: CIVL 340 Transportation Engineering I
courses.description: The analysis and design of the elements of transportation facilities in development of transport technology; vehicle motion; vehicle/pavement interaction; elements of road design; principles of queuing and roadway capacity; rail transit performance and capacity analysis; economics as applied to transport.

courses.name: BIOL 205 Comparative Invertebrate Zoology
courses.description: An introduction to the unity, diversity and evolutionary history of invertebrates.
courses.prerequisites: Either (a) all of BIOL 121, BIOL 140 or (b) all of SCIE 001, BIOL 140. (Or (c) 8 transfer credits of first-year biology.)

courses.name: STS 501 Proseminar in Science and Technology Studies
courses.description: Classic work in the history, philosophy, rhetoric, and sociology of science, and the development of a unified science and technology studies.  Required for all students in the STS Program.  This course is co-taught.
courses.prerequisites: (Enrolment in STS Program or permssion of the STS Advisory Committee.)

courses.name: FRST 413 Ecological Plant Biochemistry.
courses.description: The structure, biosynthesis, distribution and biological function of secondary plant metabolites.
courses.prerequisites: Either (a) all of BIOL 200, BIOL 201 and one of BIOL 209, BIOL 210;  or (b) all of FRST 200, FRST 210.

courses.name: MUSC 556 Vocal Chamber Ensemble
courses.description: Open only to graduate students.

courses.name: BIOL 363 Laboratory in Animal Physiology
courses.description: Experimental studies in animal physiology. Restricted to Majors and Honours students in Biology, Nutritional Sciences and Biophysics.

courses.name: PHAR 502 Advanced Concepts in Pharmacokinetics
courses.description: Models of linear and dose-dependent systems in pharmacokinetics including sustained release, volumes of distribution, drug clearance, metabolite kinetics, multiple dosing and computer modelling.

courses.name: ELEC 205 Electronics Laboratory
courses.description: Experiments involving electronic devices and circuits.

courses.name: EDCP 699 Doctoral Dissertation
courses.description: Pass/Fail.

courses.name: PSYC 331 Forensic Psychology
courses.description: The application of psychological theory and research to legal issues and the criminal justice system. Credit will not be granted for both PSYC 331 and PSYC 430.
courses.prerequisites: Either (a) PSYC 100 or (b) all of PSYC 101, PSYC 102. (or (c) 6 credits of 200-level psychology (but not PSYC 205 or 263).)

courses.name: COEC 298 Introduction to Finance
courses.description: Basic principles of financial valuation, including the time-value of money and the risk/return tradeoff. Develops tools for the quantitative analysis of corporate and/or individual financing and saving decisions, and of capital budgeting decisions. Credit will be granted for only one of COEC 293 or COMM 298.

courses.name: LAW 564 Taxation of Trusts and Estates
courses.description: Not offered each year, consult Faculty.  Credit will be granted for only one of LAW 412 or LAW 564.
courses.prerequisites: One of LAW  220, LAW  407, LAW  506, LAW  561.

courses.name: COMM 386D Topics in Business III - INNOVATN LDRSHP
MATH 422 Fields and Galois Theory
courses.description: Field extensions, the Galois correspondence, finite fields, insolvability in radicals, ruler and compass constructions, additional topics chosen by instructor.

courses.name: MEDG 521 Molecular and Cell Biology of Cancer
courses.description: Focuses on molecular and cell biology of cancer through a series of lectures, reviews, student presentations and discussion.

courses.name: LLED 590 Graduating Paper
courses.description: Pass/Fail.

courses.name: CONS 486 Fish Conservation and Management
courses.description: Principles of fish biology, population and community ecology necessary to understand conservation and management; overview of current issues, tactics and institutions involved with fisheries conservation and management.

courses.name: FRST 532C Directed Studies in Forest Management - DIR STDY FOR MGM
PHYS 571 Physical Cosmology
courses.description: Credit will not be given for both ASTR 403 and PHYS 571.

courses.name: POLI 464A Problems in International Relations - PROB INTRL RELTN
courses.description: Content varies from year to year. Consult the departmental website. One section (of 3 credits) is reserved for fourth-year students in the Major program in International Relations.

courses.name: ISCI 398 Co-operative Work Placement I
courses.description: Industrial or academic work experience for a minimum of 4 months. Normally taken in Winter Session of third year or Summer Session after third year. Technical report required. Restricted to students in the ISP Co-op program.

courses.name: SANS 100 Introductory Sanskrit I
courses.description: Basic vocabulary and most important grammatical features of classical Sanskrit. Useful to students of South Asian history, culture, languages, philosophies, and religions, and of linguistics and classics. Credit will be granted for only one of SANS 100 or SANS 102.

courses.name: NEST 318 Egyptomania
courses.description: The adaptation and appropriation of ancient Egypt in ancient and modern art, architecture, film, and music; the development of Egyptology since the 19th century.

courses.name: PSYC 348C Directed Studies in Biopsychology - DIR STUD BIOPSYC
courses.description: Directed investigation of an experimental problem requiring a written report of the findings.
courses.prerequisites: (At least 72% average in the preceding 30 credits and permission of a faculty member who is prepared to supervise the investigation.)

courses.name: MUSC 591B Music Performance (Major) - VOICE
courses.description: Private instruction, vocal or instrumental.

courses.name: MATH 418 Probability
courses.description: Probability spaces, random variables, distributions, expectation, conditional probabilities, convergence of random variables, generating and characteristic functions, weak and strong laws of large numbers, central limit theorem.
courses.prerequisites: A score of 68% or higher in MATH 321.

courses.name: LAW 359 Family Law
courses.description: The law relating to family relationships, including the law of marriage, divorce, maintenance, custody, matrimonial property, and related matters. Credit will be granted for only one of LAW 240 or LAW 359.

courses.name: FMED 426 Brain and Behaviour
courses.description: Structure and functional interrelationship within the central nervous system; normal and abnormal functions.

courses.name: COMM 101 Business Fundamentals
courses.description: The different disciplines of business and their combination in management planning and decision-making.

courses.name: PHIL 330A Social and Political Philosophy - SOC POLI PHIL
courses.description: Theories of political and legal obligation and authority, legal reasoning, society and the state. Readings in classic and contemporary texts.

courses.name: CHBE 495 Thesis Proposal-Biotechnology Topic
courses.description: Literature search, planning, equipment design for an individual research project leading to a written proposal and oral presentation. Topic to be chosen from a selection of biotechnology topics offered by the department.

courses.name: SOCI 599A Special Topics Seminar - SPEC TOPICS SEM
ORNT 400 Orientation to Medical School and Profession
courses.description: A general introduction to the medical school including beliefs and values embedded within the curriculum. The overall curricular design and expectations regarding evaluation are discussed.

courses.name: EOSC 520 Advanced Mineralogy
courses.description: Crystal structure, chemistry, origin and paragenesis of major rock-forming and ore minerals.

courses.name: CHEM 300 Communicating Chemistry
courses.description: Effective argumentation and communication skills in chemistry. Only open to students in a Chemistry specialization.

courses.name: ELEC 412 Optical Waveguides and Photonics
courses.description: Planar dielectric waveguides; single mode optical fibers; integrated optics waveguides and devices; semiconductor lasers; optical detectors; optical communications links.

courses.name: ASIA 309 South Asian Beyond South Asia
courses.description: A history of South Asian peoples and communities that emigrated overseas, including Indo-Canadians.

courses.name: LING 431 Field Methods I
courses.description: Elicitation, transcription, organization, and analysis of linguistic data from a native speaker of a language not commonly studied. Practical experience in the use of fieldwork equipment.

courses.name: THTR 448B Directed Studies in Theatre Theory and Practice - DIR ST THTR THRY
ATSC 201 Meteorology of Storms
courses.description: Characteristics and physical processes of thunderstorms, tornadoes, lightning, hail, hurricanes, blizzards, cyclones and other storms.

courses.name: POLI 540A Core Seminar in Political Theory - CORE SM POL THRY
MUSC 310 Orchestration
courses.description: The study of orchestration through the analysis of orchestral works, listening and scoring projects. Activities also include choral arranging and scoring for stage band and wind ensemble.

courses.name: KIN 261 Health Policy and Society
courses.description: Health policy and the social context in relation to active health.

courses.name: PSYC 340E Directed Studies in Psychology - DIRECTED STUDIES
courses.description: Directed investigation of a problem, requiring a written report of the findings.
courses.prerequisites: (At least 72% average in the preceding 30 credits and permission of a faculty member who is prepared to supervise the investigation.)

courses.name: COMM 449 Supply-Chain Management
courses.description: Integrated management of production and logistics systems; management of inter-organizational  relationships in the supply chain, including vendor selection, bidding and negotiation processes, partnering and performance measurement.

courses.name: ECON 221 Introduction to Strategic Thinking
courses.description: An introduction to how people interact in strategic situations drawn from political science, history, psychology, law, biology, military history, economics, business, and anthropology. The focus will be on developing intuition.  May not be taken for credit by students with fourth-year standing. Credit will be granted for only one of ECON 221 or ISCI 344.

courses.name: MECH 392 Manufacturing Processes
courses.description: Manufacturing characteristics of materials and their control. Metal forming processes, plastic deformations, rolling, forging, drawing, extrusion, sheet metal forming. Machining processes and machine tools, turning, milling, drilling, grinding. Metal fabrication, welding and casting. An introduction to process planning.

courses.name: LAW 565 International Taxation
courses.description: The tax aspects of international transactions. Credit will be granted for only one of LAW 410 or LAW 565.
courses.prerequisites: One of LAW  220, LAW  407, LAW  506, LAW  561.

courses.name: KIN 454A Field Experience - FIELD EXPERIENCE
courses.description: Students have the opportunity to develop their leadership, instruction, and professional skills in a variety of supervised fieldwork settings. Students should select the section of the course (A, B) most relevant to their program of study and career goals.

courses.name: PHIL 364 Darwin, Evolution, and Modern History
courses.description: Darwin and the science of evolution in nineteenth and early twentieth century.

courses.name: ZOOL 500D Directed Studies in Zoology - DST IN ZOOLOGY
PHYS 560 Physics and Engineering of Particle Accelerators
courses.description: Injectors, radio frequency acceleration, superconducting acceleration elements, beam dynamics, and applications of electron accelerators.

courses.name: EDUC 496E Practicum (Secondary) for Previously Certified Teachers - TEACH PRACT SECD
courses.description: Pass/Fail.
courses.prerequisites: (Recent completion of secondary teaching methods courses in the subjects to be taught.)

courses.name: CIVL 508 Dynamics of Structures II
courses.description: Dynamic response of discrete and continuous systems; structural property matrices and eigenvalue problem; introduction to random vibrations; wave propagation analysis; experimental techniques and computer modelling.

courses.name: PHYS 520A Teaching Techniques in Physics and Astronomy - TEACH PHYS&ASTR
courses.description: Foundations of physics and astronomy education research, lesson plans, development of grading, effective questioning, effective presentations, methods in peer evaluation, and peer teaching.

courses.name: STAT 443 Time Series and Forecasting
courses.description: Trend and seasonality, autocorrelation, stationarity, stochastic models, exponential smoothing, Holt-Winters methods, Box-Jenkins approach, frequency domain analysis.
courses.prerequisites: One of MATH 302, MATH 318, STAT 302 and one of STAT 200, ECON 325.

courses.name: AUDI 547C Directed Reading in Audiology and Speech Sciences - DIR READ AUDI&SP
courses.description: May be taken more than once.

courses.name: JAPN 212 Intermediate Japanese II A
courses.corequisites: (JAPN 212 and JAPN 213 normally taken in the same year.)

courses.name: EDCP 467A Special Topics in Curriculum and Pedagogy - SP TPCS C&P
ECON 565 Market Structure and Business Behaviour
FRST 248 Co-operative Work Placement.
courses.description: Supervised work experience in an approved organization for a minimum of 15 weeks. Restricted to students in the Co-operative Education Program in the Faculty of Forestry. Orientation workshops required. Final work term report required.

courses.name: EOSC 420 Volcanology
courses.description: Field and lab-based studies in volcanology concentrating on physical and chemical aspects of volcanic processes.

courses.name: PHYS 102 Electricity, Light and Radiation
courses.description: Introduction to optics, electricity and magnetism, electric circuits, radioactivity, including biological applications. Please consult the Faculty of Science credit exclusion list: http://www.calendar.ubc.ca/vancouver/index.cfm?tree=12,215,410,414
courses.corequisites: One of MATH 101, MATH 103, MATH 105, MATH 121.

courses.name: MTRL 571 Advanced Nanofibre Technology
courses.description: Processing and properties of nanomaterials in the context of fibrous and composite materials. Credit will only be given for one of MTRL 471, 571.

courses.name: FNIS 320 Methods Seminar
courses.description: Responsible and community-based research from a critical Indigenous perspective; methods for identifying and assessing research materials, critical analysis, oral history/qualitative research interviewing and analysis, and research ethics in the design and implementation of community-based student research projects. Credit will be granted for only one of FNIS 320 or FNSP 320.

courses.name: MRNE 480 Seminars and Papers in Marine Science
courses.description: Instruction in the critical analysis of published research papers and of oral seminars.
courses.prerequisites: (Completion of second year in a biology program.)

courses.name: ECON 337 Economic History of the United States
courses.description: The growth of the United States from the Colonial Era to the present: British colonialism, development of slave-based agriculture, the western expansion, the 'American system' of manufacturing, cyclical instability and depression, and the distribution of income.

courses.name: AUDI 516 Discourse Analysis
courses.description: May be taken more than once for credit.

courses.name: SPAN 402 Advanced Spanish III
courses.description: Advanced studies in Spanish language and style.

courses.name: BIOL 427 Ornithology and Herpetology
courses.description: Ecology, evolution, behavior, and conservation of birds, amphibians, and reptiles.  Laboratories and field projects will focus on identification, systematics, and natural history, with particular attention to species from British Columbia.

courses.name: MUSC 562E Wind and Percussion Chamber Ensembles - WIND CHAM ENS PC
courses.description: Open only to graduate students.

courses.name: GREK 202 Second-Year Ancient Greek II
courses.description: Completion of the grammatical foundations of Ancient Greek, Part II; introduction to the reading of unadapted passages of Greek literature.

courses.name: FIST 200 Introduction to Canadian Cinema
courses.description: History and aesthetics of Canadian cinema.

courses.name: FNH 471 Human Nutrition Over the Life Span
courses.description: Nutritional requirements and dietary patterns of healthy individuals throughout the life span.

courses.name: THTR 274 Beginning Voice and Movement II
courses.description: Open only to B.F.A. Acting students.

courses.name: CICS 530 Advanced Software Engineering Project
courses.description: Design implementation and test of a large software system in an operational environment with emphasis on a team approach.
courses.prerequisites: All of CICS 505, CICS 511, CICS 514, CICS 516, CICS 520, CICS 525.

courses.name: GEOG 371 Research Strategies in Human Geography
courses.description: Formulating a research problem and selecting an appropriate research strategy. Research strategies range from social scientific survey methods to ethnography. Priority enrolment for honours and major students in Geography.

courses.name: MATH 441 Mathematical Modeling: Discrete Optimization Problems
courses.description: Formulation of real-world optimization problems using techniques such as linear programming, network flows, integer programming, dynamic programming. Solution by appropriate software.

courses.name: ELEC 481 Economic Analysis of Engineering Projects
courses.description: Time-money relationships; economic analysis of alternatives including the effects of interest rates, inflation, depreciation, taxation and uncertainty; cost estimation and budgeting; financial analysis of engineering operations.

courses.name: CICS 520 Database Systems
courses.description: Relational database design, table design, formal and commercial relational database languages, storage structures, query optimization, data mining, and other applications.

courses.name: PCTH 548C Directed Studies in Pharmacology - DIRECTED STUDIES
courses.description: In special cases, with the approval of the department head, advanced courses may be arranged.

courses.name: MECH 423 Biomechatronics
courses.description: Design of mechatronic systems to measure and manipulate biological materials and processes; compliant structures; bioelectronic circuits; biomedical embedded systems and BioMEMS.  Example applications from clinical medicine and biomedical research. Credit will be granted for only one of MECH 423, ELEC 472 or EECE 424.
courses.prerequisites: MECH 366 and one of ELEC 302, EECE 363.

courses.name: FNH 475 Clinical Dietetics II
courses.description: The role of nutrition and the application of therapeutic diets in the prevention, etiology and treatment of specialized areas of clinical nutrition. Restricted to students in the Dietetics Major.

courses.name: LING 327 Introduction to Semantics
courses.description: The analysis and theory of linguistic meaning with emphasis on formal techniques for semantic analysis and their application to empirical phenomena in language, including pragmatics.

courses.name: CIVL 564 Engineering Management of Solid Wastes
courses.description: Characteristics of solid wastes; introduction to solid waste collection, treatment and disposal. Evaluation of current practice and analysis of future potential of landfills, composting, combined treatment, recycle and re-use.

courses.name: CONS 302 Issues in Genomics and the Environment
courses.description: Current and topical issues, including genetic determinism, environmental DNA, genomics and climate change, revival of extinct species, and applications of genomics in natural environments.

courses.name: HGSE 356 Biophysical Dynamics of the Marine-Terrestrial Interface
courses.description: Nutrient cycling between the marine environment and coastal forest ecosystems; how the physical characteristics of this interface affect inputs; which species play a pivotal role in driving interactions.  Part of the Haida Gwaii Fall Semester.
courses.corequisites: All of HGSE 355, HGSE 357, HGSE 358, HGSE 359.

courses.name: ARCH 515 Design Media I
courses.description: Foundations of manual and digital skills and concepts employing a variety of subjects, techniques and software.

courses.name: POLI 405A Topics in Canadian Politics - TPC CANADA POLI
courses.description: This seminar examines in depth some of the important issues in Canadian politics.
