courses.description: Approved and supervised work experience with a public or private organization for a minimum of 13 weeks full-time. Orientation workshops. Final work term report required. Restricted to students in the Arts Co-operative Education Program.
courses.prerequisites: (6 credits first-year English or Arts I; 6 credits of science; 6 credits of literature; satisfaction of Faculty language requirement.)

courses.name: CIVL 202 Civil Engineering II
courses.description: The social and biophysical context of infrastructure and the impact of technologies on people, the economy, and the environment. Specific topics vary from year to year.

courses.name: COMM 353 Financial Accounting: Intermediate I
courses.description: An examination of accounting as a means of measurement and as an information system for external reporting purposes.
courses.corequisites: Either (a) all of COMM 297, COMM 397 or (b) COMM 298.

courses.name: LIBR 535 Instructional Role of the Librarian
MIDW 101 Counselling for Maternity Care Providers
courses.description: Theory, knowledge, strategies, and skills of person-centered counselling including family systems, trauma theory, theory, grief counselling, motivational interviewing skills, self-awareness and mindfulness, interprofessional communication, and cultural competency in continuity of care.

courses.name: ITAL 402 Advanced Studies in Italian Language and Style II
courses.description: Advanced reading, writing, speaking, comprehension. Special emphasis on composition. Alternates with ITAL 401.

courses.name: MATH 318 Probability with Physical Applications
courses.description: Random variables, discrete and continuous distributions. Random walk, Markov chains, Monte Carlo methods. Characteristic functions, limit laws. Please consult the Faculty of Science Credit Exclusion List: www.students.ubc.ca/calendar/index.cfm?tree=12,215,410,414.
courses.prerequisites: One of MATH 152, MATH 221, MATH 223 and one of MATH 215, MATH 255, MATH 256, MATH 265.
courses.corequisites: One of MATH 256, MATH 257, MATH 267, MATH 316.

courses.name: ASTR 101 Introduction to the Solar System
courses.description: General principles of the celestial sphere, laws of motion and light, optics, and telescopes; current knowledge of the Sun and Solar System.
courses.prerequisites: One of PHYS 11, PHYS 12. (plus Principles of Mathematics 12.)

courses.name: VISA 330 Intermediate Painting I
courses.description: Development of techniques and personal style in relation to ideas. History and contemporary issues in painting will be introduced  to assist students in conceptualizing their painting practice.

courses.name: JAPN 300 Advanced Modern Japanese: Reading and Writing I
courses.description: Selected texts covering various aspects of Japanese cultural history and contemporary Japanese culture/society; emphasis on grammatical analysis and development of advanced competencies for reading and writing. JAPN 300 and 301 are normally taken in the same year.

courses.name: FRST 536C Advanced Studies in Forest Mensuration - ADV FOR MENSURAT
courses.description: Development and analysis of forest inventory systems; sequence and patterns of tree growth; analysis of crown development; improvement of stand growth and yield; methods of biomass analysis.

courses.name: EDCP 491 Home Economics II - Secondary: Curriculum and Pedagogy
LING 345 Pragmatics
courses.description: Selected topics in pragmatics and information structure, including variations in their cross-linguistic expression and the corresponding influence of sentence form on context.

courses.name: POLI 320B Government and Politics of the United States of America - GOVRT&POLTCS USA
courses.description: The distinctive political system of the U.S. Covers all major institutions and processes, focusing on contemporary issues. Comparisons with the Canadian system. Sources of political failure and possible reform.

courses.name: BAMS 580D Topics in Applied Management Science - TPCS MNGMNT SCIE
SPPH 581N Selected Topics - KNOWLDGE TRNSLTN
courses.description: By seminar and directed readings, certain topics of current interest are explored in depth.

courses.name: BUSI 100 Micro Foundations of Real Estate Economics
courses.description: Basic principles of microeconomics and application to current economic problems.

courses.name: KIN 367 Leisure Services for Persons with a Disability
courses.description: Policy issues relating to leisure opportunities for persons with disabilities.

courses.name: MEDG 548A Directed Studies - DIRECTED STUDIES
courses.description: A series of laboratory sessions, directed readings and directed counselling interviews related to selected areas of Medical Genetics. This advanced course may be taken upon approval of the department head.

courses.name: COMM 452 Taxes and Decision Making
courses.description: Analysis of business and financial decisions in the presence of taxes.

courses.name: VISA 583B MFA Research Seminar - MFA RSRCH SEMINR
RHSC 589A Major Project, Part II - MAJOR PROJ PRT 2
courses.prerequisites: RHSC 587. (Permission of the project coordinator is also required.)

courses.name: ARCH 538B Study of Architecture Abroad - ARCH ABROAD
courses.description: More than one section may be taken concurrently.

courses.name: MUSC 454 History of Opera I
courses.description: The development of opera between 1600 and 1800.

courses.name: EDUC 143 Seminar and Classroom Observation I
courses.description: Pass/Fail.

courses.name: EPSE 682 Multivariate Designs and Analysis in Educational Research
GEOB 402 Air Pollution Meteorology
courses.description: The nature of atmospheric pollutants. The ability of the atmosphere to disperse, transform, and remove pollutants. Air pollution dispersion models. Air quality monitoring, criteria, and standards.

courses.name: SPPH 567 Quantitative Methods for the Assessment and Analysis of Exposure Data
courses.description: Determinants of exposure, sampling strategies.

courses.name: GRSJ 235 Gender, Race, Sexuality, and Social Structures in Modern Asia
courses.description: Situates ?Asia? in a global context and explores the complex relationships between gender, social structures, and social change.

courses.name: EOSC 322 Metamorphic Petrology
courses.description: Deciphering lithospheric processes as recorded by the mineralogy, chemistry and textures of metamorphosed rocks.

courses.name: SPAN 102 Beginners' Spanish II
courses.description: Grammar, composition, translation, oral practice.

courses.name: ARTH 343 Art and Photography in Canada to 1920
courses.description: Art, artists, and art institutions from the establishment of the French and English colonies to the founding of the Group of Seven: issues of race, wilderness, and colonial expansion.

courses.name: MINE 485 Cave Mining Systems: Design and Planning
courses.description: Designs, planning, and leading practices are applied to underground mining systems reliant on induced and controlled rock mass caving.

courses.name: MEDG 548C Directed Studies - DIRECTED STUDIES
courses.description: A series of laboratory sessions, directed readings and directed counselling interviews related to selected areas of Medical Genetics. This advanced course may be taken upon approval of the department head.

courses.name: ARCL 424 Practicing Archaeology and the Management of Cultural Resources
courses.description: Survey of the use of archaeology in the public context and interest, particularly the identification, evaluation, conservation, and management of archaeological resources.  Laws and policies, principles, methods, and ethical concerns guiding current practices, public involvement, relationships with indigenous communities, and contemporary issues in cultural resources management.

courses.name: LATN 201 Second-Year Latin I
courses.description: Completion of the grammatical foundations of classical Latin, Part I.

courses.name: BIOL 404 Ecological Methodology
courses.description: Design, execution, and analysis of ecological surveys and experiments. Practical field methods for estimating population metrics and describing community structure. Computer techniques for the statistical analysis of ecological data.
courses.prerequisites: One of BIOL 300, STAT 200 and one of BIOL 230, BIOL 302, BIOL 303, BIOL 304.

courses.name: ENGL 346B Chaucer and the Middle Ages - CHAUCER&MID AGES
courses.description: A detailed study of Chaucer's major works.
courses.prerequisites: (3rd year standing and 6 credits of first-year English, or Arts One, or 6 credits of ASTU 100 from CAP or 3 credits of first-year English and 3 credits of ASTU 150)

courses.name: COHR 486D Special Topics in Organizational Behaviour and Human Resources - NEGOTN FOR LDRS
MUSC 205 Aural Skills III
courses.description: Continuation of MUSC 106. Restricted to B.Mus. students.

courses.name: AUDI 566C Audiology Practicum II - AUDI PRACTICM II
STAT 549A Thesis for Master's Degree - THESIS FOR MSTRS
EOSC 445 Engineering Design Project
courses.description: Geological engineering design project from scope definition to final design.  Based on a problem from industry.

courses.name: CRWR 508W Advanced Writing for Graphic Forms I - ADV GRAPHC FRM I
RSOT 515 Practice Skills and Therapeutic Procedures I
COHR 433 Employment Law
courses.description: Introduction to legislation and application of legal principles that govern the employment relationship.
courses.prerequisites: All of COMM 292, COMM 393 and one of COMM 203, COMM 392.

courses.name: MINE 493 Seminar
courses.description: Oral presentation of a technical nature. Use of closed circuit television for personal evaluation.

courses.name: PLAN 542 Practical Practice: City Planning as a Craft
courses.description: Approach, role, style, and essential skills of practical urban planning: working at the community level; developing overall policy; managing development; undertaking urban design; and engaging in the political process.

courses.name: ASTR 200 Frontiers of Astrophysics
courses.description: Stellar masses and evolution. White dwarfs, neutron stars, and black holes. Extrasolar planet formation and detection. Dark matter in the Milky Way and other galaxies. Cosmological observations and principles. Weather permitting, observations will be conducted.
courses.prerequisites: Either (a) one of PHYS 101, PHYS 107, PHYS 117, PHYS 157, PHYS 153 and one of MATH 101, MATH 103, MATH 105, MATH 121;  or (b) SCIE 001.

courses.name: GEOG 410 Environment and Society
courses.description: Geographical analysis of society-environment relations. Relates resource management to environmental politics, political economy, and sustainable development. Perspectives drawn from political ecology and political economy, environmental history and environmental philosophy.

courses.name: EDCP 501 Master's Seminar
courses.description: Pass/Fail.

courses.name: CDST 350B Canadian Studies - CDN STUDIES
courses.description: An interdisciplinary introduction to Canadian studies. Required of all majors.

courses.name: BIOL 342 Integrative Biology Laboratory
courses.description: Field-based and laboratory-based investigation of organisms.
courses.prerequisites: Either (a) all of BIOL 121, BIOL 140 or (b) all of SCIE 001, BIOL 140. (or (c) 8 transfer credits of first-year biology; and third-year standing or higher in Combined Major in Science.)

courses.name: EDUC 490I Special Studies in Education - SPEC STUDIES ED
courses.description: Topics not covered in a course. A pilot course may be offered under this name for only one year and with permission of the Associate Dean (Teacher Education).

courses.name: KIN 500D Special Topics in Kinesiology - SPEC TPCS KIN
ELEC 461 Nanotechnology in Electronics
courses.description: Topics of special importance to understanding and designing electronic devices in which quantum effects and the discrete nature of matter become important.
courses.prerequisites: One of CHEM 312, EECE 352, ELEC 315, PHYS 250, PHYS 304.

courses.name: SOCI 354B Community Studies - COMMUNITY
courses.description: Study of the organization of human communities; a focus upon collective activities including family, work, neighbourhood, and formal and informal networks.

courses.name: VISA 310 Intermediate Digital Arts I
courses.description: Exploring issues and topics in interactive digital media and culture through the creation of critical contemporary art. Includes technical instruction with a focus on the development of individual and group projects.

courses.name: SPPH 503 Epidemiological Methods 2
courses.description: Critical thinking in epidemiology; principles and methods of study design; context for epidemiological investigations of human health.
courses.prerequisites: Either (a) all of HCEP 400, HCEP 502 or (b) all of SPPH 400, SPPH 502.

courses.name: EDST 518 Theory and Research on Adult Learning
ECON 311 Principles of Macroeconomics
courses.description: The scope of this course is approximately the same as that of ECON 102. The course is intended for upper-level students only. Credit will be given for only one of ECON 311 and ECON 102.

courses.name: EPSE 688A Supervision of School Psychology Practice - SUPERV SCH PSYCH
courses.description: Instruction and practice in the supervision of school psychology.
courses.prerequisites: (Restricted to students in the School Psychology Ph.D. Program.)

courses.name: CHEM 527 Materials Chemistry
courses.description: Credit will not be given for both CHEM 527 and CHEM 427.

courses.name: UDES 504 History and Theory of Urban Design
PUNJ 200 Intermediate Punjabi
courses.description: Study of the grammar and introduction to Punjabi literature. As of 2011W, credit will be granted for only one of PUNJ 201/202 or PUNJ 200.

courses.name: EECE 550 Topics in Power Electronic Design
courses.description: New devices and applications in power electronics.

courses.name: BMEG 501 Interdisciplinary Team Project in Medical Technology Innovation
BMEG 554C Directed Studies in Biomedical Engineering - DR STD BIOMD ENG
JAPN 210 Intermediate Japanese I A
courses.description: Integrated coverage of topics on culture and cross-cultural communication designed to develop competencies in speaking, listening, reading, and writing. Note: JAPN 210 and 211 are normally taken in the same year.

courses.name: ARST 515 Arrangement and Description of Archives
PLAN 548X Current Issues in Planning - ETHICS IN PLAN
courses.description: Each year the school may offer one or more courses on a topical issue covering recent advances in the field.

courses.name: HIST 327 Colonial America: Encounter and Settlement, 1607 - 1763
courses.description: Encounters between European, African, and Indigenous North American peoples as well as the history of the colonies within the Atlantic world, from the late sixteenth century to the eve of the American Revolution.

courses.name: EECE 509 Advanced Microsystems Design
courses.description: Project-based modeling techniques applied to microsystems; multi-physics at microscale; physical limitations in MEMS; interface with electronics; behavioural modeling languages for mixed analog-digital system design.

courses.name: CHEM 498 Co-operative Work Placement III
courses.description: Approved and supervised technical work experience in an industrial research setting for a minimum of 3.5 months. Taken during the summer following fourth year. Technical report required. Restricted to students admitted to the Co-operative Education Program in Chemistry.

courses.name: ASIA 451 Modern Chinese Authors in Translation
courses.description: Study of one influential modern Chinese author, such as Lu Xun, Shen Congwen, Eileen Chang, Yu Hua, Mo Yan, or Wang Anyi.

courses.name: NURS 420 Clinical Nursing Focus: Adults Experiencing Acute or Chronic Health Conditions
courses.description: Credit is given for one of NURS 420, 422, 423, 424, or 425.
courses.prerequisites: All of NURS 302, NURS 303, NURS 304, NURS 305, NURS 306, NURS 333, NURS 334, NURS 335, NURS 336, NURS 337, NURS 338, NURS 339, NURS 340, NURS 341, NURS 342, NURS 343.

courses.name: MATH 103 Integral Calculus with Applications to Life Sciences
courses.description: Antiderivatives and definite integrals, infinite series, applications to probability and dynamical systems. Please consult the Faculty of Science Credit Exclusion List: www.students.ubc.ca/calendar/index.cfm?tree=12,215,410,414.
courses.prerequisites: One of MATH 100, MATH 102, MATH 104, MATH 110, MATH 111, MATH 120, MATH 180, MATH 184.

courses.name: FISH 500 Issues in Fisheries Research: Seminars - Fisheries Management
PSYC 547E Reading and Conference - READG & CONFRNCE
GEOB 449B Undergraduate Thesis - UNDERGRAD THESIS
courses.description: Original research on an approved topic, developed under the guidance of a faculty member. Open to 4th year students in Geographical Biogeosciences with appropriate background courses related to the research topic, and permission of the directing faculty member. The 3-credit option is only available to students who complete GEOB 449 in tandem with GEOB 409.

courses.name: SOCI 350C Sociological Theories: Classical and Contemporary Approaches - SOCI THEORIES
courses.description: An examination of selected traditions, conceptual problems, and current topics in the field of sociological theory.

courses.name: CCFI 580C Problems in Education - PROB IN EDUC
courses.description: Investigation and report of a problem.

courses.name: SPAN 357 Survey of Peninsular Literature and Culture from the Origins to 1700
courses.prerequisites: SPAN 302 and one of SPAN 220, SPAN 221.
courses.corequisites: (SPAN 302 may be taken as a co-requisite, with the permission of the instructor or the Spanish Major Adviser.)

courses.name: ASIA 360A A Specific Asian Literature in Translation - SP ASIAN LIT TRN
courses.description: Introduction to the literature of a linguistic area of Asia not covered in existing courses. Not given every year. Consult the Department for details. May be taken multiple times on different subjects for credit.

courses.name: CRWR 507A Advanced Writing of Drama for the Stage I - ADV DRMA STG I
SURG 510 Surgical Care in International Health
courses.description: Online course. Foundation to international surgery. The discussion of the global burden of unmet surgical needs and a professional response in low and middle income regions of the world.

courses.name: THTR 449 Supervised Study and Honours Essay
MECH 436 Fundamentals of Injury Biomechanics
courses.description: Introduction to injury biomechanics. Anatomy. Impact experiments. Multi-body dynamic simulation and finite element analysis. Skull, face, brain, spine, eye, pelvis, abdomen, and extremity injury. Anthropomorphic test devices, seat belts, airbags, child restraints, and helmets. Credit cannot be obtained for both MECH 436 and MECH 536.

courses.name: LAW 406A Topics in Criminal Justice - TPCS CRIM JUSTCE
courses.description: Not offered each year, consult Faculty.

courses.name: PHIL 441A Philosophy of Perception - PHIL OF PERCEPT
courses.description: The contribution of the senses to knowledge of the external world; the nature of perception and its contribution to empirical knowledge.
courses.prerequisites: PHIL 240. (or COGS 200 if accompanied by 3 credits in PHIL at the 200-level or above.)

courses.name: DENT 776B Interdisciplinary Care in Orthodontics and Dentofacial Orthopedics III - INTD ORTH&DN III
PHIL 433A Bio-Medical Ethics - BIOMEDICAL ETHIC
courses.description: Moral problems arising in the health sciences, especially in medicine but also in biology, psychology, and social work. Topics include abortion, death and euthanasia, genetic engineering, behaviour modification, compulsory treatment, experimentation with human beings and animals, and the relationship between professionals and their patients, subjects or clients. No philosophical background is required.

courses.name: MTRL 486 Nondestructive Evaluation
courses.description: Principles of test methods; inspection techniques and equipment; quantitative flaw evaluation; reliability analysis.

courses.name: HIST 364 Europe in the Late Middle Ages
courses.description: A survey of the development of institutions, ideas and the economy in Europe from about 1000 CE through the fourteenth century.

courses.name: MIDW 405 Advanced Topics in Midwifery Theory and Practice
courses.description: Theoretical principles for midwifery care of pregnancy, labour, birth, newborns, and the puerperium.  Emphasis on assessment and management skills for abnormal situations.  Includes a five-day intensive session in Vancouver, a series of online tutorials, and lab practice.

courses.name: LAW 374 Municipal Law
courses.description: The municipality as a legal entity; its creation, operation and powers; by-laws and their validity; contractual liability; judicial review; business regulation; expropriation and land use control.

courses.name: CONS 449A Directed Studies in Natural Resources Conservation - DIR ST NTL RS CN
courses.description: In special cases and with the approval of the instructor concerned, a student may carry out directed studies of specific problems in natural resources conservation.

courses.name: EOSC 211 Computer Methods in Earth, Ocean and Atmospheric Sciences
courses.description: Mathematical computer-based problem solving in the physical, chemical, and biological sciences. Problems drawn from studies of the earth, the oceans and the atmosphere.
courses.prerequisites: One of MATH 101, MATH 103, MATH 105, MATH 121, SCIE 001.

courses.name: SPPH 525 Issues and Concepts in Public Health
courses.description: History of public health research and practice; occupational and environmental health; health services and systems; social and lifecourse determinants of health; and population health and emerging trends.

courses.name: BIOL 234 Fundamentals of Genetics
courses.description: Genotype and phenotype, mechanisms of inheritance, genetic analysis. Please consult the Faculty of Science Credit Exclusion Lists: www.students.ubc.ca/calendar/index.cfm?tree=12,215,410,414.
courses.prerequisites: Either (a) all of BIOL 112, BIOL 121 or (b) SCIE 001. (or (c) a corequisite of CHEM 203 and one of BIOL 112 or BIOL 121.)

courses.name: LLED 565B Special Course in Subject Matter Field - SPC C SUBJ MTFLD
courses.description: Courses in various subject matter fields designed to bring teachers up to date in recent findings in each field.

courses.name: BIOL 201 Introduction to Biochemistry
courses.description: Biological molecules, protein structure and enzyme action, energy transfer, central metabolic pathways and their regulation. Examples drawn from plants, animals and microorganisms. (Consult the Credit Exclusion list within the Faculty of Science section of the Calendar.)
courses.prerequisites: BIOL 200 and one of CHEM 233, CHEM 260. (; or BIOL 200 and a corequisite of CHEM 213; or a corequisite of either CHEM 313 or CHEM 330.)

courses.name: KIN 454B Field Experience - FIELD EXPERIENCE
courses.description: Students have the opportunity to develop their leadership, instruction, and professional skills in a variety of supervised fieldwork settings. Students should select the section of the course (A, B) most relevant to their program of study and career goals.

courses.name: ECON 370 Benefit-Cost Analysis and the Economics of Project Evaluation
courses.description: Techniques and problems in benefit-cost analysis of public projects. Examination of alternative approaches to public decision-making such as cost-effectiveness analysis and multiple-objective frameworks. Case studies of projects in the areas of natural resources, the environment, human resources, public services, and transportation.

courses.name: EDST 501 Research Traditions in Educational Administration
URSY 520 Urban Systems Planning
courses.description: Planning for engineers. Demand-side planning: population and demand modeling; demand management. Supply-side planning:  long term planning, strategic planning. Data, metrics, indicators and assessment.

courses.name: FIPR 299 Directed Studies: On-Campus Research
courses.description: On-campus film production field research. Based on film project work on campus productions. Restricted to Film Production students except with permission. Contact department.

courses.name: SPPH 508 M.P.H. Practicum
courses.description: Includes a significant component of applied epidemiology and biostatistics in a field setting.

courses.name: FMST 314 Relationship development
courses.description: The study of the development, course, and decline of personal relationships.
courses.prerequisites: Either (a) SOCI 200 or (b) all of PSYC 101, PSYC 102 or (c) SOCI 240.

courses.name: GRSJ 101 Gender, Race, Sex and Power
courses.description: An overview of intersectional feminist debates and theoretical traditions. Credit will be granted for only one of WMST 100 or GRSJ 101.

courses.name: PSYC 545A Advanced Statistics I - ADV STATS 1
MTRL 595 Advanced Biomaterials
courses.description: Formation and structure-function relations of biological materials, the interaction of tissue-synthetic biomaterials, advanced biomaterials design, biomimetic processing, and current progress in drug delivery systems and biomedical devices.

courses.name: PHAR 321 Biophysical Pharmacy I
courses.description: Applications of the physical chemical properties of drugs to oral drug delivery systems.

courses.name: LLED 570 Theory and Research in English Language Education: Discourse Perspectives
courses.prerequisites: (Admission into the TESL Graduate Program or permission of instructor.)

courses.name: COHR 486A Special Topics in Organizational Behaviour and Human Resources - GNDR&DVRSTY LDSP
CPSC 425 Computer Vision
courses.description: Introduction to the processing and interpretation of images.  Image sensing, sampling, and filtering.  Algorithms for colour analysis, texture description, stereo imaging, motion interpretation, 3D shape recovery, and recognition.
courses.prerequisites: All of MATH 200, MATH 221 and either (a) CPSC 221 or (b) all of CPSC 260, EECE 320.

courses.name: ELEC 211 Engineering Electromagnetics
courses.description: Electrostatics, electric currents, dielectrics, capacitance, electrostatic potential, magnetostatics.
courses.prerequisites: One of MATH 263, MATH 253 and one of PHYS 102, PHYS 153, PHYS 158.

courses.name: HIST 425 War and Society
courses.description: Continuity and change in the relations of war and society, the connections between the economy, society, the military, and government in peacetime as well as war; not a course in military history.

courses.name: FNEL 282 Structures of Endangered Languages: Conservation and Revitalization
courses.description: Development of skills in the documentation, transcription and analysis of grammatical structures in endangered languages, focusing on the diversity within BC Aboriginal languages. Applied techniques in documentation, workflow and multi-media digital annotation, guided by community-based ethical protocols and conservation/revitalization goals.

courses.name: EOSC 448A Directed Studies - DIRECTED STUDIES
courses.description: Investigation of a topic to be agreed upon by a member of the faculty and the student. Permission of an undergraduate advisor and of the supervising faculty member is required before registration.

courses.name: CIVL 436 Matrix Structural Analysis and Dynamics
courses.description: Further techniques in matrix structural analysis; non-rigid supports, temperature-shrinkage effects, computer implementation; matrix representation of structural dynamics; mode shapes, natural frequencies, continuous systems; lumped mass models, modal analysis, response spectra.

courses.name: CPSC 221 Basic Algorithms and Data Structures
courses.description: Design and analysis of basic algorithms and data structures; algorithm analysis methods, searching and sorting algorithms, basic data structures, graphs and concurrency.
courses.prerequisites: One of CPSC 210, EECE 210, CPEN 221 and one of CPSC 121, MATH 220.

courses.name: BOTA 528 Current Topics in Plant Biochemistry
GRSJ 325 Decolonizing and Feminist Qualitative Methodologies
courses.description: Data collection techniques, the politics of interpretation, and the formulation of a research proposal using a feminist, anti-racist framework.
courses.prerequisites: All of GRSJ 101, GRSJ 102. (or third-year standing.)

courses.name: MRNE 437 Population and Community Ecology of Marine Organisms
courses.description: Emphasis on interactions among organisms and between organisms and their physiochemical environment, and on biological diversity.
courses.prerequisites: (Completion of second year in a biology program.)

courses.name: FNH 490 Topics in Food, Nutrition, and Health
courses.description: Analysis and interpretation of current issues in food, nutrition and health.

courses.name: FRST 303 Principles of Forest Science
courses.description: Introduction to growth of trees and forests with emphasis on evolutionary, ecological and environmental aspects. Not available for credit to undergraduate students in the Faculty of Forestry.

courses.name: LAW 507 Evidence
courses.description: The admissibility and use of evidence in litigation. Credit will be granted for only one of LAW 507, LAW 280 or LAW 476.

courses.name: ENGL 357K Restoration and Eighteenth-Century Studies - RES & 18TH CENT
courses.prerequisites: (3rd year standing and 6 credits of first-year English, or Arts One, or 6 credits of ASTU 100 from CAP or 3 credits of first-year English and 3 credits of ASTU 150)

courses.name: EDCP 408 Art, Education and Cultural Diversity
courses.description: Pass/Fail.

courses.name: STAT 399 Co-operative Work Placement II
courses.description: Work experience in an industrial research setting. Normally taken during Summer Session following third year. Restricted to students admitted to the Co-operative Education Program in Statistics.

courses.name: EDCP 564 Texts, Politics, and Ideologies of Curriculum Development
CHEM 304 Fundamentals of Physical Chemistry
courses.description: Review of thermodynamics concepts; introduction to statistical mechanics; solution thermodynamics; phase equilibria; electrochemistry.
courses.prerequisites: CHEM 201 and one of MATH 200, MATH 217, MATH 226, MATH 253, MATH 263.

courses.name: APBI 440 Plant Genomics
courses.description: Concepts, principles, and recent discoveries in genome structure and comparative genomics in plants with a focus on economically important plants; applications of genomics approaches to questions in plant genetics, evolution, and ecology.

courses.name: GEOG 318 Sustainability in a Changing Environment
courses.description: Biophysical and human causes of short- and long-term environmental change at various spatial scales, including measurement, interpretation, and policy.

courses.name: CIVL 435 Advanced Structural Analysis
courses.description: Shear flow, shear deformation, St. Venant torsion, warping torsion, P-delta and geometric stiffness, buckling of columns and frames, cylindrical shells, beams on elastic foundation, shear wall analysis, elasto-plastic analysis. Introduction to the finite element method. Credit will be granted for only one of CIVL 435 or CIVL 539.

courses.name: CHIN 321 Business Chinese I (Heritage)
courses.description: Practical business-focused reading, writing, and presentation skills addressing business interactions and documents.

courses.name: SCAN 414 Topics in Danish and Northern European Cultural Studies (in English).
courses.description: Selected topics, such as ethnicity, migration, identity, women's issues, Danish and Northern European film.

courses.name: FRST 448 Co-operative Work Placement.
courses.description: Supervised work experience in an approved organization for a minimum of 15 weeks. Restricted to students in the Co-operative Education Program in the Faculty of Forestry. Final work term report required.

courses.name: CPSC 121 Models of Computation
courses.description: Physical and mathematical structures of computation.  Boolean algebra and combinations logic circuits; proof techniques; functions and sequential circuits; sets and relations; finite state machines; sequential instruction execution.

courses.name: PHIL 220A Symbolic Logic I - SYMBOLIC LOGIC I
courses.description: Sentential and predicate logic. Translation from natural language; truth tables and interpretations; systems of natural deduction up to relational predicate logic with identity; alternative proof methods. Some sections may use computer-based materials and tests.

courses.name: STAT 548B Directed Studies in Statistics - DIRECTED STUDIES
MECH 431 Engineering Economics
courses.description: Discounted cash flows. Sources of funds, cost of capital. Effects of depreciation, taxes, inflation. Evaluation and comparison of economic models for engineering projects. Replacement decisions. Public project analysis. Risk analysis. Project control, inventory analysis, simulation.

courses.name: APBI 316 Equine Biology, Health and Nutrition
courses.description: Physiology, growth and reproduction of the horse; nutrition, diet formulation and feeding practices; common diseases, their prevention and treatment.

courses.name: LAW 352 Aboriginal Peoples and Canadian Law
courses.description: Survey of the history and present status of the legal relationships between Canada's Aboriginal peoples and the state. Credit will be granted for only one of LAW 200 or LAW 352.

courses.name: MTRL 361 Modelling of Materials Processes
courses.description: Mathematical and physical modelling of processes employed in the production of materials. The application of models to analyse, design and improve materials production.

courses.name: MECH 462 Finite Element Analysis
courses.description: Theory and element selection. Virtual work and weighted residual formulation. Linear elastic analysis. Heat transfer analysis. Isoparametic elements. Development of computer programs for simple problems. Utilization of existing computer packages. Application to mechanical engineering problems.

courses.name: ECON 325 Introduction to Empirical Economics
courses.description: Essentials of probability and statistics for applied work in economics. Topics include descriptive statistics, probability, estimation, hypothesis testing, and analysis of variance. Please consult the Faculty of Science Credit Exclusion List: http://www.calendar.ubc.ca/vancouver/index.cfm?tree=12,215,410,414
courses.prerequisites: All of ECON 101, ECON 102, MATH 104, MATH 105.

courses.name: CPSC 448A Directed Studies in Computer Science - DIRECTED STUDIES
courses.description: Open ordinarily to students in Computer Science with at least a 72% average and the permission of the head of the department or designate. The course may consist of supervised reading, participation in a seminar, and one or more programming projects.

courses.name: MICB 506C Microbiological and Immunological Research - MICB&IMMUN RSRCH
courses.description: Developing, discussing, and undertaking research projects.  Oral communication skills, peer review skills, scientific ethics, and the ability to critically evaluate papers in the literature.  To be taken only with permission of the department head.

courses.name: EDCP 373A Information and Communication Technologies I - Secondary: Curriculum and Pedagogy - ICT I SEC C&P
courses.description: Pass/Fail.

courses.name: ASIA 338 Modern India: From Conquest to Raj
courses.description: The history of India from the coming of the Europeans to the rise of the nationalist movement with emphasis on the social and economic impact of British imperialism.

courses.name: CPSC 259 Data Structures and Algorithms for Electrical Engineers
courses.description: Advanced procedural programming.  Fundamental algorithms for sorting and searching.  Data structures including lists, trees, and hash tables.  Introduction to scripting languages and file input/output.

courses.name: MUSC 512F Directed Individual Studies - ADV ORCH CONDUCT
courses.description: Approval by the Director, School of Music, is required.

courses.name: HIST 101 World History to Oceanic Contact
courses.description: Origins and diffusion of the world's great religions; cultural contact along overland trade routes; emergence of civilizations such as the Inca, Chinese, and Christian European; ordering of societies and their political development.

courses.name: DENT 721 Clinical Endodontics, Year 1
courses.description: Endodontic treatment of patients in the clinic under the supervision of specialist instructors. Supervised endodontic treatment clinic.

courses.name: HEBR 202 Intermediate Biblical Hebrew II
courses.description: The second year of Biblical Hebrew with emphasis on rapid reading of poetry and prose along with grammar.

courses.name: ISCI 448A Directed Studies - DIRECTED STUDIES
courses.description: Permission of the Director is required.

courses.name: POLI 316A Global Indigenous Politics - GLB INDIG POLTIC
courses.description: The political dynamics of Indigenous peoples? politics on the global level; the legal and practical realities of colonization as a global Indigenous experience; current global Indigenous political issues and avenues of Indigenous resistance.

courses.name: GBPR 500 Building Blocks of Forest Biomass
courses.description: Anatomy, physiology, composition, ultrastructure of the cell wall, molecular organization, and chemistry of forest biomass.

courses.name: BAMA 580D Topics in Marketing - TPCS MARKETING
GRSJ 327 Feminist Theories of Representation and Difference
courses.description: Feminist scholarship emphasizing languages and processes of representation and the construction of difference in cultural discourses and institutions.
courses.prerequisites: Either (a) all of GRSJ 101, GRSJ 102 or (b) all of WMST 101, WMST 102. (or third-year standing.)

courses.name: EECE 532 Biomedical Microdevices
courses.description: Principles of sensors, actuators, microfluidics, biotechnology and nanotechnology, with applications in probing, detection, assaying, and drug delivery.

courses.name: ARST 575J Topics in the Management of Records - TPCS MGMT RECRDS
FNH 340 Food Theory
courses.description: Principles of food preparation based on the physical and chemical properties of food.
courses.prerequisites: FNH  200 and either (a) all of CHEM 111, CHEM 113 or (b) all of CHEM 121, CHEM 123.

courses.name: CRWR 503A Advanced Writing for Children I - ADV WRIT CHILD I
HIST 380C The Making of Modern China: Nationalism, War, Revolution - MODERN CHINA
courses.description: The history of China from 1800 to the present including the decline of the Qing empire, the rise of modern nationalism, foreign invasion, and China's multiple revolutions.

courses.name: FNIS 452 Indigenous Social Movements
courses.description: Draws on Indigenous and non-Indigenous intellectual traditions to explore the theoretical, cultural, political, economic, and historical bases of Indigenous peoples decolonization struggles in Canada. Credit will be granted for only one of FNSP 401A, FNIS 452, or FNSP 452.
courses.prerequisites: One of FNSP 200, FNIS 210, FNSP 210, FNIS 220, FNSP 220. (or third-year standing.)

courses.name: CELL 505 Current Topics in Intracellular Trafficking
courses.description: Organization of membranes and organelles within cells and how molecules are targeted to intracellular sites.

courses.name: PHYS 404 Introduction to Medical Physics
courses.description: Radiotherapy, X-ray imaging, nuclear medicine, magnetic resonance imaging and biomedical optics.
courses.prerequisites: (Third yearstanding in Science or Applied Science is required. MATH 200 (or MATH 217 or MATH 226 or MATH 267) is recommended.)

courses.name: PHYS 399 Co-operative Work Placement III
courses.description: Approved and supervised technical work experience in an industrial research setting for a minimum of 3.5 months. Normally taken during the summer following the third year. Technical report required. Restricted to students admitted to the Co-operative Education Program in Physics.

courses.name: EDUC 496B Practicum (Secondary) for Previously Certified Teachers - TEACH PRACT SECD
courses.description: Pass/Fail.
courses.prerequisites: (Recent completion of secondary teaching methods courses in the subjects to be taught.)

courses.name: ASIA 325 Hong Kong Cinema
courses.description: A survey of the cinema of Hong Kong from the post-war period to the present. The influence of Hong Kong on global cinema, and the forces (artists, studios, audiences, etc.) that have given rise to filmmaking styles and genres perceived as "distinctively Hong Kong."

courses.name: POLI 351 Environmental Politics and Policy
courses.description: Domestic and international determinants of environmental policy; alternative approaches to environmental protection. The sustainable development paradigm; public opinion and interest group pressures; risk assessment; mandatory, voluntary and market-based policy instruments.

courses.name: BIOC 450 Membrane Biochemistry
courses.description: Biochemistry of membranes and membrane proteins, membrane fusion, electrical signaling, and the involvement of membrane proteins in disease and drug development.
courses.prerequisites: One of BIOC 303, BIOT 380 and all of BIOC 402, BIOC 410.

courses.name: ENVR 400 Community Project in Environmental Science
courses.description: Instructor-guided collaboration between student teams and community partners on community-based environmental science projects. Teams articulate project questions and goals, devise methods, conduct research and communicate results. Credit will be given for only one of ENVR 400 or ENVR 449.

courses.name: MTRL 340 Manufacturing in Materials Engineering
courses.description: Manufacturing processes from a materials perspective; metal casting, heat treating processes, forming processes, machining, and joining. Role of manufacturing in microstructure and material properties development and on component performance.

courses.name: LAW 358D Topics in First Nations Law - TPCS 1ST NATIONS
courses.description: Not offered each year, consult Faculty.

courses.name: DENT 430 Dentistry III
courses.description: A multi-disciplinary course integrating didactic, simulation, clinical, and community service learning. Students function as team members in clinical group practices with individual progression through the Clinical Clerkships.

courses.name: APBI 314 Animals and Society
courses.description: Contemporary use of animals for food production, companionship, recreation and science; social and ethical issues concerning human impacts on animals; animals in human culture; protection of animals by society and the law.
courses.prerequisites: (At least third-year standing in any faculty.)

courses.name: FREN 371 Introduction to French Literary Theory and Methodology
courses.description: A survey of basic terminology, methods, problems, and theoretical trends in French literary criticism, specifically designed to provide students with a foundation for advanced study of literature in French.

courses.name: PUNJ 401 Devotional Literature in Punjabi
courses.description: Emphasis is on reading and written expression. Analytical writing in English and Punjabi required.

courses.name: CAPS 448B Directed Studies in Physiology - DIRECTED STUDIES
BUSI 450 Intermediate Financial Accounting II
courses.description: A continuation of the examination of accounting as a means of measurement and as an information system for external reporting purposes.

courses.name: FRE 515 Agribusiness Management
courses.description: Credit will be granted for only one of FNH 415, FOOD 515 or FRE 515.

courses.name: PHYS 520B Teaching Techniques in Physics and Astronomy - TEACH PHYS&ASTR
courses.description: Foundations of physics and astronomy education research, lesson plans, development of grading, effective questioning, effective presentations, methods in peer evaluation, and peer teaching.

courses.name: IGEN 230 Introduction to Engineering Design
courses.description: Introduction to engineering design methods, problem solving, working individually and in teams, and methods of communication of results. Engineering design projects will be assigned. Restricted to students in the second year of the Integrated Engineering program.

courses.name: CLST 232 Ancient Rome
courses.description: A survey of the ancient Roman world from the foundation of the city to the death of Constantine.

courses.name: EPSE 516 Seminar in the Development and Education of Highly Able and Creative Learners
ISCI 498 Co-operative Work Placement III
courses.description: Industrial or academic work experience for a minimum of 4 months.  Technical report required.  Restricted to students admitted to the Co-op Program in ISP.

courses.name: LIBR 600 Advanced Seminar in Research Methods
EPSE 689A Pre-Doctoral Internship in School Psychology - INTERN SCH PSYCH
courses.description: Pass/Fail.
courses.prerequisites: (Restricted to students in the School Psychology Ph.D. Program.)

courses.name: COMM 460 Social and Nonprofit Marketing
courses.description: Examines the role, use, and application of marketing in government agencies and nonprofit institutions.

courses.name: BIOC 398 Internship Work Placement I
courses.description: Approved and supervised technical work experience in an industrial or academic laboratory for three or four months. Technical report required. Restricted to students admitted to the Internship Program in Biochemistry and Molecular Biology.
courses.prerequisites: (Completion of academic third year in Biochemistry major or honours program is required.)

courses.name: RHSC 587 Major Project, Part I
courses.prerequisites: (Permission of the project coordinator is required.)

courses.name: COMM 525 Introduction to Behavioural Research Methods for Business
HGSE 355 Applied Ecology of Coastal Terrestrial Ecosystems
courses.description: Processes that shape coastal terrestrial ecosystems through time and applications to current ecological reality.  Part of the Haida Gwaii Fall Semester.
courses.corequisites: All of HGSE 356, HGSE 357, HGSE 358, HGSE 359.

courses.name: CAPS 499 Cooperative Work Placement IV
courses.description: Approved and supervised relevant work experience in an industrial, academic, or government setting for a minimum of 13 weeks full time. Work term report required. Restricted to students admitted to the Co-op Option in Honours Cellular, Anatomical and Physiological Sciences (B.Sc.).

courses.name: CIVL 417 Coastal Engineering
courses.description: General discussion of waves; linear wave theory; finite amplitude waves; standing waves; seiches; harbour design; wave shoaling, refraction and diffraction; beaches and coasts; wave statistics; wave generation; wave forces on piles, walls and breakwaters; tides; instrumentation and modelling techniques.

courses.name: ELEC 352 Electric Energy Systems
courses.description: Balanced and unbalanced three phase energy systems. Modeling of generators, transmission lines, transformers and loads. High voltage transmission, low voltage industrial and domestic distribution.
courses.prerequisites: One of EECE 253, ELEC 202 and one of EECE 373, ELEC 342.

courses.name: HIST 393 Introduction to History and Philosophy of Science
courses.description: An examination of historical, conceptual, and methodological conditions of scientific knowledge through detailed consideration of important episodes in the history of science.

courses.name: FNEL 489 Topics in First Nations and Endangered Languages
courses.description: Selected topics will vary. Multiple versions of this course may be taken, under consultation with the FNEL program advisor, for up to a maximum of 12 credits.

courses.name: BIOL 530 The Biology of the Cell
BIOL 321 Morphology and Evolution of Bryophytes
courses.description: A study of evolution, taxonomy and morphology of mosses, liverworts and hornworts with emphasis on living plants in their environment.

courses.name: ATSC 409 Numerical Techniques for Ocean, Atmosphere and Earth Scientists
courses.description: Web-based introduction to the practical numerical solution of ordinary and partial differential equations including considerations of stability and accuracy. Credit will be granted for only one of ATSC 409 or ATSC 506/EOSC 511.
courses.prerequisites: One of MATH 215, MATH 255, MATH 256, MATH 265. (Familiarity with a programming language is required.)

courses.name: BIOL 340 Introductory Cell Biology Laboratory
courses.description: Experiments using unicellular eukaryotes or prokaryotes with emphasis on techniques in microscopy and cell biology.
courses.prerequisites: All of BIOL 140, BIOL 200. (And at least third-year standing in Science.)

courses.name: KIN 201 Co-operative Work Placement
courses.description: Supervised, technical work experience in an established company or organization for a minimum of three months. Technical report. Restricted to students meeting the requirements of the School of Kinesiology and the Co-operative Education Program.  Pass/Fail.

courses.name: EECE 571F Electrical Engineering Seminar and Special Problems - RF INTGRTD CIRCT
HUNU 500 Research Methods in Human Nutrition
courses.description: Experimental design, methods of survey research, nutritional epidemiology, clinical research, and laboratory animal research. Issues such as animal models, ethics in animal and human research, statistical methods, and preparation of written reports and manuscripts, etc., will be addressed. Required of all M.Sc. and Ph.D. students in Human Nutrition.

courses.name: FRST 495 Biological Diversity and Forest Management
courses.description: Principles, problems, and practices of managing  forests and nature reserves for biological diversity; integration of forestry and wildlife with particular emphasis on diversity of all life forms.

courses.name: FRST 512 Belowground Forest Ecosystems
courses.description: Review of current literature on specific topics in forest soil ecology, including bacterial endophytes, microbial diversity, nutrient cycling, and mycorrhizae.

courses.name: ELEC 432 Digital Communications
courses.description: Formulation of the digital communication problem; definition of information, source and channel coding; digital modulation techniques, signal space, design of optimum digital receivers and performance calculations; trellis coded modulation; spread spectrum techniques; issues in wireless communication techniques and new standards.

courses.name: PHAR 552 Issues in Pharmacy Practice Research
courses.description: Research methods applied to the study of social and behavioural aspects of health care and pharmacy practice. Open only to pharmacy administration doctoral students who have completed graduate-level courses in statistics and research design.

courses.name: BUSI 442 Case Studies in Appraisal I
courses.description: Examines the day-to day issues that affect the practice of real estate appraisal.

courses.name: FREN 221 Introduction to Modern Literature written in French and to Textual Analysis
courses.description: Students will familiarize themselves with techniques of literary analysis, as applied to representative works from the 18th century to the present, including theatre, fiction, poetry and non-fiction prose.  To be taken by all students intending to proceed to the Minor, Major or Honours program.
courses.prerequisites: FREN 123. (or assignment based on placement test.)

courses.name: POLI 342A Modern Political Theory: Analysis of a Selected Theorist - MOD POL TH:SELCT
courses.description: A detailed examination of an acknowledged masterpiece of modern political theory. The text and attendant literature vary from year to year. Consult the departmental website.

courses.name: LFS 150 Scholarly Writing and Argumentation in Land and Food Systems
courses.description: Communicating concepts of food systems and links to human and environmental health through writing, elements of argumentation, evaluating evidence, and searching for and citing references to back up claims; small-class experience. Enrolment limited to LFS students with first year status and a Language Proficiency Index (LPI) of 4 or equivalent.

courses.name: CRWR 430 Preparation for a Career in Writing
HIST 490W Seminar for Majors in History - SEM FOR HIST MAJ
courses.description: Selected problems in the theory and practice of historical work. Check with the department for course offerings. Restricted to fourth year students majoring in History or in the History and Philosophy of Science. Also open to History Honours students.

courses.name: SOCI 440A Economic Sociology - ECONMC SOCIOLOGY
courses.description: Analysis of economic actions and institutions using the concepts and methods of sociology.

courses.name: BA 511 Community Business Project
courses.description: Registration restricted to students in the M.M. Program.

courses.name: BUSI 111 British Columbia Real Estate Law and Real Estate Ethics
courses.description: Canadian legal system and contract law and detailed aspects of real estate law as it applies in British Columbia.

courses.name: MUSC 313 Choral Conducting
courses.description: The relation of conducting gestures to choral sound; development of practical skills in directing ensembles and reading scores; attendant issues of vocal technique and pedagogy.

courses.name: MICB 412 Topics in Immunological Research
courses.description: Presentations, library research, paper reviews and class discussion on selected areas of advanced molecular and cellular immunological research.
courses.prerequisites: MICB 302 and one of MICB 402, MEDG 410.

courses.name: EPSE 553 Theories of Cognitive Assessment
courses.description: Theoretical foundations and issues concerning the nature, measurement, and understanding of cognitive abilities of children and youth.

courses.name: FREN 370 Introduction to French Linguistics
courses.description: A survey of basic terminology, methods, problems, and theoretical trends in French linguistics, specifically designed to provide students with a foundation for advanced language study in French.

courses.name: MECH 327 Thermal System Design
courses.description: Air standard cycles; first and second law of cycles.  Gas mixtures.  Energy conservation. Equilibrium. Reacting systems. Fluid flow, heat transfer, and material considerations. Economic and environmental impact of energy use. Application to thermofluid systems such as power plants.
courses.corequisites: MECH 325 and one of MECH 328, ENPH 253, IGEN 330.

courses.name: LAW 488 Clinical Term
courses.description: Designed to explore the legal system in relation to disadvantaged members of society. Under supervision, students will act for clients in a range of legal matters and can expect to appear before courts and tribunals. Students will also work with community-based organisations. Credit will be granted for only one of LAW 474, LAW 490, or LAW 491. Pass/Fail.

courses.name: BIOL 415 Evolutionary Processes in Plants
courses.description: Experimental and comparative analysis of evolutionary processes, speciation, and phylogenetic patterns in plants.

courses.name: PHYS 107 Enriched Physics 1
courses.description: Classical mechanics including conservation laws, angular momentum of rigid bodies and simple harmonic motion, wave phenomena, with an introduction to special relativity, quantum mechanics, nuclear physics, statistical mechanics and solid state physics. Please consult the Faculty of Science credit exclusion lists: http://www.calendar.ubc.ca/vancouver/index.cfm?tree=12,215,410,414
courses.prerequisites: Either (a) a score of 85% or higher in PHYS 12 and a score of 85% or higher in MATH 12;  or (b) a score of 85% or higher in PHYS 100 or (c) a score of 85% or higher in PHYS 12 and a score of 85% or higher in PREC 12. (MATH 12 = Principles of Mathematics 12; PREC 12 = Pre-calculus 12.)
courses.corequisites: One of MATH 100, MATH 102, MATH 104, MATH 120, MATH 180, MATH 184.

courses.name: PHIL 314A Philosophy in the 17th Century - PHILL 17TH CENT
courses.description: Survey of 17th-century philosophy from Bacon to Leibniz, including the writings of Hobbes, Descartes, and Spinoza. The influence of science and religion on philosophical thought.

courses.name: LARC 582E Seminar: Special Topics - LIVING ROOF SEM
CELL 508 Molecular Genetic Analysis
courses.description: Methodologies and resources for genetic analysis of cellular function.

courses.name: CHEM 341 Global Challenges: A Chemical Perspective
courses.description: Importance of chemistry in society. Detailed case studies drawn from modern chemistry: human health, energy, commodity chemicals, materials, green chemistry, agriculture.

courses.name: ASIA 369 Asian Folklore
courses.description: A survey of oral and expressive traditions in Asia, including jokes, superstitions, fairy tales, myths, music, and foodways; practical training in collecting and archiving folklore.

courses.name: LFS 399 Co-operative Work Placement II
courses.description: Work experience in relevant private and/or public sector settings.  Work terms are normally four months long.  Restricted to students admitted to the Co-op Program in Land and Food Systems. Pass/Fail.

courses.name: MUSC 207C Composition II - COMPOSITION 2
courses.description: Continuation of MUSC 107.
courses.prerequisites: MUSC 107. (and permission of Composition Division based on submission of scores.)

courses.name: CLST 311 Women in the Bronze Age, Classical Greek and Hellenistic Cultures
courses.description: The images projected in mythology, literature, and art are compared with realities of women's lives insofar as they can be reconstructed from historical, legal, and archaeological records.

courses.name: RHSC 504B Directed Studies in Rehabilitation - DST REHABILIT'N
ENGL 222 Literature in Canada
courses.description: The major types of Canadian writing: fiction, poetry, non-fictional prose, and drama
courses.prerequisites: Either (a) ARTS 001 or (b) two of ENGL 100, ENGL 110, ENGL 111, ENGL 112, ENGL 120, ENGL 121 or (c) ASTU 100 or (d) ASTU 150 and one of ENGL 110, ENGL 111, ENGL 120, ENGL 121;  or (e) WRDS 150 and one of ENGL 110, ENGL 111, ENGL 120, ENGL 121. (Or 6 credits of first-year English.)

courses.name: THTR 547A Directed Studies in Theatre and Drama and Film/Television - DIRECTED STUDIES
KIN 284 Physical Growth and Motor Development
courses.description: Characteristics of physical growth and motor development related to physical activity; factors affecting, and measurement of, physical growth and motor development.

courses.name: MUSC 521A Seminar in Performance Practices - PERFORMANCE PRAC
courses.description: Studies in the theoretical and practical problems of musical interpretation.

courses.name: VISA 352 Intermediate Print Media III: Interdisciplinary Approaches to Image Production
courses.description: Lithographic printing; suitable for students interested in drawing and print media interface in context of contemporary art; related digital and photographic technologies employed.
courses.prerequisites: Either (a) one of VISA 220, VISA 250 or (b) one of VISA 281, FINA 281, VISA 283, VISA 284, VISA 290, FINA 283, FINA 284, FINA 290.

courses.name: RHSC 583B Applying Research to Practice - APPLY RSRCH PRAC
COGS 401 Seminar in Cognitive Systems
courses.description: Interdisciplinary seminar integrating theory, methods, and current research topics.

courses.name: FOOD 511 Master of Food Science Workshops
courses.description: Honours/Pass/Fail.

courses.name: SOWK 416 Advanced Integrative Seminar in Social Work Theory, Policy and Practice
courses.description: Development of professional judgement, evaluation, and self-evaluation in practice.

courses.name: DENT 771 Orthodontic and Dentofacial Orthopedic Clinics I
courses.description: Continues in second year.

courses.name: ENGL 344A Medieval Studies - MEDIEVAL STUDIES
courses.prerequisites: (3rd year standing and 6 credits of first-year English, or Arts One, or 6 credits of ASTU 100 from CAP or 3 credits of first-year English and 3 credits of ASTU 150)

courses.name: MEDI 570 Cardiovascular Pathophysiology
courses.description: Pathogenesis, abnormal physiology and therapeutic approaches in heart disease including cardiac arrhythmia, heart failure, myocardial infarction, hypertension, atherosclerosis.

courses.name: WOOD 384 Wood Sawmilling and Drying
courses.description: Introduction to primary log breakdown systems and lumber material flow in modern sawmills and planermills. Lumber drying equipment and methods.

courses.name: THTR 391C Rehearsal and Performance - REHEARS&PERFORM
courses.description: Open only to  B.F.A. Acting students.
courses.prerequisites: All of THTR 271, THTR 272, THTR 273, THTR 274.

courses.name: BAMA 514 Brand Management
courses.description: Restricted to students in one of the following programs: M.B.A., J.D./M.B.A., M.B.A./M.A.A.P.S., M.Sc.B., M.M., I.M.B.A.; or a Ph.D. with a BADM specialization.

courses.name: PHIL 435A Environmental Ethics - ENVIROMNTL ETHIC
courses.description: Moral problems arising in the context of human relationships to nature and to non-human living things, considered in terms of both general moral theory and policy formation. Topics include moral standing, animal rights, obligations to future generations, pollution, hazardous materials, the depletion of natural resources and the treatment of non-human living things.

courses.name: FREN 457 Translation II
courses.description: Advanced translation.

courses.name: GEOB 206 Geomorphic Processes and Hazards
courses.description: Earth surface processes shaping the landscape; identification of hazards and hazardous areas associated with these processes; introduction to techniques for measurement and analysis at various spatial and time scales; field trips are required.
courses.prerequisites: One of GEOB 103, EOSC 110, PHYS 101, PHYS 107, PHYS 153, SCIE 001.

courses.name: NURS 590A Directed Studies in Nursing - DIRECTED STUDIES
EDCP 305 Digital Media in Arts Education: Introduction
MUSC 135 Opera Repertoire I
courses.description: A musico-dramatic study and analysis of representative works in the international operatic theatre from 1600 to the present, through musical, literary and graphic sources. Each sequential year of study, the student is expected to show increased facility in musical and dramatic analysis as well as a greater understanding of the works under examination. Open to students outside the B.Mus. program by permission of the instructor.

courses.name: FRST 524 Environmental Perception
courses.description: Perceptual processes mediating behaviour in humans, with special attention given to the emotional processing of visual stimuli.

courses.name: IWME 503 Chemical and Biological Industrial Water Treatment Design
courses.description: Fundamental principles of process design for chemical and biological systems to treat water used in and effluents generated from industrial processes. Industry application examples: mining, oil sands, oil and gas, pulp and paper, agriculture, food and beverage.

courses.name: MUSC 319A Introduction to Electroacoustic Music - INTRO ELECRO MUS
courses.description: Study of acoustics, audio technology, and electroacoustic composition. Composition of original works using facilities of the UBC Electroacoustic Music Studio.
courses.prerequisites: MUSC 119 and one of MUSC 100, MUSC 110. (Permission of instructor is also required.)

courses.name: BIOL 548H Advanced Topics in Biology - ADV TOPICS BIOL
COEC 394 Government and Business
courses.description: Roles of government and business in the Canadian economy including effects of public policy on the business environment. Ethical foundations of government, business and personal decision-making. Credit will be granted for only one of COEC 392 or COMM 294.

courses.name: FRST 588 Fluvial Ecohydrology
courses.description: Hydrology, geomorphology and ecology of streams and their catchments; significance of stream processes within the fluvial network; management issues, particularly in the context of forest harvesting.

courses.name: CONS 340 Introduction to Geographic Information Systems for Forestry and Conservation
courses.description: Introduction to principles, practice and context of Geographic Information Systems (GIS) applied to forest management and natural resource conservation issues. Priority enrolment to students in the Faculty of Forestry.

courses.name: LAW 467C Topics in Corporate Law - TPCS CORP LAW
courses.description: Not offered each year, consult Faculty.

courses.name: FIST 434B Studies in Film - STUDIES IN FILM
courses.description: A seminar devoted to a topic of current interest in film. Topic will change from year to year. May be repeated for credit when topics differ.

courses.name: ARCH 571A Seminar: Technology and Analysis - CMNCTG CNSTRCTN
courses.description: Topics across a range of building material and construction technology-based subject matter.

courses.name: LAW 303 The Western Idea of Law
courses.description: A comparative and interdisciplinary study of the evolution of Western law from its origins in mythology and patriarchy through to the present time. Not offered each year, consult Faculty.

courses.name: CIVL 581 Soil Dynamics for Design Practice
courses.description: Seismic loading and its effect on earth structures; dynamic response of single, and multi-degree of freedom systems and continuous systems; behaviour of soil under dynamic loading; pore pressure generation and liquefaction effects; seismicity and seismic design parameters; dynamic analysis of earth structures; seismic design of soil-structure systems.

courses.name: EDCP 498 Curriculum Inquiry in Home Economics Education
courses.description: Culminating inquiry in curriculum and pedagogy for the Home Economics Education Diploma.

courses.name: BIOC 548B Directed Studies - DIRECTED STUDIES
courses.description: In special cases, with approval of the department head, advanced courses may be arranged for graduate students in attendance.

courses.name: MICB 301 Microbial Ecophysiology
courses.description: Dynamics and control of prokaryotic cellular processes in response to the biotic and abiotic environment including metabolic interactions and metabolic cooperation between microorganisms.
courses.prerequisites: Either (a) all of BIOL 201, MICB 201 or (b) BIOT 380.

courses.name: THTR 521 Styles in Directing
courses.description: An advanced course in directing; detailed study of the major styles in the history of production.

courses.name: NURS 427 Consolidated Practicum

courses.name: ENGL 545B Studies in Canadian Literature - STUDIES CAN LIT

courses.name: MIDW 350 Inter-Professional Placement

Note: Students who intend to use RUSS 101, 102 and 200 to satisfy the Faculty of Arts language requirement must register for both RUSS 101 and 102 in the same year.

courses.name: PHAR 648 Seminar for Ph.D. Students
courses.description: Attendance at regular seminars throughout the session and presentation of one or more papers on selected topics.

courses.name: MINE 590B Special Advanced Topics - MINE PRJ ECONMC

courses.name: MEDI 502 Experimental Medicine Methodology

courses.description: Introduces the student to the clinically relevant basic sciences and pathophysiological events of the human gastrointestinal (GI) tract comprising the oral cavity and teeth, esophagus, stomach, bowel, exocrine pancreas, liver and biliary tree as well as the fundamental principles of human nutrition.

courses.name: EPSE 592 Experimental Designs and Analysis in Educational Research
courses.prerequisites: EPSE 482. (EPSE 483 may not be used as a prerequisite to EPSE 592.)

courses.name: KIN 499 Projects in Kinesiology
courses.description: Provides opportunities to perform research pertaining to a chosen area of kinesiology.
courses.prerequisites: (Fourth-year standing and permission of the Associate Director, Undergraduate Program.))

courses.name: COMM 386E Topics in Business III - SOCIAL ENTRPRISE
MUSC 533E Advanced Studies in Music Theory - ANALYSIS & PERF
courses.description: Advanced seminar in music theory.  May be repeated for credit if different topics are covered.

courses.name: DPAS 410 Doctor, Patient and Society
courses.description: This multidisciplinary course will examine critical issues in health care. Problem-based tutorials will address the patient-doctor relationship, health care systems, research, epidemiology, prevention, ethics, behavioural and social sciences, resource allocation, multiculturalism, and marginalized populations.

courses.name: AUDI 660B Seminar in Hearing Science - SEM HEARING SCIE
BA 551 Business Capstone
courses.description: Pass/fail.  Registration restricted to students in the M.M. Program.

courses.name: KIN 415 Conceptual Approaches to Games Education
courses.description: Examination of developmentally appropriate conceptual and tactical approaches to team game instruction.

courses.name: NAME 524 Shipbuilding Project Management
courses.description: Terminology; planning; scheduling; budgeting and cost accounting; risk management; quality control; shipbuilding applications.

courses.name: POLI 420D Advanced Topics in Comparative Politics - ADV TPCS CMP PLI
courses.description: Seminar in comparative analysis of politics in democratic systems. For specific content in a given year, consult the departmental website.
courses.prerequisites: Two of POLI 220, POLI 320, POLI 321, POLI 322, POLI 323, POLI 324, POLI 325, POLI 326, POLI 327, POLI 328, POLI 329, POLI 330, POLI 331, POLI 332, POLI 333, POLI 350, POLI 351.

courses.name: ITST 415 Topics in the Italian Literature and Culture of the Renaissance in Translation
courses.description: Masterpieces of the Italian Renaissance in literature and the other arts. Authors and artists studied range from Pico to Ariosto and Machiavelli, from Botticelli to Leonardo and Michelangelo. Precludes credit for ITAL 405.

courses.name: KIN 101 Co-operative Work Placement
courses.description: Supervised, technical work experience in an established company or organization for a minimum of three months. Technical report. Restricted to students meeting the requirements of the School of Kinesiology and the Co-operative Education Program.  Pass/Fail.

courses.name: CNPS 578C Individual and Family Counselling Theories and Interventions - IND&FAM CNSL T&I
courses.description: Major counselling theories, interventions for change and corresponding skill development.

courses.name: THTR 408B Advanced Study in Design and Scenography - ADV STDY DSGN
courses.description: Topics will vary from year to year. Consent of Department required.

courses.name: LAW 460 Advanced Corporate Law
courses.description: Selected topics such as the nature of shares, equity financing, corporate structure and reorganization, and shareholder squeezeouts.

courses.name: BMEG 410 Biomedical Equipment, Physiology, and Anatomy
courses.description: Principles and operation of biomedical equipment for cardiovascular system, respiratory system, renal dialysis, endoscopy, surgery, and imaging. Functional relationships of biomedical equipment to physiology and anatomy of major body systems. Restricted to students in EECE and MECH Biomedical Engineering options.

courses.name: LIBR 514H Topics in the Bibliographic Control of Information - TPCS BBL CTL INF
KIN 454C Field Experience - FIELD EXPERIENCE
courses.description: Students have the opportunity to develop their leadership, instruction, and professional skills in a variety of supervised fieldwork settings. Students should select the section of the course (A, B) most relevant to their program of study and career goals.

courses.name: COMM 298 Introduction to Finance
courses.description: Introduces the basic principles of financial valuation, including the time-value of money and the risk/return tradeoff. Develops tools for the quantitative analysis of corporate and/or individual financing and saving decisions, and of capital budgeting decisions. Credit will be granted for only one of COMM 298 or COEC 298.
courses.prerequisites: All of COMM 290, COMM 293 and one of COMM 295, ECON 201, ECON 301.

courses.name: EDUC 278 Teaching Biology
courses.description: For Dadaab, Kenya teacher education students.

courses.name: THTR 450 Scenery Production II
courses.description: Technical direction; complex techniques and problems in scenery production.

courses.name: CHEM 218 Fundamentals of Reactivity in Inorganic Chemistry
courses.description: Chemical reactivity of inorganic systems: oxidation/reduction chemistry; multiply-bonded systems; main group chemistry.

courses.name: ANAE 430 Introduction to Anesthesia
courses.description: Patient assessment and preparation for surgery, conduct of general and regional anesthesia and airway management.

courses.name: MATH 221 Matrix Algebra
courses.description: Systems of linear equations, operations on matrices, determinants, eigenvalues and eigenvectors, diagonalization of symmetric matrices. Please consult the Faculty of Science Credit Exclusion List: www.students.ubc.ca/calendar/index.cfm?tree=12,215,410,414.
courses.prerequisites: Either (a) a score of 64% or higher in one of MATH 100, MATH 102, MATH 104, MATH 110, MATH 120, MATH 180, MATH 184 or (b) one of MATH 101, MATH 103, MATH 105, MATH 121, SCIE 001. (or (c) advanced credit for MATH 100.)

courses.name: APBI 398 Research Methods in Applied Animal Biology

courses.name: DENT 591 Endodontic Case Management I

courses.name: MUSC 169B Intensive Chamber Ensemble - INT CHMB ENS

courses.name: ECON 442 Issues in Economic Development

courses.name: SPPH 523 Global Health and Human Security
courses.description: Global threats to human health stemming from conflict, poverty, and environmental degradation.

courses.name: LING 451 Acquisition of Phonology
courses.description: Development of the phonological system in typical first language acquisition from the perspective of diverse linguistic topics. Phonetic transcription of child speech.

courses.name: CHBE 456 Heterogenous Catalysis and Advanced Reactor Design
courses.description: Definition of heterogeneous catalysis; properties of catalysts; kinetics of catalytic reactions; ideal heterogeneous reactors; non-isothermal reactor design; mass and heat transfer effects in heterogeneous reactors; examples of industrial reactors.

courses.name: LATN 101 First-Year Latin I
courses.description: Classical Latin for students with no previous knowledge of Latin, Part I.

courses.name: FIPR 399A Directed Studies: Off-Campus Research - DS: OFF-CAMP RES
courses.description: Off-campus film production field research. Based on film project work outside the university.

courses.name: ANTH 541 Advanced Seminar in Critical Museum Anthropology

courses.name: LAW 489 Clinical Term: Paper
courses.description: The graded component of LAW 488.

courses.name: APBI 415 Applied Animal Behaviour
courses.description: Application of principles and research methods of animal behaviour to practical problems in the care of farm, companion, wild and research animals, and in animal training, and human-wildlife conflict.

courses.name: ANTH 300A Contemporary Anthropological Theory - CONTMP ANTH THRY
courses.description: Contemporary approaches to society and culture in anthropology.

courses.name: MINE 486 Mining and The Environment
courses.description: Environmental topics of importance to engineers practicing within the mining, metallurgical and related industries including technical practices, regulatory and public issues.

courses.name: HIST 358 State and Society in 20th century Cuba
courses.description: The history and historiography of 20th century Cuba, with particular attention to changing state structures and their impact on everyday life.

courses.name: CONS 101 Introduction to Conservation
courses.description: Seminars on current natural resources conservation and forest sciences topics.

courses.name: PHAR 342 Pharmacology II
courses.description: Principles of chemotherapy and drug resistance and the pharmacology of selected drug classes.

courses.name: POLI 324A Southeast Asian Government and Politics - S E ASIA GOVT

courses.name: ENGL 359A Studies in Romanticism - STDY ROMANTICISM
courses.prerequisites: (3rd year standing and 6 credits of first-year English, or Arts One, or 6 credits of ASTU 100 from CAP or 3 credits of first-year English and 3 credits of ASTU 150)

courses.name: CPSC 322 Introduction to Artificial Intelligence
courses.description: Problem-solving and planning; state/action models and graph searching. Natural language understanding Computational vision. Applications of artificial intelligence.
courses.prerequisites: Either (a) CPSC 221 or (b) all of CPSC 260, EECE 320 and one of CPSC 210, EECE 210, EECE 309.

courses.name: ENGL 535A Studies in the Victorian Period - STD IN VICT ERA
APBI 312 Animal Physiology II

courses.name: EDUC 503A Ethnography and Education - ETHNOGRHY & EDUC
LLED 552 Theoretical Foundations of Reading Research and Practice

courses.name: LIBR 620 Advanced Study in Major Area
MUSC 553 University Singers
courses.description: Open only to graduate students.

courses.name: CIVL 200 Engineering and Sustainable Development
courses.description: Implications of a finite biosphere and the complexities inherent in environmental decision-making.

courses.name: MATH 313 Topics in Number Theory
courses.description: Topics chosen by the instructor. These might include: division algorithms, group theory, continued fractions, primality testing, factoring.  Please consult the Faculty of Science Credit Exclusion List: www.students.ubc.ca/calendar/index.cfm?tree=12,215,410,414.

courses.name: FNIS 451 Indigenous Feminisms
courses.description: The historical, cultural, political, and activist roots of contemporary Indigenous feminisms. Indigenous feminist methodologies, theory, and praxis in relation to contemporary Indigenous politics and social justice movements. Credit will be granted for only one of FNSP 401D, FNIS 451, or FNSP 451.
courses.prerequisites: One of FNSP 200, FNIS 210, FNSP 210, FNIS 220, FNSP 220. (or third-year standing.)

courses.name: EPSE 586 Analyzing Discourse and Talk: An Overview of Methods
courses.description: Credit will be granted for only one of EPSE 586, LLED 501, and LLED 575.

courses.name: BIOL 525B Topics in Systematics and Evolution - TPC SYST & EVLTN

courses.name: RMES 520 Climate Change: Science, Technology and Sustainable Development
courses.description: Interdisciplinary science of climate change and its impacts; options for mitigation and adaptation.

courses.name: ELEC 441 Control Systems
courses.description: Relationships between system parameters and system responses for linear control systems. Design specifications for dynamic and steady-state performance and realization by use of feedback control. Robust design of PID controllers and multivariable controllers.

courses.name: LAW 552C Topics in Common Law Theory and Practice: Public Law I - PUBLIC LAW I

courses.name: CIVL 446 Engineering Design and Analysis II

courses.name: PHAR 410 Pharmaceutical Research: From Bench to Bedside and Beyond
courses.description: Basic, translational, clinical, and community-based research.

courses.name: GERM 301 German Literature 1900 - 1945 (in English)
courses.description: Reading and discussion of selected works against the background of literary, social, and political developments in twentieth-century Germany with special emphasis on plays and novels dealing with the First World War and Nazism.

courses.name: STAT 548A Directed Studies in Statistics - DIRECTED STUDIES
