courses.description: Studio-based experience in thinking strategies and design processes applied to business innovation in the private, public, and social sectors. Emphasis on problem solving, co-creation, and innovation for external clients in a collaborative environment.

courses.name: BMEG 500 Orientation to Clinical Environment
courses.description: Operation of biomedical and clinical engineering facilities at hospitals. Daily activities of healthcare workers. Patients? experience.

courses.name: LLED 201 Critical Reading and Writing in Academic and Professional Registers

courses.name: ARCH 403 Themes in Architecture and Design

courses.name: SOCI 350B Sociological Theories: Classical and Contemporary Approaches - SOCI THEORIES

courses.name: FIPR 469G Special Projects - SPECIAL PROJECTS
courses.description: Advanced film production, including interdisciplinary projects.

courses.name: PHAR 303 Pharmacy Skills II
courses.description: Legal, technical and professional aspects of dispensing prescriptions and providing pharmaceutical care, primarily for community pharmacy practice.

courses.name: ARCH 517 Design Media II

courses.name: EDCP 556 Theory and Research in the Social Context of School Science

courses.name: ARCH 405 Architectural History II

Examine questions such as whether a sophisticated enough computer should be deemed a conscious intelligent being. Focus on philosophical literature on consciousness, intelligence, animal minds, and the mind-body relation.

courses.name: FRST 395 Forest Wildlife Ecology and Management

courses.name: CHIN 433 Classical Chinese II (Heritage)

courses.prerequisites: One of CHIN 313, CHIN 314, CHIN 317, CHIN 318, CHIN 323.

courses.prerequisites: Either (a) PSYC 100 or (b) all of PSYC 101, PSYC 102. (or (c) 6 credits of 200-level Psychology (but not 205 or 263).)

courses.name: GEOB 503A Topics in Geomorphology and Hydrology - TPCS GEMO & HYDR

courses.description: Current and emerging themes in bacterial pathogenesis including cellular microbiology, bacterial cell biology processes and their role in virulence including secretion systems to deliver virulence factors and immune evasion strategies employed by pathogens.  Development of antibiotics and resistance to antibiotics.

courses.prerequisites: One of STAT 200, STAT 241, STAT 251, BIOL 300, COMM 291, ECON 325, FRST 231, PSYC 218, PSYC 366.

courses.prerequisites: Either (a) all of CPSC 213, CPSC 221 or (b) all of CPSC 210, CPSC 213, CPSC 260, EECE 320.

courses.name: EPSE 577 Seminar in Assessment and Positive Behaviour Support in School and Community Settings
ELEC 271 Selected Topics in Biomedical Engineering
courses.description: Effective communication in a multidisciplinary environment, introduction to emerging areas of biomedical engineering and biotechnology, ethics, and responsibility. Restricted to students admitted to the Biomedical Engineering program in Electrical Engineering.

courses.name: COMM 205 Introduction to Management Information Systems
courses.description: Overview of computer technology and terminology; use of computers as managerial and administrative tools; the management of computer resources and the influence of information technology within the organization. Credit will be granted for only one of COMM 205 or COMM 391.

courses.name: ENGL 232 Approaches to Media Studies
courses.description: Approaches to the study of media: philosophical; technological; cultural; theoretical.

courses.name: MUSC 249 Collaborative Piano II
courses.description: Further development of skills and performance practice with primary emphasis on voice/piano partnership principles and repertoire. Strong sight-reading skills essential. For Piano majors; open to others by audition.

courses.name: THTR 491C Advanced Rehearsal and Performance - AD REHEARS&PERF
courses.description: Open only to B.F.A. Acting students.

courses.name: LLED 489B Applied Linguistics for Teachers - APPL LING TEACH
ARST 556E Topics in Archival Automation - TPCS ARCH AUTMTN
MUSC 193B Music Performance (Major) - VOICE
courses.description: Private instruction, vocal or instrumental.

courses.name: PLAN 550C Directed Studies - DIRECTED STUDIES
courses.description: In special cases and with the approval of the Director of the school, a student may study an advanced topic under the direction of a faculty member.

courses.name: EDCP 551 Mathematics Education: Current Issues
courses.description: An advanced course in curriculum and pedagogy.

courses.name: LLED 386 Secondary Theatre: Introduction to Curriculum and Pedagogy
courses.description: Pass/Fail.

courses.name: EPSE 591 Theory and Practice of Program Evaluation
HUNU 547E Directed Studies - DIRECTED STUDIES
courses.description: In special cases, directed studies on certain aspects of nutrition may be arranged for graduate students in attendance.

courses.name: ARCH 505 Architectural History 1B
courses.description: Debates in modern and contemporary architectural thought, including critical analysis of the contribution of the 20th century producers of architecture, engineering, and industrial design.

courses.name: FRE 490 Current Issues in Food and Resource Economics
PATH 300 Background to Medical Laboratory Science
courses.description: Introductory lectures and laboratory sessions in clinical chemistry, haematology and blood banking, hospital microbiology, preparation and examination of tissue sections. For Medical Laboratory Science students without previous experience in hospital laboratories.
courses.prerequisites: All of BIOL 112, BIOL 200, BIOL 201, CHEM 123, CHEM 205, CHEM 233, CHEM 235, MICB 202.

courses.name: MECH 457 Mechanical Engineering Design Project
courses.description: A capstone design project designed to give students experience in the design/development of practical mechanical devices. Projects are provided by local industry and engineering research laboratories. Credit will be given for only one of: MECH 454, MECH 457, MECH 458, MECH 459, or APSC 496.
courses.prerequisites: MECH 328. (and fourth-year standing in Mechanical Engineering.)

courses.name: ORPA 722 Paediatric Orthopaedics
courses.description: Case presentation in paediatric orthopaedics, stressing history, physical findings and total management of the patient, including a review of paediatric fractures with x-rays.

courses.name: ENDS 440 Environment and Urban Form
courses.description: Relationships between, and integration of, the natural environment and the physical form, spatial structure, and livability of cities.

courses.name: SPAN 501B Theoretical Approaches to Literature - TH APPR LIT
SPPH 581C Selected Topics - DATA ANALYSIS
courses.description: By seminar and directed readings, certain topics of current interest are explored in depth.

courses.name: LING 546C Directed Reading in Topics related to Linguistics - DIRECTED READING

courses.description: Introduces network concepts and methods for exploring social and organizational connectivity for work, socializing, and knowledge production. Examines impact of social media on connections that span space and place; peer production on authority structures; ubiquitous mobile connectivity on daily life.

courses.name: FRE 374 Land and Resource Economics
courses.description: Willingness to pay, opportunity costs, externalities, and market failures in natural resource markets; dynamic efficiency; economic applications including mineral, marine, forest, land, water, and biodiversity.

courses.name: RUSS 206 Nineteenth-Century Russian Writers in Translation
courses.description: The writings, lives, and thought of selected authors.

courses.name: ASTR 311 Exploring the Universe II: Stars and Galaxies
courses.description: A survey of recent discoveries in modern astronomy without the use of advanced mathematics. Stars, pulsars, black holes, galaxies, quasars and the origin and evolution of the Universe. Not open to first year students and not for credit in the Faculties of Science and Applied Science.

courses.name: MICB 353 Food Microbiology Laboratory
courses.description: Procedures and principles associated with isolation, enumeration, characterization and handling of microorganisms. Restricted to students registered in the Food Science program.

courses.name: MUSC 402B Special Projects - SPECIAL PROJECTS
courses.description: For fourth-year students who receive permission of the Director of the School of Music to do advanced studies in their major field.

courses.name: PLAN 548W Current Issues in Planning - WORK-NON PROFITS
courses.description: Each year the school may offer one or more courses on a topical issue covering recent advances in the field.

courses.name: GEOB 270 Geographic Information Science

courses.name: COMM 362 Consumer Behaviour

courses.name: MUSC 562B Wind and Percussion Chamber Ensembles - BRASS CHAMB ENS
courses.description: Open only to graduate students.

courses.name: LAW 353 Aboriginal and Treaty Rights

courses.name: PLAN 548N Current Issues in Planning - ECOLOG FOOTPRINT
courses.description: Each year the school may offer one or more courses on a topical issue covering recent advances in the field.

courses.name: CLST 307 Greek Law
courses.description: The study of Greek legal theory, practice, and institutions from their origin in self-help, through the early lawgivers and their codes, to the developed system of Athens in the fifth and fourth centuries. A variety of test cases from the works of the Greek orators will be explored.

courses.name: JRNL 520D Special Topics in Contemporary Journalism - REPRT INDGENOUS

courses.prerequisites: Either (a) GEOG 101 or (b) all of GEOG 102, GEOG 103 or (c) all of GEOB 102, GEOB 103.

courses.name: COMM 390 Business Writing
courses.description: An activity-focused course providing the opportunity to study and practice forms of writing needed in business.
courses.prerequisites: One of ENGL 112, ASTU 150, WRDS 150, ENGL 100, ENGL 120, ENGL 121. (ENGL 1st, Arts One, a minimum of 18 cr. of Coordinated Arts Program.)

courses.name: KIN 469 Chronic Health Issues, Physical Activity, and Community Practice
courses.description: Issues related to physical activity and public health. Focus on community interventions.  Creation of activity plans that promote physical, mental, and/or social well-being in persons dealing with chronic health issues. Community service-learning component.

courses.name: FREN 409C Studies in French Literature of the Seventeenth Century - FR 17TH CENT LIT
courses.description: Topics may include works by Corneille, Racine, Moli?re, Descartes, Pascal, La Fontaine, and Mme de la Fayette.
courses.prerequisites: One of FREN 320, FREN 321, FREN 328, FREN 329, FREN 330.

courses.name: ARTH 540A Studies in 20th Century Art - 20TH CENT ART
MTRL 489 Seminar III
courses.description: Training and practice in public speaking and presentation of technical papers.

courses.name: LIBE 461 Administration of the School Library Resource Centre
courses.description: The role, philosophy, and management of school library resource centres in elementary and secondary schools.

courses.name: ENGL 362 Studies in a Nineteenth-Century Genre
courses.prerequisites: (3rd year standing and 6 credits of first-year English, or Arts One, or 6 credits of ASTU 100 from CAP or 3 credits of first-year English and 3 credits of ASTU 150)

courses.name: KIN 275 Exercise Physiology I
courses.description: Acute and chronic effects of exercise on body systems; basic concepts of cardiovascular, respiratory and muscular responses to physical activity.

courses.name: CNRS 502B Studies in Law and Society - STUDIES LAW
BIOL 463 Gene Regulation in Development
courses.description: Control of gene expression in development; the genetic and physiological basis of epigenetic determination; inductive interactions.
courses.prerequisites: BIOL 335 and one of BIOC 300, BIOC 302, BIOC 303. (BIOL 331 is recommended.)

courses.name: RMES 516 Urban Watershed Management
courses.description: Urban land use impacts on water resources with a focus on impervious surfaces, storm-water management, non-point sources of pollution, cumulative effects, water quality, rehabilitation of urban streams and application of best management practices. Prior completion of RMES 515 strongly recommended.  Credit will be given for only one of RMES 516 or SOIL 516.

courses.name: MUSC 508C Composition - COMPOSITION
courses.description: A continuation of MUSC 507.

courses.name: MUSC 307C Composition III - COMPOSITION III
courses.description: Continuation of MUSC 207.
courses.prerequisites: MUSC 207. (and permission of Composition Division based on submission of scores.)

courses.name: PHAR 414 Problems in Pharmaceutics and Biopharmaceutics
courses.description: Individual assignments involving library and laboratory investigation of problems involved in the development of pharmaceutical dosage forms.

courses.name: CLST 301 The Technical Terms of Medicine and Biological Science
courses.description: Acquaints the student with the Greek and Latin elements from which most specialized terms of modern medicine are constructed. Intended primarily for students planning to enter the medical, pharmaceutical, or biological sciences.

courses.name: MRNE 415 Structure and Function in Marine Animals
courses.description: Principles of classification, evolution, morphology, biomechanics, physiology and biochemistry will be illustrated in representatives from a variety of animal phyla.
courses.prerequisites: (Completion of second year in a biology program.)

courses.name: MUSC 136C Piano Repertoire I - PIANO REPERT I
courses.description: Performance and discussion of the repertoire for string-keyboard instruments essential to the performer and teacher. Special attention to matters of structure, style, and performance practices. Required of piano performance majors and open to piano concentrators, space permitting. First term prerequisite to second term.

courses.name: CHEM 407 Statistical Mechanics in Chemistry
courses.description: Introductory concepts of statistical mechanics and statistical thermodynamics. Applications to chemistry with emphasis on understanding chemical reactivity. Credit will not be given for CHEM 503/CHEM 407 and PHYS 455.

courses.name: ATSC 506 Numerical Techniques for Ocean, Atmosphere and Earth Scientists
courses.description: Credit will not be granted for both ATSC 409 and ATSC 506/EOSC 511.

courses.name: SOCI 285 Citizenship and Identity
courses.description: The concepts of citizenship, identity, and human rights as social processes shaping individuals and communities (both local and global).

courses.name: NURS 586I Specialized Domains of Nursing Practice - SP D NURS PRAC
AUDI 670C Seminar in Developmental Phonetics and Phonology - SEM DEVL PH&PHL
courses.description: Examination of current research, roles of theories in understanding the relationship between speech sound production and comprehension/perception.

courses.name: ENGL 555A Studies in Literature and the Other Arts - STDIES LIT/ARTS
CNPS 504 School Counselling
courses.description: Theory and practice of elementary school counselling.

courses.name: MIDW 430 Comprehensive Midwifery Theory and Practice
courses.description: In-depth review of the theoretical principles and evidence basis for comprehensive midwifery care.  Tutorials are carried out in an online live classroom setting.

courses.name: PSYC 217 Research Methods
courses.description: Focus on various research methods used in psychology, with an emphasis on critical thinking and experimental design.  Restricted to students in the Faculty of Arts who have declared their major in one of Psychology, Cognitive Systems, or Speech Sciences (Linguistics Department).

courses.name: ASIA 372 Development of Traditional Chinese Thought
courses.description: Chinese thought from the Han dynasty (206 BCE to 220 CE) to Wang Yangming (1472-1529) in its historical and cultural contexts. Prerequisite: ASIA 371.

courses.name: APSC 210 Co-operative Work Placement
courses.description: Supervised, technical work experience in an established company or organization for a minimum of three months. Technical report. Restricted to students meeting the requirements of the Faculty of Applied Science and the Co-operative Education Program.

courses.name: MUSC 530A Topics in Ethnomusicology - TEACHING WLD MUS
courses.description: Topics involving methodology and fieldwork in non-Western traditions. Topics will vary and students should consult the School as to areas of focus in any given term.

courses.name: CRWR 501B Advanced Writing of Poetry I - ADV POETRY I
PLAN 548O Current Issues in Planning - PRPRTY & LEGAL
courses.description: Each year the school may offer one or more courses on a topical issue covering recent advances in the field.

courses.name: HIST 403A Seminar in the History of International Relations - INTRNATNL RELTNS
courses.description: Selected topics in the history of international relations. Priority for registration will be given to fourth-year majors in the International Relations and History programs.

courses.name: GEOG 220 Geopolitics
courses.description: Political geographic perspectives on todays interdependent world through three themes: borders, regions, and flows.

courses.name: MEDG 565 Advanced Genetic Counselling Seminar
courses.description: Patient attitudes toward genetic counselling; the grieving process in response to pregnancy loss, death, and disability; risk perception, attitudes toward prenatal testing, dealing with results of genetic testing, crisis counselling, giving bad news; ethical dilemmas; legal and professional issues.
courses.prerequisites: MEDG 560. (And acceptance into M.Sc. Genetic Counselling program.)

courses.name: APSC 310 Co-operative Work Placement
courses.description: Supervised, technical work experience in an established company or organization for a minimum of three months. Technical report. Restricted to students meeting the requirements of the Faculty of Applied Science and the Co-operative Education Program.

courses.name: MINE 504 Rock Fragmentation
courses.description: Theory and practice of drilling and blasting; explosive types and strengths. Blast pattern design for underground and surface operations. Credit will be granted for only one of MINE 504 or MINE 565.

courses.name: EDUC 344 Issues in Indigenous Education
courses.description: Pass/Fail.

courses.name: FRST 576 Advanced Wood Mechanics
courses.description: Analysis and design of structural wood products, influences of material inhomogeneity and variability; creep and time dependent fracture phenomena; structural performance of wood products such as panel products, lumber, glued laminated timber and I-Beams. Impact of codes on marketing of structural wood products.

courses.name: ANTH 472 Anthropological Study of Social Inequality
courses.description: An anthropological perspective on the historical origins and theoretical explanations of social inequality.

courses.name: CHEM 250 Inorganic Chemistry
courses.description: Chemistry of selected groups of inorganic compounds, considered in relation to industrial processes.
courses.prerequisites: One of CHEM 113, CHEM 123, CHEM 154, SCIE 001.

courses.name: ENGL 462A Twentieth-Century British and Irish Studies - 20CENT BRIT & IR
courses.prerequisites: (3rd year standing and 6 credits of first-year English, or Arts One, or 6 credits of ASTU 100 from CAP or 3 credits of first-year English and 3 credits of ASTU 150)

courses.name: PHAR 351 Therapeutics I
courses.description: Rational drug therapy, management of patient-specific drug-related problems and therapeutic monitoring of selected disease states.

courses.name: EPSE 171 Education in the Adolescent Years
courses.description: For Dadaab, Kenya teacher education students.

courses.name: ANAT 448L Directed Studies in Anatomy - DIRECTED STUDIES
courses.description: Permission of the Head and supervisor required.

courses.name: SOIL 512B Advanced Soil Biology - ADV SOIL BIOL
courses.description: Current research in root-soil interfaces. Offered in alternate years.
courses.prerequisites: SOIL 321. (Permission of the instructor is also acceptable.)

courses.name: GEOG 525 Cultures of Nature in Contemporary Political Ecologies
BMEG 590 Biomedical Engineering Professional Skills
courses.description: Formulate and implement a professional skills development plan involving workshops on topics such as writing, presentation, teaching, finance, marketing, equity, ethics.  Pass/Fail grading.

courses.name: ENGL 496B Directed Readings in English Literature - DIRECTED READING
courses.description: For Honours students only.

courses.name: BIOC 402 Proteins: Structure and Function
courses.description: Structural components of proteins, classification by primary, secondary and tertiary structure, protein chemistry and purification, peptide and protein synthesis by chemical means and three-dimensional structure determination using X-ray diffraction and NMR.
courses.prerequisites: One of BIOC 302, BIOC 303, BIOT 380. (A minimum standing of 65% is recommended in these courses.)

courses.name: APSC 101 Introduction to Engineering II
courses.description: An introduction to the engineering profession including: the engineering design process, sustainability, prototype testing, introduction and application of the relevant foundational scientific principles, team functioning, engineering graphics, and technical communication.

courses.name: ANTH 201A Ethnic Relations - ETHNIC RELATIONS
courses.description: An introduction to the study of the relations between ethnic groups and of the interplay between ethnicity and other social factors. The course examines such concepts as: ethnicity, racism, prejudice, discrimination, assimilation, and multiculturalism. Ordinarily the course deals with ethnic groups in British Columbia, and students are expected to carry out elementary research projects.

courses.name: EDUC 321A School-based Orientation Practicum: Elementary - SCL PRACT ELEM
courses.description: Pass/Fail.

courses.name: COMM 471 Mergers and Acquisitions
courses.description: Mergers and acquisitions as a focal point in making important corporate decisions deduced from careful study of relevant business cases.

courses.name: BIOL 341 Introductory Molecular Biology Laboratory
courses.description: Use of recombinant DNA techniques.
courses.prerequisites: BIOL 200. (And at least third-year standing in Science.)

courses.name: PHTH 511 Pathology for Physical Therapy I
PATH 720 Microbiological Diagnosis
courses.description: Conduct of bacterial, fungal, parasitological, and viral laboratory tests relevant to the microbiological examination of patients. For medical residents.

courses.name: HUNU 547B Directed Studies - DIRECTED STUDIES
courses.description: In special cases, directed studies on certain aspects of nutrition may be arranged for graduate students in attendance.

courses.name: NURS 577D Graduate Practicum in Nursing - GRAD PRAC NURS
GRSJ 501 Issues in Decolonizing and Feminist Methodologies
AANB 504 Research Methodology in Applied Animal Biology
GRSJ 401 Body, Gender and Society
courses.description: An interdisciplinary examination of the body, exploring how social relations and space are implicated in the constitution and experience of gendered bodies and identities, with an emphasis on feminist analyses of body-societal relations.
courses.prerequisites: Either (a) all of GRSJ 101, GRSJ 102 or (b) all of WMST 101, WMST 102. (or third-year standing.)

courses.name: PERS 100 Basic Persian I
courses.description: Basic vocabulary and the fundamentals of modern Persian grammar, structure, and pronunciation, as well as reading, writing, listening, and speaking.

courses.name: EDUC 496A Practicum (Secondary) for Previously Certified Teachers - TEACH PRACT SECD
courses.description: Pass/Fail.
courses.prerequisites: (Recent completion of secondary teaching methods courses in the subjects to be taught.)

courses.name: FMED 425 Endocrine and Metabolism
courses.description: This block will focus on normal and abnormal carbohydrate and lipid metabolisms well as the physiological function and disorders of the pituitary, thyroid and adrenal. Relevant pathology, anatomy, genetics, biochemistry, pharmacology, and radiology will be included as learning issues.

courses.name: EOSC 528 Advanced Coal Geology
courses.description: The origin and character of coal and associated strata. Petrology, chemistry and physical properties of coal. Sedimentology of peat, biochemical and geochemical stages of coalification and oxidation of coal. Use of organic matter as a geothermometer and inbasinal analysis. Structural analysis and character of coal deposits. Analytical methods applied to coal.

courses.name: PATH 457 Clinical Laboratory Microbiology
courses.description: Selected clinical laboratory exercises plus seminars to illustrate the diagnosis and management of patients with microbial infections. Elective course limited to third- and fourth-year medical students.

courses.name: ATSC 405 Cloud Physics and Chemistry
courses.description: Cloud thermodynamics, chemistry and microphysics. Computer modelling of droplet growth, convection, and mixing. Application of differential equations to atmospheric problems.
courses.prerequisites: MATH 215. (Familiarity with a programming language is required.)

courses.name: NURS 511 Theoretical Foundations of Nursing Practice
CRWR 305A Intermediate Writing of Creative Nonfiction - INTMD CR NON FIC
courses.description: An exploration of and practice in the writing of creative non-fiction, covering four of the more basic forms of this genre: memoir, profile, commentary, and exposition. Manuscript submission is not required for admission.

courses.name: EDCP 342A Mathematics - Secondary: Curriculum and Pedagogy - MATH SEC C&P
courses.description: Pass/Fail.
courses.prerequisites: (A completed concentration in mathematics or permission of the Head.)

courses.name: MUSC 220 History of Music III
courses.description: The development of Western music from circa 1800 to circa 1900.
courses.prerequisites: MUSC 121 and one of MUSC 100, MUSC 110.

courses.name: LAW 350C Issues of Equality and Social Justice - ISSUES EQL&SOCIL
courses.description: Selected topics related to the Charter right to equality and other rights related to social justice. Not offered each year, consult Faculty.

courses.name: COMM 605 Advanced Topics in Urban Land Economics II
MEDG 420 Human Genomics and Medical Genetics
courses.description: Sequence and structure of the human genome. Human genetic evolution. Identification of genes affecting normal and pathological variation.  Molecular mechanisms of genetic diseases and disorders. Medical applications of human genetics.
courses.prerequisites: BIOL 335. (A standing of 'B' or higher is recommended.)

courses.name: POLI 369A Issues in International Security - ISS IN INTL SECU
courses.description: An examination of issues such as interstate conflicts, terrorism, environmental change, international crime. Topics will vary from year to year.

courses.name: ANTH 217 Culture and Communication
courses.description: The study of communication; the relation between communication and its cultural context with emphasis on verbal and non-verbal communication, cross-cultural communication, and cultural differences in the use of oral, literate, and electronic media.

courses.name: ZOOL 500B Directed Studies in Zoology - DST IN ZOOLOGY
ENGL 310 History and Theory of Rhetoric: Classical Rhetoric
courses.description: Introduction to classical rhetoric with attention to the analysis of present-day texts.

courses.name: ECON 102 Principles of Macroeconomics
courses.description: Elements of theory and of Canadian policy and institutions concerning the economics of growth and business cycles, national income accounting, interest and exchange rates, money and banking, the balance of trade.

courses.name: MEDG 570 Introductory Clinical and Laboratory Rotation
courses.description: Clinical experience in prenatal procedures and counselling; teratogen counselling. Clinically relevant experience in cytogenetics, molecular, biochemical disease and embryopathology laboratories.

courses.name: KIN 400 Planning Physical Education, Sport and Exercise Programs
courses.description: Processes, techniques and considerations in the planning, implementation and evaluation of physical education, sport and exercise programs in both public and private agencies.

courses.name: RUSS 200 Second-Year Russian
courses.description: Intermediate oral practice, grammar, reading, composition. A special section may be provided for Science students.

courses.name: ENGL 318 History of the English Language: Early History
courses.description: Principles of language change and language typology. The development of the English language from its Indo-European origins to the end of the Anglo-Saxon period.

courses.name: EDUC 440 Aboriginal Education in Canada
courses.description: Pass/Fail.

courses.name: PLAN 561 Seminar in Real Property Development and Planning
courses.description: Topics will vary.

courses.name: CRWR 311A Intermediate Writing for Lyric Forms - INT WRT LYRIC
courses.description: Techniques of and practice in writing for lyric forms, including song lyrics, lyrical narratives, and libretti. Manuscript submission is not required for admission.

courses.name: SOWK 551 Health and Social Care Praxis
EOSC 116 Mesozoic Earth: Time of the Dinosaurs.
courses.description: Earth's tectonics, climate, and oceans during the time of the dinosaurs.  Reading the fossil record of Earth from its earliest origins up to and including the Mesozoic, 250 - 65 million years ago.

courses.name: CIVL 511 Advanced Topics in Steel Structures
courses.description: Seismic design of steel buildings; composite design; welding of steel; corrosion protection; application of CAD in steel design.

courses.name: THTR 350 Scenery Production I
courses.description: Scenery construction, rigging, and systems.

courses.name: GRSJ 102 Decolonizing and Feminist Perspectives from Local to Global
courses.description: Intersectional feminist theory and practice, focusing on contemporary issues in a transnational context. Credit will be granted for only one of WMST 100 or GRSJ 102.

courses.name: CHEM 399 Co-operative Work Placement II
courses.description: Approved and supervised technical work experience in an industrial research setting for a minimum of 3.5 months. Taken during the summer following the third year. Technical report required. Restricted to students admitted to the Co-operative Education Program in Chemistry.

courses.name: ECED 480B Selected Topics in Early Childhood Education - SELECT TOPIC ECE
PHAR 506 Critical Appraisal of Pharmacotherapy Literature
courses.description: Identification, evaluation, and application of evidence relevant to improving clinical pharmacy practice and patient care.

courses.name: SURG 430 Surgery
courses.description: Post-operative care of patients, evaluation of pre-operative patients, mastery of technical skills for common ward procedures, assessing ambulatory patients and assisting in the operating room.

courses.name: MINE 522A Processing of Mineral Fines - PRO MIN FINES
courses.description: Particulate systems. Role of particle size and interfacial phenomena in properties of disperse systems. Stability of colloids and suspensions DLVO (Dejaguin-Landau-Vervey-Overbeek). Credit will be granted for only one of MINE 522 or MINE 572.

courses.name: ASIA 355 History of Chinese Cinema
courses.description: Introduction to the work of major directors.

courses.name: FRST 421 Quantitative Forest Management
courses.description: Introduction to the quantitative tools necessary in forest management. Available only through Distance Education.

courses.name: POLI 373 Ethics in World Politics
courses.description: When is it right to wage war?  Who should pay for global warming?  Should the wealthy provide foreign aid- how much?  Analysis of traditions of moral thought to reach reasoned judgments about such dilemmas in global politics.

courses.name: LAW 443 Creditors' Remedies
courses.description: Remedies of an unsecured creditor; fraudulent conveyances and preferences; builders' liens; bankruptcy.

courses.name: MATH 321 Real Variables II
courses.description: The Riemann or Riemann-Stieltjes integrals. Sequences and series of functions, uniform convergence. Approximation of continuous functions by polynomials. Fourier series. Functions from Rm to Rn, inverse and implicit function theorems.

courses.name: ITST 110 Introduction to Italian Literature and Culture
SPPH 566 Occupational Hygiene Practice
courses.description: Application of occupational hygiene principles using field investigations, critical appraisal of results, and communication with labour and management.

courses.name: ARCH 539 Architectural Design Abroad
courses.description: Design studio component of term-long study abroad offering.

courses.name: PATH 438E Medical Laboratory Science: Directed Studies - MED LAB - DST
courses.description: Investigation of a specific topic in Medical Laboratory Science. Permission of the department head is required.

courses.name: LAW 471D Preventing Wrongful Convictions - WRONGFUL CONVCTN
courses.description: Substantive legal principles and rules of evidence that can cause or help to prevent wrongful convictions or other miscarriages of justice. Roles of the participants in the criminal justice system. Not offered each year; consult Faculty.

courses.name: EOSC 110 The Solid Earth: A Dynamic Planet
courses.description: Earth's origin, composition, structure, and natural resources. Plate tectonics as the driving force for volcanism, mountain building, and earthquakes.  Imaging Earth's interior. Environmental geoscience and sustainability. (Consult the Credit Exclusion list for the Faculty of Science section of  the Calendar.)

courses.name: MECH 555 Fundamentals of Microelectromechanical Systems
courses.description: Micro-fabrication of MEMS: solid-state technology and other micromachining techniques. Engineering principles of various MEMS devices.

courses.name: FNH 309 Food Process Science
courses.description: Preservation of tissue and fluid food systems by selected physical and chemical treatments with emphasis on product-process interactions.

courses.name: CIVL 493 Case Studies of Construction Methods
courses.description: Identification and evaluation of solutions to construction site operation problems: the relationship between design and construction; factors affecting productivity and safety; measurement of on-site performance.

courses.name: PHYS 100 Introductory Physics
courses.description: An introduction to fundamental concepts such as force, energy, momentum, and the use of graphs and vectors in physics; geometrical optics; electricity; laboratory exercises to familiarize the student with both the phenomena and the basic laboratory instruments commonly used to measure them. Students with credit for Physics 12 may not obtain credit for this course unless they took AP, IB, or A-level Physics and were offered advanced credit for PHYS 100.
courses.prerequisites: (Principles of Mathematics 12 or Pre-calculus 12 is required; Physics 11 is required for first-year students, strongly recommended for others.)

courses.name: ASIA 396 Chinese Grammar and Usage II
courses.description: In-depth examination of modern Chinese grammar and its usage including word formation, syntactic constructions, discourse cohesions, semantics, and stylistic considerations. Continuation of ASIA 386.
courses.prerequisites: ASIA 386. (or higher level of Chinese language proficiency.)

courses.name: ISCI 350 Darwinian Medicine
courses.description: Using the Darwinian theory of natural selection to explore explanations of infectious diseases, allergies, cancer, mental illness, and other human diseases. Priority to students in the Integrated Sciences Program.
courses.prerequisites: (Third-year standing in the Faculty of Science.)

courses.name: ARCH 531 Architectural Technology II
courses.description: Analysis and design of advanced assemblies. Integration of multiple building systems within a wide range of construction types, and more complex enclosures in a variety of climatic conditions. Emphasis on technical performance, durability and sustainability.

courses.name: JAPN 301 Advanced Modern Japanese: Reading and Writing II
courses.description: Continuation of JAPN 300.

courses.name: EPSE 699 Doctoral Dissertation
courses.description: Pass/Fail.

courses.name: ENGL 229E Topics in the Study of Language and/or Rhetoric - LANG / RHETORIC
courses.prerequisites: Either (a) ARTS 001 or (b) two of ENGL 100, ENGL 110, ENGL 111, ENGL 112, ENGL 120, ENGL 121 or (c) ASTU 100 or (d) ASTU 150 and one of ENGL 110, ENGL 111, ENGL 120, ENGL 121;  or (e) WRDS 150 and one of ENGL 110, ENGL 111, ENGL 120, ENGL 121. (Or 6 credits of first-year English.)

courses.name: EDCP 303 Ceramic Design and Pedagogical Approaches: Art Education
courses.prerequisites: (6 credits of introductory art studio or art history courses.)

courses.name: KIN 369 Instructional Analysis and Design in Sport and Physical Activity Programs
courses.description: Instructional design and technologies applied to sport and physical activity programs.

courses.name: KIN 362 Inclusive Physical Activity for Individuals with Special Needs
courses.description: For persons with disabilities; a developmental, lifelong approach to programming. Includes field work.

courses.name: THTR 406 Costume Design II
courses.description: Complex problems and selected historical studies in costume design.

courses.name: COMM 692 Research Seminar in Policy Analysis
EDCP 362B Curriculum Design and Evaluation: Practical and Theoretical Issues - CURR DES & EVAL
SPAN 358 Survey of Peninsular Literature and Culture from 1700 to the Present
courses.prerequisites: SPAN 302 and one of SPAN 220, SPAN 221.
courses.corequisites: (SPAN 302 may be taken as a co-requisite, with the permission of the instructor or the Spanish Major Adviser.)

courses.name: ANAT 517 Functional Human Microscopic Anatomy: Basic Tissues, Organs and Systems
CRWR 550A Teaching Creative Writing - TEACH CR WRIT
CIVL 523 Project Management for Engineers
courses.description: Perspectives of project management as it relates to civil engineering. Case studies are used to illustrate key issues.

courses.name: LIBR 557 Information Retrieval Systems: Concepts and Practice
EDCP 302A Art - Secondary: Curriculum and Pedagogy - ART SEC CRC&PED
courses.description: Pass/Fail.
courses.prerequisites: (A concentration in art or permission of the Head.)

courses.name: MECH 433 Biofluids
courses.description: Review of principles, biorheology, circulatory biofluid mechanics, synovial fluid in joints, biofluid dynamics of the human brain, respiratory biofluid mechanics, flow and pressure measurement techniques in human body.

courses.name: POLI 328B Topics in Comparative Politics - COMPARATIVE POLI
courses.description: Topics will vary from year to year. Consult the departmental website.

courses.name: PHAR 462 Non-Prescription Drugs and Self-Care of the Patient IV
courses.description: The use of non-prescription drugs for selected conditions.

courses.name: PHYS 409A Experimental Physics - EXPTL PHYSICS
courses.description: A laboratory course with a wide choice of experiments for fourth year Honours and Major students. Topics include solid state, nuclear, classical, quantum, electromagnetic and low temperature physics. For six credits, two weekly laboratory periods and completion of a project in second term are required.

courses.name: CHEM 410 Physical Chemistry of the Solid State
courses.description: Introduction to the theory of electrons in solids; bands and zones. Absorption of light and excitons. Vacancies, interstitials, electronic defects and dislocations and their roles in chemical reactivity. Credit will not be given for CHEM 410/CHEM 502 and PHYS 474.
courses.prerequisites: CHEM 202 and one of CHEM 201, CHEM 205.

courses.name: PSYC 448C Directed Studies in Biopsychology - DIR STUD BIOPSYC
courses.description: Directed investigation of an experimental problem requiring a written report of the findings.
courses.prerequisites: (At least a 72% average in the preceding 30 credits and permission of a faculty member who is prepared to supervise the investigation.)

courses.name: LATN 525A Seminar in Latin Literature - SEMINAR LATN LIT
MICB 447 Experimental Molecular Biology
courses.description: A laboratory course with a choice of independent, supervised research projects. Students develop protocols to carry out investigation of selected molecular biology problems.
courses.prerequisites: Either (a) BIOT 380 or (b) MICB 323 or (c) all of MICB 322, MICB 398.

courses.name: EECE 595 Mixed-Signal and RF Integrated Circuits and Systems Test
UDES 505 Urban Design as Public Policy: Policymaking for a Sustainable Region
PLAN 425 Urban Planning Issues and Concepts
courses.description: Evolution, practice and future of urban planning and development, with emphasis on institutional arrangements, housing, transportation, urban design and development control. For third- and fourth-year undergraduate students interested in urban planning.
courses.prerequisites: One of URST 200, COMM 306, GEOG 350. (or permission of the instructor.)

courses.name: RUSS 316 Russian through Film (in Russian)
courses.description: Conversation and composition using Russian film.

courses.name: LFS 398 Co-operative Work Placement I
courses.description: Work experience in relevant private and/or public sector settings.  Work terms are normally four months long.  Restricted to students admitted to the Co-op Program in Land and Food Systems. Pass/Fail.

courses.name: BAFI 520 Empirical Finance
courses.prerequisites: BAFI 511 and one of BAFI 500, BAFI 540.

courses.name: MICB 402 Advanced Immunology
courses.description: Molecular basis of lymphocyte development, activation and adhesion; immunogenetics and the major histocompatibility complex. Consult the credit exclusion list within the Faculty of Science section of the calendar.
courses.prerequisites: One of MICB 302, BIOT 380. (If MICB 302 is used as the prerequisite for MICB 402, students are required to take one of the following as a corequisite: BIOL 234, BIOL 335, MICB 325.)

courses.name: MATH 257 Partial Differential Equations
courses.description: Introduction to partial differential equations; Fourier series; the heat, wave and potential equations; boundary-value problems; numerical methods. Please consult the Faculty of Science Credit Exclusion List: www.students.ubc.ca/calendar/index.cfm?tree=12,215,410,414.

courses.name: KIN 401 Co-operative Work Placement
courses.description: Supervised, technical work experience in an established company or organization for a minimum of three months. Technical report. Restricted to students meeting the requirements of the School of Kinesiology and the Co-operative Education Program.  Pass/Fail.

courses.name: POLI 504A Topics in Canadian Politics - TOPS CDN POLITCS
ASIA 376 The Sikhs: Formations, Contexts, and Historical Development
courses.description: Introduction to the historical development of Sikh traditions in India and Diaspora, from the 15th century to the present, with attention to broader historical contexts.

courses.name: ELEC 301 Electronic Circuits
courses.description: Analysis and design of electronic circuits; biasing of and small-signal models for transistors; frequency response of amplifiers; feedback and stability aspects of amplifier design; OP-AMPs; active filters; oscillators; IC specification and selection. Credit will only be given for one of EECE 356, ELEC 301, and EECE 374.
courses.prerequisites: Either (a) one of EECE 252, ELEC 204 or (b) one of EECE 251, ELEC 201 and one of EECE 253, ELEC 202, EECE 263, ELEC 203.

courses.name: FRST 497 Graduating Essay or Technical Report
courses.description: A technical description of a study or a detailed literature review of at least 4,000 words, developed under the guidance of a Faculty member. Available only to students in their graduating year.

courses.name: COMM 439 Business Telecommunications
courses.description: Basic data communications concepts and technology; local area, wide area, and enterprise networks; the Internet; wireless networking; network development life cycle; network security and management.

courses.name: FREN 122 Contemporary French Language and Literature I
courses.description: A review of French grammar and an introduction to contemporary literature written in French, with emphasis on essay writing and textual analysis.
courses.prerequisites: One of FREN 12, FREN 112, FREN 121. (or equivalent..)

courses.name: LAW 402D The Law of Sexual Offences - LAW SEX OFFENCES
courses.description: Criminal law relating to sexual offences, including non-consent, evidentiary and procedural rules, and sentencing.  History of sexual offence laws and law reform movements.

courses.name: ARCH 556 Co-op Work Placement 2
courses.description: Approved and supervised work experience for a minimum of 4 months. Technical report required. Restricted to students admitted to the Architecture Co-op Education Program.

courses.name: MECH 536 Fundamentals of Injury Biomechanics
courses.description: Introduction to injury biomechanics. Anatomy. Impact experiments. Multi-body dynamic simulation and finite element analysis. Skull, face, brain, eye, pelvis, abdomen, and extremity injury. Anthropomorphic test devices, seat belts, airbags, child restraints, and helmets. Credit cannot be obtained for both MECH436 and MECH536.

courses.name: PHYS 447B Advanced Topics in Physics - ADV TPCS PHYS
courses.description: Directed studies available to students in Honours Physics with approval from the Head of the Department.

courses.name: MECH 420 Sensors and Actuators
courses.description: Measurement of motion, stress, force, torque, temperature, flow and pressure; principles of sensors and signal conditioning methods; selection and sizing of actuators.
courses.prerequisites: All of MECH 360, MECH 463, MECH 366 and one of ELEC 343, EECE 376.

courses.name: ELEC 456 Decision Support Methods in Power Systems Operation
courses.description: Principles; acceptable regions of operation; energy management systems; load flow methods; static and dynamic security; contingency analysis; transient and voltage stability; on-line stability assessment.

courses.name: ECON 211 Macroeconomic Policy
courses.description: A survey of policy issues, such as the costs of inflation and unemployment, monetary and fiscal policy, the effects of government debt and exchange rate policy.  May not be taken for credit by students with fourth-year standing.

courses.name: SOIL 548 Major Project
courses.description: Professional paper on topics focusing on emerging issues in water and land resources.

courses.name: GEOG 520 Themes and Interpretive Issues in Modern Human Geography
courses.description: Themes and interpretive issues in modern human geography. Students from outside Geography require the permission of the Head of the department.

courses.name: COMM 469 International Marketing
courses.description: An analysis of the scope and significance of contemporary international business operations with particular reference to the marketing management problems encountered by firms with multinational branches and subsidiaries.

courses.name: MICB 322 Molecular Microbiology Laboratory
courses.description: Aseptic handling and characterization of microbes, growth properties, enzyme assays, protein analysis and plasmid isolation. Restricted to students in Microbiology and Immunology specializations.
courses.prerequisites: All of BIOL 200, BIOL 201, CHEM 233, MICB 201, MICB 202.

courses.name: EDST 548 Critical Perspectives on Teacher Unions in Educational Leadership
ENVR 449 Environmental Science HonoursThesis
courses.prerequisites: ENVR 300. (and fourth-year standing in the B.Sc. Environmental Sciences honours program.)

courses.name: MATH 102 Differential Calculus with Applications to Life Sciences
courses.description: Functions, derivatives, optimization, growth and decay, discrete probability. Please consult the Faculty of Science Credit Exclusion List: www.students.ubc.ca/calendar/index.cfm?tree=12,215,410,414.
courses.prerequisites: (High-school calculus and one of (a) a grade of 80% or higher in BC Principles of Mathematics 12 or Pre-calculus 12, or (b) a satisfactory score in the UBC Mathematics Basic Skills Test.)

courses.name: FRST 232 Computer Applications in Forestry
courses.description: Techniques involved in solving forestry problems with microcomputers using word processing, spreadsheet, procedural language, and database management tools.

courses.name: APSC 496D Interdisciplinary Engineering Design Project - INTER ENG PRJECT
courses.description: Projects involving students from several departments.

courses.name: MDVL 490A Research Seminar in Medieval Studies - RSRCH SEMNR MDVL
courses.description: An intensive research seminar in a specific period, area, or issue integrating topics in medieval history, literature, and the arts; topics vary from year to year; interested students should consult the Medieval Studies advisor.

courses.name: LAW 312D Topics in Philosophy of Law and Theoretical Perspectives - TPCS PHIL&THRTCL
courses.description: Not offered each year, consult Faculty.

courses.name: ATSC 448A Directed Studies - DIR STUDY
courses.description: Investigation of a topic to be agreed upon by a member of the faculty and the student.  Permission of the undergraduate advisor and of the supervising faculty member is required before registration.

courses.name: BIOL 548P Advanced Topics in Biology - ADV TOPICS BIOL
SOWK 570K Directed Studies in Social Work - DIRECTED STUDY
PAED 430 Paediatrics
courses.description: In-patient experience; experience in ambulatory clinics. Clinical teaching in small groups and Academic Half-Days, which supply a series of lectures and seminars. Emphasis on acquisition of clinical skills and a knowledge base of general paediatrics. Clinical duties include patient histories, physical examinations, participation in investigation and management, following patient progress, taking part in daily rounds, and night call.

courses.name: MINE 552 Mining Geostatistics
courses.description: Basic geostatistical concepts. Applications of geostatistical techniques and stochastic simulation to orebody modelling and grade control.

courses.name: EDCP 580A Problems in Education - PROB IN EDUC
courses.description: Directed Studies and Major Essay in the diverse disciplines and topics of curriculum and pedagogy.

courses.name: CHEM 412 Electronic Structure of Atoms and Molecules
courses.description: Introduction to variational methods; many-electron systems; semi-empirical methods; perturbation theory; computational methods.
courses.prerequisites: One of CHEM 312, PHYS 304 and one of MATH 152, MATH 221, MATH 223.

courses.name: MIDW 215 Ethics in Maternity Care
courses.description: Ethics using ethical theory in health care and midwifery.

courses.name: BUSI 445 Real Estate Development I
courses.description: Real estate development process from the project idea to the cursory feasibility stage.  Steps in development planning, including analysis, design and evaluation.  Evaluating development potential, land acquisition, and site planning.

courses.name: CNPS 580C Problems in Education - PROB IN EDUC
courses.description: Investigation and report of a problem.

courses.name: COMM 295 Managerial Economics
courses.description: Economic foundations of managerial decision-making. Demand theory, cost and production, market structure, competitive strategy, organization of the firm, welfare-economic foundations of business regulation. Credit may be obtained for only one of ECON 201, ECON 206, ECON 301, ECON 304, FRE 295, COMM 295.
courses.prerequisites: Either (a) ECON 100 or (b) all of ECON 101, ECON 102.

courses.name: SPPH 563 Technical Aspects of Chemical and Biological Hazard Control
courses.description: Industrial ventilation, heating and air conditioning systems, respiratory protection, chemical protective clothing.

courses.name: HIST 432 International Relations of the Great Powers in the Twentieth Century
courses.description: The international relations of the great powers from the end of the First World War to the end of the Cold War.

courses.name: GPP 502 International Macroeconomics
courses.description: Introduces challenges of an interlinked global economy through modern macroeconomics. International linkages through labor, capital and goods markets, monetary and fiscal policy linkages, currency and debt crises. Theory and real-world applications.

courses.name: ITAL 202 Second-Year Italian II
courses.description: Reading, writing and oral practice, with constant and systematic reference to the grammatical structure of the language.

courses.name: THTR 440D Topics in Theatre - TOPICS IN THTR
courses.description: An examination in depth of a selected area of theatre history, theory or practice. Topics will change from year to year. May be repeated for credit when topics differ.
courses.prerequisites: (6 credits of THTR at the 300-level or above.)

courses.name: LARC 599 Research Thesis
courses.description: Open only to M.A.S.L.A. candidates.

courses.name: CPSC 421 Introduction to Theory of Computing
courses.description: Characterizations of computability (using machines, languages and functions). Universality, equivalence and Church's thesis. Unsolvable problems. Restricted models of computation. Finite automata, grammars and formal languages.
courses.prerequisites: Either (a) CPSC 221 or (b) all of CPSC 260, EECE 320. (CPSC 320 is recommended.)

courses.name: FRST 452 Coastal Field School
courses.description: Site diagnosis and preparation of management options in coastal forests. Extrasessional course; fees will be assessed to meet expenses.
courses.prerequisites: (Third or fourth year-standing in the B.S.F. program.)

courses.name: INDE 454 Self-directed Senior Elective in Clinical or Academic Medicine
courses.description: A fourth-year self-directed elective to advance students' learning in clinical or academic medicine.

courses.name: EDST 511 Organization and Administration of Higher Education
PHYL 548A Advanced Topics in Human Physiology - ADV HUMAN PHYL
ORPA 724 Trauma Rounds
courses.description: Orthopaedic traumatology is reviewed, with emphasis being placed on applied basic science, surgical anatomy, diagnosis and definitive management. These sessions are supervised by a faculty member and are held weekly, each session lasting one hour.

courses.name: EOSC 340 Global Climate Change
courses.description: Mechanisms and processes of past and future global environmental and climate change.
courses.prerequisites: Either (a) SCIE 001 or (b) one of CHEM 111, CHEM 121, CHEM 154 and one of MATH 101, MATH 103, MATH 105, MATH 121 and one of PHYS 101, PHYS 107, PHYS 117, PHYS 153, PHYS 157.

courses.name: EPSE 390A Special Topics - SELECTED TOPICS
courses.description: A study of innovative practices, ideas, and theories in special education. The specific topics may change yearly to reflect changing priorities and interests in special education, and the specific interest and competencies of visiting and regular faculty.
courses.prerequisites: One of EPSE 312, EPSE 317. (Permission of the instructor is required.)

courses.name: MINE 393 Seminar
courses.description: Oral presentation of topics by students.

courses.name: KIN 500C Special Topics in Kinesiology - SPEC TPCS KIN
ARCH 532 Architectural Structures II
courses.description: Complex multi-span and continuous systems: effective material configuration, approximate methods of analysis, selection of appropriate structural systems, earthquake configuration and high rises.

courses.name: ARCL 231 Ancient North America
courses.description: Introductory survey of North American archaeology comparing the ancient cultures from all major regions of Canada and the US.

courses.name: MTRL 398 Engineering Written Communication
courses.description: Written communication in engineering. Reporting of technical material.

courses.name: CHIN 101 Basic Chinese I: Part 1 (Non-Heritage)
courses.description: Skills in listening, speaking, reading, and writing in Mandarin Chinese, an active vocabulary of about 250 Chinese words, and basic grammar.

courses.name: PLAN 549C Master's Thesis - MASTERS THESIS
courses.description: Research and preparation of a thesis on a topic in public policy or professional practice.

courses.name: CAPS 303 Laboratory in Human Physiology (Honours)
courses.description: Techniques and principles of human physiology. This course must be taken in conjunction with CAPS 301. Restricted to Cellular, Anatomical and Physiological Sciences and Pharmacology Honours students.

courses.name: JAPN 150 Intensive Beginning Japanese I
courses.description: An introduction to modern spoken and written Japanese with emphasis on both form (grammar and syntax) and functions. Offered in Term 1. Not available for credit to students with JAPN 12.

courses.name: MUSC 300 Compositional and Analytical Approaches to Post-Tonal Music
courses.description: Concepts essential to understanding and performing art music, since 1900, in which functional triadic harmony is absent or subsidiary to other musical processes. Detailed consideration of works of major composers up to the present, through analysis, composition, and musicianship exercises.

courses.name: ASTU 400Q Interdisciplinary Studies in Arts - INTERDISCIP STUD
courses.description: For upper-division students in the Faculty of Arts. Topics announced annually.

courses.name: DHYG 401 Oral Epidemiology
courses.description: Basic epidemiological and statistical concepts and tests relevant to evidence-based oral health practices.

courses.name: EECE 563 Wireless Communication Systems
courses.description: Characterization of fading channels such as land-mobile, mobile-satellite, cellular and indoor; modem design and performance on fading channels, diversity techniques, carrier and bit synchronization; effects of non-linearities and interference on system performance, and remedies; software and hardware system designs; system architectures (FDMA, TDMA, CDMA); cellular systems: frequency allocation, spectrum efficiency, and channel assignment strategies; spread spectrum systems.

courses.name: PHAR 540B Topics in Pharmacology - TOPICS IN PHARM
courses.description: Lectures and supervised studies in selected areas of pharmacology. Enrolment restricted.

courses.name: MATH 307 Applied Linear Algebra
courses.description: Applications of linear algebra to problems in science and engineering; use of computer algebra systems for solving problems in linear algebra.
courses.prerequisites: One of MATH 152, MATH 221, MATH 223 and one of MATH 200, MATH 217, MATH 226, MATH 253, MATH 263.

courses.name: POLI 440B Contemporary Political Theory - CONT POLI THEORY
courses.description: This seminar examines the political ideas of leading political philosophers of the twentieth century. Consult the departmental website.

courses.name: CONS 451 Integrated Field School
courses.description: Field methods, research and analysis, community oriented projects, and the interactions between biological and social aspects of conservation research. Students may not take any other courses in conjunction with CONS 451. Restricted to B.Sc.N. students in the fourth year of the Science and Management Major.

courses.name: THTR 505 Scenery Design Studio I
courses.description: Scenery design for theatre and other performance forms.

courses.name: LARC 595 Graduate Project Part I
courses.description: Preparation of a graduation design project proposal including literature review.

courses.name: MUSC 593G Music Performance (Major) - ORCH CONDUCTING
courses.description: Private instruction, vocal or instrumental. May be repeated for credit, in accordance with program requirements.

courses.name: CHEM 315 Chemistry Integrated Laboratory I
courses.description: Principles and techniques of modern chemistry applied by integrating experiments chosen from organic, inorganic, physical, and analytical chemistry.
courses.prerequisites: One of CHEM 201, CHEM 202, CHEM 203, CHEM 208, CHEM 211, CHEM 235.

courses.name: CLST 332 Roman Art and Architecture
courses.description: An introduction to the visual culture of the ancient Roman world from the 8th century BCE to the 4th century CE.

courses.name: SPPH 581J Selected Topics - GLOBAL HEALTH
courses.description: By seminar and directed readings, certain topics of current interest are explored in depth.

courses.name: ANTH 412A Advanced Topics in the Anthropology of Gender - TPCS ANTH GENDER
courses.description: Contemporary theory employed in the anthropological study of gender.

courses.name: LARC 502 Landscape Architecture Design Studio II
EOSC 240 Site Investigation
courses.description: Theory and practice of site investigation for geological engineers, including background studies, field work, remote sensing, development of ground models, importance of geological variability and uncertainty. Impacts on design, project risk and decision making.

courses.name: LLED 220 Introduction to Translating in a Globalized Society
courses.description: Basic tenets of translation as a methodology for increasing students' sociocultural understanding, intercultural communication, pragmatics, and written English.

courses.name: RSOT 527 Evidence for Practice I: Research Paradigms and Methods
PHAR 503P Graduate Clinical Clerkship - GRAD CLIN CLRKSP
courses.description: This course will consist of clinical rotations of 4-6 weeks' duration (20-40 hours per week, 2 credit/rotation) in selected specialty areas in medicine and clinical pharmacy. Students will be assigned to clinicians in the selected specialty who are members of either the Faculty of Medicine or Pharmaceutical Sciences and who are appointed as clinical instructors for this course. Rotations will take place at the site(s) where the majority of the clinician's practice is conducted.

courses.name: JAPN 303 Advanced Modern Japanese: Conversation and Composition II
courses.description: Improvement of speaking and writing skills through readings and discussions on a variety of social and cultural issues; emphasis on the development of formal presentation skills.

courses.name: INDS 530B Directed Studies - DIRECTED STUDIES
courses.description: A series of directed readings related to student's area of interdisciplinary studies. This advanced course may be taken upon approval of the Program head.

courses.name: MEDG 575 Advanced Clinical Rotation
courses.description: In-depth clinical experience in general and prenatal genetic counselling.
courses.prerequisites: MEDG 570. (And acceptance into M.Sc. Genetic Counselling program.)

courses.name: EOSC 428 Field Techniques in Groundwater Hydrology
courses.description: Hydraulic head measurements, water-quality sampling, pump and slug testing, infiltration measurements, profiling techniques. Held over five days after spring term at the Richmond groundwater hydrology field-school site. Enrolment limitations.

courses.name: ECON 345 Money and Banking
courses.description: Financial markets and financial institutions in theory and practice; structure and development of the Canadian financial system; development and theory of the regulation of the financial system; process of monetary control; theory and history of central banking and monetary policy.

courses.name: SPPH 570 Current Issues in Public Health Practice
FIPR 234 Production Planning and Professional Practices
courses.description: Planning of film productions from concept to completion.

courses.name: GREK 102 First-Year Ancient Greek II
courses.description: An introduction to Classical and Hellenistic Greek, Part II.

courses.name: GEOG 362 Geography of Economic Development
courses.description: Geographical approaches to economic development; models of economic development and spatial change; influences on spatial economic change; case studies from the developed, third, and socialist worlds.

courses.name: EDUC 418D School-based Extended Practicum: Elementary - EXT PRACT ELEM
courses.description: Pass/Fail.
courses.prerequisites: (Normally all requirements set to precede this practicum)

courses.name: POLI 420A Advanced Topics in Comparative Politics - ADV TPCS CMP PLI
courses.description: Seminar in comparative analysis of politics in democratic systems. For specific content in a given year, consult the departmental website.
courses.prerequisites: Two of POLI 220, POLI 320, POLI 321, POLI 322, POLI 323, POLI 324, POLI 325, POLI 326, POLI 327, POLI 328, POLI 329, POLI 330, POLI 331, POLI 332, POLI 333, POLI 350, POLI 351.

courses.name: GEOB 401 Urban Meteorology
courses.description: The impact of urbanization upon atmospheric processes and climates. The energy and water balances of cities. Meteorological effects (urban heat island, precipitation modification, etc.) and their significance. Models of the urban atmosphere.
courses.prerequisites: One of GEOG 204, GEOB 204, GEOG 300, GEOB 300, AGRO 244, APBI 244.

courses.name: ENPH 459 Engineering Physics Project I
courses.description: Project planning, management and reporting. This course involves writing a project proposal, carrying out an open-ended Engineering project, and reporting the results both orally and in writing.

courses.name: MTRL 475 Microstructure Engineering
courses.description: Follows the production of metallurgical products, focusing on process design models used to describe solidification, recrystallization, and precipitation.

courses.name: LING 405 Morphology
courses.description: Analytic and theoretical consideration of the interrelation of word formation, sound patterning, and meaningful sentence structure. Not offered every year.

courses.name: CHEM 411 Synthesis and Chemistry of Natural Products
courses.description: A discussion of synthetic methods and their application to natural products, particularly in the areas of alkaloids, steroids and terpenes. Credit will not be given for both CHEM 411 and CHEM 566.

courses.name: MICB 202 Introductory Medical Microbiology and Immunology
courses.description: Introduction to cellular and humoral immune responses, the properties of viruses and the principles of bacterial pathogenesis. (Consult the Credit Exclusion list within the Faculty of Science section of the Calendar.)
courses.prerequisites: One of BIOL 112, BIOL 200, MICB 201, PHAR 201, SCIE 001.

courses.name: COMM 693 Seminar in Research Methodology I
NRSC 500 Neuroscience I
courses.description: Comprehensive multidisciplinary course with lectures, seminars, and laboratory demonstrations encompassing molecular, cellular, systemic, and behavioural approaches to the study of nervous systems. Emphasis is on the physiology, pharmacology, and biochemistry of excitable cells and their synaptic interactions. Permission of Neuroscience Chair is required. Normally to be taken in conjunction with NRSC 501.

courses.name: POLI 571A Qualitative Methods of Political Analysis - QAL MTH POL ANYL
MECH 435 Orthopaedic Biomechanics
courses.description: Musculoskeletal anatomy. Muscle and joint loads. Muscle mechanics. Musculoskeletal dynamics. Gait. Tissue mechanics of tendon, ligament, articular cartilage, and bone. Biomaterials. Application examples in orthopaedics including joint replacement and fracture fixation.
courses.prerequisites: Either (a) MECH 221 or (b) all of APSC 278, MECH 260.

courses.name: SPPH 200 Understanding the Sociocultural Determinants of the Health of Populations
courses.description: The Interprofessional Health and Human Service (IHHS) course covers the idea of "population health," and the implementation and evaluation of programs or policies to improve health. Open to all students. Credit will be granted for only one of SPPH 200 or IHHS 200.

courses.name: MICB 506D Microbiological and Immunological Research - MICB&IMMUN RSRCH
courses.description: Developing, discussing, and undertaking research projects.  Oral communication skills, peer review skills, scientific ethics, and the ability to critically evaluate papers in the literature.  To be taken only with permission of the department head.

courses.name: INDS 502E Interdisciplinary Studies: Thematic Seminars - INTERFACULTY THM
courses.description: Seminars, lectures, and discussions of topics involving several faculties. Contact the Interdisciplinary Studies Program for specific topics (www.isgp.ubc.ca).

courses.name: ASIA 598 Asia and the Museological Imagination
courses.description: Credit will be granted for only one of ASIA 498 OR 598.

courses.name: MTRL 365 Mechanical Behaviour of Materials
courses.description: Polycrystalline and single crystal deformation; dislocation theory; strengthening mechanisms; fracture mechanics; fatigue; high temperature deformation mechanisms.

courses.name: MECH 470 Energy Conversion Systems
courses.description: Energy supply and demand. Energy conversion chain. Electrical power generation using thermal power plants, renewable energy, and fuel cells. Rankine cycle steam power. Brayton cycle gas turbine power plants, intercooling, reheat, and regeneration. Combined and binary cycles. Nuclear power.

courses.name: DENT 516 Pediatric Dentistry Case Review and Treatment Planning I
courses.description: Continues in year 2.

courses.name: HIST 326 Canada Since 1945: Affluence and Anxiety in the Atomic Age.
courses.description: Includes immigration policy; the welfare state; Aboriginal peoples; the Cold War; resource economies and national politics; continentalism and free trade; constitutional crises; conflicting nationalisms; and new social movements.  Credit will only be granted for one of HIST 326 or 426, if 426 was taken before 2007W.

courses.name: SPPH 519 Qualitative Methods in Health Research Design
courses.description: Purposes, context, procedures, and relationships within qualitative health research and methologies.

courses.name: COGS 402 Research in Cognitive Systems
courses.description: Supervised research project in a Cognitive Systems-related laboratory.

courses.name: MINE 402 Mine Ventilation and Occupational Health and Safety
courses.description: Design and analysis for ventilation systems for mining. Topics such as ventilation design, ventilation surveys, thermodynamic aspects, psychrometry of air and air conditioning.

courses.name: NURS 305 Introduction to Critical Inquiry and Research
courses.description: Introduction to fundamental theories, concepts, evidence, and competencies pertaining to scientific inquiry, evidence-based and informed practice, and research utilization in health care.

courses.name: CPSC 500 Fundamentals of Algorithm Design and Analysis
HIST 323 The Atlantic Revolutions,1763-1838
courses.description: An examination of the political, cultural, and intellectual transformations that reshaped the Atlantic world between 1763 and 1838; special attention will be given to British North America within the context of the Age of Revolutions.

courses.name: BIOL 465 Diversity and Evolution of Fishes
courses.description: Introduction to fish diversity, with a focus on their phylogenetic interrelationships and the evolutionary, ecological, and biogeographic processes involved in generating patterns of fish biodiversity.

courses.name: MECH 510 Computational Methods in Transport Phenomena I
courses.description: Analytical, computational, and experimental methods in fluid mechanics. Overview of CFD program development. Finite volume methods, spacial discretization and spatial accuracy analysis. Boundary conditions. Time advance methods, time accuracy, and stability. Application to model problems and to the incompressible laminar Navier-Stokes equations. Validation techniques for CFD codes.

courses.name: MEDG 448B Directed Studies - DIRECTED STUDIES
courses.description: A supervised individual program of study of a topic to be agreed upon by a member of faculty and the student. Permission of the appropriate supervisor and the department head is required.

courses.name: ENPH 481 Entrepreneurial Projects I
courses.description: A project course for students pursuing entrepreneurial training within Engineering Physics, and wishing to further develop projects resulting from ENPH 459.

courses.name: THTR 272 Beginning B.F.A. Acting II
courses.description: Open only to B.F.A. Acting students.

courses.name: EDST 553A Group Inquiry into Educational Practices - GRP INQ ED PRAC
CIVL 301 Optimization and Decision Analysis in Civil Engineering
courses.description: Review of numerical methods; introduction to systems engineering; application of optimization, probability, and decision-making to civil engineering systems and projects.

courses.name: KORN 440A Supervised Study in the Korean Language - SPRV STDY KORN
courses.description: Primarily for students in Asian Studies and Linguistics.

courses.name: CPEN 333 System Software Engineering
courses.description: Operating systems principles, real-time systems, principles of concurrent and multi-threaded programming, information structures, introduction to object oriented analysis, design, and modeling using UML, testing of software systems.
courses.prerequisites: One of CPSC 259, CPSC 260 and one of EECE 259, CPEN 211, EECE 355, CPEN 312.

courses.name: ADHE 329 Developing Short Courses, Workshops and Seminars
courses.description: Organization and administration of adult education events such as short courses, seminars, workshops, conferences and institutes.

courses.name: ASIA 533A Topics in Modern Japanese Literature - TOP MOD JAPN LIT
GEOB 372 Cartography
courses.description: Cartographic methods: development of cartography; projections; data ordering, compilation and symbolization; cartographic design, map reproduction.
courses.prerequisites: (6 credits from GEOB 102, GEOB 103, GEOB 200, GEOB 204, GEOB 207.)

courses.name: LLED 580C Problems in Education - PROB IN EDUC
courses.description: Investigation and report of a problem.

courses.name: ASTR 404 Astronomical and Astrophysical Measurements
courses.description: Astronomical instrumentation and techniques for ground and space-based observations. Theory of measurement, imaging, interferometry and spectroscopy of electromagnetic radiation at optical, radio, infrared, and X-ray wavelengths. Astronomical data analysis.
courses.prerequisites: All of PHYS 210, PHYS 408 and one of PHYS 312, MATH 316.

courses.name: RELG 306 Archaeology and the Bible
courses.description: The impact of archaeological research on understanding the history and religion of ancient Israel.

courses.name: FRST 548A Major Essay - MAJOR ESSAY
courses.description: For non-thesis master's degree programs.

courses.name: FMST 316 Human Sexuality
courses.description: An examination of human sexual development and behaviour.

courses.name: MECH 466 Automatic Control
courses.description: Process and system characteristics; transient response; the closed loop; block diagrams and transfer functions; control actions; stability; Nyquist diagrams; Bode diagrams; root locus methods; frequency response; system compensation; nonlinear control systems; digital computer control. Laboratory experiments to support the lecture content. Credit cannot be obtained for both MECH 466 and MECH 467.
courses.prerequisites: Either (a) all of MECH 220, MECH 221, MECH 463 or (b) all of MATH 255, MECH 463 and one of ELEC 201, ELEC 202, EECE 251, EECE 253.

courses.name: CNPS 579 Research in Counselling Psychology
courses.description: Assumptions and methods of major research paradigms.
courses.prerequisites: One of EDUC 500, EPSE 481 and one of EPSE 482, EPSE 483.

courses.name: LAW 555C Topics in Common Law Theory and Practice: Legal Theory and Practice - LEGAL THEORY
SOCI 444 Sociology of Aging
courses.description: Demographic, economic, and social trends associated with aging, ageism, and aging populations.

courses.name: BOTA 544 Plant Molecular Biology Laboratory
courses.description: Admission to the course is limited and requires recommendation from the Head of Botany or the Director of the Biotechnology Laboratory.
courses.prerequisites: (BIOL 335 is recommended as either a prerequisite or corequisite.)

courses.name: SPAN 490R Topics in Spanish-American Literature of the Twentieth-Century - SP-AM LIT 20C
courses.prerequisites: One of SPAN 220, SPAN 221 and SPAN 302.

courses.name: CRWR 508V Advanced Writing for Graphic Forms I - ADV GRAPHC FRM I
WOOD 449B Directed Studies in Wood Products Processing - DIR ST WD PR PRC
courses.description: In special cases and with the approval of the instructor concerned, a student may carry on directed studies of specific problems in wood products processing.

courses.name: LIBR 514E Topics in the Bibliographic Control of Information - TPCS BBL CTL INF
ITAL 102 First-Year Italian II
courses.description: Grammar, reading, writing and oral practice for beginners without previous exposure to the Italian language or dialects.

courses.name: MINE 554 Mine Economics and Finance
courses.description: Mine valuation using discounted cash flow analysis and option pricing methods. Sources of mine finance and requirements. Sensitivity and risk assessment. Introduction to metals marketing, hedging and risk management.

courses.name: LLED 601 Theories for Language and Literacy Research
courses.prerequisites: (Admission to the Ph.D. program in LLED.)

courses.name: FRE 306 Introduction to Global Food Markets
courses.description: An overview of global food markets including recent trends (e.g., vertical coordination, strategic alliances, multinationals and small firms in niche markets), marketing and trade institutions such as state-trading enterprises and WTO regulations, issues specific to developing nations, and case studies.

courses.name: THTR 508 Costume Design Studio II
courses.description: Complex costume design for opera, dance, theatre, and other performance forms.

courses.name: RMES 502 Seminar on Resources and Environment
courses.description: Environment and resource management goals and issues. Students enrolled in the program will give two presentations. The first will outline specific research interests of the students. The second will provide a synopsis of research at a time when the student is nearing completion of the thesis. Faculty members and other speakers will also be invited to participate and present seminars.

courses.name: BIOC 440 Concepts in Molecular Biology
courses.description: Developing areas of molecular biology, focusing on experimental design and data analysis. Signal transduction, the use of model eukaryotes, and the regulation of gene expression.
courses.prerequisites: One of BIOC 303, BIOT 380 and all of BIOC 402, BIOC 410.

courses.name: MUSC 509B Advanced Orchestration and Arranging - ADV ORCHESTRATON
ECON 490 Seminar in Applied Economics
courses.description: Selected problems and issues in the theory and practice of Economics. Each section will focus on a different field. Restricted to Economics Majors, and Combined Majors in Economics their final academic session.
courses.prerequisites: All of ECON 325, ECON 326 and one of ECON 301, ECON 304 and one of ECON 302, ECON 305. (For additional possible prerequisites see individual course descriptions on the School's  website.)

courses.name: BIOC 509 Membrane Structure and Function
