courses.description: The physical properties and functional roles of lipids in membranes, liposomes, membrane permiability; membrane function; structure, biosynthesis and cell sorting of membrane proteins; and the structure-function relationships of channels, transporters and receptors. Given in alternate years.

courses.name: EPSE 565R Special Course in Subject Matter Field - SP CRSE: SUBJ FL
PLAN 519A Internships - INTERNSHIPS
courses.description: Guided hands-on experience of day-to-day planning in a workplace environment.

courses.name: MUSC 312 Instrumental Conducting
courses.description: The relation of conducting gestures to instrumental sound; development of practical skills in directing ensembles and reading scores, considering instruments' special characteristics.

courses.name: ECED 405A Foundations of Curriculum and Instruction in Early Childhood Education - FND ERLY CHLD ED
SOCI 342 Consumers and Consumption
courses.description: The structure and culture of consuming and consumption.

courses.name: GRSJ 450B Directed Studies - DIRECTED STUDIES
courses.description: General reading and/or a research undertaking, with the agreement, and under supervision of, a faculty member selected by the student and approved by the GRSJ Undergraduate Advisor. A written paper or equivalent will be required. Open to GRSJ majors or minors.

courses.name: MRNE 400A Directed Studies - DIRECTED STUDIES
courses.description: A research project approved by the supervisor in the field of interest of the student designed to take advantage of the opportunities offered by the Bamfield Marine Sciences Centre. Note: the supervisor may be teaching at the Marine Centre; or a member of faculty of WCUMSS whether at the Marine Centre as a research investigator or as one of the members of WCUMSS.

courses.name: LFS 490A Topics in Agricultural Sciences - TOP IN AG SCI
courses.description: Analysis and interpretation of current issues in agricultural sciences.

courses.name: CPEN 411 Computer Architecture
courses.description: Quantitative principles, instruction set design, methods for performance improvements, pipelining, multiple instruction issue, dynamic scheduling, branch prediction, memory systems, caches, multi-core, multiple views of the design space, other advanced architectures. Credit will be given for only one of CPSC 313 or EECE 476 or CPEN 411.
courses.prerequisites: Either (a) one of EECE 353, CPEN 311 or (b) one of EECE 355, CPEN 312.

courses.name: EECE 571C Electrical Engineering Seminar and Special Problems - CTRL TCHNQ LLC
EOSC 578 Seminal Papers in Biological Oceanography
PLAN 545C Planning Studies Abroad - STUDIES ABROAD
courses.description: An extended site visit outside Canada to understand the cultural context for community and regional planning issues and the local institutional response.

courses.name: EOSC 314 The Ocean Environment
courses.description: An introduction to the oceans and the processes that have shaped them, their composition and movement, waves, tides, beaches, interactions with the atmosphere and human exploitation of the non-living resources. Not for credit in the Faculties of Science or Applied Science. No background in Science or Mathematics is required.

courses.name: LFS 498 Co-operative Work Placement III
courses.description: Work experience in relevant private and/or public sector settings.  Work terms are normally four months long.  Restricted to students admitted to the Co-op Program in Land and Food Systems. Pass/Fail.

courses.name: CHEM 345 Integrated Chemistry Laboratory II
courses.description: Further development of principles and techniques of modern chemistry applied by integrating experiments chosen from organic, inorganic, physical, and analytical chemistry.   Open only to students in Chemistry Major or Honours specializations.

courses.name: PSYC 348B Directed Studies in Biopsychology - DIR STUD BIOPSYC
courses.description: Directed investigation of an experimental problem requiring a written report of the findings.
courses.prerequisites: (At least 72% average in the preceding 30 credits and permission of a faculty member who is prepared to supervise the investigation.)

courses.name: LAW 348D Comparative Constitutional Law - COMP CONSTNL LAW
courses.description: Comparison of the constitutional history, government structure and powers, and protection of individual rights between the United States and Canada.

courses.name: ETEC 520 Planning and Managing Learning Technologies in Higher Education
PCTH 548A Directed Studies in Pharmacology - DIRECTED STUDIES
courses.description: In special cases, with the approval of the department head, advanced courses may be arranged.

courses.name: POLI 369B Issues in International Security - ISS IN INTL SECU
courses.description: An examination of issues such as interstate conflicts, terrorism, environmental change, international crime. Topics will vary from year to year.

courses.name: GEOG 311 Urban Environments
courses.description: The impact of urban development on the natural environment and vice versa. Study of the ecology and metabolism of cities and green urban design, using global and local case studies.
courses.prerequisites: Not open to students with credit for GEOG 210.

courses.name: APSC 183 Matter and Energy II
courses.description: Atomic structures and bonding, solid crystals, chemical equilibrium, reactions in gas phase and in aqueous solutions, acid-base and redox reactions, kinetics of chemical reactions, thermochemistry, electrochemistry.

courses.name: RELG 309 Jews and Christians
courses.description: Aspects of Jewish-Christian relations from the beginnings of Christianity to the present day. Emphasis on the study of Christian and Jewish texts in translation.

courses.name: PCTH 514 Seminar in Pharmacology or Therapeutics
courses.description: To give students experience in the presentation of data and to enhance communication skills in the discussion of scientific topics. All students will present at least one seminar during their graduate work and would be expected to attend all seminars.

courses.name: ECED 439 Assessment of Infants and Young Children with Special Needs
courses.description: (Formerly EPSE 420).

courses.name: MEDD 411 Foundations of Medical Practice I
courses.description: Integrating foundational and clinical sciences and clinical practice themes. Case-based approach fostering the development of evidence-based clinical reasoning and clinical skills. Organized on the basis of clinical presentations. Pass/fail.

courses.name: MATH 419 Stochastic Processes
courses.description: Random walks, Markov chains, branching processes, Poisson processes, continuous time Markov chains, martingales, Brownian motion.

courses.name: CHBE 241 Material and Energy Balances
courses.description: Introduction to Chemical and Biological Engineering; units; stoichiometry; phase equilibria; material balances; energy balances.

courses.name: GRSJ 230 Gender, Race, Sexuality, and Representation in Modern Asia
courses.description: The complex relationships between mechanisms of power, gender, and representation in Asia in different spaces examined through an interdisciplinary lens.

courses.name: EPSE 437 Interventions for Children and Adolescents with Behaviour Disorders
ARCH 502 Introductory Workshop
courses.description: Commences in August the two weeks prior to Labour Day. Enrolment mandatory for all incoming students. A non-refundable fee will charged to cover expenses. Credit will not be given for both ARCH 502 and LARC 511.

courses.name: ORPA 904 Seminar in Orthopaedics
courses.description: A series of 60 seminars in orthopaedics and traumatic surgery given over a two-year period: thirty sessions in each of the two years. One evening per week throughout the Winter Session. For post-graduate students proceeding to Certification and Fellowship of the Royal College of Physicians and Surgeons of Canada.

courses.name: ENGL 347K Renaissance Studies - RENAISS STUDIES
courses.prerequisites: (3rd year standing and 6 credits of first-year English, or Arts One, or 6 credits of ASTU 100 from CAP or 3 credits of first-year English and 3 credits of ASTU 150)

courses.name: STAT 547C Topics in Statistics - TOPICS IN STAT
courses.description: Students should consult the Statistics Department for the particular advanced topics offered in a given year.

courses.name: EPSE 481 Introduction to Research in Education
courses.description: The nature of scientific study and essentials of survey, experimental and other empirical research designs. Designed for students proceeding to graduate work.
courses.prerequisites: EPSE 482. (May also be taken as a corequisite.)

courses.name: KORN 301 Readings in Korean Topics I
courses.description: Readings in intermediate-level Korean on aspects of Korean culture, customs, and contemporary life, along with structured conversations based on those readings. As of 2011W, credit will be granted for only one of KORN 301/302 or KORN 300.

courses.name: CPEN 281 Technical Communication
courses.description: Written and oral communication in engineering. Technical description, report preparation, business correspondence, and oral presentation of technical material. Restricted to students in second year of Electrical and Computer Engineering programs. Credit will be granted for only one of ELEC 281, CPEN 281, or APSC 201.
courses.prerequisites: One of APSC 176, ENGL 110, ENGL 111, ENGL 112, ENGL 120, ENGL 121.

courses.name: PATH 570 Cardiovascular Pathophysiology
courses.description: Pathogenesis, abnormal physiology, and therapeutic approaches in heart disease including cardiac arrhythmia, heart failure, myocardial infarction, hypertension, atherosclerosis.

courses.name: PHIL 449A Continental Philosophy - CONTINENTAL PHIL
courses.description: A study of European philosophers from amongst Husserl, Heidegger, Habermas, Foucault, Derrida, Lacan, Levinas, and others.

courses.name: SOWK 525 Advanced Social Work Practice: Mental Health
courses.prerequisites: (A version of SOWK 440 with a focus on mental health, or equivalent (as specified by the School), including one-year employment experience in BC Mental Health system.)

courses.name: WOOD 290 Secondary Wood Products Manufacturing
courses.description: Basic secondary wood products manufacturing. Focus on producing and joining lumber, edging, drilling, veneers and CNC equipment.

courses.name: LAW 336 Chinese Law: Implications for Canada-China Relations
courses.description: Overview of the laws and legal system in the People's Republic of China with some introduction to Taiwan law. Legal interpretation of implications for Canada-China relations.

courses.name: PATH 402 Medical Laboratory Science: Haematology
courses.description: A theoretical and practical examination of those modern concepts of haematology which relate to the practice of medical laboratory science.

courses.name: ELEC 451 Power Electronics
courses.description: Power diodes, thyristors, transistors and FETs; analysis of idealized circuits with generalized loads; AC-DC, DC-DC, DC-AC, AC-AC converters, modulation techniques, gating circuits; practical design and applications.
courses.prerequisites: One of EECE 365, ELEC 344, EECE 370, EECE 373, ELEC 342, EECE 374.

courses.name: POLI 303 Federalism in Canada
courses.description: Theory and practice of federalism; cultural duality, social stresses, and problems of flexibility. The constitution and role of the courts.

courses.name: CPSC 311 Definition of Programming Languages
courses.description: Comparative study of advanced programming language features. Statement types, data types, variable binding, parameter passing mechanisms. Methods for syntactic and semantic description of programming languages.

courses.name: MATH 210 Introduction to Mathematical Computing
courses.description: Introduction to numerical computation, computer algebra, mathematical graphics. Primarily for second year students taking a degree in mathematics. One hour laboratory each week.
courses.prerequisites: One of MATH 101, MATH 103, MATH 105, MATH 121, SCIE 001.
courses.corequisites: One of MATH 215, MATH 255, MATH 256, MATH 265 and one of MATH 152, MATH 221, MATH 223.

courses.name: PLAN 580 Urban Transportation Planning
courses.description: Topics include the relationship between transportation and urban activity systems; analysis of supply and demand; accessibility and environment; institutional arrangements and public finance.

courses.name: ASIA 250 Introduction to Buddhism
courses.description: Origins, basic teachings, development of Theravada, Mahayana, and Tantric traditions, historical spread first through Asia and later the world, and Buddhism in contemporary societies.

courses.name: POLI 390 Honours Seminar
courses.description: An examination of the dimensions of Political Science and the major debates within the discipline.

courses.name: ANAT 448N Directed Studies in Anatomy - DIRECTED STUDIES
courses.description: Permission of the Head and supervisor required.

courses.name: MTRL 598 Seminar
courses.description: Presentation and discussion of current topics in metals and materials research. A required course for graduate students in metals and materials which carries no academic credit.

courses.name: FRST 432 Molecular Ecology
courses.description: Use of molecular genetic tools to investigate ecological  processes in natural population; DNA variation and its application in landscape genetics, phylogeography, behavioural ecology, conservation genetics, and association genetics. Emphasis placed on statistical and computational data analysis.

courses.name: PHIL 260A Science and Society in the Contemporary World - SCIE & SOCIETY
courses.description: An introduction to the historical development, conceptual foundations, and cultural significance of contemporary science. Themes will vary from year to year.

courses.name: PHAR 551 Pharmacy in Canada
courses.description: Cultural, social, behavioural and organizational foundations and theories of pharmacy in the Canadian health care system. Open only to Pharmacy Practice graduate students.

courses.name: EDST 601A Doctoral Seminar - DOCTORAL SEM
courses.description: Required of students in the first year of a doctoral program. Pass/Fail.

courses.name: SANS 300 Further Readings in Sanskrit
courses.description: Study of selected texts belonging to a particular period (e.g., Vedic) or representing a specific branch of kavya (poetic literature) or sastra (technical-philosophical literature).

courses.name: CHEM 519A Topics in Molecular Spectroscopy - TOP MOL SPECTROS
MINE 331 Physical Mineral Processes
courses.description: Mineral processing unit operations and sampling, crushing, grinding, screening, classification, gravity separation, magnetic separation, electrostatic separation, concentrate dewatering practices.

courses.name: PHRM 100 Foundations of Pharmacy
courses.description: Scientific concepts and pharmacy practice principles. Role of the pharmacist, patient assessment skills, professional identity, communication skills, and an understanding of legal and ethical responsibilities.

courses.name: FRST 530 Multiple Regression Methods
courses.description: Matrix algebra; algebra and inference of multiple linear and multiple curvilinear regressions for solution of problems in forestry and related fields. Non-linear regression. Methods of least squares for analysis of variance and covariance.

courses.name: EDCP 508B Review of Research in Curriculum and Pedagogy - REV RES CURR&PED
courses.description: Studies of recent research bearing on education practice.

courses.name: ARCH 513 Environmental Systems and Controls I
courses.description: Building form and fabric considerations to assure appropriate thermal, luminous, sonic, and atmospheric conditions within buildings.

courses.name: CNPS 427 Guidance: Planning and Decision-making
courses.description: The work of the beginning counsellor and guidance worker in assisting students with educational, vocational, and personal planning and decision-making.

courses.name: ATSC 498 Co-operative Work Placement III
courses.description: Approved and supervised technical work experience in an industrial, university or government setting for a minimum of 14 weeks. Normally taken in the Summer Session (Terms 1 and 2) after fourth year. Technical report required. Restricted to students admitted to the Co-operative Education Program in Atmospheric Science.
courses.prerequisites: ATSC 399 and one of ATSC 303, GEOB 304.

courses.name: MATH 615A Topics in Algebraic Geometry - ALGEBRAIC GEOMET
PCTH 404 Drug Assay and Pharmacometrics
courses.description: The techniques, including methods of statistical analysis, used to detect and measure the actions of endogenous or exogenous chemicals, using chemical assays and bioassays as appropriate. Enrolment limited to students in Pharmacology and others with permission of the department head.

courses.name: CHBE 597 M.A.Sc. Thesis Proposal Development
courses.description: Techniques for preparation of a critical literature review and focussed research proposal for M.A.Sc. candidates. Students perform oral and written critiques of published research in their area of study, define research questions and hypotheses, and develop a focussed research proposal.

courses.name: ECON 447 Monetary Theory
courses.description: Theoretical analysis of economies that use money; the emergence of money; the roles of money in the economy; models of money demand; the optimal quantity of money seignorage and inflation; monetary policy and macroeconomic stability; monetary policy in an open economy.
courses.prerequisites: One of ECON 301, ECON 304 and one of ECON 302, ECON 305.

courses.name: ZOOL 554 Topics in Comparative and Environmental Physiology
ORPA 715 Orthopaedic Clinic
courses.description: Evaluation of new patients and diagnosis and treatment of appropriate diseases. Basic signs and clinical features are both stressed in the total management of the patient. Two hours per week in the Outpatient Department under supervision of an orthopaedics faculty member.

courses.name: EOSC 332 Tectonic Evolution of North America
courses.description: An overview of the geology and tectonic evolution of North America; comparisons and contrasts between Precambrian rocks of the North American craton and Phanerozoic belts of the Cordilleran, Appalachian, Ouachita and Innuitian orogens;  interrelations between sedimentation, deformation, metamorphism and magmatism in a plate tectonic context.

courses.name: NURS 507 Pharmacology and Therapeutics in Primary Care
SPAN 221 Introduction to Literary Analysis in Spanish
courses.description: Critical analysis (e.g., terminology, analytical concepts) of at least three genres through the study of selected Iberian and Latin American literary texts.  This course is required for the Major Program and is taught in Spanish.

courses.name: LLED 493A Supervised Study in Modern Languages Education - SPR ST MDN LANG
FREN 578B Studies in Romance Philology - ROMANCE PHILOLGY
EECE 592 Architecture for Learning Systems
courses.description: Learning in neural networks; error backpropagation, simulated annealing, content addressable memories. Data representation topics. Reinforcement learning (RL). Implementation challenges in real world scale problems. Architectures for function approximation in RL. Comparison with conventional AI; history and emerging trends.

courses.name: PCTH 305 Basic Human Pharmacology
courses.description: Lectures and assigned reading on the effects, mechanisms of action, absorption, distribution, fate and excretion of major classes of therapeutic agents. Indications for the use of particular drugs will be discussed in terms of risk versus benefit for the individual and for society.

courses.name: ETEC 510 Design of Technology- Supported Learning Environments
EDST 541 Adult Learning: Contexts and Perspectives
LFS 302B International Field Studies - INTERNL FLD STD
courses.description: Field studies carried out abroad under staff direction. Participating students are assessed a fee.

courses.name: APBI 496B Applied Animal Biology Practicum - APBI PRACTICUM
courses.description: Application of principles and concepts of Applied Animal Biology to experiential learning in the fields of wild, companion, lab, and farm animal welfare and management.
courses.prerequisites: (Third-year standing or higher. APBI 314 and/or APBI 315 are recommended.)

courses.name: MICB 498 Co-operative Work Placement III
courses.description: Work experience in an industrial research setting, taken during the Summer Session (Terms 1 and 2) following fourth year. Restricted to students admitted to the Co-operative Education Program of Biotechnology in Microbiology and Immunology.

courses.name: PSYC 462 Drugs and Behavioural Neuroscience
courses.description: Introduction to neurochemical systems and functional neuroanatomy; animal models of human cognitive processes and mental disorders; neurochemical foundations and treatments for mental disorders. BIOL 205 and/or PCTH 325 recommended.

courses.name: ENGL 480 Asian Canadian and/or Asian Transnational Studies
courses.prerequisites: (3rd year standing and 6 credits of first-year English, or Arts One, or 6 credits of ASTU 100 from CAP or 3 credits of first-year English and 3 credits of WRDS 150.)

courses.name: MICB 507 Topics in Molecular Pathogenesis and Immunology
SURG 548A Seminar in Surgery - SEM IN SURGERY
CHIN 413 Introductory Modern Chinese Literature II (Non-Heritage)
courses.description: A reading-intensive introduction to modern Chinese literature from 1949 to the present, with a focus on fiction.

courses.name: LAW 463 Securities Regulation
courses.description: The law relating to the distribution of securities. Continuous and timely disclosure requirements and civil liability.

courses.name: LAW 408 Taxation of Corporations and Shareholders
courses.description: The taxation of corporations, the taxation of shareholders, and the tax implications of the reorganization of corporations. Credit will be granted for only one of LAW 408 or LAW 562.

courses.name: CELL 512 Gene and Cell-based Therapies for Disease
courses.description: The development of gene and cell-based therapies and their translation into clinical use.

courses.name: ARTH 225 Art in Europe to the Sixteenth Century
courses.description: A selective survey of painting, sculpture, and architecture.

courses.name: FRST 546 Research Methods and Philosophies in Science
courses.description: Lectures and seminars in research philosophies and methods with special emphasis on field and applied research.

courses.name: PLAN 522 Qualitative Data Collection and Analysis
SPPH 530 Epidemiology of Occupational and Environmental Health
courses.description: Design and analysis of etiologic research in occupational health.

courses.name: COGS 200 Introduction to Cognitive Systems
courses.description: Interdisciplinary examination of human mental processes and how these are mediated by the brain. Will draw on cognitive psychology, linguistics, cognitive neuroscience, philosophy, artificial intelligence.
courses.prerequisites: (second-year standing in the Faculty of Arts or Science.)

courses.name: LAW 477 Negotiation and Dispute Resolution
courses.description: Negotiation and bargaining; formulation of general principles governing the negotiation process; negotiation in legal practice; alternative means of dispute resolution.

courses.name: MUSC 538C Staging and Directing Opera - STAGE&DRCT OPERA
WOOD 249 Contemporary Topics in Forestry and Wood Products
courses.description: Seminars on current forestry and wood products topics.

courses.name: WOOD 485 Furniture Construction
courses.description: The theory and practice of modern construction techniques used in the manufacture of furniture and cabinets.

courses.name: BUSI 330 Foundations of Real Estate Appraisal
courses.description: Introduction to concepts and techniques for appraising the value of real estate.

courses.name: PHAR 590 Research in the Pharmaceutical Sciences: Principles and Methods
FNH 481 Dietetic Internship I
courses.description: Full-time internship placements within British Columbia health authorities. Pass/Fail.

courses.name: BAFI 580C Special Topics in Finance - TPCS FINANCE
MATH 549A Thesis for Master's Degree - MASTERS THESIS
MATH 414 Mathematical Demonstrations
courses.description: Students will prepare material illustrating ideas and applications of mathematics and present it to audiences outside the University. Intended for third or fourth year Mathematics students and Math/Science Education students.

courses.name: MUSC 520A Introduction to Music Research - INTRO MUSIC RES
courses.description: Principal resources of the research library.

courses.name: SOWK 316 Integrative Seminar in Social Work Theory, Policy and Practice
courses.description: Integrates students' learning from field, practice, policy and theory courses for the purposes of professional development.

courses.name: NEST 101 Introduction to Near Eastern and Egyptian Archaeology
courses.description: An overview of the past two centuries of archaeological investigations of the civilizations of the ancient Near East and Egypt.

courses.name: ENGL 492C Senior Honours Seminar - SR HONORS SEMNR2
courses.description: Offerings in literary research.

courses.name: CIVL 316 Hydrology and Open Channel Flow
courses.description: Introduction to open channel hydraulics, engineering hydrology, and water resource systems; estimation of design discharge; flood statistics; nonuniform steady open channel flow; energy and momentum principles, backwater analysis; culvert and bridge hydraulics.

courses.name: SOIL 524 Instrumentation for Biometeorology
courses.description: The theory, design and evaluation of instrumentation for biometeorological research. Consent of instructor.

courses.name: CIVL 439 Design of Timber Structures
courses.description: Design of timber structural elements using limit states design principles; joints and fasteners, sawn lumber and engineered wood products, light frame systems and shear walls.

courses.name: DENT 774B Interdisciplinary Care in Orthodontics and Dentofacial Orthopedics I - INTD ORTH&DNT I
courses.description: Continues in second year.

courses.name: ARTH 377 Arts of the Northwest Coast Peoples: The South
courses.description: The histories, historiography and cultural diversity of the Southern  Northwest Coast region; persistence and innovation in the arts in communities, and in cross-cultural and market spheres.

courses.name: MICB 323 Molecular Immunology and Virology Laboratory
courses.description: Genetic manipulations of bacteria, introductory immunological and virological procedures, tissue culture. Restricted to students in Microbiology and Immunology specializations.

courses.name: FMED 401 Host Defenses and Infection
courses.description: An introduction to the anatomic and physiologic basis of host defense against infection. The classification and pathogenic mechanisms of micro-organisms will be taught as will the biological and pharmacological bases of treatment and prevention.

courses.name: EOSC 475 Marine Microbiology
courses.description: Advanced biology, ecology and diversity of marine microbes. Emphasis on the roles of bacteria and viruses in marine foodwebs and geochemical cycles.
courses.prerequisites: (A minimum of 6 credits of third-year level life science courses.)

courses.name: CPSC 304 Introduction to Relational Databases
courses.description: Overview of database systems, ER models, logical database design and normalization, formal relational query languages, SQL and other commercial languages,data warehouses, special topics.
courses.prerequisites: Either (a) CPSC 221 or (b) all of CPSC 260, EECE 320 and one of CPSC 210, EECE 210, EECE 309.

courses.name: EPSE 598B Field Experiences - FIELD EXPERIENCE
courses.description: Pass/Fail.

courses.name: APBI 322 Horticultural Techniques
courses.description: An introduction to horticultural practice in an experiential learning format. Plant identification, seeding, propagation, pruning, cultivation media, pesticide application and safety are examined in the context of integrated crop management. An additional fee may be required for the pesticide certification examination.

courses.name: MINE 540 Acid Rock Drainage
courses.description: Lectures and seminars on topics of importance in acid rock drainage including fundamentals of ARD generation, prediction, prevention, control, treatment and monitoring for waste management and regulatory control in the mining industry. Credit will be granted for only one of MINE 540 or MINE 580.

courses.name: SPPH 400 Statistics for Health Research
courses.description: Planned collection, numeric and graphic summarization, and elementary statistical analysis of data. Examples primarily from health sciences illustrate standard techniques for parametric and non-parametric hypothesis testing; regression and correlation; contingency tables. Also randomization, "blindfolding" and other specifically biomedical topics in statistics. Class size may be limited.
courses.prerequisites: (Ability to use high school Algebra and simple graphs.)

courses.name: LAW 439 Construction Law
courses.description: Legal issues relating to the construction process. Not offered each year, consult Faculty.

courses.name: MINE 598 Seminar
courses.description: Topics in mining, mineral processing and the environment for M.A.Sc. and M.Eng. students.

courses.name: EDUC 449B Supervised Research Investigation - SUPERVISED RSRCH
courses.description: Available only to outstanding students approved by the Associate Dean (Teacher Education).

courses.name: PHAR 403 Clinical Skills: Administration of Injections
courses.description: Training for authorization to administer injections.

courses.name: RELG 500A Topics in Biblical Studies - BIBLICAL STUDIES
courses.description: Studies in the history, literature, canon and text, and the religious thought of the Old and New Testaments. This includes the study of the cultural and religious milieu out of which these documents arose. Such studies require a competence in the canonical languages (Biblical Hebrew and/or Koine Greek), usually achieved by not less than two years of study.

courses.name: RHSC 512 Directed Studies in Pathology in Rehabilitation
VISA 401E Advanced Open Studio - ADV OPEN STUDIO
courses.description: Research-based studio with thematic or disciplinary focus.  Intended for senior Visual Art undergraduate students.
courses.prerequisites: Three of VISA 310, VISA 311, VISA 320, VISA 321, VISA 330, VISA 331, VISA 340, VISA 341, VISA 350, VISA 351, VISA 360, VISA 361, VISA 370, VISA 390.

courses.name: PHIL 362A History and Philosophy of Economics from Aristotle to Adam Smith - HIST/PHIL ECON
courses.description: The development of economic thought from Aristotle to Adam Smith, focusing primarily on the conceptual foundations of economics, particularly the problems of value, distribution, and economic growth.

courses.name: HUNU 505 Current Issues in Applied Nutrition
PSYC 448E Directed Studies in Biopsychology - DIR STUD BIOPSYC
courses.description: Directed investigation of an experimental problem requiring a written report of the findings.
courses.prerequisites: (At least a 72% average in the preceding 30 credits and permission of a faculty member who is prepared to supervise the investigation.)

courses.name: PHAR 508 Advanced Applications in Clinical Pharmacokinetics
courses.description: Pharmacokinetic applications in therapeutic drug monitoring and patient care; specific drugs and disease states; effects of age and concomitant drug administration.

courses.name: CNPS 508B Review of Research in Educational Methods - REV RES ED MTD 2
courses.description: Studies are made of recent research bearing on educational practice.
courses.prerequisites: (Appropriate senior undergraduate introductory or methods course.)

courses.name: ECED 508B Review of Research in Early Childhood Education - REV RES IN ECED
POLI 511A Core Seminar in Comparative Government and Politics - CORE CMP GOV&POL
ECED 580B Problems in Early Childhood Education - PROB IN ECE
courses.description: Investigation and report of a problem.

courses.name: ASTR 300 Galaxies
courses.description: Structure and kinematics of our galaxy. Spiral arms and dynamics of stars in spiral and elliptical galaxies. Galactic formation, evolution, dynamics, and groups. Active galaxies and quasars.
courses.prerequisites: One of ASTR 202, ASTR 205 and one of PHYS 210, EOSC 211, CPSC 302, CPSC 303.

courses.name: KIN 375 Exercise Physiology II
courses.description: Transport of oxygen during exercise in humans.  Regulation and integration of the cardiovascular and respiratory systems during exercise.

courses.name: MECH 550B Special Advanced Courses - SUSTNB BUILD SCI
courses.description: Special advanced lecture courses may be arranged for graduate students upon the approval of the department head. There will not be more than 6 credits in any one such course.

courses.name: ITST 333 Masterpieces of the Novella in Italian Literature
courses.description: A study of the genre of the novella as an expression of social and political contexts within and across cultures from its inception in feudal times to the post-modern age.

courses.name: BIOL 335 Molecular Genetics
courses.description: Isolation and identification of genes, analysis of gene structure; gene expression and its regulation in prokaryotes and in eukaryotes; developmental genetics.
courses.prerequisites: One of BIOL 233, BIOL 234, BIOL 334, MICB 322, FRST 302.

courses.name: MUSC 593B Music Performance (Major) - VOICE
courses.description: Private instruction, vocal or instrumental. May be repeated for credit, in accordance with program requirements.

courses.name: THTR 320 History of Theatre I
courses.description: Core concepts in world theatre history and the development of theatre prior to the nineteenth century.

courses.name: GRSJ 505A Directed Reading in Advanced Feminist Studies - DIR READ FEMNST
PHAR 456 Introduction to Pharmacoeconomics and Health Technology Assessment
courses.description: An introduction to the essential components of economic assessments of health technologies with a particular focus on pharmaceuticals as technologies.

courses.name: FNH 430 Enology and Wine Biotechnology
courses.description: Yeasts and bacteria involved in wine making, metabolic pathways leading to the production of flavour and spoilage compounds, genetic improvement of wine yeasts, and red and white wine fermentations. Approaches and technologies for the improvement of wine safety. Sensory evaluation of wines.

courses.name: SPAN 312B Topics in Latin American Literature in Translation - LA LIT IN TRANS
courses.description: Introduction for the non-specialist to the major contemporary Latin American literary works and their cultural background. Not available for credit toward a Major or Minor program in Spanish.

courses.name: CHIN 208 Intensive Intermediate Chinese II (Non-Heritage)
courses.description: Skills in listening, speaking, reading, and writing, and understanding of Chinese culture.

courses.name: INDS 502D Interdisciplinary Studies: Thematic Seminars - INTERFACULTY THM
courses.description: Seminars, lectures, and discussions of topics involving several faculties. Contact the Interdisciplinary Studies Program for specific topics (www.isgp.ubc.ca).

courses.name: EDCP 301 Art - Elementary: Curriculum and Pedagogy
courses.description: Pass/Fail.

courses.name: ENGL 349A Seventeenth-Century Studies - 17TH CENT STUDIE
courses.prerequisites: (3rd year standing and 6 credits of first-year English, or Arts One, or 6 credits of ASTU 100 from CAP or 3 credits of first-year English and 3 credits of ASTU 150)

courses.name: RELG 101 Introduction to the Western (Abrahamic) Religions: Judaism, Christianity, and Islam
courses.description: An overview of the three main western monotheistic (Abrahamic) religions, together with the concepts used in studying religion, The focus will be on the origins and representative texts along with some historical development and current experience of each religion.

courses.name: SOWK 572A Child and Family: Policy and Practice - CHLD&FAM POL&PRC
ETEC 565M Special Course in Subject Matter Field - SC SUB MAT FIELD
FNH 455 Applied International Nutrition
courses.description: Applying nutrition concepts and principles in addressing problems of malnutrition and food insecurity in international settings.  Basics of developing culturally acceptable, sustainable nutrition intervention programs.

courses.name: ASTU 400S Interdisciplinary Studies in Arts - MUSQUEAM
courses.description: For upper-division students in the Faculty of Arts. Topics announced annually.

courses.name: WOOD 280 Wood Anatomy and Identification
courses.description: Introduction to tree growth; macroscopic and microscopic anatomy and identification of softwoods and hardwoods; descriptions of cell wall ultra-structure, wood variability and wood quality.

courses.name: STAT 203 Statistical Methods
courses.description: Organizing, displaying and summarizing data. Inference estimation and testing for elementary probability models. Not for credit towards a B.Sc. (Consult the Credit Exclusion list within the Faculty of Science section in the Calendar.)

courses.name: HIST 356 Twentieth-Century Germany
courses.description: The political, social, and cultural history of Germany in the twentieth century.

courses.name: PHYS 400 Introduction to Elementary Particles
courses.description: Standard model, classification of elementary particles and forces of nature, symmetries, conservation laws, quark model, quantum electrodynamics, quantum chromodynamics, and the theory of weak interactions.

courses.name: FIPR 399C Directed Studies: Off-Campus Research - DS: OFF-CAMP RES
courses.description: Off-campus film production field research. Based on film project work outside the university.

courses.name: BAHR 580D Topics in Human Resources - TPCS HUMAN RES
ANTH 341A Museums, Heritage and Memory - MUSE HERITG MEM
courses.description: Museums, galleries, monuments, and other cultural institutions' relations to our perception of history and geography.

courses.name: GRSJ 305 Issues in Community and International Organizing
courses.description: Critical examination and practical applications of concepts, theories, methods, and strategies of gender-aware organizing at the community and international levels.
courses.prerequisites: Either (a) all of GRSJ 101, GRSJ 102 or (b) all of WMST 101, WMST 102. (or third-year standing.)

courses.name: PHAR 453A Directed Studies in Pharmacy Practice - DIR STDY PHAR PR
courses.description: Individual assignments involving library and field work investigations of problems associated with pharmacy practice. Enrolment restricted. Open to upper level students.
courses.prerequisites: (Successful completion of the first three years of required courses in the pharmacy curriculum.)

courses.name: NEST 401 Literature of Ancient Egypt or the Ancient Near East
courses.description: The main genres and texts of Egyptian and Ancient Near Eastern Literature and their modern Interpretation. Credit will be granted for only one of NEST 401 or 505.

courses.name: MECH 520 Control Sensors and Actuators
courses.description: Review of control, instrumentation and design. Performance specification of control components, component matching, error analysis. Operating principles, analysis, modelling, design considerations of control sensors and actuators such as analog sensors for motion measurement, digital transducers, stepper motors, DC motors, induction motors, synchronous motors, and hydraulic actuators. Control techniques pertaining to actuators. Applications.

courses.name: HIST 365 Europe During the Renaissance
courses.description: The interplay between new and traditional ideas, styles, and institutions from the fourteenth to the mid-sixteenth century, with emphasis upon the relationship of social, economic, and political factors to intellectual and cultural change.

courses.name: LIBE 590 Graduating Paper
courses.description: Pass/Fail.

courses.name: DENT 542 Oral Cell Biology and Biochemistry
PHYS 504 Special Relativity and Classical Electromagnetism
courses.description: Boundary-value problems, Green's functions and multipole expansions, magnetostatics, Faraday's law of induction, retarded potentials, Poynting's theorem and conservation laws, gauge invariance. Propagation of electromagnetic waves. Presentation of radiation from moving charges, classical electron theory.
courses.prerequisites: (A background in electricity and magnetism such as covered PHYS 401 is highly recommended.)

courses.name: RMES 515 Integrated Watershed Management
courses.description: Methods of watershed evaluation, land-water interactions, key aspects of hydrology, water quality and aquatic biota, land use impacts on water resources, community involvement, and integration of multiple land use activities and their cumulative impacts.  Credit will be give for only one of SOIL 515 or RMES 515.

courses.name: CHEM 405 Biophysical Chemistry
courses.description: Interactions of macromolecules in solution: ligand, antibody and ion binding to macromolecules; thermodynamics of polymer solutions; excluded volume effects; phase separation; partition in two phase polymer solutions.

courses.name: BAEN 580C Topics in Entrepreneurship - TPCS ENTREPR'SHP
EDUC 504 Seminar in Qualitative Data Analysis
courses.prerequisites: One of EDUC 503, EPSE 595. ((May also be taken as co-requisites.))

courses.name: SOWK 554C Qualitative Methods in Social Work Research - RSCH-QUALT MTHDS
FREN 495R Research Seminar in French - RESEARCH SEMINAR
courses.description: Research on critical topics related to selected literary works. Limited enrolment: required of honours, but open to majors students in French. May be taken twice for credit, with different content, to a maximum of 6 credits.
courses.prerequisites: One of FREN 320, FREN 321, FREN 328, FREN 329, FREN 330.

courses.name: LIBR 542E Services for Youth - SERVICES YOUTH
ECON 407 Topics in Macroeconomics
courses.description: Selected topics in advanced macroeconomic analysis.
courses.prerequisites: One of ECON 301, ECON 304 and one of ECON 302, ECON 305 and one of ECON 303, ECON 306.

courses.name: MATH 360 Mathematical Modeling in Science
courses.description: Principles of model selection and basic modeling techniques in biology, earth science, chemistry and physics. Optimization, dynamical systems and stochastic processes. Preference will be given to Combined Major in Science students, or to students in Year 3 or higher.
courses.prerequisites: One of MATH 101, MATH 103, MATH 105, MATH 121, SCIE 001.

courses.name: PSYC 207 Contemporary Topics in Biological and Cognitive Psychology
courses.description: A focus on the interpretation of contemporary research in neuroscience, cognition, perception, memory, and learning.

courses.name: KORN 410B Modern Korean Short Fiction - MOD KORN SHRT FC
courses.description: Reading and translating twentieth-century Korean short fiction.

courses.name: HIST 339 The United States Since 1945: The Limits of Power
courses.description: American military and geo-political power during and after Cold War; wars in Korea, Vietnam, and Middle East; domestic issues including McCarthyism, social movements (blacks, women, youth, gays and lesbians, and Native Americans), consumerism, immigration, and rise of New Right.

courses.name: CPSC 416 Distributed Systems
courses.description: Concepts and design of distributed systems. Communication architecture and models for interprocess communication. Process migration, naming, distributed file systems, fault tolerance, and concurrency control.
courses.prerequisites: One of CPSC 313, EECE 315, CPEN 331 and one of CPSC 317, EECE 358, ELEC 331.

courses.name: PHAR 430 Biomolecular Pharmaceutical Chemistry I
courses.description: Chemical principles and their application to drugs used to regulate enzyme activity.

courses.name: EECE 571A Electrical Engineering Seminar and Special Problems - ANT PROPGTN II
CRWR 502V Advanced Writing for New Media I - ADVWR NEWMEDIA I
LAW 344D Innovations in Governance and Regulatory Design - GOV & REG DESIGN
courses.description: Emerging interdisciplinary scholarship on regulation, governance, and institutional design.  Examination of research and experience around both formal and legal regulatory strategies, and other informal, decentred, or non-state-based methods of ordering individual and organizational behaviour.

courses.name: ANAT 515 Functional Human Anatomy of the Musculoskeletal Systems: Back, Limbs and Joints
SPPH 510 Measurement of Health Care
courses.description: Concepts and techniques of measurement in epidemiological research.  Topics covered include validity, reliability and misclassification, scale design and the construction of questionnaires and indices for both health outcomes and exposures.

courses.name: BUSI 221 Real Estate Finance in a Canadian Context
courses.description: History, function and mechanics of Canadian mortgage markets.

courses.name: FRST 408 Problems of Forest Entomology
courses.description: Decision-making in the protection of forests from insects. Insect problems viewed from other disciplines of forestry. Bases of biological and economic evaluation, and choice of control methods.

courses.name: ECON 226 Making Sense of Economic Data
courses.description: Formulation of a testable hypothesis, identification of relevant data, use of appropriate statistical tools.  May not be taken for credit by students with fourth-year standing in ECON or COMM. Not available for credit to students already having credit for either of ECON 325 or ECON 326 (or equivalent).

courses.name: EPSE 515A Seminar in Behaviour Disorders - SEM BHVR DSORDRS
PORT 102 First-Year Portuguese II
courses.description: Grammar, composition, translation, oral practice. Credit will be granted for only one of PORT 102 or PORT 110.

courses.name: FMPR 420 Family Practice Continuum II
courses.description: This clinical course is a continuation of FMPR 401. Supervised patient interviewing, history taking, and physical examinations in the Family Practice setting. A period of time will be spent in family practice settings demonstrating focused care in a particular area.

courses.name: FIPR 469A Special Projects - SPECIAL PROJECTS
courses.description: Advanced film production, including interdisciplinary projects.

courses.name: FIPR 131 Introduction to Screen Acting
courses.description: Fundamental techniques used to create emotionally engaged and narratively effective performances for film, video, and digital media.

courses.name: MUSC 693D Music Performance (Major) - WIND,BRASS&PERC
courses.description: Private instruction, vocal or instrumental.

courses.name: CLST 111 Late Republican and Early Imperial Rome
courses.description: The history and culture, values, and achievements of Late Republican and Early Imperial Rome.

courses.name: PHYS 216 Intermediate Mechanics
courses.description: Review of kinematics, Newton's laws, angular momentum and fixed axis rotation. Rigid body motion, central forces, non-inertial frames of reference.
courses.prerequisites: One of PHYS 101, PHYS 107, PHYS 117, PHYS 157, PHYS 153, SCIE 001 and one of MATH 152, MATH 221, MATH 223.
courses.corequisites: One of MATH 200, MATH 217, MATH 226, MATH 253, MATH 263.

courses.name: PHYS 305 Introduction to Biophysics
courses.description: Physical principles involved in biological systems at the microscopic and molecular scales. Diffusion, low Reynolds number dynamics, the physicist's view of biomolecular structure, models of molecular motors and membranes.
courses.prerequisites: One of PHYS 102, PHYS 108, PHYS 153, SCIE 001 and either (a) one of PHYS 203, PHYS 313 or (b) one of ENPH 257, PHYS 257, CHEM 201, CHEM 205 and one of MATH 302, MATH 318, STAT 241, STAT 251, STAT 302.

courses.name: MATH 100 Differential Calculus with Applications to Physical Sciences and Engineering
courses.description: Derivatives of elementary functions. Applications and modeling: graphing, optimization. Consult the Faculty of Science Credit Exclusion List: www.students.ubc.ca/calendar/index.cfm?tree=12,215,410,414.
courses.prerequisites: (High-school calculus and one of (a) a score of 80% or higher in BC Principles of Mathematics 12 or Pre-calculus 12, or (b) a satisfactory score in the UBC Mathematics Basic Skills Test.)

courses.name: ECON 482 The Economic Consequences of Religion
courses.description: Analysis of the economic aspects of religious behaviour, the structure of religious organizations, the effects of competition in the religious marketplace, the economic benefits of religion, and some of the ill-effects of religion (such as religious strife and terrorism).

courses.name: EDCP 355A Chemistry - Secondary: Curriculum and Pedagogy - CHEM SEC C&P
courses.description: Pass/Fail.
courses.prerequisites: (A completed concentration in chemistry or permission of the Head.)

courses.name: BIOC 448A Directed Studies in Biochemistry - DIRECTED STUDIES
courses.description: A library (3 credits) or a laboratory project with written report (3 or 6 credits) allowing a student to undertake an investigation on a specific topic as agreed upon by the faculty and student.
courses.prerequisites: (Permission of the Department Head is required.)

courses.name: COHR 486B Special Topics in Organizational Behaviour and Human Resources - IMPROV FOR LDRS
MATH 521 Numerical Analysis of Partial Differential Equations
FRE 460 Economics of Food Consumption
courses.description: Microeconomics of consumer decisions and public policy in food contexts; foodborne illness; economic causes and consequences of obesity; sin taxes and prohibitions; information campaigns and advertising; labeling; food waste and ethics.

courses.name: ASIA 561A Problems of Modernization in Eastern and Southern Asia - MODERN S&E ASIA
ELEC 494 Biomedical Engineering Capstone Design Project
courses.description: Design, analysis, and implementation of solutions in response to a real world biomedical engineering problem, provided by industry, research laboratories, or other suitable entities.  Includes coverage of topics such as project management.

courses.name: EPSE 303 Teaching Highly Able Learners
courses.description: Identification and appraisal of developmental and educational needs of highly able learners.

courses.name: LAW 491 Law Students Legal Advice Program Credit
courses.description: Restricted to a limited number of upper year students who (a) in their first or second year have participated in the provision of legal services to the public through the Law Students Legal Advice Program, and (b) continue that participation in their second or third year. A student who receives credit for LAW 474, LAW 488 or LAW 490 cannot receive credit for this course.

courses.name: EDST 577 Social Contexts of Educational Policy, Politics and Practice
PHIL 334 Sex, Gender and Philosophy
courses.description: Relationship between sex, gender, and philosophy. Topics may include ethics, epistemology, science, social relations, law, and personhood.

courses.name: FNH 482 Dietetic Internship II
courses.description: Full-time internship placements within British Columbia health authorities. Pass/Fail.

courses.name: EMBA 598B Topics in Strategy and Economics - TPCS STRAT&ECON
courses.description: Restricted to Executive M.B.A. students.

courses.name: ENGL 492B Senior Honours Seminar - SR HONORS SEMNR2
courses.description: Offerings in literary research.

courses.name: PHYS 555A Directed Studies in Physics - DIRECTED STUDIES
courses.description: With approval of the department head, advanced studies under the direction of a staff member may be arranged in special cases.

courses.name: PLAN 550B Directed Studies - DIRECTED STUDIES
courses.description: In special cases and with the approval of the Director of the school, a student may study an advanced topic under the direction of a faculty member.

courses.name: MUSC 161A Piano Chamber Ensembles - PIANO CHAM ENSEM
courses.description: May be repeated for credit in accordance with program requirements for B.Mus.

courses.name: LATN 102 First-Year Latin II
courses.description: Classical Latin for students with no previous knowledge of Latin, Part II.

courses.name: MECH 464 Industrial Robotics
courses.description: Definition and classification of industrial robotic devices. Selection and implementation issues. Workcell environments. Forward and inverse kinematics, dynamics, trajectory planning. Sensing and manipulation tasks. Control architectures. Credit will be granted for only one of ELEC 442, EECE 487, MECH 464, or MECH 563.

courses.name: CCFI 580A Problems in Education - PROB IN EDUC
courses.description: Investigation and report of a problem.

courses.name: PHIL 100 Introduction to Philosophy
courses.description: Basic problems and methods of Philosophy. Topics such as the existence of God, the nature and scope of human knowledge, the relationship between mind and body, personal identity, free will, issues and problems in moral philosophy. Credit will not be granted for both PHIL 100 and either or both PHIL 101 or PHIL 102.

courses.name: COMM 482 New Product Development
courses.description: How new products are developed and the factors that influence success and failure throughout the various stages of development.

courses.name: APSC 411 Co-operative Work Placement
courses.description: Supervised, technical work experience in an approved company or organization for a minimum of three months. Technical report. Restricted to students meeting the requirements of the Faculty of Applied Science and Co-operative Education.

courses.name: PHIL 371 Foundations of Chinese Thought
courses.description: Chinese thought from the Han dynasty (206 BCE to 220 CE) in its historical and cultural contexts. Includes among others: Confucius; Mo Zi; the Legalists/Authoritarians; Zhuang Zi; the Lao Zi book.

courses.name: SPAN 490H Topics in Spanish-American Literature of the Twentieth-Century - SP-AM LIT 20C
courses.prerequisites: One of SPAN 220, SPAN 221 and SPAN 302.

courses.name: SCAN 411A Scandinavian Drama and Film in Translation - DRAMA & FILM TRN
courses.description: Traces the explosive development of a provincial theatre into one of the seminal forces of twentieth-century drama and film. Emphasis on Ibsen, Strindberg, and Bergman.

courses.name: RELG 209 Eden to Exile: Introduction to the Hebrew Bible
courses.description: An overview of the Hebrew Bible ("Old Testament"), with emphasis on its ancient Near Eastern context; its competing religious perspectives; and its limits as a historical source.

courses.name: LLED 213 Introduction to Intercultural Communication and Socialization in Multicultural Contexts
courses.description: The processes by which individuals become competent members of society through the use of language.

courses.name: MINE 501B Topics for Engineers in the Mining Industry - NRTH AMER MINE
courses.description: Leading practices and technologies employed in the Canadian Mining Industry.  Topics include: mining, mineral processing, mine finance and mining and the environment.

courses.name: BIOC 498 Internship Work Placement III
courses.description: Approved and supervised technical work experience in an industrial or academic research setting for four months. Technical report required. Restricted to students admitted to the Internship Program in Biochemistry and Molecular Biology.

courses.name: ASIA 410 International Relations in Premodern East Asia
courses.description: International relations, particularly between Korea and Japan in the premodern East Asian context, focusing on migration, trade, diplomacy, war, collective memory, mutual perceptions, and the context of the Sinocentric international order.

courses.name: SOCI 100C Introduction to Sociology - INTRO SOCIOLOGY
courses.description: Introduction to problems in the analysis of social structures and processes. Basic sociological concepts will be introduced and their application demonstrated in various areas of sociology. Credit will be granted for only one of (i) SOCI 100C (6) or (ii) SOCI 100A (3) and SOCI 100B (3).

courses.name: HIST 408 U.S. Foreign Relations from Independence to World War II
courses.description: U.S. foreign policy and international history.  Examines the American rise to power and political, economic, and cultural relationships between the United States and other peoples, organizations, and states worldwide.

courses.name: PHYS 516 Statistical Mechanics
courses.description: Mean field theory, Landau theory of phase transitions, critical phenomena, renormalization theory. Monte Carlo method, linear response theory, fluctuations.

courses.name: FRST 449C Directed Studies in Forestry - DIRECTED STUDIES
courses.description: In special cases and with the approval of the instructor concerned, a student may carry on directed studies of specific problems in forestry.

courses.name: LLED 480E Advanced Studies in Language and Literacy Education - ADV ST LNG LIT
courses.description: Credit will be given for only 6 credits of LLED 480 and 429.

courses.name: HIST 237A History of the United States - HISTORY OF USA
courses.description: Survey from colonial period to present examining political system, slavery, Civil War, race relations and civil rights, westward expansion, industrialization, feminism, expanding international presence, Cold War, and modern culture.

courses.name: GREK 401B Greek Prose - GREEK PROSE
courses.description: Studies in history, philosophy and/or oratory.

courses.name: SOWK 529A Communities and Social Development: Debates, Approaches and Fields of Practice - CMNTY & SC DEV
EDCP 492 Special Study in Home Economics: Textile Studies
PSYC 312A History of Psychology - PSYCHOLOGY HIST
courses.description: The principal trends of psychological explanation and events in the history of psychology from the earliest times to the present. Open only to Major or Honours students or by permission of the instructor.
courses.prerequisites: Either (a) PSYC 100 or (b) all of PSYC 101, PSYC 102. (or (c) 6 credits of 200-level Psychology (but not 205 or 263).)

courses.name: SCAN 336 Scandinavian Crime Fiction (in English)
courses.description: Crime fictions and films as a mirror of Scandinavian society.

courses.name: LAW 611C Doctoral Seminar II: Comparative and Interdisciplinary Perspectives on Legal Theory - DOC SEM II: COMP
courses.description: Applicability of legal concepts in different cultures and societies, and the consequences for the form and structure of law.

courses.name: PHAR 452 Therapeutics IV
courses.description: Rational drug therapy, management of patient-specific drug-related problems and therapeutic monitoring of selected disease states.

courses.name: EDST 527 Higher Education Policy: International and Comparative Perspectives
MUSC 403C Selected Topics in Music - INTRACTIV PRFMNS
courses.description: See School of Music schedule for description and prerequisites. Restricted to B. Mus. and B.A. in Music students.

courses.name: ARCL 309 The Archaeology of Collapse and Sustainability
courses.description: An evaluation of the issues of sustainability and collapse of ecological and social systems through the archaeological study of the past.

courses.name: FNEL 102 Introduction to a Salish Language II
courses.description: Continued focus on the diverse range of language learning skills that advance competency in conversational fluency, pronunciation, comprehension, vocabulary, oral traditions, literacy, grammatical understanding, and the cultural contextualization of language use.

courses.name: BIOC 514 Advanced Topics in Protein Chemistry
courses.description: Topics will include contemporary theoretical and experimental investigation of protein structure-function relationships. Topics will vary. Given in alternate years.

courses.name: MINE 590G Special Advanced Topics - EXTRCTIV INDSTRY
courses.description: A special advanced course may be arranged upon the approval of the department head.

courses.name: SPHA 563 Ethics and Ethical Decision Making in Health Care
EDCP 378 Business Education II - Secondary: Curriculum and Pedagogy
courses.description: Pass/Fail.

courses.name: ARTH 347 Architecture in Europe: Modern Paradigms of Design (1837-present)
courses.description: An examination of new requirements imposed on architecture by the consolidation of a capitalist economy, industrialization, new technologies and scientific methods.

courses.name: FRST 305 Silviculture
courses.description: Silviculture concepts and principles; stand dynamics; artificial and natural regeneration; cultural techniques for forest stand establishment and stand tending; silvicultural systems; decision making and development of prescriptions; connections to forest planning.

courses.name: SURG 504 Advanced General Surgery I
courses.description: Fundamental concepts in general surgery. Given in alternate years.

courses.name: MECH 405 Acoustics and Noise Control
courses.description: Wave properties; the decibel; hearing, deafness, and hearing protectors; noise criteria and regulations; sound measurement; sound-source characterization; real noise sources, sound propagation outdoors, in ducts and pipes and in rooms; sound transmission; silencers; sound absorbers; partitions.

courses.name: LAW 563 Taxation of Partnerships and Trusts
courses.description: Survey of statutory and judicial rules governing the taxation of income earned through partnerships and trusts. Credit will be granted for only one of LAW 409 or LAW 563.
courses.prerequisites: One of LAW  220, LAW  407, LAW  506, LAW  561.

courses.name: ITST 231 Introduction to Italian Culture I: From the Middle Ages to the Early Modern Period
CIVL 441 Transportation Planning and Analysis
courses.description: Transportation systems planning and analysis: data needs; surveys and analysis; sampling techniques; trip generation; trip distribution; modal choice; trip assignment; traffic impact studies; system evaluation.

courses.name: LING 433 Native Languages of the Americas
courses.description: Survey of the indigenous languages of the Americas. Study of the basis of genetic classification and areal similarities. The structure of representative languages will be presented and contrasted. The present status of American Indian languages will be considered. Note: this course is not necessarily offered every year.

courses.name: ORPA 721 Orthopaedic Seminars
courses.description: A series of seminars is given weekly, and during each 2-hour session a topic in clinical orthopaedics is reviewed. The subject matter includes the whole spectrum of orthopaedics. One or more faculty members are in attendance at each seminar.

courses.name: SPPH 541 Economic Evaluation
courses.description: Economic evaluation of health service interventions and programs, with emphasis on methods and components of program costing.

courses.name: EOSC 561 Theory and Methods in Seismic Interpretation
courses.description: Topics to be selected from the following: forward modelling, analysis and inversion procedures as used in multichannel reflection, wide-angle reflection and refraction studies of the lithosphere. Velocity analyses, wave equation migration, dip moveout, synthetic seismograms, tomographic inversion, one-dimensional synthetic seismograms, tau-p methods, waveform inversion, two-dimensional ray tracing and synthetic seismograms, tomographic inversion.

courses.name: LAW 409 Taxation of Partnerships and Trusts
courses.description: Survey of statutory and judicial rules governing the taxation of income earned through partnerships and trusts. Credit will be granted for only one of LAW 409 or LAW 563.

courses.name: ASIA 310A Studies in the History of a Major Asian Civilization - STDS HIST MAJ AS
courses.description: Study of an Asian culture area different from those covered in existing courses. Not given every year. Consult Department for details. May be taken multiple times on different subjects for credit.

courses.name: PORT 308 Portuguese for Business (in Portuguese)
courses.description: Communicative Portuguese for students studying Commerce or otherwise preparing for a career in business.

courses.name: FIPR 533B Advanced Problems in Directing - ADV PROB FILM PR
courses.description: Problems in directing narrative film. Explores problems in scripting, performance, shot design, and editing through seminars, workshops with acting students, and production exercises.

courses.name: MATH 001 Algebra
courses.description: Numbers and their properties; exponents, radicals, absolute value, inqualities, functions and their graphs; factoring; solving polynomial, rational, and exponetial equations; and the sine and cosine law. Non-credit Math course offered by Continuing Studies in consultation with the Mathematics Department and taught by Continuing Studies instructors.

courses.name: INDS 530C Directed Studies - DIRECTED STUDIES
courses.description: A series of directed readings related to student's area of interdisciplinary studies. This advanced course may be taken upon approval of the Program head.

courses.name: EDUC 490W Special Studies in Education - SPEC STUDIES ED
courses.description: Topics not covered in a course. A pilot course may be offered under this name for only one year and with permission of the Associate Dean (Teacher Education).

courses.name: SPHA 502 Managerial Accounting
courses.description: Development and use of accounting information for management planning and control, and the development of cost information for financial reports. Same as BAAC 550; credit will not be given for both.

courses.name: HIST 402A Problems in International Relations - PRBS INTRNL RELN
courses.description: Selected topics such as trade, migration, diplomacy, war, migration, colonialism, and post- colonialism. Priority for registration to majors in History or International Relations.

courses.name: LIBR 559P Topics in Computer-Based Information Systems - TPCS CP-BSED INF
EPSE 317 Development and Exceptionality in the Regular Classroom
courses.description: The teacher's role in dealing with major developmental and special educational issues and problems within the regular classroom program, including working with supportive services, parents, and communities. Designated sections will focus on early childhood, middle childhood or adolescence. Pass/Fail.

courses.name: CHEM 398 Co-operative Work Placement I
courses.description: Approved and supervised technical work experience in an industrial research setting for a minimum of 3.5 months. Taken during the winter term of the third year. Technical report required. Restricted to students admitted to the Co-operative Education Program in Chemistry.

courses.name: AUDI 530A Research Methods - RESEARCH METHODS
courses.description: May be taken more than once for credit.

courses.name: EDST 581 Leadership, Administration, and the Aims of Education
PATH 415 Immunopathology
courses.description: Immunological events causing tissue injury.

courses.name: LFS 499 Co-operative Work Placement IV
courses.description: Work experience in relevant private and/or public sector settings.  Work terms are normally four months long.  Restricted to students admitted to the Co-op Program in Land and Food Systems. Pass/Fail.

courses.name: SPPH 581T Selected Topics - SELECTED TOPICS
courses.description: By seminar and directed readings, certain topics of current interest are explored in depth.

courses.name: NEST 304 Art and Archaeology of Ancient Egypt
ENDS 301 Environmental Design Studio I
courses.description: Introduction to the study of relationships of human beings' environments; methods of analysis and composition; physical properties of land, natural and man-made; simple spatial and functional programs deployed in the creation of outdoor spaces.

courses.name: FRST 449E Directed Studies in Forestry - DIRECTED STUDIES
courses.description: In special cases and with the approval of the instructor concerned, a student may carry on directed studies of specific problems in forestry.

courses.name: COMM 386G Topics in Business III - VENTURE CAPITAL
FRST 519 Forests and Society
courses.description: Emphasis on tropical and sub-tropical countries, where the majority of forest-dependent people live.

courses.name: RHSC 509 Facilitating Learning in Rehabilitation Contexts
CIVL 426 Virtual Design and Construction
courses.description: Creation and use of building information models (BIM) for managing the construction process.  3D parametric modeling, 4D modeling, design coordination, model-based cost estimating, BIM performance measurement, and integrated project delivery methods.

courses.name: HIST 490Q Seminar for Majors in History - SEM FOR HIST MAJ
courses.description: Selected problems in the theory and practice of historical work. Check with the department for course offerings. Restricted to fourth year students majoring in History or in the History and Philosophy of Science. Also open to History Honours students.

courses.name: BIOL 548Q Advanced Topics in Biology - ADV TOPICS BIOL
APBI 417 Production and Postharvest Physiology of Vegetable Crops
courses.description: Morphology, growth and development, production, compostition, quality, and postharvest physiology of vegetable crops.

courses.name: GRS 397B Regional Directed Field Studies - REG DIR FLD STUD
courses.description: Participating students may be assessed a fee.

courses.name: THTR 474 Advanced Speech and Movement II
courses.description: Open only to B.F.A. Acting students.

courses.name: NURS 306 Introduction to Leadership, Ethics, and Policy in Health Care
courses.description: Introduction to fundamental theories, concepts, evidence and competencies pertaining to health care leadership, ethics and policy.

courses.name: SPPH 581R Selected Topics - PED NTR PUB HLTH
courses.description: By seminar and directed readings, certain topics of current interest are explored in depth.

courses.name: ORPA 717 Orthopaedic Grand Rounds
courses.description: Formal presentations by the orthopaedic residents, fellows, faculty and guests. Subject matter includes the whole spectrum of orthopaedics.

courses.name: MECH 223 Mechanical Design
courses.description: Design methodology, synthesis and analysis. Design projects representing both mechanical mechanism design and thermofluid systems.

courses.name: CHEM 235 Organic Chemistry Laboratory
courses.description: Techniques of organic chemistry. To be taken in conjunction with, or in the term following, CHEM 233.

courses.name: MECH 479 Computational Fluid Dynamics
courses.description: Techniques for numerical solution of ordinary and partial differential equations, including an introduction to the finite difference, finite volume and finite element approaches. Simulation of laminar and turbulent flows, including common turbulent models. Validation techniques.

courses.name: ECED 590B Graduating Project - GRADUATING PRJCT
courses.description: Pass/Fail.

courses.name: SOWK 415 Practicum II
courses.description: A supervised practicum in an assigned social service, two days a week throughout the program year. Enrolment is limited to students in the B.S.W. program. This course will be graded Pass/Fail.

courses.name: LARC 511 Introductory Workshop
courses.description: Commences in August the two weeks prior to Labour Day. Enrolment mandatory for all incoming students. A non-refundable fee will be charged to cover expenses.

courses.name: HGSE 358 Conservation Ecology: Applications of Multiple Sources of Ecological Knowledge
courses.description: Examination of different types of ecological knowledge, including traditional knowledge and experiential knowledge, and their role in conservation.  Part of the Haida Gwaii Fall Semester.
courses.corequisites: All of HGSE 355, HGSE 356, HGSE 357, HGSE 359.

courses.name: LING 546D Directed Reading in Topics related to Linguistics - DIRECTED READING
WOOD 465 Wood Industry Business Management
courses.description: Business management concepts common in the forest products industry including marketing, customer research, product development and design.

courses.name: AUDI 550D Advanced Topics in Audiology - ADV TPCS AUDI
courses.description: May be taken more than once for credit.

courses.name: HIST 273 History of India
courses.description: Societies, cultures, and politics of the Indian subcontinent from its ancient civilizations to the formation of the modern nation-states of South Asia.

courses.name: BIOL 153 Human Biology
courses.description: The principles of biology with particular reference to the human body (anatomy and physiology). Laboratories include selected experiments on organ physiology and general anatomy. Please consult the Faculty of Science Credit Exclusion Lists: www.students.ubc.ca/calendar/index.cfm?tree=12,215,410,414.

courses.name: PHAR 401 Pharmacy Skills III
courses.description: Legal, technical and professional aspects of dispensing prescriptions and providing pharmaceutical care, primarily for community pharmacy practice.

courses.name: ARST 545 Advanced Arrangement and Description of Archival Documents
BUSI 294 Introductory Management Accounting
courses.description: Introduction to the development and use of accounting information for management planning and control, and the development of cost information for financial reports.

courses.name: THTR 245 Play-Interpretation and Production-Analysis
courses.description: Basic methods of interpreting dramatic texts and analyzing plays in performance. The plays presented on the Frederic Wood Stage will be studied in this course.

courses.name: EDCP 410 Music and Movement - Elementary: Curriculum and Pedagogy
courses.prerequisites: EDCP 308. (Or an introductory course in music education.)

courses.name: PCTH 512 Experimental Design and Analysis in Pharmacology
courses.description: A series of lectures, tutorials and exercises designed to improve student skills in the design and statistical analyses of pharmacological experiments.

courses.name: MEDD 410 Transition into Medical Education
courses.description: Orientation to the Medical Doctor Undergraduate Program curriculum content, learning activity types, and assessment types. Sets expectations of the medical profession. Topics include basic human biology and behavioural/psychosocial aspects of medicine, clinical skills, and anatomy. Pass/fail.

courses.name: SOCI 414A Feminist Theory - FEMINIST THEORY
courses.description: The emergence of feminist theory, its relationship to sociology, and the major theoretical schools of thought. The social basis and development of feminist thought from critiques of scholarship and research to contemporary debates will be addressed.

courses.name: GSAT 501 Intensive Laboratory Course
courses.description: Theory, application, and operation of instrumentation employed in modern genomics research: data analysis.

courses.name: FOPR 459 Economics, Contracts, and Finances in Forest Operations
courses.description: A capstone project-based course with applications of engineering economics, contract preparation, and financial planning in the context of Forest Operations.

courses.name: CIVL 409 Design of Water Supply and Waste Conveyance Systems
courses.description: Identification and evaluation of design solutions for providing a community with adequate water supply, collecting and disposing of stormwater and sewage, and managing excess stormwater flow.

courses.name: PHAR 499 Cases in Pharmaceutical Sciences IV
courses.description: Case studies and other activities integrating scientific and clinical concepts.

courses.name: ASIA 385 Chan/Zen Buddhism: Doctrine and Practice
courses.description: The history, doctrines, and practices of Chan Buddhism, particularly the profound influence of Chan Buddhism on various aspects of East Asian culture.

courses.name: BIOL 433 Plant Genetics
courses.description: Emphasis on molecular aspects. Systems and techniques for genetic analysis in plants; isolation and regulation of plant genes; genetic dissection of plant-specific processes; transposable elements; gene transfer in plants; cytoplasmic inheritance; genetic engineering.

courses.name: LAW 201 Canadian Constitutional Law
courses.description: Principles of Canadian constitutional law, including Canadian federalism, the Charter of Rights and Freedoms, and the unique constitutional status and rights of Aboriginal Peoples in Canada.

courses.name: ANTH 409A Topics in Applied Anthropology - TPS APPLIED ANTH
courses.description: Advanced study of the theory and practice of applied, action, and consultancy anthropology. Topics may include the application of anthropology to questions of aboriginal rights and title, education, medicine, development, women and development, tourism, and other social issues.

courses.name: DENT 773 Orthodontic and Dentofacial Orthopedic Clinics III
FMED 427 Reproduction
courses.description: Reproduction, human sexuality, pregnancy, lactation and aging.

courses.name: PSYC 349 Honours Seminar
courses.description: Orientation to psychological research, with special emphasis on ongoing research within the department; effective presentation of research findings, oral and written; critical evaluation of research. Requires a research project.
courses.prerequisites: Either (a) PSYC 100 or (b) all of PSYC 101, PSYC 102;  and all of PSYC 217,  218.

courses.name: BIOL 345 Human Ecology
courses.description: Basics of ecology are introduced, focussing on observations of the natural world. Assignments, including a group project, consider connections between research, awareness and practical uses of ecology. Not for credit in the Life Sciences.

courses.name: POLI 464E Problems in International Relations - PROB INTRL RELTN
courses.description: Content varies from year to year. Consult the departmental website. One section (of 3 credits) is reserved for fourth-year students in the Major program in International Relations.

courses.name: JAPN 151 Intensive Beginning Japanese II
courses.description: Continuation of JAPN 150. Offered in Term 2.

courses.name: ASTU 400Y Interdisciplinary Studies in Arts - INDIS APRCH RELG
courses.description: For upper-division students in the Faculty of Arts. Topics announced annually.

courses.name: EDST 602A Doctoral Seminar - DOCTORAL SEMINAR
courses.description: For students in the second year of a doctoral program. Pass/Fail.

courses.name: MUSC 564 Jazz Ensemble
courses.description: Open only to graduate students.

courses.name: LLED 491C Supervised Study in English Education - SUPER ST ENGL ED
MATH 152 Linear Systems
courses.description: 2D and 3D geometry, vectors and matrices, eigenvalues and vibration, physical applications. Laboratories demonstrate computer solutions of large systems. Please consult the Faculty of Science Credit Exclusion List: www.students.ubc.ca/calendar/index.cfm?tree=12,215,410,414.

courses.name: CAPS 424 Mammalian Endocrinology
courses.description: Hormonal control of homeostatic, metabolic and reproductive function. Intended for Honours students in Cellular, Anatomical and Physiological Sciences or other life sciences.
courses.prerequisites: (A cumulative average of 75% over at least 90 credits attempted in the first three years of a student's program and a minimum mark of 75% in CAPS 301 or PHYL 301. Permission of the course director is also required.)

courses.name: PHIL 464 Philosophy of Biology
