courses.description: Methodological, historical, philosophical and social science questions about biology. Credit will be given for only one of PHIL 464 or BIOL 446.
courses.prerequisites: (Fourth-year standing in any degree program or 9 credits of philosophy.)

courses.name: WOOD 400 Co-operative Work Placement
courses.description: Approved and supervised work experience with a public or private organization for a minimum of 13 weeks fulltime.  Final work term assignment required. Restricted to students in the Co-operative Education Program in Wood Products Processing.

courses.name: APBI 351 Plant Physiology
courses.description: Mechanisms and regulation of functional processes contributing to the assimilation, transport and utilization of water, mineral nutrients and carbon by plants.
courses.prerequisites: BIOL 121 and either (a) CHEM 123 or (b) all of CHEM 111, CHEM 113. (CHEM 233 is recommended.)

courses.name: SPHA 521 Organizational Behavior
courses.description: The effects of individual and group behaviour on organizational processes and outcomes. The organization as an actor and how it behaves in different types of environments.

courses.name: FRE 385 Quantitative Methods for Business and Resource Management
courses.description: Spreadsheet modeling and analysis of business and resource management problems: decision analysis, forecasting, linear programming, simulation modeling, and inventory management.
courses.prerequisites: One of ECON 101, ECON 310 and one of LFS  252, BIOL 300, FRST 231, STAT 200.

courses.name: FNH 413 Food Safety
courses.description: Microbial and chemical factors that underlie public health challenges in the food supply chain; prevalence and nature of organisms which cause foodborne diseases; approaches and technologies for improvement of food safety.

courses.name: OPTH 450 Ophthalmology
courses.description: Third-year Medicine Students only. An introduction to Clinical Ophthalmology: four morning sessions introducing the third-year Medical Students to basic ophthalmic history, clinical symptoms, signs and patient management.

courses.name: MICB 401 Environmental Microbiology Laboratory
courses.description: Microbiological analysis of environmental samples using culture-dependent and culture-independent methods.

courses.name: MUSC 695A Music Performance (Major) - KEYBOARD INST'S
courses.description: Private instruction, vocal or instrumental.

courses.name: MTRL 382 Ceramics
courses.description: Fundamentals of engineering ceramics focusing on raw materials, forming, sintering and properties, characterization, and design with ceramics.

courses.name: EPSE 482 Introduction to Statistics for Research in Education
courses.description: Basic concepts and principles of descriptive and inferential statistics. Designed for students proceeding to graduate work involving quantitative methodology.

courses.name: BIOL 428 Evolutionary Morphology of Marine Invertebrates
courses.description: Comparative analysis of marine invertebrate morphology from a macroevolutionary perspective.  Origin and evolution of reoccurring adaptations in meiofaunal, benthic, pelagic, and deep-sea invertebrates, including their larval stages.

courses.name: CPSC 344 Introduction to Human Computer Interaction Methods
courses.description: Basic tools and techniques, teaching a systematic approach to interface design, task analysis, analytic and empirical evaluation methods.
courses.prerequisites: One of CPSC 210, EECE 210, EECE 309, CPEN 221.

courses.name: EDUC 315A School-based Orientation Practicum - SCL ORNTN PRACT
courses.description: Pass/Fail.

courses.name: EECE 574 Self-Tuning Control
courses.description: Adaptive control; system identification; self-tuning control; design and implementation considerations; algorithm convergence and stability; industrial applications.

courses.name: BUSI 101 Capital Markets and Real Estate
courses.description: Basic principles of macroeconomics and application to current economic problems.

courses.name: LLED 478B Introduction to Teaching English as a Second Language - INTRO TO TESL
courses.prerequisites: (For TESL Certificate, 6 credits of LLED 489, ENGL 329, LING 420, LING 200, LING 201 taken within the last five years or taken as corequisite with consent of instructor. For B.Ed. TESL, LLED 315.)

courses.name: CIVL 509 Nonlinear Structural Analysis
courses.description: Nonlinear behaviour of structures and the formulation of elements to model such behaviour; solution strategies; nonlinear material and section response; nonlinear dynamic analysis; nonlinear geometry; application of nonlinear analysis in engineering practice.

courses.name: STAT 547Q Topics in Statistics - TOPICS IN STAT
courses.description: Students should consult the Statistics Department for the particular advanced topics offered in a given year.

courses.name: ECED 441 Early Intervention for Infants and Young Children with Sensory Loss and Motor Impairments
courses.description: (Formerly EPSE 441).

courses.name: ASIA 337 The Korean People in Modern Times (1600 to the present)
courses.description: The transformation of Korea from a Confucian state into an industrial nation. The rise of nationalism and modern ideologies in Korea. Cultural, social and economic changes Korea has undergone as it has entered the modern world.

courses.name: ARTH 361 Modern and Post-Modern Art in China
courses.description: An investigation of China's varied resistance to and pursuits of modernity and post-modernity through examination of Chinese art from the 18th to 21st centuries.

courses.name: DENT 561D Directed Studies in Dental Sciences - DST DENTAL SCIE
EDST 503 Foundations of Adult Learning and Education
LAW 358B Topics in First Nations Law - TPCS 1ST NATIONS
courses.description: Not offered each year, consult Faculty.

courses.name: EPSE 408 Educational Programming for Highly Able Learners
courses.description: Planning elementary and secondary level programs for highly able learners.

courses.name: APSC 261 Technology and Society I
courses.description: The course deals with the influence of technology on the social, political, economic, and environmental aspects of society. The specific subject matter varies from year to year. Examples of subjects considered include, resources, energy, nuclear power, technology, the effects of technology on the family, education, agriculture, international policy and others.

courses.name: MICB 306 Molecular Virology
courses.description: Introduction to virus structure and replication. Detailed examination of selected viruses including polio, HIV and cancer-causing retroviruses. Development of vaccines and anti-viral drugs, the use of virus vectors to cure genetic diseases.

courses.name: MINE 553 Modeling of Industrial Systems
courses.description: Use of mathematical programming, network theory, queuing models and simulation to model service and production operations in industry. Use of models in decision-making.

courses.name: HIST 464 First Contacts in the Pacific
courses.description: An interdisciplinary history of early European contact with the Indigenous peoples of the northwest coast of  North America and the Pacific Islands.

courses.name: BMEG 550 Biomedical Engineering Technology
courses.description: Principles of operation, clinical applications, and engineering design of common medical devices for measuring physiological signals.

courses.name: BASM 531 Multinational Enterprises
courses.description: Credit will not be granted for both BASM 531 and BAIM 501.

courses.name: ASIA 254 Sex, Gender, and Sexuality in Japanese Literature and Film
courses.description: The integral role that sex, gender, and sexuality play in literary and cinematic works from Japan. Literary works will be read in translation, movies will be subtitled.

courses.name: COHR 404 Power and Politics
courses.description: Examines the sources and consequences of power in the context of different corporate and national cultures.
courses.prerequisites: COMM 292 and one of COMM 203, COMM 392.

courses.name: ASIA 304 Survey of South and Southeast Asian Performing Arts
courses.description: An historical perspective of the performing arts of South and Southeast Asia, highlighting the role of music, dance, and the dramatic arts in the lives of actors and audiences.  Option to complete a practicum performance.

courses.name: MINE 293 Seminar
courses.description: Oral presentation of topics by students. Graded on basis of report and presentation.

courses.name: VISA 480 Advanced Seminar I
courses.description: Readings in art theory and criticism.

courses.name: CRWR 213 Introduction to Writing for the New Media
courses.description: An exploration of and practice in writing for new media, including podcasting, blogging, and writing for websites, games, and online environments. Manuscript submission is not required for admission.

courses.name: SOWK 440Q Integrative Seminars in Social Work - INTGRTV SEM SOWK
courses.description: A series of seminars offered during the final term of studies which address salient issues in social policy and social work practice and draw upon combined knowledge from social work and related disciplines.

courses.name: MEDI 548A Directed Studies in Experimental Medicine - DST IN EXPTL MED
GEOB 207 Introduction to Biogeography
courses.description: Geographical ecology emphasizing plant distributions, abiotic-biotic interactions, effects of disturbance, succession, and human impacts across scales. Labs and field trips examine a local site.
courses.prerequisites: One of GEOG 102, GEOB 102 and one of GEOG 103, GEOB 103.

courses.name: FRST 308 Forest Entomology
courses.description: An introduction to insects that cause damage to forests and forest products; how insects live; life cycles and attack symptoms of representatives of major groups of insects; principles for control and management. Available only through Distance Education.

courses.name: PHAR 503N Graduate Clinical Clerkship - GRAD CLIN CLRKSP
courses.description: This course will consist of clinical rotations of 4-6 weeks' duration (20-40 hours per week, 2 credit/rotation) in selected specialty areas in medicine and clinical pharmacy. Students will be assigned to clinicians in the selected specialty who are members of either the Faculty of Medicine or Pharmaceutical Sciences and who are appointed as clinical instructors for this course. Rotations will take place at the site(s) where the majority of the clinician's practice is conducted.

courses.name: ANAT 548A Directed Studies in Anatomy and Cell Biology - DIRECTED STUDIES
ANTH 478A Ethnographic Film Methods - ETHNO FILM METHD
courses.description: Ethnographic digital video production, including methods of ethnographic fieldwork, creation of field notes, and research design; basics of digital video planning, production, and editing. Production fees are charged for this course. Prerequisite: ANTH 378 is recommended.

courses.name: MUSC 358 History of Jazz
courses.description: Jazz styles and their cultural contexts; the relationship of performers and audiences; issues of race and gender; non-Western influences.

courses.name: EDCP 210 Introduction to Music Education
courses.description: Role of music education in schools and society, including historical, philosophical, psychological, and sociological perspectives. Includes guided class observations and practice music teaching in elementary and secondary schools. Criminal Record Check required.

courses.name: MIDW 305 Midwifery Theory for Variations in Primary Care
courses.description: Theoretical principles of care for pregnancy, birth, and the puerperium with an emphasis on the recognition and management of variations of normal and findings outside of normal.  Consists of a one-week intensive time in Vancouver, during which emergency skills certification is acquired, and weekly web-based tutorials.

courses.name: CAPS 301 Human Physiology
courses.description: Organ systems function with particular reference to mammalian and human physiology.  See credit exclusion list: http://www.calendar.ubc.ca/vancouver/index.cfm?tree=12,215,410,414
courses.prerequisites: Either (a) SCIE 001 or (b) all of BIOL 112, BIOL 121 and one of MATH 101, MATH 103, MATH 105, MATH 121 and one of PHYS 100, PHYS 101, PHYS 107 and one of CHEM 203, CHEM 233, CHEM 260.

courses.name: MECH 698 Seminar
courses.description: Current topics in mechanical engineering for doctoral students.

courses.name: RMES 505 Qualitative Methods in Interdisciplinary Contexts
courses.description: Research design, data quality, analysis, representation, ethics review, structured and unstructured interviews, field observations, survey design.

courses.name: ZOOL 500A Directed Studies in Zoology - DST IN ZOOLOGY
MUSC 692A Music Performance (Major) - KEYBOARD INST'S
courses.description: Private instruction, vocal or instrumental.

courses.name: MUSC 465 Song Repertoire II
courses.description: A sequel to MUSC 365, exploring the solo art song repertoire from the Romantic era to the present.

courses.name: PHYS 170 Mechanics I
courses.description: Statics of particles, equilibrium or rigid bodies, rigid body statics and internal forces, trusses; kinematics: rectilinear motion; dynamics:  Newton's second law, friction, impulse, momentum, work and energy.  Please consult the Faculty of Science Credit Exclusion List: www.students.ubc.ca/calendar/index.cfm?tree=12,215,410,414.
courses.prerequisites: One of PHYS 12, PHYS 100 and one of MATH 100, MATH 102, MATH 104, MATH 110, MATH 120, MATH 180, MATH 184.
courses.corequisites: One of MATH 101, MATH 103, MATH 105, MATH 121.

courses.name: HIST 324 Inventing Canada, 1840-1896
courses.description: An examination of political, cultural and national developments within the British North American colonies in the second half of the nineteenth century. Credit will not be granted for both HIST 324 or 326, if 326 was taken before 2007W.

courses.name: NURS 502 Ethics and Politics of Nursing
EOSC 311 The Earth and its Resources
courses.description: An introduction to the Earth with emphasis on its industrial and aesthetic resources. Rocks, minerals, gold, diamonds, sediments, fossils, oil and gas, canyons, and volcanoes and the processes that create them. Not for credit in the Faculties of Science and Applied Science. No background in Science or Mathematics is required.

courses.name: HIST 367 Europe in the Age of the Enlightenment
courses.description: Europe during the age of the Enlightenment, from the end of the religious wars to the French Revolution, with emphasis on political, social, cultural, and intellectual changes in their global context.

courses.name: FNH 250 Nutrition Concepts and Controversies
courses.description: Fundamental concepts and principles of human nutrition applied to current nutrition issues.
courses.prerequisites: All of BIOL 112, BIOL 121. (At least second-year standing required.)

courses.name: DENT 561E Directed Studies in Dental Sciences - DST DENTAL SCIE
ASTU 501 Co-operative Work Placement I
courses.description: Approved and supervised paid work experience with a public or private organization for a minimum of 13 weeks full-time. Final written report required. Restricted to Master's degree students in departments with approved co-op programs.

courses.name: HIST 250A Latin American History - LATN AMERCN HIST
courses.description: A general course designed to show by discussion of the major issues how the modern society and culture of Latin America came into being.

courses.name: ASIA 332 Confucianism in China and Beyond: Reinventions of Tradition
courses.description: Key ideas and trends in Confucian thought and practice from its origins to modern times through primary sources in translation and secondary scholarship.

courses.name: CNPS 586 Ethics in Counselling Psychology
courses.description: Ethical decision-making and legal issues in counselling psychology research and practice.

courses.name: MTRL 442 Coatings and Surface Modification
courses.description: Strategies for ceramic and metallic coatings by melting-solidification, from the vapour state and from solution, and methods of surface modification.

courses.name: SPAN 365 Survey of Spanish-American Literature and Culture since the 1820s
courses.prerequisites: One of SPAN 220, SPAN 221 and SPAN 302.
courses.corequisites: (SPAN 302 may be taken as a co-requisite, with the permission of the instructor or the Spanish Major Adviser.)

courses.name: PSYC 359 Advanced Research Methods in Behavioural Sciences
courses.description: Prepares students for graduate studies or other advanced behavioural research; experimental design and analytic techniques; laboratory with computer applications.
courses.prerequisites: Either (a) all of PSYC 217, PSYC 218 or (b) PSYC 366.

courses.name: EDCP 340 Mathematics - Elementary and Middle Years: Curriculum and Pedagogy
courses.description: Pass/Fail.

courses.name: BIOL 448G Directed Studies in Biology - DIRECTED STUDIES
courses.description: A course designed to allow students to undertake an investigation on a specific topic as agreed upon by the faculty member and the student. Permission of the supervisor required. No more than six credits of BIOL 448 may be taken with the same supervisor.

courses.name: FOOD 527A Special Topics in Food Science - SP TPS FOOD SCIE
PLAN 545D Planning Studies Abroad - STUDIES ABROAD
courses.description: An extended site visit outside Canada to understand the cultural context for community and regional planning issues and the local institutional response.

courses.name: ENGL 489 Language Majors Seminar
courses.description: Required of all Language Majors.  See department website (http://www.english.ubc.ca/ugrad/majors/compl_lang.htm) for options.

courses.name: DENT 573 Literature Review in Periodontics II
LAW 404 The Law of Homicide
courses.description: Available in online distance education format only.  Elements of sentencing for murder, manslaughter and infanticide; defences to homicide; parties to homicide; and corporate homicide.

courses.name: ENGL 223 Literature in the United States
courses.description: The major types of American writing: fiction, poetry, drama and non-fictional prose.
courses.prerequisites: Either (a) ARTS 001 or (b) two of ENGL 110, ENGL 111, ENGL 112, ENGL 120, ENGL 121 or (c) ASTU 100 or (d) ASTU 150 and one of ENGL 110, ENGL 111, ENGL 120, ENGL 121;  or (e) WRDS 150 and one of ENGL 110, ENGL 111, ENGL 120, ENGL 121. (Or 6 credits of first-year English.)

courses.name: RELG 203 Scriptures of the Near East
courses.description: An introduction to the scriptures of Judaism, Christianity, and Islam.

courses.name: COMM 464 E-Marketing
courses.description: Investigation of Internet-based marketing, emphasizing customer-focused perspectives, competitive situations and analysis of the effectiveness of business websites using marketing principles and practices.

courses.name: ENGL 492A Senior Honours Seminar - SR HONORS SEMNR2
courses.description: Offerings in literary research.

courses.name: FRST 351 Interior Field School
courses.description: Field study at an interior BC location concentrating on land use, management and silviculture. Fees will be assessed to meet expenses.

courses.name: LARC 503 Landscape Architecture Design Studio III
PHYL 527 Advanced Topics in Respiratory Physiology
INDE 450 Senior Clerkship
courses.description: A senior clinical elective for fourth-year students. Students will participate in all relevant clinical and academic activities associated with the particular rotation.

courses.name: EDST 508A Review of Research in Educational Studies - REV RES ED STUDS
AUDI 516A Discourse Analysis - DISCOURSE ANYL
courses.description: May be taken more than once for credit.

courses.name: ASIA 308 Myth, Ritual and Epic in Ancient India
courses.description: Myths of creation Gods and goddesses of the Vedic pantheon. Connections with myths in other parts of the world, particularly in the Indo-European tradition. Literary representations of the myths.

courses.name: LATN 501A Latin Prose - LATIN PROSE
courses.description: History, oratory and/or philosophy.  Credit will not be given for both LATN 401 and LATN 501.

courses.name: PHAR 554 Advanced Hospital Pharmacy Management
courses.description: Institutional, professional and regulatory factors that influence the planning, implementation and control of pharmacy services in hospitals. Permission of instructor required.

courses.name: LAW 380C Externship Reflection - EXTRNSHP REFLECT
courses.description: Structured reflective exercises on the LAW 379 Externship experience.

courses.name: VISA 401B Advanced Open Studio - ADV OPEN STUDIO
courses.description: Research-based studio with thematic or disciplinary focus.  Intended for senior Visual Art undergraduate students.
courses.prerequisites: Three of VISA 310, VISA 311, VISA 320, VISA 321, VISA 330, VISA 331, VISA 340, VISA 341, VISA 350, VISA 351, VISA 360, VISA 361, VISA 370, VISA 390.

courses.name: APSC 440 Management Fundamentals for Technology-Based Product Marketing and Development
courses.description: Management topics are presented from the perspective of technology-based industrial practice; project management, marketing and marketing planning, product development and commercialization, introduction to quality management, teamwork and effective individual participation.

courses.name: EOSC 432 Fossil Fuels
courses.description: Origin, geochemistry and distribution of petroleum and coal in the stratigraphic record. Sedimentation of organic matter, organic diagenesis, migration and accumulation of hydrocarbons. Principles of exploration and development. Techniques for measurement of organic maturation and source rock analyses.

courses.name: ECON 304 Honours Intermediate Microeconomic Analysis I
courses.description: Consumer behaviour, producer theory, exchange, monopoly, oligopoly, externalities, public goods, general equilibrium and welfare economics. Credit may be obtained for only one of ECON 301 or 304 or COMM 295.
courses.prerequisites: A score of 68% or higher in all of ECON 101, MATH 104, MATH 105.

courses.name: PSYC 523 Experimental Neuropsychology and Animal Models
courses.description: Not offered each year; consult Department of Psychology.

courses.name: SPPH 545 Community Health Promotion
courses.description: Practice and community-based (participatory) research related to health promotion, including its historical and philosophical roots. Application of social and behavioural theories to participatory research and the planning, implementation, and evaluation of community health promotion initiatives.

courses.name: MIDW 104 Lactation Consultation for Maternity Care Providers
courses.description: Breastfeeding physiology, pathophysiology, and strategies for support of the dyad based on best-practice principles.  Discussion of major Canadian and international initiatives for the support and protection of breastfeeding.

courses.name: PHYS 565 Applications of Radioisotopes in Science and in Medicine
courses.description: Use of radioisotopes in nuclear medicine, materials science, environmental science, and nuclear physics in combination with the associated production, processing, and detection technologies.

courses.name: CIVL 513 Concrete Structures
courses.description: Response of prestressed and non-prestressed concrete elements and structures; comparison of analytical predictions and experimental results; simplified design procedures.

courses.name: ANTH 500 History of Anthropological Thought
courses.description: Various approaches to anthropology, from classical to contemporary.

courses.name: EECE 583 CAD Algorithms for Integrated Circuits
courses.description: Algorithms used in contemporary computer-aided design tools targeting custom integrated circuits and field-programmable gate arrays, including high-level synthesis, logic optimization, partitioning, placement and routing, optimization techniques.

courses.name: SCAN 413B The Literatures of the Baltic in English Translation - LIT BLT ENG TRAN
courses.description: An examination through literature of the historical, cultural, and ethnic elements that have made the Baltic area the crossroads of northeastern Europe. The emphasis is on literature from the Germanic  and Finno-Ugric languages. Authors to be studied include Strindberg, Tikkanen, Transtromer, Kaplinski, Grass, Bobrowski, Lenz.

courses.name: BIOF 501A Special Topics in Bioinformatics - TPCS BIOINFORMCS
RHSC 589B Major Project, Part II - MAJOR PROJ PRT 2
courses.prerequisites: RHSC 587. (Permission of the project coordinator is also required.)

courses.name: ARCH 598 Research Thesis
courses.description: Restricted to M.A.S.A. candidates.

courses.name: BAEN 550 Fundamentals in Entrepreneurship
courses.description: Not available to M.B.A. students.

courses.name: CENS 303B Representations of the Holocaust (in English) - REPRESENTNS HOLO
courses.description: The Nazi Holocaust in film and literature from Central, Eastern, and Northern European Countries.

courses.name: CIVL 583 Urban Engineering Methods and Models
courses.description: The application of urban analysis methods and models to the design of municipal and transportation engineering systems.

courses.name: LIBE 598A Field Experiences - FIELD EXPER 1
courses.description: For students in master's, doctoral, and diploma programs.

courses.name: LLED 371 Foundations of Teaching French: Secondary
courses.description: Pass/Fail.
courses.prerequisites: (A completed concentration in French of permission of the Department Head.)

courses.name: NURS 530 Advanced Practice in Nursing
courses.description: Study of advanced practice nursing models, their development and implementation with a changing health care system.

courses.name: ARBC 202 Classical Arabic (Intermediate) II
courses.description: Increased reading ability as well as learning the further essentials of grammar. Continuation of ARBC 201.

courses.name: MECH 328 Mechanical Engineering Design Project
courses.description: Design project course linked to MECH 325, MECH 326, or MECH 327. Applying the design process, making educated assumptions and decisions, and working in teams to provide a new mechanical design. Weekly lecture discussing product development and various factors affecting the design.

courses.name: EDUC 496C Practicum (Secondary) for Previously Certified Teachers - TEACH PRACT SECD
courses.description: Pass/Fail.
courses.prerequisites: (Recent completion of secondary teaching methods courses in the subjects to be taught.)

courses.name: PHYS 298 Co-operative Work Placement I
courses.description: Approved and supervised technical work experience in an industrial research setting for a minimum of 3.5 months. Normally taken during the winter term of the second year. Technical report required. Restricted to students admitted to the Co-operative Education Program in Physics.

courses.name: COHR 402 Leadership
courses.description: Explores the characteristics of effective leadership and examines how to be a better leader.
courses.prerequisites: COMM 292 and one of COMM 203, COMM 392.

courses.name: MUSC 436 Opera Theatre Techniques II
courses.description: Advanced studies in acting, movement, gesture, dance and stage combat. Emphasis on communication and the art of singing and acting recitative in foreign languages.

courses.name: ARCL 405 Archaeological and Anthropological Mapping
courses.description: Current methods in mapping spatial information in archaeology and related subfields of anthropology.

courses.name: SANS 102 Introductory Sanskrit
courses.description: Basic vocabulary and most important grammatical features of classical Sanskrit. Useful to students of South Asian history, culture, languages, philosophies, and religions, and of linguistics and classics. As of 2011W credit will be granted for only one of SANS 100/101 or SANS 102.

courses.name: LAW 469 Civil Procedure
courses.description: Problems in the conduct of civil litigation including: ethical considerations; substantive problems such as notice, pleading, and discovery; and selected procedural problems. Credit will be granted for only one of LAW 270 or LAW 469.

courses.name: LAW 508D Business Organizations - BUSNS ORGANIZTNS
courses.description: A conceptual overview of business organizations in Canada, including partnerships and corporations, and the rights and duties of shareholders and directors. Credit will be granted for only one of LAW 508, LAW 230 or LAW 459.

courses.name: BIOL 436 Integrated Functional Genomics
courses.description: Global transcript, protein, and metabolite profiling technologies and their integration; applications focus on plant functions and plant interactions with pathogens and pests.

courses.name: CHBE 596 Engineering Report
courses.description: For M.Eng. students. Carry out a literature review, conduct a research or design project and prepare an engineering report under the supervision of a faculty member.

courses.name: CIVL 562 Environmental Contaminant Analysis Laboratory
courses.description: An advanced laboratory course to familiarize the student with environmental engineering laboratory procedures, instrumental analyis, sampling techniques and data analysis.

courses.name: AUDI 514B Hearing Science I - HEARING SCI I
MIDW 320 Variations in Midwifery Clinical Care
courses.description: Clinical education experiences with the preventative and therapeutic midwifery care of pregnancy, birth, and the puerperium.  Emphasis on the recognition and management of variations of normal and findings outside normal.  A 12-week practicum in locations around the province.  Pass/Fail.

courses.name: PHIL 120 Introduction to Critical Thinking
courses.description: Tools for dealing with both everyday and more technical arguments and concepts. Analysis and resolution of confusions, ambiguities, and fallacies. This course is restricted to students with fewer than 90 credits.

courses.name: ITST 419 Topics in Modern and Contemporary Italian Literature and Culture in Translation
courses.description: Italian literature of the 20th century in its intellectual, socio-political and cultural context. Precludes credit for ITAL 409.

courses.name: SPAN 301 Advanced Spanish I
courses.description: Composition, translation, and oral practice.  Special emphasis on pronunciation and syntax.

courses.name: MEDG 535 Genetics and Ethics
courses.description: This course is intended to serve the diverse needs of genetic counseling students, research graduate students in genetics, genetic residents and clinical fellows, other health professional students, and graduate students from other sciences and humanities.

courses.name: PCTH 449A Honours Thesis - HONOURS THESIS
courses.description: A research problem directed by a faculty member. Restricted to Honours Pharmacology students.

courses.name: ELEC 463 Micro/Nanofabrication and Instrumentation Laboratory
courses.description: Microfabrication methods and nanofabrication techniques. Imaging and characterization of micro and nanostructures. Restricted to students admitted to the Nanotechnology and Microsystems Option in Electrical Engineering.

courses.name: CNRS 500 Pro-Seminar in Ancient Mediterranean Studies
MUSC 512B Directed Individual Studies - INDIVDL STUDIES
courses.description: Approval by the Director, School of Music, is required.

courses.name: EDST 582 The Study of Educational Organizations
CIVL 561 Investigation, Risk Assessment and Management of Chemicals in Geo-Environment
courses.description: Sampling, investigations, fate and transport of chemicals in soil, water, sediment, biota and air; exposure pathways assessment and toxicological principles for receptors; risk-based approach to site remediation, treatment and control technologies.

courses.name: ELEC 462 Sensors and Actuators in Microsystems
courses.description: The mechanisms, design, fabrication, and testing of microsensors, actuators, and microelectromechanical systems (MEMS).

courses.name: EDUC 418E School-based Extended Practicum: Elementary - EXT PRACT ELEM
courses.description: Pass/Fail.
courses.prerequisites: (Normally all requirements set to precede this practicum)

courses.name: CHBE 563 Applied Heterogeneous Catalysis
courses.description: Techniques for characterizing catalysts and their surfaces. Commercial methods of preparing catalysts. Chemistry of catalytic reactions and the impact of catalyst properties, mechanisms and kinetics on reactor engineering. Applications of catalytic oxidations, hydrogenations, C-C bond formation and cracking.

courses.name: BA 504 Integration and Professional Development: Foundation
EECE 518 Human Interface Technologies
courses.description: Human sensation, perception, kinetics; input technologies, gesture, vision, speech, audio; metaphors, information appliances, ubiquitous computing, wearable computing; output technologies, video display, speech, audio, tactile, haptic; evaluation methodology; user-centered design.

courses.name: ENGL 541B Studies in American Literature Since 1890 - AMER LIT 1890 ON
CHEM 319 Practical Skills for Chemical Research
courses.description: The nature of scientific research; practical skills for chemical research; communicating science.  Restricted to Honours students with third year standing and, with permission of the department Head, to Major students with satisfactory third year standing.

courses.name: LAW 349D Topics in Constitutional Law - TPCS CONSTNL LAW
courses.description: Not offered each year, consult Faculty.

courses.name: CRWR 359A Intermediate Fiction Workshop - INTRMD FICTION
courses.description: An intermediate level workshop class in writing of fiction. Manuscript submission is not required for admission.

courses.name: GRSJ 307 Gender, Race, Sexuality, and Popular Culture
courses.description: Critical examination of mainstream and alternative media images of gender, race, and sexuality in the context of networked social media, film, music, and television.
courses.prerequisites: Either (a) all of GRSJ 101, GRSJ 102 or (b) all of WMST 101, WMST 102. (or third-year standing.)

courses.name: SOWK 560C Directed Field Studies in Social Work II - DIR FLD STUDIES
CHBE 455 Kinetics and Reactor Design
courses.description: Kinetics of homogeneous chemical and biological reactions, isothermal ideal reactor design, analysis of non-ideal reactors using residence time distribution and mixing models.

courses.name: EDUC 495C Practicum (Elementary) for Previously Certified Teachers - TEACH PRACT ELEM
courses.description: Pass/Fail.
courses.prerequisites: (Completion of recent elementary teaching methods courses in the subjects to be taught.)

courses.name: PHYL 511C Seminar in Mammalian Physiology - MAMMALIAN PHYL
BOTA 546C Topics in Botany - TOPICS IN BOTANY
BIOL 499 Co-operative Work Placement IV
courses.description: Work experience in an industrial research setting, taken during the Winter Session (Terms 1 and 2) following fourth year. Restricted to students admitted to the Co-operative Education Program in Biology.

courses.name: EDCP 598C Field Experiences - FIELD EXPERIENCE
courses.description: Field experiences in community-based or museum contexts. Focus on curriculum design and evaluation.

courses.name: SOIL 503 Advanced Soil Sampling, Analyses and Data Interpretation
courses.description: Field and laboratory analytical techniques in the chemical, biological and physical assessment of soils. Credit will be granted for only one of SOIL 503 or APBI 403.

courses.name: CENS 201 Contrasts and Conflicts: The Cultures of Central, Eastern and Northern Europe (in English)
courses.description: An introduction to the cultural history of the peoples of Central, Eastern and Northern Europe as reflected in their literature, art and music.

courses.name: KIN 343 Biology of Human Athletic Performance
courses.description: Basics of exercise physiology and related issues pertaining to sports and athletic performance for non-Kinesiology students.  Not for credit in the B.Kin. Program.

courses.name: MUSC 165G World Music Ensembles - AFRICAN MUS/DANC
courses.description: Training on traditional instruments and their techniques, with emphasis on ensemble performance. Different sections focus on the music of different cultures, e.g., Bali, China, Ghana, Korea. May be repeated for credit in accordance with program requirements for B.Mus. or B.A. in Music, or when permitted in other programs.

courses.name: ASTU 210 Global Citizenship, Part 1: Introduction
courses.description: Themes of global citizenship, sustainability, and civil society, and barriers and bridges to global thinking.

courses.name: KIN 515 Gap Analysis
courses.description: Using analytics to obtain, describe, and visualize data to create a sport profile. Determine optimal programming decisions for coached athletes based on their performance pathway and gold medal profile. Apply research methods and principles of scientific inquiry, performance analysis, descriptive, prescriptive, and predictive analytics to improve athlete development and performance.

courses.name: PHYS 101 Energy and Waves
courses.description: Fluids, harmonic oscillator, travelling waves, standing waves, sound, and interference of light waves, including diffraction.  Please consult the Faculty of Science Credit Exclusion List: www.students.ubc.ca/calendar/index.cfm?tree=12,215,410,414
courses.corequisites: One of MATH 100, MATH 102, MATH 104, MATH 110, MATH 120, MATH 180, MATH 184.

courses.name: GERM 411 Major Controversies in German Culture (in English)
courses.description: Selected debates and controversies in the German-speaking countries.

courses.name: CPSC 319 Software Engineering Project
courses.description: The design, implementation, and test of a large software system, using a team approach.

courses.name: COMM 120 Business Immersion
courses.description: A broad introduction to the field of business and how the different disciplines within business interact and combine in business decision-making. For Master of Management - Dual Degree Option students only.

courses.name: AUDI 575 Language Development and Disorders in the School Years
CHBE 356 Process Dynamics and Control
courses.description: Introduction to modeling of chemical processes; transient response analysis; design of feedback control systems; stability analysis; frequency response analysis; process control applications; instrumentation; advanced control techniques; distributed control systems.

courses.name: LLED 501 Analyzing Discourse and Talk: An Overview of Methods
courses.description: Credit will be granted for only one of LLED 501, LLED 575, and EPSE 586.

courses.name: PORT 201 Second-Year Portuguese I
courses.description: Grammar, composition, translation, oral practice, readings. Credit will be granted for only one of PORT 201 or PORT 210

courses.name: WOOD 241 Programming for Wood Products Manufacturing Applications
courses.description: Practical computer and problem solving cases taken from wood products manufacturing industrial applications.

courses.name: COMM 457 Fundamentals of Financial Accounting
courses.description: Financial accounting for business organizations; principles and problems of accounting measurements; forms of business organizations; financing of businesses. (For non-Commerce students only).

courses.name: MECH 505 Industrial and Environmental Acoustics and Vibration
courses.description: Fundamentals of acoustics and vibrations, physiologic effects, measurement, instrumentation, interpretation of data, industrial standards, and control. For students in Occupational and Environmental Hygiene; other graduate students may enrol with permission of the instructor.

courses.name: LAW 377 Immigration Law
courses.description: Admission of immigrants into Canada; refugee protection; practice and procedure before immigration tribunals and the courts.

courses.name: SPPH 511 Cancer Control and Epidemiology
courses.description: Collection and analysis of epidemiological data on cancer; genetic, occupational, and other risk factors; analytic techniques; cancer control, prevention, screening, early detection, and policy issues.

courses.name: PHAR 450D Selected Topics - SELECTED TOPICS
courses.description: Thesis or Essay.

courses.name: ENPH 259 Experimental Techniques
courses.description: Basic experimental techniques in acquisition, analysis, and presentation and communication of data and technical results.
courses.prerequisites: One of APSC 176, ENGL 110, ENGL 111, ENGL 112, ENGL 120, ENGL 121 and either (a) all of PHYS 108, PHYS 109 or (b) one of PHYS 102, PHYS 153 or (c) SCIE 001 or (d) all of PHYS 157, PHYS 158, PHYS 159.

courses.name: THTR 371 Intermediate B.F.A. Acting I
courses.description: Open only to B.F.A. Acting students.
courses.prerequisites: All of THTR 271, THTR 272, THTR 273, THTR 274.

courses.name: MUSC 165F World Music Ensembles - BALINESE GAMELAN
courses.description: Training on traditional instruments and their techniques, with emphasis on ensemble performance. Different sections focus on the music of different cultures, e.g., Bali, China, Ghana, Korea. May be repeated for credit in accordance with program requirements for B.Mus. or B.A. in Music, or when permitted in other programs.

courses.name: PHYS 349 Directed Research Project in Physics
courses.description: A research project, undertaken under the direction of a faculty member, culminating in a written report. This course requires  approval of the course instructor  and  program  advisor in the Department of Physics and Astronomy.

courses.name: APBI 460 Advanced Agroecology
courses.description: The relationship between biological diversity and sustainability for the management of agroecosystems; emphasise on ecological interactions between natural ecosystems and agroecosystems, including connections between agroecology and conservation biology. A fee will be assessed each student to cover field trip costs.

courses.name: MATH 552 Introduction to Dynamical Systems
courses.description: Ideas, methods and applications of bifurcation theory and dynamical systems: differential and difference equations, local bifurcations, perturbation methods, chaos.
courses.prerequisites: One of MATH 215, MATH 255, MATH 256 and one of MATH 256, MATH 257, MATH 316.

courses.name: DHYG 412 Oral Health Care Trends and Topics
courses.description: Critical analysis of health care trends and oral health care delivery with emphasis on underserved diverse populations.

courses.name: PHAR 341 Pharmacology I
courses.description: Pharmacological principles and the pharmacology of selected agents.

courses.name: APBI 418 Intensive Fish Production
courses.description: Management of fin fish throughout the life cycle; broodstock, egg, larvae, and juvenile. Control of environmental factors, including pathogens, for maximum productivity at all life stages.

courses.name: SPAN 309 Business Spanish of International Trade in the Hispanic World (in Spanish)
courses.description: The language and the legal, logistic, and administrative procedures of international trade. For students at level B2 (CEFR). For further information on CEFR levels see http://www.fhis.ubc.ca/undergraduate/spanish/advising/deciding-what-spanish-course-to-take.html. Not available for credit toward a Major or Minor in Spanish.

courses.name: APSC 262 Technology and Society II
courses.description: The course deals with the influence of technology on the social, political, economic and environmental aspects of society. The subject matter varies from year to year and differs from APSC 261. It may be taken as a continuation of APSC 261 or taken independently. Examples of subjects considered include pollution, work place health hazards, social impact of computers, problem solving, green revolution, technology and the third world, engineering ethics and others.

courses.name: CNPS 698 Pre-Doctoral Internship
courses.description: A 1600-hour supervised internship in Counselling Psychology. Internship sites offer counselling services as detailed in the "Speciality Guidelines for the Delivery of Services by Counselling Psychologists" (APA). Pass/Fail.

courses.name: PLAN 548M Current Issues in Planning - STRATEGIC PLN
courses.description: Each year the school may offer one or more courses on a topical issue covering recent advances in the field.

courses.name: FRE 420 The Economics of International Trade and the Environment
courses.description: Market failure and gains from trade in the presence of natural resource externalities; the multilateral trading system and the environment; case studies in trade-related environmental impacts.
courses.prerequisites: One of ECON 301, FRE  295, COMM 295. (or 6 credits of upper-level FRE or ECON.)

courses.name: COMM 466 New Venture Design
courses.description: Teams comprising students in COMM 466 and APSC 486 propose a new product, produce a viable prototype, and develop a business plan for the marketplace.  Credit may only be obtained for one of COMM 466 and APSC 486.

courses.name: LIBR 529 Services for Families and Early Literacy in the Preschool Years
FMST 440 Family Economic Issues
courses.description: The study of the impact of economic issues on families.

courses.name: CHBE 344 Unit Operations I
courses.description: Characterization of particles, droplets, and bubbles; comminution, screening and classification; filtration, sedimentation, centrifugal separations and fluidization; thermal operations including evaporation and crystalization.

courses.name: ARST 556H Topics in Archival Automation - TPCS ARCH AUTMTN
FMST 312 Parent-child Relationships
courses.description: Parent-child interaction over the life span.

courses.name: WOOD 449D Directed Studies in Wood Products Processing - DIR ST WD PR PRC
courses.description: In special cases and with the approval of the instructor concerned, a student may carry on directed studies of specific problems in wood products processing.

courses.name: COMM 481 Co-operative Work Placement IV
courses.description: Approved and supervised work experience for a minimum of 35 months. Normally taken during the fall term of the fourth year. Technical report required. Restricted to students admitted to the Co-operative Education Program in Commerce.

courses.name: KIN 360 Sport, Peace, and Conflict
courses.description: Relationships that sport and leisure have with peace, conflict, and social inequality in Canada and internationally.

courses.name: ECON 466 The Economics of Government Regulation of Business
courses.description: Normative and positive theories of government regulation of business. Topics include natural monopoly, socially optimal monopoly pricing, regulation of multi-firm industries, competition policy. Selected empirical studies.

courses.name: LARC 522 Landscape Architectural History
courses.description: History, principles, and theory of landscape architecture in Europe, America and Asia. Influence of cultural attitudes and societal change upon natural environments, parks, gardens, and town planning.

courses.name: LAW 394 Mining Law
courses.description: Acquisition of mineral interests; development, financing and organization of mining companies; regulation of exploitation industry interests; management taxation. Not offered each year, consult Faculty.

courses.name: LAW 437 Commercial Transactions
courses.description: The law of sale of goods, bills of exchange, promissory notes, and cheques.

courses.name: MUSC 512E Directed Individual Studies - DOCT THESIS PREP
courses.description: Approval by the Director, School of Music, is required.

courses.name: EDCP 322A Physical Education - Secondary: Curriculum and Pedagogy - PHYS ED SEC C&P
courses.description: Pass/Fail.
courses.prerequisites: (A completed concentration in physical education or permission of the head.)

courses.name: CEEN 501 Energy System Fundamentals
courses.description: Thermodynamic analysis of energy conversion processes, power cycles and refrigeration cycles. Exergy analysis of conventional energy systems. Thermal conversion technologies.
courses.prerequisites: (3 credits of thermodynamics at the second- or third-year level.)

courses.name: SPPH 504 Application of Epidemiological Methods
courses.description: This second level course will teach research trainees to apply methods taught in prior courses towards the development of a fundable research protocol and the analysis and interpretation of real epidemiologic data.
courses.prerequisites: Either (a) all of HCEP 400, HCEP 500, HCEP 502 or (b) all of SPPH 400, SPPH 500, SPPH 502 and one of SPPH 503, SPPH 506, SPPH 519, SPPH 530.

courses.name: MTRL 252 Pyrometallurgy
courses.description: Process flow sheets for ferrous and non-ferrous metal extraction; mass and energy conservation; roasting and smelting; refractory properties.

courses.name: LING 452 Acquisition of Syntax
courses.description: Central issues in the first language acquisition of syntax, including early lexical and semantic development, acquisition of morphology, and syntactic development (e.g., word order, questions).

courses.name: CAPS 422 Mammalian Cardiovascular and Respiratory Physiology
courses.description: The control and integration of cardio-pulmonary function in mammals. Intended for Honours students in Cellular, Anatomical and Physiological Sciences or other life sciences.
courses.prerequisites: (A cumulative average of 75% over at least 90 credits attempted in the first three years of a student's program and a minimum mark of 75% in CAPS 301 or PHYL 301 or its equivalent. Permission of the course director is also required.)

courses.name: COMM 294 Managerial Accounting
courses.description: Introduction to the development and use of accounting information for management planning and control and the development of cost information for financial reports. Credit will be granted for only one of COMM 294 or COEC 394.

courses.name: CSIS 450B Topics in Critical Studies in Sexuality - TPCS CRT STDY SX
courses.description: A thematic course, which explores current questions and issues in relation to the study of sexuality. Topics may vary from year to year.

courses.name: VISA 250 Introduction to Print Media
courses.description: Visual print culture, and contemporary and historical technical print practices. Emphasis on hand-drawn intaglio, relief, screen and/or stencil printing, and graphic digital applications.
courses.prerequisites: A score of 72% or higher in VISA 110 and a score of 72% or higher in one of VISA 180, VISA 182 and a score of 72% or higher in VISA 183.

courses.name: GPP 504 Policy Analysis and Evaluation
courses.description: Fundamentals of policy analysis and program evaluation for a professional context. Standard tools of policy analysis, risk assessment, and evaluation to design policy interventions and implement monitoring and evaluation systems for effectiveness. Case studies for government, international organizations, and NGOs.

courses.name: SOWK 440B Integrative Seminars in Social Work - INTGRTV SEM SOWK
courses.description: A series of seminars offered during the final term of studies which address salient issues in social policy and social work practice and draw upon combined knowledge from social work and related disciplines.

courses.name: CNPS 574 Career Planning and Decision-Making Counselling
courses.description: Theory, research, and practice of career planning and decision counselling.

courses.name: HEBR 101 Elementary Biblical Hebrew Part I
courses.description: Introduction to Biblical Hebrew grammar. Includes translation of prose and poetry from the Hebrew Bible.

courses.name: HIST 317 Britain, 1850-1918
courses.description: Britain from the Great Exhibition to the Great War: the creation of a mass electorate, the "New Imperialism," the "New Woman," and the ways that class, race, gender, and sexuality shaped modern Britain.

courses.name: LLED 325A Teaching and Learning French in Elementary Schools - T & L FREN ELEM
courses.description: Taught in French. Strategies, theoretical foundations, and approaches related to teaching elementary French (Immersion, Core, Intensive) programs. Pass/Fail.
courses.prerequisites: (A completed concentration in French or permission of the Head.)

courses.name: THTR 440B Topics in Theatre - TOPICS IN THTR
courses.description: An examination in depth of a selected area of theatre history, theory or practice. Topics will change from year to year. May be repeated for credit when topics differ.
courses.prerequisites: (6 credits of THTR at the 300-level or above.)

courses.name: RMES 550 Environmental Policy Analysis
courses.description: Determination of risks and values in environmental policy decisions.

courses.name: POLI 492 Honours Thesis
courses.description: In consultation with faculty, students develop a research project, report on their project during seminars, give feedback on their fellow students' projects, and write a thesis.

courses.name: EECE 564 Detection and Estimation of Signals in Noise
courses.description: Formulation of the detection problem, optimum receiver principles, signal space, maximum likelihood decisions, error performance calculations. Estimation of signals in noise, linear and non-linear estimation, cost functions, recursive mean square estimation, Wiener and Kalman filters.

courses.name: CHIN 113 Basic Chinese I: Part 2 (Heritage)
courses.description: Continuation of CHIN 111.

courses.name: ANTH 495B Advanced Studies in Anthropology - ADV STUDIES
courses.description: An intensive examination of selected topics in Anthropology. Consult the Department for this year's offerings.

courses.name: MECH 572 Convection Heat Transfer
courses.description: Governing equations for laminar and turbulent flow. Forced convection in internal and external flow. Free, and combined free and forced convection. Heat transfer at high velocities, in rarefied gases and in two-phase flow. Mass transfer.

courses.name: SPHA 503 Financial Reporting
courses.description: Preparation of external financial reports.

courses.name: WRDS 150 Research and Writing in the Humanities and Social Sciences
courses.description: Writing and reading in the social sciences and humanities, focusing on practices which the research disciplines share, and those which differentiate them. Credit will be granted for only one of WRDS 150 or ASTU 150.

courses.name: MTRL 494 Composite Materials
courses.description: Understanding the properties and the mechanical behaviour of composite materials with emphasis on analysis, design, and manufacturing. Credit will only be given for one of MTRL 494, 594.

courses.name: PHAR 362 Non-Prescription Drugs and Self-Care of the Patient II
courses.description: The use of non-prescription drugs for selected conditions.

courses.name: APBI 260 Agroecology I
courses.description: Introduction to the biophysical and socioeconomic factors affecting systems management and production in selected agroecosystems.  A fee will be assessed each student to cover field trip costs.

courses.name: NAME 578 Marine Engineering
courses.description: Marine propulsion systems; ship engines; shafting; ship vibrations; on-board systems (piping, HVAC, electrical); advanced propulsion systems.

courses.name: ANAT 590 Introduction to Functional Human Anatomy: Survey of Microscopic Anatomy, Neuroanatomy and Gross Anatomy
BIOL 347 Principles and Methodology in Biological Research
courses.description: Contemporary research in the Botany and Zoology Departments; history and methodology of scientific discovery; seminars on current problems. Restricted to Honours students in Biology. Not to be taken concurrently with BIOL 449.

courses.name: MECH 469 Dynamic System Modeling
courses.description: Modeling of mechanical, electrical, fluid, and thermal systems; analytical models; model representations such as linear and bond graphs; response analysis; digital simulation.

courses.name: GREK 101 First-Year Ancient Greek I
courses.description: An introduction to Classical and Hellenistic Greek, Part I.

courses.name: VISA 241 Introduction to Digital Photography
courses.description: Introduction to digital photography image creation in relation to contemporary art. Emphasis on digital camera use, file management, and digital print production.  Only one of VISA 240 and VISA 241 may be used toward the program requirements of the B.F.A. Visual Art and the B.A. Visual Art programs.
courses.prerequisites: A score of 72% or higher in one of VISA 180, VISA 182 and all of VISA 183, VISA 110.

courses.name: JAPN 100 Beginning Japanese I
courses.description: An introduction to modern spoken and written Japanese with emphasis on both form (grammar and syntax) and functions (Non-intensive). Not available for credit to students with JAPN 11 and/or JAPN 12.

courses.name: MUSC 163 Contemporary Players
courses.description: Performance of contemporary music. An ensemble of variable size, including both instrumentalists and singers, will be formed to present several concerts of 20th-century music during the academic year.  May be repeated for credit in accordance with program requirements for B.Mus. or B.A. in Music.

courses.name: DENT 512 Pediatric Dentistry Literature Review III
courses.description: Continues in year 3.

courses.name: ANTH 331A Art, Aesthetics and Anthropology - ART&ANTHROPOLOGY
courses.description: Anthropological perspectives on art, aesthetics, and expressive culture.

courses.name: ECED 421 Supporting Young Children Through Home, School, and Community Relationships
EDCP 471B Technological Practices in Education: Technical Problems - TECHNICAL PROB
ANAT 548B Directed Studies in Anatomy and Cell Biology - DIRECTED STUDIES
NURS 336 Professional Nursing Practice with Communities and Populations
courses.description: Analysis and application of theories and strategies for working in partnership with populations, health professionals, and community services providers. Students use primary health care principles and population health promotion approaches during community nursing practice.
courses.prerequisites: All of NURS 302, NURS 303, NURS 304, NURS 305, NURS 306.
courses.corequisites: Either (a) all of NURS 338, NURS 339, NURS 340 or (b) all of NURS 341, NURS 342, NURS 343.  (Depends on sequencing of NURS 336 with other professional practice courses.)

courses.name: PLAN 548V Current Issues in Planning - TRANSPORT PLN
courses.description: Each year the school may offer one or more courses on a topical issue covering recent advances in the field.

courses.name: CHIN 213 Intermediate Chinese I: Part 2 (Heritage)
courses.description: Continuation of CHIN 211.

courses.name: CHIN 315 Advanced Chinese Speaking and Writing I (Heritage)
courses.description: Public-speaking and writing skills at an advanced level. Can be taken concurrently with CHIN 311 and CHIN 321.

courses.name: SPAN 302 Advanced Spanish II
courses.description: Composition, translation, and oral practice.  Special emphasis on pronunciation and syntax.

courses.name: GEOG 379B Field Course in Human Geography - FLD CRS HUM GEOG
courses.description: As announced by the department a year in advance.

courses.name: EPSE 565F Special Course in Subject Matter Field - SP CRSE: SUBJ FL
ASTU 410 Co-operative Work Placement III
courses.description: Approved and supervised work experience with a public or private organization for a minimum of 13 weeks full-time. Final work term report.

courses.name: CHEM 302 Atmospheric Environmental Chemistry
courses.description: Introduction to structure, composition and chemical processes occurring in Earth's atmosphere, including interactions with solar radiation, stratospheric ozone layer, photochemical smog and acid rain.

courses.name: LAW 459 Business Organizations
courses.description: A conceptual overview of business organizations in Canada, including partnerships and corporations, and the rights and duties of shareholders and directors. Credit will be granted for only one of LAW 230, LAW 459, or LAW 508.

courses.name: KIN 151 Biomechanics I
courses.description: Application of elementary principles of physics and math to a quantitative analysis of movement.  Analysis will also focus on the development of forces within muscles and their effect on initiating and controlling human movement.

courses.name: MUSC 606 Readings in Orchestral Repertoire
courses.description: Continuation of MUSC 506.

courses.name: ANAT 448J Directed Studies in Anatomy - DIRECTED STUDIES
courses.description: Permission of the Head and supervisor required.

courses.name: DERM 430 Clinical Dermatology
courses.description: Exposure to a number of aspects pertaining to the clinical practice of dermatology.
courses.prerequisites: (Completion of first- and second-year medicine program.)

courses.name: FIPR 534B Advanced Production for Film and Television - ADV PROD FILM&TV
ANTH 202A Contemporary Social Problems - ANTH CON SOC PRB
courses.description: Cultural background to contemporary events; problems of nationalism and regional conflicts, economic and social development, gender, religion and social change. Course may stress a different region of the world in different years.

courses.name: AUDI 568C Audiology Practicum IV - AUDI PRCTCM IV
NURS 339 Critical Inquiry and Research in Health Care Practice
courses.description: Exploration of the application of theories, concepts, evidence and competencies pertaining to scientific inquiry, and the role of evidence informed practice in supporting health care across the range of healthcare disciplines.
courses.prerequisites: All of NURS 302, NURS 303, NURS 304, NURS 305, NURS 306.

courses.name: BIOL 413 Zoogeography
courses.description: The role of physical, ecological, and evolutionary processes in determining the geographic distribution of animals including humans, with implications for speciation and conservation. Restricted to students in third and fourth year.

courses.name: CHBE 575 Air Pollution Control
courses.description: Characteristics of various air pollutants, their behaviour in the atmosphere, monitoring problems, technology of particle collection and control of pollutant gases. Particular problems of regional interest are discussed.

courses.name: EDCP 510 Video Ethnography in Education Research: Culture, Technology, and Interpretation
CIVL 582 Transportation Engineering Impacts
courses.description: Methods to measure, predict and evaluate impacts of transportation modes. Discussion of measures to reduce impacts.

courses.name: EECE 699 Doctoral Dissertation
courses.description: For Ph.D.

courses.name: FIST 100 Introduction to Film Studies
courses.description: Basic aesthetic, economic, sociological, and technological aspects of film.

courses.name: CNTO 301 Basic Cantonese I
courses.description: Elementary level (part I) course in Cantonese for non-heritage learners with no prior exposure to or background in Cantonese. Focus on training for basic oral skills in Cantonese. Open to speakers with no prior Cantonese speaking background.
courses.prerequisites: One of CHIN 107, CHIN 108, CHIN 117, CHIN 118.

courses.name: AUDI 549 M.Sc. Thesis
courses.description: Pass/Fail.

courses.name: MATH 320 Real Variables I
courses.description: The real number system; real Euclidean n-space; open, closed, compact, and connected sets; Bolzano-Weierstrass theorem; sequences and series. Continuity and uniform continuity. Differentiability and mean-value theorems.
courses.prerequisites: Either (a) a score of 68% or higher in MATH 226 or (b) one of MATH 200, MATH 217, MATH 226, MATH 253, MATH 263 and a score of 80% or higher in MATH 220.

courses.name: MTRL 485 Failure of Materials
courses.description: Failure by excess deformation, fracture, fatigue, and environmental effects. Failure theories and case studies of engineering failures.

courses.name: UDES 501 Design Studio: Ecological Regional Design
MATH 317 Calculus IV
courses.description: Parametrizations, inverse and implicit functions, integrals with respect to length and area; grad, div, and curl, theorems of Green, Gauss, and Stokes. Please consult the Faculty of Science Credit Exclusion List: www.students.ubc.ca/calendar/index.cfm?tree=12,215,410,414.
courses.prerequisites: One of MATH 200, MATH 226, MATH 253. (MATH 221 is recommended.)

courses.name: MUSC 104 Introduction to Diatonic Harmony
courses.description: Triads, key and elementary harmony in Western music. Elements of musical form. Aural training and exercises in composition, modeled on historical styles. Not for credit in the B.Mus.

courses.name: THTR 499B Production III - PRODUCTION III
courses.description: Assigned projects in Theatre or Film design and production.
courses.corequisites: One of THTR 405, THTR 406, THTR 407, THTR 408, THTR 450, THTR 452, THTR 454, THTR 456, THTR 470.

courses.name: MECH 485 Aircraft Design: Structures
courses.description: Development of aircraft wing structure, moments of inertia for complex shapes, crippling loads, shear lag.

courses.name: PHAR 503A Graduate Clinical Clerkship - GRAD CLIN CLRKSP
courses.description: This course will consist of clinical rotations of 4-6 weeks' duration (20-40 hours per week, 2 credit/rotation) in selected specialty areas in medicine and clinical pharmacy. Students will be assigned to clinicians in the selected specialty who are members of either the Faculty of Medicine or Pharmaceutical Sciences and who are appointed as clinical instructors for this course. Rotations will take place at the site(s) where the majority of the clinician's practice is conducted.

courses.name: FRST 490 Visual Resource Management
courses.description: Methodologies for analysis, design and management of the visual guidelines; operational policies of resource extraction industries and the implication on multiple land use management.

courses.name: FNIS 220 Representation and Indigenous Cultural Politics
courses.description: Representation, identity, and cultural politics through Indigenous literature, film, and the visual arts; the relationship between these sites of cultural production and the self-determination struggles of Indigenous peoples. Credit will be granted for only one of FNSP 200, FNIS 220, or FNSP 220.

courses.name: COMM 306 Urban Land Economics
courses.description: Examines economic factors affecting the urban land market, with an emphasis on determinants of urban land values, the housing market, urban transportation, and land use policies.

courses.name: THTR 310 Theory of Drama Performance
courses.description: The basic principles of dramaturgy and theory of performance. Historical and contemporary writing on dramatic theory and criticism and their relation to theatrical practice.

courses.name: FRST 309 Forest Pathology
courses.description: Biology and management of forest tree diseases. Available only through Distance Education.

courses.name: FRST 499 B.S.F. Thesis
courses.description: An independent study or research project on an approved topic, developed under the guidance of a Faculty member. Available only to students in their graduating year.

courses.name: MATH 440 Complex Analysis
courses.description: The residue theorem, the argument principle, conformal mapping, the maximum modulus principle, harmonic functions, representation of functions by integrals, series, and products. Other topics at the discretion of the instructor.
courses.prerequisites: MATH 300 and a score of 68% or higher in MATH 320.

courses.name: GEOG 319 Environmental Impact Assessment
courses.description: The principles, implementation, and role of environmental impact assessment in environmental management, in Canada and internationally.

courses.name: CIVL 556 Modeling and Optimization of Civil Engineering Systems
courses.description: Applications of practical simulation and optimization software systems and operations research methodologies in design, analysis, and operation of civil engineering systems.

courses.name: HIST 256 History of Africa
courses.description: An introduction to selected themes and historical approaches in African history. These may include African geography and identities, sources and methodology, pre-modern state formation, gender relations, world religions, labour systems, colonialism, and post-colonialism.

courses.name: ASIA 357 Modern Korean Fiction in Translation
courses.description: Selected novels and stories written between 1906 and the present.

courses.name: BIOL 445 Darwin's Fishes
courses.description: A series of computer-assisted lectures using ichthyology and the work of Charles Darwin to illustrate basic principles of biology, and their practical implementation, i.e., how biologists select research programs, generate and test hypotheses, and present their case to peers and the public.

courses.name: COMM 490A Directed Studies in Commerce - DIRECTED STUDIES
courses.description: An investigation and report on a topic to be agreed upon by a member of the faculty and a senior student.

courses.name: EDCP 523A Seminar in Art Education - SEMINAR ART EDUC
PHYS 410 Computational Physics
courses.description: Scientific programming applied to problems in physics. Fundamentals of numerical analysis for continuum problems. Solution of linear and non-linear algebraic systems, ordinary differential equations and stochastic problems.
courses.prerequisites: One of PHYS 312, MATH 257, MATH 316 and one of PHYS 210, EOSC 211, CPSC 110, CPSC 111, APSC 160.

courses.name: GRS 290 Global Issues in Cultural Context
courses.description: Students interact face-to-face and on-line as a community of learners to discuss global issues in agriculture, food, and natural resources in cultural context. Typically taken prior to studying abroad.
courses.prerequisites: (Open only to students in the B.Sc. (GRS) program.)

courses.name: PSYC 499 Cooperative Work Placement IV
courses.description: Approved and supervised relevant work experience in an industrial, academic, or government setting for a minimum of 13 weeks, full time. Normally taken in Summer Session after fourth year. Work term report required. Restricted to students admitted to the Co-op Program in Psychology (B.Sc.).

courses.name: CHEM 417 Nuclear Chemistry and Radiochemistry
courses.description: Basic treatment of the nucleus, with analogy to concepts in chemistry. Nuclear stabilities and associated radioactive decay processes. Nuclear structure. Applications of radioisotopes in chemistry. The interaction of radiation with matter.
courses.prerequisites: CHEM 201. (or with permission CHEM 205. CHEM 312 is recommended.)

courses.name: SOWK 440C Integrative Seminars in Social Work - INTGRTV SEM SOWK
courses.description: A series of seminars offered during the final term of studies which address salient issues in social policy and social work practice and draw upon combined knowledge from social work and related disciplines.

courses.name: BIOL 548I Advanced Topics in Biology - ADV TOPICS BIOL
CHEM 213 Organic Chemistry
courses.description: Spectroscopy of organic compounds.  Mechanistic analysis of chemical reactivity of common functional groups with a focus on carbon-carbon bond formation; functional group interconversion.  Preference will be given to students in Chemistry or Biochemistry specializations.
courses.prerequisites: Either (a) CHEM 203 or (b) a score of 76% or higher in CHEM 233.

courses.name: MIDW 325 Professional Issues in Midwifery
courses.description: Professional issues in midwifery including responsibilities and conduct, self-care, peer review, inter-professional relations and communication, legal and business concepts, and continuous quality assurance and improvement in practice.  A series of lectures and workshops delivered in an intensive format over two weeks.  Pass/Fail.

courses.name: ARCH 521 Architectural Design Studio IV
courses.prerequisites: All of ARCH 500, ARCH 501, ARCH 520, ARCH 511, ARCH 512, ARCH 513, ARCH 531.

courses.name: EPSE 526 Seminar in Specific Learning Disabilities
GERM 300 Intermediate German III
courses.description: Fluency in many relevant situations; competence in the most important areas of cultural life; familiarity with study resources and study skills. Review and expansion of grammar; fostering of speaking and writing skills.

courses.name: SPHA 555 Biostatistics
courses.description: Data collection, numeric and graphic summarization, and elementary statistical analysis. Examples primarily from health sciences.

courses.name: BUSI 393 Introduction to Business Law
courses.description: Introduction to the law of contracts, with particular reference to contracts for sale of goods and related law of personal property, principles of agency, partnership, and company law.

courses.name: WOOD 449A Directed Studies in Wood Products Processing - DIR ST WD PR PRC
courses.description: In special cases and with the approval of the instructor concerned, a student may carry on directed studies of specific problems in wood products processing.

courses.name: CRWR 408V Writing for Graphic Forms I - GRAPHIC FORMS 1
courses.description: A workshop class in the writing of graphic novel, manga, and other forms of illustrated writing. The ability to draw is not required. Admission is restricted to B.F.A. Majors in Creative Writing.

courses.name: SOCI 425A Urban Sociology - URBAN SOCIOLOGY
courses.description: Demographic, behavioural, and organizational aspects of urban structures and of urbanization in different societies and periods.

courses.name: FRE 521D Topics in Food and Resource Economics - TOPICS IN FRE
COMM 454 Accounting for Management Control and Incentives
courses.description: Design of accounting systems for facilitating and influencing management decisions, with emphasis on performance evaluation in organizations.

courses.name: EDST 602B Doctoral Seminar - DOCTORAL SEMINAR
courses.description: For students in the second year of a doctoral program. Pass/Fail.

courses.name: GEOB 373 Introductory Remote Sensing
courses.description: Aerial photography; measurement from aerial photographs; photo-interpretation in geographic analysis; remote sensing of the earth's surface and atmosphere.
courses.prerequisites: GEOB 270. (Or third-year standing in ENSC or GEOB specializations.)

courses.name: LAW 476 Evidence
courses.description: The admissibility and use of evidence in litigation. Credit will be granted for only one of LAW 280, LAW 476, or LAW 507.

courses.name: PHYS 527B Topics in Nuclear Physics - TPS NUCLEAR PHYS
courses.description: Selected topics from current nuclear theory.

courses.name: FREN 349 French Literatures in Translation II
courses.description: Literary works since the French Revolution.  Topics may include literature from France, Quebec, Africa, the Caribbean.  Not available for credit towards a Minor, Major or Honours program in French. May be taken up to two times for a total of 6 credits with different content.
courses.prerequisites: (6 credits of first year English, ARTS 001 or Foundations and at least second-year standing.)

courses.name: EOSC 429 Groundwater Contamination
courses.description: Contaminant transport processes in groundwater flow systems; aqueous and multiphase transport; mathematical models describing migration and chemical evolution of contaminant plumes; case studies.

courses.name: ANAT 548D Directed Studies in Anatomy and Cell Biology - DIRECTED STUDIES
ARST 556M Topics in Archival Automation - TPCS ARCH AUTMTN
ENGL 512A Middle English Studies - MID ENGL STUDIES
ARCL 103 Introduction to Archaeology
courses.description: Survey of world archaeology, from the emergence of humankind to the beginning of state societies.

courses.name: MTRL 466 Engineering Project I
courses.description: Design projects to illustrate the full spectrum of design encountered in Metals and Materials Engineering including the design of components, structures and processes used to manufacture materials.

courses.name: SOIL 516 Urban Watershed Management
courses.description: Urban land use impacts on water resources with a focus on impervious surfaces, storm-water management, non-point sources of pollution, cumulative effects, water quality, rehabilitation of urban streams, and application of best management practices. Prior completion of RMES 515 strongly recommended.  Credit will be give for only one of SOIL 516 or RMES 516.

courses.name: ENGL 472D American Studies - AMERICAN STUDIES
courses.prerequisites: (3rd year standing and 6 credits of first-year English, or Arts One, or 6 credits of ASTU 100 from CAP or 3 credits of first-year English and 3 credits of ASTU 150)

courses.name: CIVL 416 Environmental Hydraulics
courses.description: Application of hydraulic engineering principles to problems of environmental concern. Pollutant transport and dispersion. Mixing in rivers and lakes. Theory of jets and plumes. Design of outfall diffusers.

courses.name: COMM 486D Special Topics in Business - DEV SOC ENTR AFR
RHSC 504C Directed Studies in Rehabilitation - DST REHABILIT'N
CPEN 312 Digital Systems and Microcomputers
courses.description: Data representation in digital computers; boolean algebra; the design and optimization and implementation of combinatorial and sequential circuits; modern digital circuit technologies; memory and programmable logic devices; organization and operation of microcomputers; data/address bus organization; input-output interfacing. Credit will be granted for only one of EECE 355, CPEN 312, EECE 259, CPEN 211, and EECE 256.
courses.prerequisites: One of EECE 251, ELEC 201, EECE 252, ELEC 204, EECE 263, ELEC 203, MECH 221.

courses.name: BABS 550 Application of Statistics in Management
courses.description: Not available to MBA students.

courses.name: SOCI 100B Introduction to Sociology - INTRO SOCIOLOGY
courses.description: Introduction to problems in the analysis of social structures and processes. Basic sociological concepts will be introduced and their application demonstrated in various areas of sociology. Credit will be granted for only one of (i) SOCI 100C (6) or (ii) SOCI 100A (3) and SOCI 100B (3).

courses.name: SURG 512 Global Disability: A Surgical Care Mandate
courses.description: Online course. Relationship of surgery to preventing and treating disabling impairments in lower income countries. Focus will be on sensory impairments (blindness and deafness) and physical impairment.

courses.name: SOCI 324 Sociology of the Life Course
courses.description: Individuals and families through the life course.

courses.name: CIVL 478 Building Science
courses.description: Building science concepts associated with the design of modern buildings, focusing particularly on the building envelope's role in environmental separation, controlling the movement of heat, air, and water in liquid and vapour states.

courses.name: SOCI 476 Interpersonal Dynamics
courses.description: Interaction processes in close relationships, especially within families.

courses.name: ISCI 300 Interdisciplinary Seminar
courses.description: Critical analysis of recent scientific literature that combines disciplines that students are integrating in their Integrated Sciences Curriculum.

courses.name: BA 580A Topics in Business Administration - TPC BUSINS ADMIN
courses.description: Restricted to students in one of: E.M.B.A., M.B.A., J.D./M.B.A., M.M., or M.B.A./M.A.A.

courses.name: CONS 127 Observing the Earth from Space
courses.description: Exploration of innovative Earth observation and other geospatial technologies and how they allow us to better understand the changing Earth.

courses.name: MUSC 403M Selected Topics in Music - SDS MUSIC GENDER
courses.description: See School of Music schedule for description and prerequisites. Restricted to B. Mus. and B.A. in Music students.
