courses.name: FNEL 180 Introduction to Endangered Language Documentation and Revitalization
courses.description: Foundational concepts in the critical study of cultural, historical, social, and political factors that impact language loss, retention, and revival. Introducing strategies and practical methodologies for collaborative, interdisciplinary, community-based documentation and revitalization projects for First Nations and Indigenous languages.

courses.name: EDUC 490J Special Studies in Education - SPEC STUDIES ED
courses.description: Topics not covered in a course. A pilot course may be offered under this name for only one year and with permission of the Associate Dean (Teacher Education).

courses.name: LAW 356 First Nations and Economic Development
courses.description: Legal issues affecting land use and economic activity involving First Nations' resources. Not offered each year, consult Faculty.

courses.name: MICB 398 Co-operative Work Placement I
courses.description: Work experience in an industrial research setting, taken during the Winter Session (Term 2) of third year. Restricted to students admitted to the Co-operative Education Program of Biotechnology in Microbiology and Immunology.

courses.name: APSC 100 Introduction to Engineering I
courses.description: An introduction to the engineering profession including: roles and responsibilities of the engineer, the engineering disciplines, sustainability, an introduction to the engineering design process, introduction and application of the relevant foundational scientific principles, prototyping, engineering graphics, technical communication, and engineering ethics.

courses.name: GEOG 211 The State of the Earth
courses.description: The demographic, economic, ecological, and technological factors that underlie current environmental challenges, considering their effects to date and their possible impact in the future.
courses.prerequisites: One of GEOB 102, GEOB 103. (GEOG 121, GEOG 122 recommended.  Second-year standing.)

courses.name: CHEM 403 Surface Chemistry and Surface Analysis
courses.description: Surfaces and phenomena occurring at surfaces and interfaces: adsorption, thermodynamic treatments, technological applications. Methods for characterization and modification of surfaces. Dynamic electrochemistry and its application to understanding fuel cells.
courses.prerequisites: CHEM 304 and one of MATH 200, MATH 217, MATH 226, MATH 253, MATH 263.

courses.name: CHIN 214 Intensive Intermediate Chinese I (Heritage)
courses.description: Integrated skills in modern Chinese. Emphasis on reading and writing and better understanding of Chinese culture.

courses.name: KIN 500A Special Topics in Kinesiology - SPEC TPCS KIN
COMM 292 Management and Organizational Behaviour
courses.description: Behaviour in organizations as it affects people as individuals, their relationships with others, their performance in groups and their effectiveness at work.

courses.name: CIVL 215 Fluid Mechanics I
courses.description: Fluid properties, hydrostatics, kinematics, and fluid dynamics: energy and momentum methods with applications. Dimensional analysis, modelling, introduction to flow in pipes and forces on immersed objects.

courses.name: MTRL 263 Transport Phenomena I - Fluid Mechanics
courses.description: Fluid statics; fluid mechanics; laminar and turbulent flow; equations of continuity and motion; boundary layers; flow in conduits and packed and fluidized beds; flow measurements.

courses.name: MUSC 309 Instrumentation
courses.description: The study of string, woodwind, brass and percussion instruments; orchestral sections and scoring for various small ensembles. Activities include demonstrations of instruments, scoring projects, analysis and listening. For credit towards the B.Mus. and the B.A. in Music; not open to other students.
courses.prerequisites: One of MUSC 111, MUSC 200. (and completion of the second-year piano requirement.)

courses.name: LLED 480B Advanced Studies in Language and Literacy Education - ADV ST LNG LIT
courses.description: Credit will be given for only 6 credits of LLED 480 and 429.

courses.name: ENGL 220 Literature in English to the 18th Century
courses.description: A survey of prose, poetry and drama to the 18th Century.
courses.prerequisites: Either (a) ARTS 001 or (b) two of ENGL 100, ENGL 110, ENGL 111, ENGL 112, ENGL 120, ENGL 121 or (c) ASTU 100 or (d) ASTU 150 and one of ENGL 110, ENGL 111, ENGL 120, ENGL 121;  or (e) WRDS 150 and one of ENGL 110, ENGL 111, ENGL 120, ENGL 121. (Or 6 credits of first-year English.)

courses.name: CHEM 301 Aqueous Environmental Chemistry
courses.description: Properties of natural waters, including gas and solid equilibria, pH, redox, complexation analysis, corrosion treatment, ion exchange, colloids and microbial transformations.

courses.name: POLI 516A Issues in Comparative Politics - COMPAR POLITICS
LLED 491A Supervised Study in English Education - SUPER ST ENGL ED
LAW 412 Taxation of Trusts and Estates
courses.description: Not offered each year, consult Faculty.  Credit will be granted for only one of LAW 412 or LAW 564.

courses.name: MUSC 402C Special Projects - SPECIAL PROJECTS
courses.description: For fourth-year students who receive permission of the Director of the School of Music to do advanced studies in their major field.

courses.name: THTR 473 Advanced Speech and Movement I
courses.description: Open only to B.F.A. Acting students.
courses.prerequisites: Three of THTR 371, THTR 372, THTR 373, THTR 374, THTR 391.

courses.name: ENVR 448B Directed Studies in Environmental Science - DIR STD ENVR SCI
courses.description: Investigation of a topic to be agreed upon by a member of the faculty and the student.  Permission of an ENSC advisor and of the supervising faculty member is required prior to registration.
courses.prerequisites: (Fourth-year standing in the Faculty of Science.)

courses.name: EOSC 533 Advanced Groundwater Hydrology
courses.description: Finite-difference models of steady-state and transient groundwater flow in the saturated and unsaturated zones; applications to regional groundwater flow, groundwater recharge, subsurface contributions to streamflow, and aquifer evaluation.

courses.name: KORN 302 Readings in Korean Topics II
courses.description: Continuation of KORN 301. As of 2011W, credit will be granted for only one of KORN 301/302 or KORN 300.

courses.name: ENVR 430 Ecological Dimensions of Sustainability
courses.description: Current issues. Application to agricultural, energy, and resource systems in terrestrial and aquatic contexts. Analysis of complex problems; incorporation of science into novel interdisciplinary solutions.
courses.prerequisites: One of ENVR 300, BIOL 230. (Or fourth year standing in the BSCN program or other demonstrated ecology background.)

courses.name: CNPS 564 Group Counselling
courses.description: Understanding, designing and knowledge of groups and how to conduct them for use in counselling and guidance services.

courses.name: HIST 490R Seminar for Majors in History - SEM FOR HIST MAJ
courses.description: Selected problems in the theory and practice of historical work. Check with the department for course offerings. Restricted to fourth year students majoring in History or in the History and Philosophy of Science. Also open to History Honours students.

courses.name: EPSE 565A Special Course in Subject Matter Field - SP CRSE: SUBJ FL
ASTU 400N Interdisciplinary Studies in Arts - ALTRD CNSCNSS
courses.description: For upper-division students in the Faculty of Arts. Topics announced annually.

courses.name: CRWR 555B Advanced Writing of Non-Fiction II - ADV WR N-FIC II
EDCP 585A Special Course in Curriculum and Pedagogy - SPECIAL CURR&PED
BMEG 598 Biomedical Engineering Seminar
courses.description: Presentation and discussion of current topics in biomedical engineering research and development. A required course for all graduate students in Biomedical Engineering.

courses.name: LAW 610C Doctoral Seminar I: Issues in Legal Theory - DOC SEM  I: ISS
courses.description: Including law and feminism, Marxism, post-modernism, social theory, law and the state; legal liberalism and its critics, and other jurisprudential discourses.

courses.name: ELEC 471 Medical Imaging
courses.description: Physical principles of ultrasound, magnetic resonance, computed tomography, nuclear medicine, and X-ray projection imaging.  Applications in diagnostics, therapeutics, and interventions.
courses.prerequisites: One of EECE 331, ELEC 371 and one of EECE 360, ELEC 341 and one of EECE 364, ELEC 311 and one of EECE 269, ELEC 221, EECE 359.

courses.name: ISCI 448B Directed Studies - DIR STUDIES
courses.description: Permission of the Director is required.

courses.name: COMM 370 Corporate Finance
courses.description: Examination of corporate enterprise decisions including capital budgeting; capital structure choice, and financial policies, tools, and valuation.

courses.name: CLST 231 Ancient Greece
courses.description: A survey of the ancient Greek world from the Minoan and Mycenaean (about 2000-1000 BCE) to the Hellenistic Period (323-30 BCE).

courses.name: POLI 260 Introduction to Global Politics
courses.description: Applies conceptual tools to topics such as war, conflict management, the global economy, poverty, and civil society.

courses.name: GEOG 429 Research in Historical Geography
courses.description: Details available from Geography Undergraduate Advisor. Not necessarily offered each year.
courses.prerequisites: (Major or Honours in Geography with at least 75 credits, or permission of the instructor.)

courses.name: EDUC 495B Practicum (Elementary) for Previously Certified Teachers - TEACH PRACT ELEM
courses.description: Pass/Fail.
courses.prerequisites: (Completion of recent elementary teaching methods courses in the subjects to be taught.)

courses.name: COMM 625A Advanced Topics in Organizational Behaviour - MCRO-LVL ORG BHV
PLAN 528B Capstone Professional Report - PROFESSION REPRT
FIPR 536A Advanced Documentary Development and Production - ADV DOC DEV&PROD
ENVR 200 Introduction to Environmental Science
courses.description: Seminars and field trips introducing the major global, regional, and local environmental issues facing human societies.
courses.prerequisites: (Open to all students with second-year, or higher, standing.)

courses.name: LAW 475A Competitive Trial Advocacy Credit - COMP TRIAL AD
courses.description: Trial advocacy. Restricted to students participating in one or more faculty approved trial advocacy competitions. Students enrolled in this course must also be enrolled in LAW 474.

courses.name: GERM 433 German for Reading Knowledge I
courses.description: A multimedia introduction to reading skills in German leading to a second year reading knowledge in just one term. Students are expected to work largely independently. Course restricted to beginners or to students with no more than one term of beginner's German (or equivalent).

courses.name: PHAR 408 Clinical Pharmacokinetics
courses.description: Lectures and discussions of topics on the application of pharmacokinetic principles and the use of therapeutic drug level monitoring in clinical pharmacy practice.
courses.prerequisites: (Successful completion of all required courses in the first three years of the pharmacy curriculum.)

courses.name: RGLA 371 Seminar in Religion and Literature
FRE 295 Managerial Economics
courses.description: Economic foundations of managerial decision-making. Organization of the firm, demand theory, cost and production, market structure, competitive strategy, welfare-economic foundations of business regulation. Credit may be obtained for only one of ECON 201, ECON 206, FRE 295, COMM 295.
courses.prerequisites: Either (a) ECON 100 or (b) all of ECON 101, ECON 102;  and MATH 105.

courses.name: PHYS 159 Introductory Physics Laboratory for Engineers
courses.description: A laboratory course with emphasis on experimental design, measurement and analysis techniques. Please consult the Faculty of Science Credit Exclusion List: www.students.ubc.ca/calendar/index.cfm?tree=12,215,410,414

courses.name: ENGL 508A Studies in the Structure of the English Language - STUD STRUC LANG
PATH 303 Cytogenetics, Tissue Culture and Cytology
courses.description: Tissue culture techniques in clinical diagnosis; cytological techniques used in the diagnosis and control of cancer. Sex chromatin determination.

courses.name: PHAR 580 Toxicology I - General Principles of Toxicology
courses.description: Absorption, distribution, metabolism and excretion of toxins. Chemical mutagenesis, carcinogenesis and teratogenesis and radiation toxicology. Various subspecialties introduced include regulatory, forensic, occupational and clinical toxicology.

courses.name: EXCH 582 Grad Student Studying Abroad on a Non-UBC Program
PATH 375 Introduction to Human Pathology
courses.description: A lecture-demonstration course designed to acquaint students in the allied health professions with a basic understanding of the causes, natural history, and pathophysiology of common disease processes.
courses.prerequisites: (6 credits each first year BIOL and CHEM)

courses.name: EOSC 513 Imaging and estimation with wavelets
SOWK 503 Communication Skills in Social Work Practice
FNH 326 Food Science Laboratory II
courses.description: Integrated laboratory encompassing the processing and analysis of foods.  Enrolment restricted to Food Science students.

courses.name: HIST 333A Third-Year Honours Seminar - 3RD YR HONRS SEM
SOCI 310A Canadian Society - CANADIAN SOCIETY
courses.description: Social organization of Canadian society: relationships between social institutions and social processes (e.g., economics, education, family, law, media, and politics); including issues of ancestry, ethnicity, gender, region, and social class.

courses.name: AANB 500 Graduate Seminar
courses.description: Participation in this course is compulsory for all graduate students in Applied Animal Biology.

courses.name: ORPA 720 Orthopaedic Basic Science Course
courses.description: Weekly lectures by orthopaedic faculty and guest faculty from other departments. Lecture topics include applied physiology, anatomy, and pathology as they relate to orthopaedic diseases.

courses.name: SPHA 554 Application of Statistics in Management
courses.description: Data analysis and statistical inference. Applications in assessment of the legitimacy and significance of reports.

courses.name: POLI 464D Problems in International Relations - PROB INTRL RELTN
courses.description: Content varies from year to year. Consult the departmental website. One section (of 3 credits) is reserved for fourth-year students in the Major program in International Relations.

courses.name: SOWK 451 Health Care Team Development
courses.description: This Interprofessional Health and Human Service (IHHS) course covers the skills, knowledge, roles, and issues involved with working successfully in interprofessional health and human service teams. Intended for upper division students in any health and human service program. Offered as IHHS 400 prior to September 2015. Credit will be granted for only one of SOWK 451 or IHHS 400.

courses.name: WOOD 449C Directed Studies in Wood Products Processing - DIR ST WD PR PRC
courses.description: In special cases and with the approval of the instructor concerned, a student may carry on directed studies of specific problems in wood products processing.

courses.name: GSAT 540 Statistical Methods for High Dimensional Biology
EOSC 353 Seismology
courses.description: Hooke's law for isotropic continua, elastic wave equation, reflection and refraction methods for imaging the Earth's internal structure, plane waves in an infinite medium and interaction with boundaries, body wave seismology, inversion of travel-time curves, generalized ray theory, crustal seismology, surface waves and earthquake source studies.

courses.name: APBI 490 Topics in Applied Biology
courses.description: Analysis and interpretation of current issues in applied biology. Prior to registration, students should consult with Student Services in the Faculty of Land and Food Systems.

courses.name: FREN 360 Introduction to Old French
courses.description: The phonetics, grammar, and vocabulary of major Old French dialects; corpus of various literary texts (842-1300).

courses.name: EDCP 312A Instrumental Pedagogy: Secondary - INSTRUM PEDGY
CHBE 496 Thesis Biotechnology Topic
courses.description: Biotechnological engineering research topic.

courses.name: PHYS 498 Co-operative Work Placement IV
courses.description: Approved and supervised technical work experience in an industrial research setting for a minimum of 3.5 months. Normally taken during the fall term of the fourth year. Technical report required. Restricted to students admitted to the Co-operative Education Program in Physics.

courses.name: ISCI 399 Co-operative Work Placement II
courses.description: Industrial or academic work experience for a minimum of 4 months. Technical report required. Restricted to students admitted to the Co-op Program in ISP.

courses.name: MICB 406 Topics in Molecular Virology
courses.description: Presentations, library research, paper reviews, class discussions about current research in virology. Topics such as molecular targets in viral therapy; chronic viral infection; virus-host cell interaction.

courses.name: ENGL 110 Approaches to Literature
courses.description: Study of selected examples of poetry, fiction, and drama. Essays are required.

courses.name: MATH 551 Perturbation Methods for Differential Equations
courses.prerequisites: MATH 550. (Ordinary and partial differential equations (MATH 400 or equivalent).)

courses.name: DENT 772 Orthodontic and Dentofacial Orthopedic Clinics II
courses.description: Continues in third year.

courses.name: EOSC 556B Studies in Applied Geophysics - ST IN APPL GEOP
ECED 590F Graduating Project - GRADUATING PRJCT
courses.description: Pass/Fail.

courses.name: PHAR 489 Advanced Pharmacy Practice Experience - Institutional
courses.description: A 160-hour pharmacy clerkship emphasizing integration of knowledge and skills in developing and assessing therapeutic plans for patients in institutional practice.

courses.name: SPPH 501 Analysis of Longitudinal Data from Epidemiological Studies
courses.description: To explore and compare methods of analyzing continuous and categorical longitudinal data. The issues of missing data and errors in measurement/misclassification will be covered in depth.
courses.prerequisites: Either (a) all of HCEP 400, HCEP 500, HCEP 502 or (b) all of SPPH 400, SPPH 500, SPPH 502 or (c) all of SPPH 500, SPPH 502, SPPH 567.

courses.name: SURG 500 Experimental Surgery
courses.description: Lectures and seminars dealing with the selected application of surgical techniques in biological investigation.

courses.name: CPSC 411 Introduction to Compiler Construction
courses.description: A practical introduction to lexical analysis, syntactic analysis, type-checking, code generation and optimization. This will be used to design and implement a compiler for a small language.

courses.name: MATH 335 Introduction to Mathematics
courses.description: Intensive course with required tutorial. Combinatorics, probability, geometry and elementary number theory. Not for credit in the Faculty of Science. Students who obtain credit at UBC for any other mathematics course cannot in the same or later years obtain credit for MATH 335. Please consult the Faculty of Science Credit Exclusion List: www.students.ubc.ca/calendar/index.cfm?tree=12,215,410,414.

courses.name: BUSI 420A Integrated Business Leadership - INTEG BUS LDRSHP
courses.description: Pass/Fail.

courses.name: MECH 535 Orthopaedic Biomechanics
courses.description: Musculoskeletal anatomy. Static and dynamic analysis of the musculoskeletal system. Gait. Musculoskeletal tissue mechanics. Biomaterials. Advanced study of relevant problems in orthopaedics, including joint replacement, fracture fixation, and spinal disorders. Credit given for only one of MECH 435 and MECH 535.

courses.name: CNPS 678A Theoretical Perspectives in Counselling Psychology - THRTCL PRSP CNPS
courses.description: Major theoretical traditions in Counselling Psychology and illustration of the links among theory, research and practices; perspectives on Counselling Psychology as a distinct field of specialization.

courses.name: LAW 419D Individual Employment Law - INDV EMPLYMT LAW
courses.description: Legal aspects of employment relationships other that those arising by collective bargaining. Not offered each year, consult Faculty.

courses.name: PHIL 211A Greek Philosophy I - GREEK PHIL I
courses.description: The Presocratics; Socrates; Sophists. Recommended as preparation for CLST/PHIL 212 and PHIL 310.

courses.name: EDCP 602A Doctoral Seminar in Curriculum and Pedagogy: Conceptualizing Research - CNCPT RESRCH SEM
MUSC 154A University Choral Union - UBC CHORAL UNION
courses.description: May be repeated for credit in accordance with program requirements for B.Mus. or B.A. in Music. Open to other students by audition, with credit, as stipulated by their faculties.

courses.name: SPPH 581M Selected Topics - EARLY CHILD HLTH
courses.description: By seminar and directed readings, certain topics of current interest are explored in depth.

courses.name: CLST 502 Topography and Monuments of Rome
courses.description: A study of the topography and monuments of ancient Rome from the Iron Age to Late Antiquity. Offered in the second term of alternate years.

courses.name: SPPH 531 Health Care Systems Analysis
courses.description: Theory, concepts, measurement, and practical skills using administrative data for analysis of health care systems.

courses.name: PHAR 399 Cases in Pharmaceutical Sciences II
courses.description: Case studies and other activities integrating scientific and clinical concepts.

courses.name: RSOT 545 Theory, Practice Skills, and Therapeutic Procedures: Advanced Applications
DHYG 310 Dental Hygiene Theory and Practice III
courses.description: The study of dental hygiene theory and practice with emphasis on diverse clients with oral health care needs.

courses.name: ORPA 509 Advanced Orthopaedics II
courses.description: The second year of the above program which will be given in alternate years.

courses.name: MATH 358 Engineering Analysis
courses.description: Fourier series; auto- and cross-correlation; power spectra;  discrete Fourier transform; boundary-value problems; numerical methods; partial differential equations; heat, wave, Laplace, Poisson, and wave equations.  Applications to mechanical engineering and practical computing applications emphasized.  Credit will be granted for only one of MECH 358 or MATH 358.

courses.name: FRST 210 Forest Plant Biology II
courses.description: The functional biology of trees and other forest plants in their environment, with an emphasis on gymnosperms.

courses.name: COMM 497 New Enterprise Development
courses.description: The particular problems and experiences encountered in starting, developing and managing new enterprises. The course includes lectures, guest speakers, and case studies.

courses.name: COHR 401 Organizational Change
courses.description: The tactics and strategies for implementing constructive modifications in organizations.
courses.prerequisites: COMM 292 and one of COMM 203, COMM 392.

courses.name: RMST 222 Literatures and Cultures of the Romance World II: Modern to Post-Modern
courses.description: An introduction to the main themes that shaped the Western part of Europe in the age of the nation state, imperialism, colonization, and decolonization.

courses.name: CIVL 433 Advanced Concrete Design
courses.description: Design of continuous reinforced concrete building frames and structures.

courses.name: LAW 315D Topics in Legal History - TPCS LGL HISTORY
courses.description: Not offered each year, consult Faculty.

courses.name: CIVL 331 Steel and Timber Design
courses.description: Introduction to limit states design of steel and timber structures: material properties, design of tension and compression members, beams, columns, and connections.

courses.name: PATH 531 Molecular and Cell Biology of Cancer
courses.description: This course focuses on molecular and cell biology of cancer and consists of a series of lectures/reviews combined with discussions and presentations by students on the topics selected by the instructors. Emphasis will be on students' presentations and discussion.
courses.prerequisites: (MEDG 421 is recommended. Course coordinator approval is required.)

courses.name: ASTU 412B Co-operative Work Placement V - COOP PLACEMENT V
courses.description: Optional extra work placement. Approved and supervised work experience with a public or private organization for a minimum of 13 weeks full-time. Final work term report.

courses.name: EECE 569 Mobile Communications Networks
courses.description: Network architectures: cellular networks, ad hoc networks; access protocols; radio and network resource management; quality of service; mobility and location management; routing; mobile-IP; current wireless technologies for personal, local and satellite networks.

courses.name: SPHA 522 Strategic Human Resources Management
courses.description: Aligning the management of human resources with organizational strategy.

courses.name: GEOG 457 Social and Behavioural Geography
courses.description: Theories of social change in the global city; labour markets; poverty and inequality; social polarization; housing markets; gentrification and housing affordability; immigration and segregation; diversity and multiculturalism; transnationalism; the entrepreneurial state; the convivial city.

courses.name: DENT 561A Directed Studies in Dental Sciences - DST DENTAL SCIE
EOSC 321 Igneous Petrology
courses.description: The origin and formation of igneous rocks.

courses.name: SOWK 315 Practicum I
courses.description: A supervised practicum in an assigned social service, two days a week throughout the program year. Limited to students in the B.S.W. program. This course will be graded Pass/Fail.

courses.name: RSOT 511 Fundamentals of Theory and Practice
LFS 250 Land, Food and Community I
courses.description: Introduction to managed systems and concepts of sustainability; economic, ecological and social components; managed landscapes, agri-food systems, and communities; urban and rural systems; the land, food, nutrition and human health continuum.

courses.name: EOSC 699 Doctoral Dissertation
courses.description: For Ph.D. (Engineering).

courses.name: MTRL 472 Welding and Joining of Materials
courses.description: Case studies addressing temperature modelling in welding and joining, material selection for welds and joints, calculation of properties for welds and joints, mechanical analysis of joints, and design of welding and joining procedures.

courses.name: ARTH 346 Architecture in Europe: Building the Fabric of the Modern State (1715-1837)
courses.description: The role of architecture within the development of the modern state.  A survey of broad cultural dynamics, particular building projects and design careers.

courses.name: CHBE 454 Chemical Process and Product Design
courses.description: Design and economic assessment of a major chemical engineering process. Students perform the synthesis of a detailed design for a practical and environmentally sound process.
courses.prerequisites: All of CHBE 346, CHBE 351, CHBE 356, CHBE 376.

courses.name: KIN 230 Human Motor Behaviour I
courses.description: Processes underlying human movement and learning motor skills and factors influencing acquisition, performance, and movement control.

courses.name: EDUC 399 Field Experience and Seminar
courses.description: Pass/Fail.

courses.name: ECED 580A Problems in Early Childhood Education - PROB IN ECE
courses.description: Investigation and report of a problem.

courses.name: CPSC 261 Basics of Computer Systems
courses.description: Software architecture, operating systems, and I/O architectures.  Relationships between application software, operating systems, and computing hardware; critical sections, deadlock avoidance, and performance; principles and operation of disks and networks.
courses.prerequisites: One of EECE 259, CPEN 211 and one of CPSC 260, EECE 210, CPEN 221.

courses.name: PHAR 503Q Graduate Clinical Clerkship - GRAD CLIN CLRKSP
courses.description: This course will consist of clinical rotations of 4-6 weeks' duration (20-40 hours per week, 2 credit/rotation) in selected specialty areas in medicine and clinical pharmacy. Students will be assigned to clinicians in the selected specialty who are members of either the Faculty of Medicine or Pharmaceutical Sciences and who are appointed as clinical instructors for this course. Rotations will take place at the site(s) where the majority of the clinician's practice is conducted.

courses.name: BIOL 351 Plant Physiology I
courses.description: Mechanisms and regulation of functional processes contributing to the assimilation, transport and utilization of water, mineral nutrients and carbon by plants. Restricted to Majors and Honours students in Biology.
courses.prerequisites: One of BIOL 121, SCIE 001 and either (a) CHEM 123 or (b) all of CHEM 111, CHEM 113. (CHEM 233 is recommended.)

courses.name: BIOL 420 Ocean Conservation and Sustainability
courses.description: An interdisciplinary conservation course with a solutions-oriented approach to marine issues, drawing from natural sciences, social sciences, business, law, and communication.

courses.name: THTR 391A Rehearsal and Performance - REHEARS&PERFORM
courses.description: Open only to  B.F.A. Acting students.
courses.prerequisites: All of THTR 271, THTR 272, THTR 273, THTR 274.

courses.name: EOSC 472 Chemical Oceanography and Marine Geochemistry
courses.description: Controls on chemical composition and elemental distributions in seawater and marine sediments (including nutrient elements, dissolved gases, the carbonate system, marine organic matter, and trace metals); solution chemistry of seawater; isotopic tracers of rates and dates in marine systems; geochemical balance in the oceans.

courses.name: LING 520 Syntactic Theory and Analysis
courses.description: Discussion and critical analysis of current issues in syntactic theory.

courses.name: CPEN 221 Principles of Software Construction
courses.description: Design, implementation, reasoning about software systems: abstraction and specification of software, testing, verification, abstract data types, object-oriented design, type hierarchies, concurrent software design.

courses.name: CHIN 117 Basic Chinese II: Part 2 (Heritage)
courses.description: Continuation of CHIN 115.

courses.name: LIBR 532 Science and Technology Information Sources and Services
AUDI 559 Practicum in Speech-Language Pathology for Audiology Majors
IAR 515C Topics in Asia Pacific Policy Studies - GLBL CHN&WLD ORD
NAME 591 Computer-Aided Ship Design Project
courses.description: A capstone design project designed to give students experience in the preliminary design of a special purpose ship. Students work individually and in teams, using advanced design software and databases, to design a vessel according to specified criteria.
courses.prerequisites: All of MECH 487, MECH 488, NAME 522, NAME 578.

courses.name: PHYS 119 Experimental Physics Lab
courses.description: Introductory laboratory course, with emphasis on data collection, data analysis techniques, and scientific reasoning. Please consult the Faculty of Science credit exclusion list: http://www.calendar.ubc.ca/vancouver/index.cfm?tree=12,215,410,414.
courses.prerequisites: One of PHYS 12, PHYS 100 and one of MATH 100, MATH 102, MATH 104, MATH 110, MATH 120, MATH 180, MATH 184.

courses.name: MUSC 206 Aural Skills IV
courses.description: Continuation of MUSC 205. Restricted to B.Mus. students.

courses.name: EOSC 114 The Catastrophic Earth: Natural Disasters
courses.description: Introduction to causes and physical characteristics of disasters such as volcanic eruptions, earthquakes, tsunamis, hurricanes, storm surge, thunderstorms, tornadoes, landslides, wind waves, meteor impacts, mass extinctions.

courses.name: FREN 222 French Language and Style I
courses.description: Grammar, vocabulary, composition, language in context. To be taken by all students intending to proceed to the Minor, Major or Honours program. Credit will not be granted for both FREN 222 and FREN 342.
courses.prerequisites: FREN 123. (Or assignment based on placement test.)

courses.name: CHEM 123 Thermodynamics, Kinetics and Organic Chemistry
courses.description: Fundamentals of chemical reactivity: thermodynamics; kinetics; organic chemistry, including stereochemistry; applications relevant to modern society.

courses.name: CRWR 356A Intermediate Screenplay Workshop - INTRMD SCRNPLAY
courses.description: An intermediate level workshop class in writing for the screen. Manuscript submission is not required for admission.

courses.name: PHAR 471 Pathophysiology II
courses.description: Pathophysiology of selected disease states.

courses.name: EOSC 323 Structural Geology I
courses.description: Analysis and interpretation of natural deformation.
courses.prerequisites: All of EOSC 221, EOSC 223 and one of EOSC 210, EOSC 222.

courses.name: CLST 402B Seminar in Classical Literature - SEM CLASSCL LIT
courses.description: Selected topics in Greek or Roman literature, with an emphasis on research. Restricted to majors and honours students in CLST, CLAS, CLAH, ARGR, and GRNE.

courses.name: CELL 506 Fluorescence Microscopy
courses.description: Principles and applications in biological research.

courses.name: DENT 567 Orthodontic and Craniofacial Orthopedic Patient Care I
courses.description: Continues in second year.

courses.name: THTR 491B Advanced Rehearsal and Performance - AD REHEARS&PERF
courses.description: Open only to B.F.A. Acting students.
courses.prerequisites: Three of THTR 371, THTR 372, THTR 373, THTR 374, THTR 391.

courses.name: DENT 712 Clinical Periodontics and Implant Surgery II
courses.description: Pass/Fail.

courses.name: ECON 328 Methods of Empirical Research
courses.description: Empirical tools used in applied research, with emphasis on the linear regression model. Registration restricted to students in the Bachelor of International Economics program. Credit will be granted for only one of ECON 326, ECON 328, or STAT 306.

courses.name: NURS 549 Quantitative Research Methods and Analytic Strategies in Nursing and Health Sciences
MTRL 201 Technical Communication
courses.description: Written and oral communication in business correspondence, engineering design methods, report preparation, and oral presentations of technical material. Restricted to students in second year of the Materials Engineering Program.
courses.prerequisites: One of APSC 176, ENGL 110, ENGL 111, ENGL 112, ENGL 120, ENGL 121.

courses.name: ARCH 511 Architectural Technology I
courses.description: Architectural technology, including materials and methods, construction types, and building system integration. Strong emphasis on enclosure performance with focus on smaller buildings and light wood framing construction.

courses.name: LATN 402B Latin Verse - LATIN VERSE
courses.description: Studies in narrative verse, comedy, satire, elegiac and lyric poetry. May be repeated for up to 12 credits.

courses.name: BIOL 326 Experimental Biology of Invertebrates
courses.description: Behaviour and ecology of invertebrates as revealed by hands-on experiments in the laboratory and field.  Marine emphasis.

courses.name: ENDS 221 Sustainability by Design
courses.description: Introduction to interactions between human and natural urban systems using local and international examples of successful sustainable community designs.

courses.name: BUSI 355 Introduction to Income Tax
courses.description: A study of income tax from the standpoint of the individual and business enterprise.

courses.name: BIOL 362 Cellular Physiology
courses.description: The cytoskeleton, cell dynamics, and regulation of cellular activities. Preference will be given to Majors or Honours students in Biology and Honours Biophysics.
courses.prerequisites: Either (a) BIOL 361 or (b) all of BIOL 201, BIOL 351.

courses.name: LARC 523 Landscape Architecture Theory
courses.description: Theoretical positions in landscape architecture and their relation to designed landscapes. Seats are reserved for students who meet one of the following sets of restrictions: 1) M.Arch. students; 2) M.A.S.A. or M.A.S.L.A. students; and 3) M.L.A. students, by instructor's permissions only.

courses.name: AUDI 567C Audiology Practicum III - AUDI PRCTCM III
LING 140 Challenging Language Myths
courses.description: Critical consideration of a broad range of commonly held beliefs about language and its relation to the brain and cognition, learning, society, change and evolution. Note. This is an elective course that does not fulfill writing requirements in any faculty or the literature requirement in the Faculty of Arts.

courses.name: APSC 278 Engineering Materials
courses.description: Atomic bonding; crystal structures and imperfections; properties of metals, ceramics, polymers, wood, concrete and fibre composite materials; selection of materials; corrosion; mechanical testing and heat treatment.

courses.name: FIPR 469H Special Projects - SPECIAL PROJECTS
courses.description: Advanced film production, including interdisciplinary projects.

courses.name: AUDI 547A Directed Reading in Audiology and Speech Sciences - DIR READ AUDI&SP
courses.description: May be taken more than once.

courses.name: CHEM 435 Bio-Inorganic Chemistry
courses.description: A discussion of the involvement of inorganic chemistry in biological systems. Chemistry of cations, metalloenzymes, and simpler model systems. Reactions of coordinated ligands, chemistry of sulphur and phosphorus. Credit will not be given for both CHEM 435 and CHEM 526.

courses.name: FNH 303 Food Product Development
courses.description: Introduction to and application of concepts involved in food product formulation and development.
courses.prerequisites: One of LFS  252, BIOL 300, EPSE 482, FRST 231, STAT 200.

courses.name: PHYS 333 Energy and Climate
courses.description: The fundamental physics behind global issues of energy use and climate change.  Not to be used to satisfy an upper-level specialization requirement in any Physics and Astronomy major or honours specialization, but may be used as an upper-level science elective for Physics and Astronomy students.
courses.prerequisites: Either (a) one of MATH 101, MATH 103, MATH 105, MATH 121 and one of PHYS 102, PHYS 108, PHYS 153;  or (b) SCIE 001.

courses.name: CHEM 406 Polymer Chemistry
courses.description: Structure and availability of monomers; Propagation mechanisms; synthesis of polymers with predetermined properties; measurement and interpretation of physical properties of polymers.
courses.prerequisites: One of CHEM 204, CHEM 213, CHEM 260 and one of CHEM 304, CHEM 251.

courses.name: HIST 409 U.S. Foreign Relations since 1945
courses.description: U.S. foreign policy and international history.  Political, economic, and cultural relationships between the United States and other peoples, organizations, and states worldwide.

courses.name: NURS 425 Clinical Nursing Focus: Community and Population Health
courses.description: Credit is given for one of NURS 420, 422, 423, 424, or 425.
courses.prerequisites: All of NURS 302, NURS 303, NURS 304, NURS 305, NURS 306, NURS 333, NURS 334, NURS 335, NURS 336, NURS 337, NURS 338, NURS 339, NURS 340, NURS 341, NURS 342, NURS 343.

courses.name: FRST 557 Site-Level Forest Land Management
courses.description: Design and implementation of site-level plans that integrate ecological, social, and economic components: silviculture, forest operations, and forest health.

courses.name: CHEM 233 Organic Chemistry for the Biological Sciences
courses.description: Reactions and properties of carbonyl compounds, carbohydrates, amino acids, nucleic acids.

courses.name: COMM 203 Managing the Employment Relationship
courses.description: The role of employment relations in enterprise performance. Managing employees under statutory law, collective bargaining, and progressive human resource management. Key issues in forming, developing, and maintaining a work force. Credit will be granted for only one of COMM 203 or COMM 392.
courses.prerequisites: COMM 292 and either (a) all of ECON 101, ECON 102 or (b) ECON 100.

courses.name: GERM 360 Heaven and Earth: Studies in German Culture and Literature before 1700.
courses.description: Masterpieces and major trends of the German literature of the Middle Ages, Renaissance and Baroque against the larger background of the political and social developments of the period.

courses.name: ENDS 402 Environmental Design Studio IV
courses.description: Expands the scale and design enquiry to emphasize the relationships between communities and environment, urban infrastructure, and ecological systems.

courses.name: MEDG 520 Advanced Human Molecular Genetics
courses.description: Genetic variation, genome analysis, cloning of genes for diseases and normal functions, mutation detection, animal models of human genetic disease.

courses.name: ARCL 140 Bones: The Origins of Humanity
courses.description: The origin and evolution of the human lineage and the emergence of human biological and cultural traits with emphasis on the fossil record before the Pleistocene. Credit will be granted for only one of ARCL 140 or ANTH 225.

courses.name: ECON 301 Intermediate Microeconomic Analysis I
courses.description: Consumer behaviour, producer theory, exchange, monopoly, oligopoly, externalities, public goods, general equilibrium and welfare economics. Credit will be granted for only one of ECON 201, ECON 301, or ECON 304.

courses.name: LLED 399 Practicum in Teaching English as a Second Language
HIST 280 Islamic World History
courses.description: The history of the Islamic world in its global dimensions from its origins to the present day through the themes of religion, law, politics, culture, and modernity.

courses.name: EDCP 362D Curriculum Design and Evaluation: Practical and Theoretical Issues - CURR DES & EVAL
CHEM 445A Projects in Experimental Chemistry - PROJCTS EXP CHEM
courses.description: Principles of experimental design, practice and problem solving in chemistry, including the opportunity to pursue projects in a research setting.
courses.prerequisites: CHEM 345. (or CHEM 335 and fourth-year standing in a Chemistry Combined Major specialization.)

courses.name: EDCP 333 Contemporary Issues in Social Studies: Secondary
courses.description: Pass/Fail.

courses.name: ASTU 400V Interdisciplinary Studies in Arts - HK NW WV CNMA
courses.description: For upper-division students in the Faculty of Arts. Topics announced annually.

courses.name: EPSE 312 Introduction to the Study of Exceptional Children
courses.description: An examination of all groups of exceptional children in terms of definition, incidence, characteristics, diagnosis and treatment. Prerequisite to most other courses in Special Education. Can be taken concurrently with several other introductory courses in Special Education.

courses.name: LLED 580E Problems in Education - PROB IN EDUC
courses.description: Investigation and report of a problem.

courses.name: FNIS 210 Indigenous Politics and Self-Determination
courses.description: The cultural, historical, political, economic, and gender dynamics that structure the relationship between Indigenous peoples and the state in Canada; Indigenous self-determination struggles in relation to constitutional recognition, self-government, land claims, and economic development. Credit will be granted for only one of FNSP 200, FNIS 210, or FNSP 210.

courses.name: CHEM 526 Bioinorganic Chemistry
courses.description: Inorganic aspects of biological chemistry; emphasis on the role of metal ions and metalloenzymes. Credit will not be given for both CHEM 526 and CHEM 435.

courses.name: COMM 394 Government and Business
courses.description: Roles of government and business in the Canadian economy including effects of public policy on the business environment. Ethical foundations of government, business and personal decision-making.

courses.name: CHIN 317 Advanced Chinese Speaking and Writing II (Heritage)
courses.description: Continuation of CHIN 315. Can be taken concurrently with CHIN 313 and CHIN 323.

courses.name: MECH 545 Fuel Cell Systems
courses.description: Energy system architecture and electrochemical energy conversion; fuel cell thermodynamics and electrochemistry; Proton Exchange Membrane Fuel Cells (PMFCs) and Solid Oxide Fuel Cells (SOFCSs); hydrogen production, storage, and distribution. Credit cannot be received for both MECH 445 and MECH 545.

courses.name: MTRL 363 Transport Phenomena III - Mass Transport
courses.description: Diffusion and mass transfer with chemical reaction; gas-liquid, gas-solid and liquid-liquid systems; analysis of mass transfer processes in metallurgical operations; mixing in continuous and batch processes.

courses.name: FRST 444 Agroforestry
courses.description: Integration of farms and forests, including tropical agroforestry systems, non-timber forest products, forest farming, woodlot management, silvopastoralism, riparian buffers, windbreaks, soil fertility improvement and nutrient cycling.

courses.name: EECE 560 Network Analysis and Simulation
courses.description: Solution of lumped and distributed networks. Time-domain solutions, discretization and integration rules. Frequency-domain solutions, FFT and windowing techniques. Systems of linear equations, reduction and sparsity techniques. Nonlinear elements. Computer-aided simulation.

courses.name: PHYS 401 Electromagnetic Theory
courses.description: Applications of Maxwell's theory. Wave propagation in dielectrics, conductors and plasmas, wave guides, radiation, antennae, and special relativity.

courses.name: GRSJ 224C Gender, Race, Sexuality, and Social Justice in Literature - GRSJ IN LIT
courses.description: Techniques of literary study, with emphasis on intersectionality and the ways in which gender is represented in literature and contributions of feminism and gender studies to literary studies.

courses.name: ATSC 398 Co-operative Work Placement I
courses.description: Approved and supervised technical work experience in an industrial, university or government setting for a minimum of 14 weeks. Normally taken in the Winter Session (Term 2) in third year. Technical report required. Restricted to students admitted to Co-operative Education Program in Atmospheric Science.

courses.name: HIST 391 Human Rights in World History
courses.description: Changing ideas about humanity and rights. Considers the relationship between human rights and the nation-state, imperialism, and capitalism. Assesses the efforts to end large-scale human rights violations and the role of the United Nations.

courses.name: LIBE 580A Problems in Education - PROB IN EDUC 1
courses.description: Investigation and report of a problem.

courses.name: CIVL 529 Condition Assessment and Rehabilitation of Civil Infrastructure
courses.description: Non-destructive testing, repair, rehabilitation, strengthening, high performance plain and fiber reinforced concrete, shotcrete, fibre reinforced polymer laminates, analysis, case studies.

courses.name: GRSJ 504A Decolonizing Praxis for Social Justice and Equality Studies: A Practicum - DECOL PRX PRACTM
MTRL 585 Topics in Fracture Mechanics
courses.description: The equations and concepts of linear elastic fracture mechanics. Fracture toughness testing, statistical theories of fracture and proof testing, stress corrosion cracking and static fatigue. Acoustic emission and other nondestructive testing methods. Case studies of large scale fractures of pressure vessels and structures.

courses.name: PHIL 460A Philosophy of Science - PHIL OF SCIENCE
courses.description: Issues common to all sciences. Philosophical questions including the character of scientific laws, theories and revolutions, the nature of scientific confirmation, causality, explanation and prediction, and the use of logic and probability. Difficulties in the interpretation of atomic physics and questions about relationships between biology and psychology. No philosophical background is assumed.

courses.name: FHIS 333 Short Fiction in Romance Literatures
courses.description: A study of the genres of the "novella" and the short story within and across Romance cultures.

courses.name: ITAL 405 Topics in the Italian Literature and Culture of the Renaissance
courses.description: Masterpieces of the Italian Renaissance in literature and the other Arts. Authors and artists studied range from Pico to Ariosto and Machiavelli, from Botticelli to Leonardo and Michelangelo. Credit will be granted for only one of ITAL 405 or ITAL 415.

courses.name: SOCI 240A Introduction to Social Interaction - SOCL INTERACTION
courses.description: A general introduction to research on social interaction, with an emphasis on group (as opposed to individual) processes and behaviour. Topics include: status, power and prestige, distributive justice, marginality and social control, authority relations, and group structure and membership, all to be studied in the context of a variety of groups (such as families, formal organizations, communities and friendship groups) and cultures.

courses.name: EDCP 391A Home Economics I - Secondary: Curriculum and Pedagogy - HMEC I SEC C&P
courses.description: Pass/Fail.

courses.name: EOSC 352 Geophysical Continuum Dynamics
courses.description: Introduction to tensor calculus and continuum mechanics. Stress, strain and strain-rate tensors. Mass, momentum and energy balance. Applications to problems of geophysical heat transport, elasticity and fluid dynamics illustrated using MATLAB.

courses.name: KIN 530A Directed Studies - DIRECTED STUDIES
courses.description: Topics selected by the student, with the approval of the Graduate Advisor, can be studied under the supervision of a member of the faculty.

courses.name: GEOB 448A Directed Studies in Geographical Biogeoscience - DS GEOGCL BIOSCI
courses.description: For fourth-year students in Geography to permit investigation of a topic to be agreed upon by a member of the faculty and the student. Permission of the department head and of a supervisory faculty member is required. Credit will be given for only one of GEOB 448 and GEOG 448.

courses.name: AUDI 685A Seminar in Language Development - SEM LANG DEVELOP
POLI 501A Core Seminar in Canadian Government and Politics - CORE CN GOV&POL
RMST 420F Studies in Romance Languages and Literature - RMNCE LANG & LIT
MINE 292 Introduction to Mineral Processing
courses.description: Overview; extracting a mineral or final product from an ore.

courses.name: LFS 340 First Nations Health and the Traditional Role of Plants
courses.description: This Interprofessional Health and Human Service (IHHS) course covers the First Nations medical systems and medicinal plants. Bridging the traditional with modern sciences. Credit will be granted for only one of LFS 340 or IHHS 301.

courses.name: FNEL 101 Introduction to a Salish Language I
courses.description: Emphasis on accurate pronunciation, conversation, basic grammatical structures and listening and literacy skills, and the study of oral traditions in their cultural context. No prior knowledge of the language is assumed.

courses.name: MUSC 695B Music Performance (Major) - VOICE
courses.description: Private instruction, vocal or instrumental.

courses.name: IGEN 201 Integrated Technical Communication
courses.description: Written and oral communication in business correspondence, engineering design methods, report preparation, and oral presentations of technical material.  Restricted to students in second year of the Integrated Engineering Program.
courses.prerequisites: One of APSC 176, ENGL 110, ENGL 111, ENGL 112, ENGL 120, ENGL 121.

courses.name: SOCI 423 Sociology of Food
courses.description: Cultural, economic, and political aspects of food production and consumption, including connections to class, ethnicity, and gender.  Food-related social movements will be included.

courses.name: MATH 499 Co-operative Work Placement IV
courses.description: Approved and supervised technical work experience involving mathematics in industry for a minimum of 3 1/2 months. Technical report required. Restricted to students admitted to the Mathematics Co-operative Education Program.

courses.name: CPSC 430 Computers and Society
courses.description: Impact of computer technology on society; historical perspectives; social and economic consequences of large-scale information processing systems and automatic control; legal and ethical problems in computer applications. Computers and the individual: machine versus human capabilities, fact and fancy; problematic interface between man and machine.
courses.prerequisites: (3 credits of Computer Science and at least third-year standing.)

courses.name: LAW 474 Trial Advocacy
courses.description: Techniques of advocacy in civil and criminal cases including interviewing, pre-trial preparation, tactical analysis, development of facts, direct and cross examination and various ethical considerations. A student who receives credit for LAW 488 or LAW 491 cannot receive credit for this course.

courses.name: VISA 580 Major Essay
courses.description: M.F.A. only.

courses.name: CIVL 411 Foundation Engineering II
courses.description: Aspects of Geotechnical Engineering. Design considerations illustrated by case histories pertinent to BC. Topics include: site investigation, terrain analyses, in situ testing, groundwater problems, deep foundations, tie back walls and bracing, tailings impoundments, Northern construction, ground ice, dikes and dams engineering. Many case histories presented in part by prominent consulting engineers in BC.

courses.name: DHYG 210 Dental Hygiene Theory and Practice II
courses.description: The study of dental hygiene theory and practice in clinical and community-based settings.

courses.name: ENVR 420 Ecohydrology of Watersheds and Water Systems
courses.description: Analysis of water resources from a water-in-ecosystem perspective. Application to natural, managed, and urban systems, considering ecological interactions with hydrological processes. Exploration of biogeochemical processes related to water quality, and human impacts on water resources.

courses.name: CHIN 463 Early Classical Chinese Poetry (Han to Tang)
courses.description: Readings in classical poetry from the Six Dynasties to early Tang, at an advanced level. Not to be taken concurrently with any CHIN courses lower than 400-level.
courses.prerequisites: One of CHIN 313, CHIN 314, CHIN 317, CHIN 318, CHIN 323.

courses.name: DENT 513 The Pediatric Patient I
courses.description: Continues in year 2.

courses.name: CHEM 154 Chemistry for Engineering
courses.description: Chemical bonding, properties of matter. Chemical thermodynamics with applications to phase equilibria, aqueous equilibria and electrochemistry. Processes at surfaces.

courses.name: ELEC 473 Biological Micro-Electro-Mechanical Systems
courses.description: Principles of sensors, actuators, microfluidics, biotechnology and nanotechnology, with applications in probing, detection, assaying and drug delivery.

courses.name: EOSC 450 Potential Fields in Earth and Planetary Sciences
courses.description: Theory, application and quantitative interpretation of potential field methods in Earth and planetary sciences. Topics drawn from problems in geophysical exploration, geodesy, geodynamics of the planets, geomagnetism, planetary magnetic fields, heat flow and fluid flow.
courses.prerequisites: One of PHYS 312, MATH 316, MATH 257 and one of PHYS 102, PHYS 108, PHYS 118, PHYS 158, SCIE 001.

courses.name: CNRS 370 Theories of Myth
courses.description: Origins, nature, and transmission of myth in the Western tradition, with particular attention devoted to the interpretation of myth from ancient times up to the present. Some background in myth is recommended.

courses.name: LLED 479 The Education of Immigrant Students
courses.description: An examination of the cultural backgrounds of major ethnic groups. Instructional techniques for meeting the needs of immigrant students in the regular classroom with respect to culture and language.

courses.name: CPEN 311 Digital Systems Design
courses.description: Advanced combinational and sequential electronic system design. Hardware specification, modeling, and simulation using hardware description languages (HDLs) and CAD tools. Design with programmable logic including FPGA's. Applications include complex state machines, microcontrollers, arithmetic circuits, and interface units. Credit will be granted for only one of EECE 353, CPEN 311 and EECE 379.
courses.prerequisites: One of EECE 259, CPEN 211, EECE 355, CPEN 312.

courses.name: FNH 351 Vitamins, Minerals, and Health
courses.description: Vitamin and mineral nutrition and their role in maintaining and promoting health.
courses.prerequisites: FNH  250 and one of BIOL 201, BIOC 202.

courses.name: POLI 101 The Government of Canada
courses.description: An examination of the institutions and processes of Canadian government.

courses.name: ANTH 414 Anthropology of Globalization
courses.description: Theories on the global flow of people, commodities, images, and ideas with critical ethnographic attention to the different ways people respond to globalization.

courses.name: MINE 592A Mining Industry Internship - MINE INTERNSHIP
courses.description: Mining or mineral processing engineering internship in which concepts, theory and practice of mining and mineral processing engineering are applied by working with industry on appropriate technical projects. Pass/fail.

courses.name: VISA 380 Studio Theory I
courses.description: A seminar in problems in contemporary art practice and related theory. Preference given to Visual Art students.

courses.name: ECON 628 Topics in Applied Econometrics I
courses.prerequisites: (Prior graduate-level work in econometrics is required.)

courses.name: STAT 538A Generalized Linear Models - GEN LINEAR MODLS
BIOL 210 Vascular Plants
courses.description: A comparative study of pteridophytes, gymnosperms and angiosperms, integrating form, function and ecology.
courses.prerequisites: Either (a) all of BIOL 121, BIOL 140 or (b) all of SCIE 001, BIOL 140. (Or (c) 8 transfer credits of first-year biology.)

courses.name: ANTH 378 Anthropology of Media
courses.description: Analysis of contemporary mass media and of the anthropological use of media (photography, film, digital audio and video, etc.).

courses.name: INDE 441 Senior Clerkship
courses.description: A senior clinical elective for fourth year students. Students will participate in all relevant clinical and academic activities associated with the particular rotation.

courses.name: COHR 303 Strategic Staffing
courses.description: Processes of workforce recruitment, selection, retention, and renewal. Includes human resources planning, development of an effective staffing strategy and employer brand, job analysis and descriptions, cost-benefit analysis of various recruiting methods, analysis and evaluation of selection methods.
courses.prerequisites: COMM 292 and one of COMM 203, COMM 392.

courses.name: LLED 573A Theories of Second Language Acquisition - SEC LANG ACQ
courses.prerequisites: (Admission into the TESL Graduate Program or permission of instructor.)

courses.name: ENGL 491C Senior Honours Seminar - SR HONORS SEMNR1
courses.description: Offerings in literary theory.

courses.name: BA 530F Study Abroad and Exchange - STUDY ABR'D&EXCH
courses.description: Restricted to students in one of the following programs: M.B.A., LL.B./M.B.A., M.Sc.B., Ph.D. with B.A.D.M. specialization, or M.M. with either ECMS or ECMJ. M.M. ECMS or ECMJ students are limited to a maximum of 12 credits in this course.

courses.name: ENGL 500 Research in English Studies
courses.description: Required of all graduate students in the M.A. program. Pass/Fail.

courses.name: EDCP 504A Review of Research in Art Education: Theory and Practice - REV RES ART EDUC
MINE 491 Mine and Plant Feasibility Study
courses.description: Design of a mining operation or a mineral processing plant as part of a realistic feasibility study project.
courses.prerequisites: MINE 396. (Fourth-year standing in Mining Engineering is required.)

courses.name: PORT 210 Intermediate Portuguese for Romance Language Speakers
courses.description: A single-term alternative to PORT 201 and 202 for students with heritage Portuguese or another Romance language. Credit will be granted for only one of PORT 210, PORT 201, or PORT 202.
courses.prerequisites: PORT 110. (Heritage speakers who feel ready to enter PORT 210 directly should consult the undergraduate adviser in Portuguese.)

courses.name: EECE 571Z Electrical Engineering Seminar and Special Problems - CMOS DSGN SILCN
THTR 323 History and Theory of Directing
LAW 556C Topics in Common Law Theory and Practice: Private and Commercial Law - PRIVATE LAW
COMM 447 Applied Project Management
courses.description: Evaluation of transport projects in the private and public sector; cost benefit analysis and related framework; project management, financing transport infrastructure.

courses.name: RHSC 506A Current Topics in Rehabilitation - CUR TPCS REHAB
EDUC 430 Community-based Field Experience
courses.description: Pass/Fail.

courses.name: SPAN 206 Conversational Spanish I
courses.description: Conversation (group discussion and debates), readings, and grammar review.

courses.name: DENT 568 Orthodontic and Craniofacial Orthopedic Patient Care II
courses.description: Continues in third year.

courses.name: DHYG 325 Applied Pharmacology
courses.description: Applied pharmacology concepts and principles for the dental health professional.

courses.name: LARC 580B Directed Studies in Design Analysis, Programming and Theory - DST DSGN AN,PR&T
KORN 410A Modern Korean Short Fiction - MOD KORN SHRT FC
courses.description: Reading and translating twentieth-century Korean short fiction.

courses.name: HIST 220A History of Europe - HIST OF EURO
courses.description: Selected themes and historical approaches in European history; may include Europe's history of religious conflict, state formation, colonialism, nationalism, industrialization, revolution, total war, globalization, genocide, or environmental change.

courses.name: POLI 369D Issues in International Security - ISS IN INTL SECU
courses.description: An examination of issues such as interstate conflicts, terrorism, environmental change, international crime. Topics will vary from year to year.

courses.name: ITAL 403 Dante Alighieri's Divine Comedy
courses.description: A close reading of Dante's masterpiece, along with excerpts from some of his other works: Vita Nuova, Convivio, Monarchia, Epistles. Precludes credit for ITST 413.

courses.name: MUSC 693C Music Performance (Major) - STRING INST'S
courses.description: Private instruction, vocal or instrumental.

courses.name: CIVL 404 Introduction to Solid Waste Management
courses.description: Characteristics of solid wastes; solid waste collection, treatment, and disposal; evaluation and analysis of landfills, composting, combined treatment, recycle, and re-use.

courses.name: MUSC 403H Selected Topics in Music - MDRN JAZZ PIANO
courses.description: See School of Music schedule for description and prerequisites. Restricted to B. Mus. and B.A. in Music students.

courses.name: APSC 178 Electricity, Magnetism, and Waves
courses.description: Coulomb's law, electric field, Gauss' law, electric potential, conductors, capacitance, electric currents, resistance, DC circuits, magnetic fields and forces, sources of magnetic fields, electromagnetic induction, mechanical waves, electromagnetic waves, light propagation, geometrical optics.

courses.name: COMM 335 Information Systems Technology and Development
courses.description: Introduction to information technology related to business use. Design, implementation and application of Information Systems.

courses.name: LLED 565D Special Course in Subject Matter Field - SPC C SUBJ MTFLD
courses.description: Courses in various subject matter fields designed to bring teachers up to date in recent findings in each field.

courses.name: BAIT 510 Project Management in Delivering Business Solutions
HIST 394 Darwin, Evolution, and Modern History
courses.description: Darwin and the science of evolution in nineteenth and early twentieth century.

courses.name: CLST 355 The Athenians and their Empire
courses.description: The sources (literary, epigraphical and other) for Athens' emergence as one of the two leading city-states in late archaic and classical Greece and the stages by which her empire grew.

courses.name: GEOG 547B Directed Reading in Human Geography - HUMAN GEO DR RDG
ASIA 387 Japanese Religions
courses.description: An introduction to traditional Japanese religions including Shinto, Buddhism, Shugendo, Confucianism, new religions and folklore, and their roles in Japanese history, culture and society.

courses.name: COMM 486M Special Topics in Business - STRAT DECSN MKNG
LAW 449 Media and Entertainment Law
courses.description: Selected legal issues relating to the media and entertainment industries and their regulation. Not offered each year, consult Faculty.

courses.name: MUSC 311 Fundamentals of Conducting
courses.description: Basic conducting techniques: patterns, cueing, dynamic shading, and physical presentation.
courses.prerequisites: One of MUSC 111, MUSC 200. (and completion of the second-year piano requirement.)

courses.name: EDCP 407 Art Education Curriculum and Pedagogy: Theory and Practice
courses.description: Pass/Fail.

courses.name: COMM 493 Strategic Management in Business
courses.description: A conceptual and practical introduction to the major areas of business strategy with an integrative perspective on managing a business. Includes the analysis of a business and its environment, the development and evaluation of strategic alternatives, and implementation of change (For non-Commerce students only in fourth year).
courses.prerequisites: One of COMM 293, COMM 457 and either (a) all of ECON 101, ECON 102 or (b) all of ECON 310, ECON 311 or (c) ECON 100 or (d) all of ECON 101, ECON 311 or (e) all of ECON 102, ECON 310.

courses.name: PSYC 498 Cooperative Work Placement III
courses.description: Approved and supervised relevant work experience in an industrial, academic, or government setting for a minimum of 13 weeks, full-time. Normally taken in fourth year Winter Session, Term 2. Work term report required. Restricted to students admitted to the Co-op Program in Psychology (B.Sc.).

courses.name: THTR 499C Production III - PRODUCTION III
courses.description: Assigned projects in Theatre or Film design and production.
courses.corequisites: One of THTR 405, THTR 406, THTR 407, THTR 408, THTR 450, THTR 452, THTR 454, THTR 456, THTR 470.

courses.name: ECON 367 Economic Analysis of Law
courses.description: The economics of market failure, equity and efficiency. Property rights, the economics of accident and contract law, economic theories of law enforcement.

courses.name: MATH 400 Applied Partial Differential Equations
courses.description: Separation of variables, first order equations, Sturm-Liouville theory, integral transform methods.
courses.prerequisites: One of MATH 300, MATH 305 and one of MATH 256, MATH 257, MATH 316.

courses.name: MATH 608D Topics in Probability - TPCS PROBABILITY
MICB 325 Analysis of Microbial Genes and Genomes
courses.description: Genetic, molecular biological and bioinformatic approaches for the analysis of microbial genomes, gene structure-function and gene expression with emphasis on bacteria.
courses.prerequisites: One of MICB 201, BIOL 234. (and third-year standing or higher.)

courses.name: MTRL 456 Environmental Degradation of Materials
courses.description: Fundamental aspects of environmental degradation of metals (corrosion), ceramics, adn polymers, with an empasis on aqueous environments.

courses.name: SURG 548C Seminar in Surgery - SEM IN SURGERY
BIOC 301 Biochemistry Laboratory
courses.description: Techniques by which the chemical and physical properties of fundamental components of the cell are studied.

courses.name: MUSC 571A Music Performance (Secondary) - KEYBOARD INST'S
courses.description: Private instruction, vocal or instrumental.

courses.name: BIOL 464 Animal Developmental Genetics
courses.description: Role of genes in embryonic development.  Emphasis on tissue specific expression patterns and the role of genetic networks in establishing cell types.

courses.name: PSYC 340B Directed Studies in Psychology - DIRECTED STUDIES
courses.description: Directed investigation of a problem, requiring a written report of the findings.
courses.prerequisites: (At least 72% average in the preceding 30 credits and permission of a faculty member who is prepared to supervise the investigation.)

courses.name: EOSC 562 Mechanics of Earthquakes and Faulting
LIBR 523 Canadian Literature and other Materials for Children
MATH 420 Real Analysis I
courses.description: Sigma-algebras, Lebesgue measure, Borel measures, measurable functions, integration, convergence theorems, Lp spaces, Holder and Minkowski inequalities, Lebesgue and/or Radon-Nikodym differentiation.
courses.prerequisites: A score of 68% or higher in MATH 321.

courses.name: HIST 403H Seminar in the History of International Relations - INTRNATNL RELTNS
courses.description: Selected topics in the history of international relations. Priority for registration will be given to fourth-year majors in the International Relations and History programs.

courses.name: BAFI 530 International Financial Environment
courses.description: Credit will not be granted for both BAFI 530 and BAIM 510.

courses.name: PHYS 219 Intermediate Experimental Physics I
courses.description: Analog electronics and amplifiers, digital electronics, analog-to-digital converters and an introduction to use of computers in data analysis and simulations.
courses.prerequisites: Either (a) all of PHYS 108, PHYS 109 or (b) PHYS 102 or (c) all of PHYS 158, PHYS 159 or (d) SCIE 001 or (e) all of PHYS 118, PHYS 119.
courses.corequisites: One of MATH 200, MATH 217, MATH 226, MATH 253, MATH 263.

courses.name: CNPS 364 Family Education and Consultation
courses.description: Examination of current theories and practices in family education and consultation.

courses.name: LING 319 Comparative and Historical Linguistics
courses.description: The historical study of language.  Linguistic change.  Language families and evidence for genetic relationship.  Comparative method and internal reconstruction.  Emphasis on phonological and morphological reconstruction. Not offered every year.

courses.name: CLCH 401 Advanced Readings in Classical Chinese
courses.description: Focus on reading longer texts in Classical Chinese, producing careful and polished translation, using appropriate reference works and appreciating nuances of style and genre. Transition from textbook-based study to independent reading and scholarly translation necessary for advanced study and research.

courses.name: CIVL 507 Dynamics of Structures I
courses.description: Fundamental analysis of simple structures subjected to dynamic loadings; vibration problems in structures; linear and nonlinear structural response of simple systems; numerical methods for practical vibration analysis.

courses.name: ARCH 545B Directed Studies in Architecture - DRECTD STDY ARCH
courses.description: Directed research and exploration of selected topics in architecture.

courses.name: CPEN 492 Software Engineering Capstone Design Project
courses.description: Design, analysis, and implementation of solutions in response to a real world software engineering problem.  Projects are provided by industry, research laboratories, or other suitable entities.  Includes coverage of topics such as project management.

courses.name: KIN 462 Skeletal Muscle Physiology: From Generation to Regeneration
courses.description: Cellular and molecular mechanisms of muscle adaptability to physical activity: muscle development, signaling cascades of hypertrophy and atrophy, and satellite cell contribution to muscle regeneration/repair; etiology of intramuscular fatigue.
courses.prerequisites: One of KIN  375, HKIN 375. (and third-year standing.)

courses.name: POLI 367B International Relations Theory and the International System - INT REL TH&IN SY
courses.description: The evolution of the international system and empirical and normative theories of international relations such as realism, liberalism, and Marxism.

courses.name: GEOB 508A Advanced Seminar in Geomorphology - ADV SEM GEOMRPHY
PSYC 311 Psychology of Sport
courses.description: Psychological theory, research, and skills training related to sport performance, exercise motivation, and adherence. Credit will not be given for both PSYC 311 and HKIN 231 and 364.
courses.prerequisites: Either (a) PSYC 100 or (b) all of PSYC 101, PSYC 102.

courses.name: LING 531 Field Methods in Linguistics I
CELL 504 Current Topics in Cytoskeleton and Cell Motility
courses.description: Structure and function of the cytoskeleton, and its involvement in various forms of cell and intracellular motility.

courses.name: BIOL 498 Co-operative Work Placement III
courses.description: Work experience in an industrial research setting, taken during the Summer Session (Terms 1 and 2) following fourth year. Restricted to students admitted to the Co-operative Education Program in Biology.

courses.name: ANTH 301 Ethnography of Eurasia
courses.description: Eurasia, including the Russian Federation, Central Asia, and Mongolia, with an emphasis on issues of power, identities, and transnational mobility in the region.

courses.name: MUSC 563 Contemporary Players
courses.description: Open only to graduate students.

courses.name: LIBR 569R Current Issues and Trends in Library Services and Information Science - CUR ISS&TRND LIB
EDST 565A Special Course in Subject Matter Field - SP CRS SUB FLD 1
STAT 306 Finding Relationships in Data
courses.description: Modeling a response (output) variable as a function of several explanatory (input) variables:  multiple regression for a continuous response, logistic regression for a binary response, and log-linear models for count data.  Finding low-dimensional structure:  principal components analysis.  Cluster analysis.  (Consult the Credit Exclusion List within the Faculty of Science section in the Calendar).
courses.prerequisites: One of MATH 152, MATH 221, MATH 223 and one of STAT 200, STAT 241, STAT 251, BIOL 300 and one of MATH 302, STAT 302.

courses.name: ECON 371 Economics of the Environment
courses.description: Economic analysis applied to various environmental issues, including sustainable development, quality of life, and environmental impacts of specific industrial and consumption activities. The design and implementation of government policies. Global environmental effects of human economic activity.

courses.name: APSC 496E Interdisciplinary Engineering Design Project - INTER ENG PRJECT
courses.description: Projects involving students from several departments.

courses.name: MICB 421 Experimental Microbiology
courses.description: Research in microbial physiology and molecular genetics.  Guided and independent laboratory projects are developed.

courses.name: CONS 498 Thesis or Special Project
courses.description: An independent study or research project of a subject of special interest to the student under the supervision of a staff member.

courses.name: CNPS 669A Research Approaches in Counselling Psychology - RES APPR TO CNPS
ASIC 220 Introduction to Sustainability
courses.description: Sustainability examined from scientific, economic, and societal perspectives.

courses.name: FRE 516 Financial and Marketing Management in Agri-food Industries
ASTU 400Z Interdisciplinary Studies in Arts - LOVECRFT COS PES
courses.description: For upper-division students in the Faculty of Arts. Topics announced annually.

courses.name: ARTH 101 Ways of Seeing: Introduction to Visual Studies
courses.description: Drawing on examples from across history and around the world, this course deals with the role of the visual in society, culture, and everyday experience.

courses.name: LARC 540 Site Analysis and Planning
courses.description: Site analysis and planning of relatively complex sites, emphasizing stormwater management design.

courses.name: WOOD 491 Environmental Facilities Design
courses.description: Introduction to pneumatic and hydraulic power, design and selection of waste recycling systems, boilers, energy generation and environmental legislation.

courses.name: POLI 341A Contemporary Political Theory - CONTMP POLI THRY
courses.description: Topics may include freedom, colonialism, capitalism, Critical Theory and ideology, power and knowledge, social justice, rationalism, gender and identity politics, and the "political."

courses.name: BIOL 417 Phylogenetic Biology
courses.description: Biodiversity from an evolutionary perspective. The evolutionary (phylogenetic) tree of genetic descent that links all organisms: its reconstruction, interpretation, and implications for fields from ecology to molecular biology.
courses.prerequisites: BIOL 200 and one of BIOL 233, BIOL 234, BIOL 334. (BIOL 336 is recommended)

courses.name: SOIL 520 Agricultural Watershed Management
courses.description: Intensive and extensive agriculture with a focus on water needs, water use, and impacts on water resources.  Non-point sources of pollution, nutrient modeling, soil and land degradation, protection, and rehabilitation of watersheds including buffer zones, wetlands, and best management practices.  Credit will be granted for only one of SOIL 520 or RMES 517.

courses.name: MUSC 326A Music Appreciation - MUSIC APPRECIATN
courses.description: An introductory course for which previous musical background is helpful, but not required. Contents include a discussion of musical concepts, evolution of forms, style, and media and detailed study of selected works from the concert repertoire. Popular forms of music (jazz, folk, rock, etc) not included. Not for credit towards the B.Mus. or B.A. in Music.

courses.name: BIOL 548G Advanced Topics in Biology - ADV TOPICS BIOL
GERM 310 Intermediate German IV
courses.description: Fostering of the ability to discuss controversial issues, express ideas clearly in writing and write essays on selected topics in German. Ongoing grammar review and expansion.

courses.name: MTRL 478 Electronic Materials
courses.description: Materials and physics aspects of semiconductor, optical and magnetic devices: energy bandstructure, crystal structure, crystal defects and impurity effects, relationship of material characteristics and physical properties; production of electronic materials and devices: single crystal growth, epitaxy, metallization, ion implantation, lithography and etching; characterization techniques: X-ray diffraction, photoluminescence.

courses.name: COMM 405 Real Estate Finance
courses.description: The role of mortgage markets, mathematical analysis of return and valuation issue and methods of dealing with lender and borrower risk exposure.

courses.name: MATH 264 Vector Calculus for Electrical Engineering
