courses.description: Divergence, gradient, curl, theorems of Gauss and Stokes. Applications to Electrostatics and Magnetostatics. MATH 264 content is strongly coupled to EECE 261 with topics and student evaluations weighted accordingly.
courses.prerequisites: One of MATH 200, MATH 217, MATH 226, MATH 253, MATH 263.

courses.name: THTR 340B Studies in Non-Western Theatre - ST NON-WEST THTR
courses.description: Open to all students in third year and above.

courses.name: SPPH 526 Leadership in Public Health
courses.description: Leadership skills; use of information technologies in leadership; evidence-informed decision-making; policy development; and knowledge exchange and translation.

courses.name: CIVL 406 Water Treatment and Waste Management
courses.description: Processes used in water and wastewater treatment. Conditions which necessitate treatment of water or wastewater, water and wastewater treatment processes and plant design. Municipal services required and associated with solid waste management.

courses.name: EDCP 555 Critical Analysis of Curriculum in Science Education
courses.description: Current ideas about science curriculum, the nature of science, and its implications for scientific literacy.

courses.name: CHEM 312 Introduction to Quantum Mechanics and Spectroscopy
courses.description: Principles of quantum mechanics; atomic wavefunctions; angular momentum; spin; atomic term symbols.
courses.prerequisites: One of CHEM 113, CHEM 123, SCIE 001 and one of MATH 200, MATH 217, MATH 226, MATH 253, MATH 263.

courses.name: ECON 455 International Trade
courses.description: International trade theory and policy in general equilibrium; relative costs, factor proportions, imperfect competition and the pattern of trade; efficiency and distribution. Credit granted for only one of ECON355 and ECON455.

courses.name: CNPS 514 Counselling Adolescents
courses.description: Theory, research, and practice of counselling adolescents.

courses.name: CHIN 305 Advanced Chinese Speaking and Writing I (Non-Heritage)
courses.description: More formal styles of oral and written communication. Can be taken concurrently with CHIN 301.

courses.name: FNH 425 Food Science Laboratory III
courses.description: Integrated course designed to illustrate principles of research and product development in the food industry.

courses.name: EDUC 490H Special Studies in Education - SPEC STUDIES ED
courses.description: Topics not covered in a course. A pilot course may be offered under this name for only one year and with permission of the Associate Dean (Teacher Education).

courses.name: EOSC 473 Methods in Oceanography
courses.description: Methods of data acquisition, study and analysis required in solving oceanographic problems. Includes a field school held during the mid-term break. A fee is to be paid by January 31. Open to third- and fourth-year students in Oceanography, or with permission of the Department Head.

courses.name: EECE 599 Thesis
courses.description: For M.A.Sc.

courses.name: LAW 483A Competitive Moots and Advocacy Credit A - COMP MOOTSA
courses.description: Appellate and related forms of advocacy. Restricted to students representing the Faculty for the first time in an approved advocacy competition.

courses.name: ENGL 211 Seminar for English Honours
courses.description: An introduction to practical criticism; required of and open only to students of ENGL 210. A limited number of texts from a range of genres and periods will be chosen for close critical analysis.

courses.name: EPSE 569 Social Psychological Foundations in Applied Psychology
POLI 333A Issues in Comparative Politics - ISSUES COMP PLTC
courses.description: An examination of a major issue in comparative politics (e.g., the media, gender, nationalism, ethnic conflict). Topics will vary from year to year.

courses.name: PSYC 300A Behaviour Disorders - BEHAVIOUR DISORD
courses.description: The definition, history, and scope of deviant behaviour; emphasis on the psychological factors that control its origins, maintenance, and modification.
courses.prerequisites: (Either (a) PSYC 100, or (b) all of PSYC 101, PSYC 102, or (c) 6 credits of 200-level Psychology (but not 205 or 263).)

courses.name: PLNT 532 Advanced Insect Physiology
courses.description: Recent advances in selected fields of insect physiology, emphasizing the neural and/or hormonal integration of metabolic activities. Offered in alternate years.

courses.name: LLED 221 Language Maintenance and the Integration of Immigrants in Canada: An Introduction
courses.description: The concept of societal and individual bilingualism/multilingualism in a variety of settings, including Canada in particular.

courses.name: BUSI 452 Case Studies in Appraisal II
courses.description: Continuation of BUSI 442

courses.name: MIDW 103 Applied Health Services for Maternity Providers
courses.description: Introduction to diagnostics related to cellular and humoral immune responses in pregnant women and newborns, the properties of viruses, epidemiology, the principles of bacterial pathogenesis, and related physiologic responses.

courses.name: GEOG 390B Geography of Selected Regions - SELECTED REGIONS
courses.description: A geographical analysis of selected regions not regularly included in the Department's offerings in regional geography (e.g., tropical Africa, Oceania). Students should consult the Department regarding regions to be covered.

courses.name: ASIA 100 Introduction to Traditional Asia
courses.description: A survey of the histories and cultures of Asia before 1600 and the coming of the Europeans. Emphasis will be given to parallel themes in the development of the civilizations of South, Southeast and East Asia.

courses.name: MECH 358 Engineering Analysis
courses.description: Fourier series; auto- and cross-correlation; power spectra; discrete Fourier transform; boundary-value problems; numerical methods; partial differential equations; heat, wave, Laplace, Poisson, and wave equations.  Applications to mechanical engineering and practical computing emphasized.  Credit will be granted for only one of MECH 358 and MATH 358.

courses.name: ENGL 406A Studies in Prose Fiction - FICTION STUDIES
courses.prerequisites: (3rd year standing and 6 credits of first-year English, or Arts One, or 6 credits of ASTU 100 from CAP or 3 credits of first-year English and 3 credits of ASTU 150)

courses.name: OBST 503 Fetal and Perinatal Metabolism
courses.prerequisites: (Knowledge of fetal growth and development, physiology, pathology of labour.)

courses.name: PATH 404 Diagnostic Histochemistry
courses.description: A lecture and laboratory course that encompasses the theory and the practice of currently available histochemical techniques. This course is to supplement the histopathological technique course taken as a requirement for CSLT (RT).

courses.name: CHBE 244 Chemical and Biological Engineering Thermodynamics I
courses.description: Energy and the first law; second law of thermodynamics; entropy; availability (energy) analysis; thermodynamic properties of fluids, application to power generation, refrigeration, and liquefaction, as well as biological, environmental, and electrochemical systems.

courses.name: NURS 509 Clinical Procedures in Primary Care Settings
CLCH 389 Introduction to Classical Chinese I (Non-Heritage)
courses.description: The basics of classical Chinese grammar, with short illustrations from texts of the Warring States and early Han Period. Credit will be granted for only one of CLCH 389 or ASIA 389.
courses.prerequisites: (First-year modern Chinese, first-year modern Japanese or Korean 301, or demonstrate a basic knowledge of Chinese characters.)

courses.name: NURS 335 Professional Nursing Practice with Adults Living with Mental Illness and their Families
courses.description: Analysis and application of theories, concepts, evidence and competencies guiding professional nursing practice with mental illness and their families in a variety of practice settings and contexts.
courses.prerequisites: All of NURS 302, NURS 303, NURS 304, NURS 305, NURS 306.
courses.corequisites: Either (a) all of NURS 338, NURS 339, NURS 340 or (b) all of NURS 341, NURS 342, NURS 343.  (Depends on sequencing of NURS 335 with other professional practice courses.)

courses.name: EPSE 593 Design and Analysis of Research with Small Samples and Single Subjects
HIST 106 Global Environmental History
courses.description: The impact humans have had on the environment, and the ways in which the physical environment has shaped human history: climate, agriculture, energy use, and urbanization.

courses.name: ASIA 364B Modern Japanese Literature in Translation - MOD JAPN LIT TRN
courses.description: An introduction to the literature and cultural history of modern Japan, with readings drawn from various literary genres, from 1868 to the present.

courses.name: CHEM 121 Structure and Bonding in Chemistry
courses.description: Fundamentals of bonding theories and structural chemistry, with applications relevant to modern society.

courses.name: FRE 501 Commodity Markets and Price Analysis
MTRL 471 Nanofibre Technology
courses.description: Introduction to nanomaterials in the form of fibres and composites, including processing, structure, characterization methods, properties, and modeling. Credit will only be given for one of MTRL 471 or MTRL 571.

courses.name: CSIS 300A Introduction to Critical Studies in Sexuality - INTR CRT STDY SX
courses.description: A multidisciplinary, team-taught course which provides an introduction to the study of sexuality, including  lesbian, gay, bisexual, heterosexual, and transgender issues and related topics.

courses.name: AFST 250A Introduction to African Studies - INTRO AFRI STUDY
courses.description: Cultural, historical, and geographical issues of African Studies.

courses.name: APSC 377 Nuclear Weapons and Arms Control
courses.description: The evolution and contemporary significance of nuclear weapons and arms control policy and technology from the perspective of the physical and life sciences and the social sciences and humanities.
courses.prerequisites: (Third-year standing in B.A. or B.Sc. programs, or second-year standing in B.A.Sc. program.)

courses.name: LLED 315A English as a Second Language - Secondary: Curriculum and Pedagogy - ESL SEC C&P
courses.description: Pass/Fail.

courses.name: POLS 424 Polish Literature and Film in Translation
courses.description: Selected films and translated literature by Polish writers and filmmakers, with emphasis on the interaction between politics and literature.

courses.name: CHEM 521A Topics in Inorganic Chemistry - TOP INORGAN CHEM
ELEC 411 Antennas and Propagation
courses.description: Basic antenna concepts; antennas for low, medium and high frequencies; terrestrial and satellite propagation links; environmental effects on electromagnetic radiation.
courses.prerequisites: One of EECE 364, ELEC 311, PHYS 301, PHYS 354.

courses.name: ECON 334 Economic History of Modern Europe
courses.description: Background, causes and effects of economic change in Europe from the 18th century to recent times. Evolution of social and economic institutions; analysis of growth, structural change, the distribution of income, and the spread of industrialization.

courses.name: POLI 110 Investigating Politics: An Introduction to Scientific Political Analysis
courses.description: The logic, challenges, and major strategies of empirical political research. Core research tasks including: asking answerable questions, defining concepts, formulating hypotheses, gathering evidence, measuring variables, constructing comparisons, drawing causal inferences, and reporting findings.

courses.name: COMM 386P Topics in Business III - PROTOTYPING
CHBE 345 Unit Operations II
courses.description: Stage-wise mass transfer operations; extraction and absorption; single and stage-wise binary and multi-component distillation; principles and equipment design for continuous contact mass transfer operations including absorption, binary distillation and others such as extraction, drying, humidification, membrane separations.

courses.name: VISA 401H Advanced Open Studio - ADV OPEN STUDIO
courses.description: Research-based studio with thematic or disciplinary focus.  Intended for senior Visual Art undergraduate students.
courses.prerequisites: Three of VISA 310, VISA 311, VISA 320, VISA 321, VISA 330, VISA 331, VISA 340, VISA 341, VISA 350, VISA 351, VISA 360, VISA 361, VISA 370, VISA 390.

courses.name: EPSE 507 Applied Child and Adolescent Psychopathology
ARTH 251 Asian Arts: From Chinese Warriors to Bollywood Posters
courses.description: A thematic examination of Asian arts, such as historic, religious, and secular painting and sculpture to contemporary visual culture.

courses.name: LLED 361 Literacy Practices and Assessment: Secondary
courses.description: Pass/Fail.

courses.name: PHYS 200 Relativity and Quanta
courses.description: Special relativity: Lorentz transformation, dynamics and conservation laws. Quantum physics: the experimental evidence for quantization; a qualitative discussion of the concepts of quantum mechanics and their application to simple systems of atoms and nuclei.
courses.prerequisites: Either (a) one of PHYS 102, PHYS 108, PHYS 118, PHYS 158, PHYS 153 and one of MATH 101, MATH 103, MATH 105, MATH 121;  or (b) SCIE 001.

courses.name: APSC 410 Co-operative Work Placement
courses.description: Supervised, technical work experience in an established company or organization for a minimum of three months. Technical report. Restricted to students meeting the requirements of the Faculty of Applied Science and the Co-operative Education Program.

courses.name: ASIA 200 Cultural Foundations of East Asia
courses.description: A comparative survey of the beliefs, assumptions and values which have shaped the civilizations of East Asia in both traditional and modern times.

courses.name: HIST 402G Problems in International Relations - PRBS INTRNL RELN
courses.description: Selected topics such as trade, migration, diplomacy, war, migration, colonialism, and post- colonialism. Priority for registration to majors in History or International Relations.

courses.name: LARC 440 SITE ANALYSIS AND PLANNING II
courses.description: Site analysis and planning of relatively complex sites, emphasizing storm water management design. Open only to B.En.D. students. Credit will be given for only one of LARC 440, LARC 540.

courses.name: ELEC 492 Electrical Energy Systems Capstone Design Project
courses.description: Design, analysis, and implementation of solutions in response to a real world electrical energy systems problem, provided by industry, research laboratories, or other suitable entities.  Includes coverage of topics such as project management.

courses.name: CHEM 503 Equilibrium Statistical Mechanics in Chemistry
courses.description: Introductory principles of Statistical Mechanics with illustrations of chemical importance. Applications to molecular gases, liquids, solids, independent particle statistics, electric and magnetic moments, radiation, chemical equilibrium and reaction rates. Credit will not be given for CHEM 407/CHEM 503 and PHYS 455.

courses.name: ITAL 101 First-Year Italian I
courses.description: Grammar, reading, writing, and oral practice for beginners without previous exposure to the Italian language or dialects.

courses.name: INDS 502U Interdisciplinary Studies: Thematic Seminars - QUAL MET ETH RES
courses.description: Seminars, lectures, and discussions of topics involving several faculties. Contact the Interdisciplinary Studies Program for specific topics (www.isgp.ubc.ca).

courses.name: VISA 180 Studio One: Foundation and Media
courses.description: Drawing, painting, and related media in an introduction to studio practice. (This course is open to all UBC students, regardless of prior experience.)

courses.name: BMEG 591P Topics in Biomedical Engineering - TPCS BIOMED ENG
CRWR 351A Intermediate Poetry Workshop - INTRMD POETRY
courses.description: An intermediate level workshop class in writing poetry. Manuscript submission is not required for admission.

courses.name: SPHA 557 Quality of Health Care
courses.description: Current concepts, methods, and applications in health care quality assessment and improvement.

courses.name: ELEC 404 RF Integrated Circuits
courses.description: Introduction to radio-frequency (RF) communication systems; matching networks, transceiver architectures, low noise amplifiers, mixers, oscillators, etc.

courses.name: WOOD 492 Modeling for Decision Support
courses.description: Applications of mathematical modeling, optimization, and simulation in forest planning and manufacturing; formulating models and interpreting results for decision support.

courses.name: MINE 590A Special Advanced Topics - MINE SUSTAIN DEV
courses.description: A special advanced course may be arranged upon the approval of the department head.

courses.name: DENT 584 Endodontic Literature Review II
courses.description: Endodontic epidemiology, materials, prognosis of treatment, geriatric endodontics, complications, treatment resistant infections, and endo-perio lesions.

courses.name: HIST 379 History of Later Imperial China
courses.description: History of China from the end of Tang to the eve of its modern transformation. Students will acquire the analytical skills and tools to understant the political, socio-economic, and cultural changes in imperial China.

courses.name: BIOL 343 Plants and Peoples
courses.description: The interactions of plants and human societies: the role of people in the origin, evolution and dispersal of food, drug and economic plants, and the influences of plants on human societies. Suitable for upper-level Arts students.

courses.name: HIST 236 Public History in Canada: Memory, Representation, and Interpretation
courses.description: An introduction to public history in Canada.  An exploration of the politics and practice of representing the past in a variety of sites, and questions of historical interpretation, memory, and audience.

courses.name: CHEM 111 Structure, Bonding, and Equilibrium in Chemistry
courses.description: Fundamentals of bonding theories, structural chemistry and equilibrium with applications relevant to modern society.
courses.prerequisites: Not open to students with credit for CHEM 12.

courses.name: APSC 182 Matter and Energy I
courses.description: Thermometry, states of matter and phase change, ideal and real gases, 1st law of thermodynamics, 2nd law of thermodynamics, liquids, solutions.

courses.name: PSYC 336 The Psychology of Language I
courses.description: Psychological abilities underlying human language; language processing, lexical representation, and principles of online conversation; animal versus human communication.
courses.prerequisites: Either (a) PSYC 100 or (b) all of PSYC 101, PSYC 102. (Non-PSYC students may substitute ENGL 329, or LING 420, or LING 200 and 201 for the above prerequisite.)

courses.name: ARTH 436 Seminar in Early Modern Art
EDST 535 Comparative and International Adult Education
CNPS 508A Review of Research in Educational Methods - REV RES ED MTD 1
courses.description: Studies are made of recent research bearing on educational practice.
courses.prerequisites: (Appropriate senior undergraduate introductory or methods course.)

courses.name: LAW 379E Externship - EXTERNSHIP
courses.description: Students work for an approved organization, supervised by a Faculty-approved mentor and a faculty member. Consult the Faculty for full eligibility criteria.
courses.prerequisites: Either (a) one of LAW  280, LAW  476 and either (a) LAW  240 or (b) all of LAW  359, LAW  260 or (c) all of LAW  400, LAW  270 or (d) LAW  469; ;  or (b) one of LAW  387, LAW  392 or (c) one of LAW  230, LAW  459. (Or other studies that provide adequate preparation for the program.)

courses.name: MINE 291 Introduction to Mining
courses.description: Leading practices and technologies employed in the design, planning, and operation of mining systems. Life cycle of surface and underground mining systems.

courses.name: MATH 302 Introduction to Probability
courses.description: Basic notions of probability, random variables, expectation and conditional expectation, limit theorems.   Please consult the Faculty of Science Credit Exclusion List: www.students.ubc.ca/calendar/index.cfm?tree=12,215,410,414.
courses.prerequisites: One of MATH 200, MATH 217, MATH 226, MATH 253, MATH 263.

courses.name: POLI 517A The State in Comparative Perspective - STATE COMP PERSP
SPPH 581P Selected Topics - HLTH ECNOMICS 1
courses.description: By seminar and directed readings, certain topics of current interest are explored in depth.

courses.name: EPSE 551A School-based Consultation - SCH-BASED CONSLT
courses.description: Same as CNPS 551.

courses.name: CHBE 362 Process and Environmental Engineering Laboratory
courses.description: Experiments to illustrate and use material presented in 200 and 300-level CHBE courses.  Field trips may be required.

courses.name: AANB 515 Animal Welfare and Animal Ethics
courses.description: Credit will be granted for only one of APBI 315, ANSC 515, and AANB 515.

courses.name: SOCI 301A Sociology of Development and Underdevelopment - DEVELOPMENT
courses.description: Processes of social change in the Third World and other developing countries. Major themes stress the relationship between urbanization and industrialization; modernization and ethnic conflict; imperialism, neo-colonialism, and foreign aid; and intra-national modernization problems such as regional underdevelopment in industrial societies.

courses.name: THTR 373 Intermediate Voice, Speech, and Movement I
courses.description: Open only to B.F.A. Acting students.
courses.prerequisites: All of THTR 271, THTR 272, THTR 273, THTR 274.

courses.name: FIST 430A Studies in Auteurism - STDY AUTEURISM
courses.description: A seminar examining the work of one or more directors, such as John Ford, Francois Truffaut, Denys Arcand, Margarethe Von Trotta, or of a screenwriter over many films.

courses.name: RMES 518 Water in International Development
courses.description: Key water issues associated with international development:  global water demand, scarcity, efficiency of use, water as a commodity, biophysical and policy aspects of water management, water and health, land use impact, water harvesting, improved irrigation, and pollution prevention.  Credit will be given for only one of SOIL 518 or RMES 518.

courses.name: EPSE 580A Investigation and Report of a Problem in Education - INV&RPT PROBS ED
GEOG 497 The Arctic
courses.description: Physical and biological characteristics of the circumpolar Arctic, emphasizing terrestrial environments and the impacts on and by humans, including: glacial history; climatology; biogeography/ecology of arctic tundra; human-environment interactions, settlement and exploration; and current environmental, social and economic problems.

courses.name: EPSE 520 Curriculum Development in the Education of Deaf and Hard of Hearing Students
CRWR 505C Advanced Writing of Creative Non-Fiction I - ADV CRTV N-FIC I
MATH 449D Honours Reading - HONOURS READING
courses.description: Independent reading by Honours students in Mathematics under the direction of a faculty member. Written report required.

courses.name: CHBE 551 Chemical Engineering Thermodynamics
courses.description: Pressure-volume-temperature relations; chemical equilibria by Gibbs' method; vapor-liquid equilibria; thermodynamic calculations by third law and quantum-statistical methods; irreversible thermodynamics and information theory.

courses.name: LLED 534A Theory and Research in Teaching Written Composition - THR RES TC WR CO
CLST 356 Alexander the Great and his Empire
courses.description: The rise of Macedon under Philip II leading to its domination of Greece and the overthrow of the Persian Empire by his son, Alexander; the subsequent spread of Greek civilization in the East.

courses.name: EOSC 434 Geological Engineering Soils and Weak Rocks
courses.description: Multi-disciplinary, geological engineering approach using case histories to apply knowledge of geomorphology, hydrogeology, soil mechanics, and rock mechanics to engineering problems in realistically complex geological environments.

courses.name: EDCP 508 Review of Research in Curriculum and Pedagogy
courses.description: Studies of recent research bearing on education practice.

courses.name: MECH 495 Industrial Engineering
courses.description: Organizational structure. Manufacturing systems and group technology. Classification and coding. Scheduling and sequencing of operations. Forecasting. Quality control for variables and attributes. Plant location. System reliability analysis. Advanced manufacturing automation concepts.

courses.name: ENGL 466A Studies in a Twentieth-Century Genre - 20C GENRE
courses.prerequisites: (3rd year standing and 6 credits of first-year English, or Arts One, or 6 credits of ASTU 100 from CAP or 3 credits of first-year English and 3 credits of ASTU 150)

courses.name: SPPH 529 Major Essay
courses.description: Required for all M.H.Sc. students.

courses.name: GEOG 353 Geographies of Migration and Settlement
courses.description: International regimes regulating migration, changes in global demographics, immigration policies of nation states, international migration patterns, settlement policies and outcomes.

courses.name: AUDI 660A Seminar in Hearing Science - SEM HEARING SCIE
NURS 304 Introduction to Relational Practice
courses.description: Introduction to relational theories to guide nursing practice within the socio-political, historical, economic and cultural context of health and health care.

courses.name: ENGL 474A Studies in Contemporary Literature - CONTEMPORARY LIT
courses.prerequisites: (3rd year standing and 6 credits of first-year English, or Arts One, or 6 credits of ASTU 100 from CAP or 3 credits of first-year English and 3 credits of ASTU 150)

courses.name: GRS 490 Global Issues in Cultural Context
courses.description: Students interact face-to-face and on-line as a community of learners to discuss global issues in agriculture, food, and natural resources in cultural context. Typically taken after studying abroad.

courses.name: PHTH 531 Pathology for Physical Therapy III
GEOG 121 Geography, Environment and Globalization
courses.description: Human geography of the modern world with particular attention to human-environment relationships, urbanization, and regional growth; trade and communications; environment and war; environmental governance and sustainability.

courses.name: GRSJ 303 Gender, Law, and Social Justice
courses.description: A survey of feminist legal thought and recent developments in feminism and law, with a focus on Canada.
courses.prerequisites: Either (a) all of GRSJ 101, GRSJ 102 or (b) all of WMST 101, WMST 102. (or third-year standing.)

courses.name: ECED 590E Graduating Project - GRADUATING PRJCT
courses.description: Pass/Fail.

courses.name: GPP 509 Communicating Policy
courses.description: The role of media, especially new media, in effectively communicating policy to stakeholders, including issues of transparency and accountability. Focus on communications formats including written, oral, and multimedia policy communications.

courses.name: EECE 584 Nanophotonics Fabrication
courses.description: Design, fabricate, and test a photonic integrated circuit (PIC) using silicon-on-insulator (SOI) technology.  Modelling and design of optical components.

courses.name: LARC 570C Co-op Work Placement - COOP WORK PLCMNT
courses.description: A mechanism for students to earn academic credit for relevant work experience outside the university. Open only to M.L.A. students.

courses.name: EDST 571 Educational Research: Relating Questions, Theory, and Methodology
PHYS 503 Condensed Matter Physics II
courses.description: Interacting electrons, electron-phonon interaction, Hubbard model, magnetism, superconductivity, use of Green functions.

courses.name: HIST 418 The 1960s in Global Perspective
courses.description: The history of the 1960s from a transnational perspective: culture, social change, student activism, and global conflict.

courses.name: EDST 597 Educational Theories: Equality, Democracy, and Justice
MECH 222 Engineering Science II
courses.description: Fluid properties, equations of state. Pressure, buoyancy, hydrostatic forces, pressure measurement. Conservation of mass, momentum, and energy. Work and heat; internal energy and enthalpy. Bernoulli's equation. Dimensional analysis, modeling. Turbulent flow in pipes; turbomachinery. Second law and the Carnot cycle; entropy; first and second law analysis of systems; exergy.

courses.name: LIBR 508 Information Practices in Contemporary Society
ENGL 464A Twentieth-Century Studies - 20TH CENTURY
courses.prerequisites: (3rd year standing and 6 credits of first-year English, or Arts One, or 6 credits of ASTU 100 from CAP or 3 credits of first-year English and 3 credits of ASTU 150)

courses.name: EDST 601B Doctoral Seminar - DOCTORAL SEM
courses.description: Required of students in the first year of a doctoral program. Pass/Fail.

courses.name: PATH 721 Microbiological Research
courses.description: Conduct of research on some aspect of clinical or basic microbiology. For medical residents.

courses.name: SPPH 512 The Design and Analysis of Clinical Trials
courses.description: Ethical considerations, intention-to-treat versus efficacy trials, principles of sampling and exclusion, methods of allocation and techniques of randomization, parallel versus cross over design, monitoring treatment outcomes, adverse effects, stopping rules, analytic techniques and data interpretation, and logistical issues in the management of clinical trials.
courses.prerequisites: Either (a) one of HCEP 502, HCEP 513 or (b) one of SPPH 502, SPPH 513.

courses.name: FNIS 401F Special Topics - SPECIAL TOPICS
courses.description: Topics will vary from year to year. Consult the departmental website: http://fnsp.arts.ubc.ca.
courses.prerequisites: One of FNSP 200, FNIS 210, FNSP 210, FNIS 220, FNSP 220. (or third-year standing.)

courses.name: CLST 401B Seminar in Classical History - SEM CLASSCL HIST
courses.description: Selected topics in Greek or Roman history, with an emphasis on research. Restricted to majors and honours students in CLST, CLAS, CLAH, ARGR, and GRNE.

courses.name: PHAR 534T Clinical Clerkships II - CLIN CLERKSHP II
courses.description: Elective clinical rotations of 4 weeks' duration in hospital, office or clinic locations.

courses.name: PSYC 440C Directed Studies in Psychology - DIRECTED STUDIES
courses.description: Directed investigation of an experimental problem, requiring a written report of the findings.
courses.prerequisites: (At least 72% average in the preceding 30 credits and permission of a faculty member who is prepared to supervise the investigation.)

courses.name: APSC 110 Co-operative Work Placement
courses.description: Supervised, technical work experience in an established company or organization for a minimum of three months. Technical report. Restricted to students meeting the requirements of the Faculty of Applied Science and the Co-operative Education Program.

courses.name: IGEN 451 Pipeline Systems and Infrastructure
courses.description: Energy infrastructure; pipe flows; equipment and facilities including compressors, pumping stations, coolers, and controls; terminals; pipeline integrity; corrosion control.
courses.prerequisites: Either (a) MECH 221 or (b) APSC 278 and one of CIVL 215, MTRL 263 and one of CIVL 230, MECH 260.

courses.name: LLED 222 Introduction to Public and Private Language Practices in a Globalized Society
courses.description: Exploration of the interrelationships between language structure, usage and social context and the interpretive differences that may result from their interaction.

courses.name: SPAN 410 Medieval Literature
courses.description: Topics in Spanish Literature from its origins to 1500.
courses.prerequisites: One of SPAN 220, SPAN 221 and SPAN 302.

courses.name: CIVL 518 Reliability and Structural Safety
courses.description: Probability theory and random variables. Performance functions and probability of non-performance: simulations and FORM/SORM methods. Applications. System reliability. Time-dependent reliability and introduction to stochastic processes.

courses.name: GEOB 409 Self-Directed Field Studies in Physical Geography
courses.description: Advanced research design, field sampling methods, instrumentation, surveying, mapping techniques, data analysis and management; self-directed fieldwork; 1 lecture per week during term and a multi-day field camp in April or May.
courses.prerequisites: GEOB 309. (Third-year standing in Geographical Biogeosciences Major.)

courses.name: EECE 531 Nanoscale Modeling and Simulations
courses.description: The many-body problem, molecular dynamics, tight-binding, first-principles (ab-initio) methods, the Hartree-Fock approach, the density functional theory, nanoscale simulation software and applications.

courses.name: MATH 340 Introduction to Linear Programming
courses.description: Linear programming problems, dual problems, the simplex algorithm, solution of primal and dual problems, sensitivity analysis. Additional topics chosen from: Karmarkar's algorithm, non-linear programming, game theory, applications.

courses.name: ANTH 545B Graduate Research Seminar - GRAD RSRCH SEM
EOSC 470 Biological Oceanography
courses.description: A quantitative examination of processes regulating the abundance, distribution and production of phytoplankton, zooplankton, microbes and fish. Controls of primary and secondary production, ecosystem dynamics and foodwebs.

courses.name: MUSC 439C Opera Workshop II - OPERA WORKSHOP 2
courses.description: A continuation of MUSC 339.

courses.name: SOCI 479A Social Determinants of Health - DETERMNTS HEALTH
courses.description: Relationships between social phenomena (e.g., personal beliefs, lifestyle practices, social support, socio-economic status, social class, gender, and ethnicity) and the health of human populations.

courses.name: FRST 347 Co-operative Work Placement
courses.description: Supervised work experience in an approved organization for a minimum of 15 weeks. Restricted to students in the Co-operative Education Program in the Faculty of Forestry. Final work term report required.

courses.name: LLED 478A Introduction to Teaching English as a Second Language - INTRO TO TESL
courses.prerequisites: (For TESL Certificate, 6 credits of LLED 489, ENGL 329, LING 420, LING 200, LING 201 taken within the last five years or taken as corequisite with consent of instructor. For B.Ed. TESL, LLED 315.)

courses.name: LAW 525 Canadian Criminal Law and Procedure
NURS 423 Clincial Nursing Focus: Children and their Families

courses.prerequisites: All of NURS 302, NURS 303, NURS 304, NURS 305, NURS 306, NURS 333, NURS 334, NURS 335, NURS 336, NURS 337, NURS 338, NURS 339, NURS 340, NURS 341, NURS 342, NURS 343.

courses.name: APBI 315 Animal Welfare and the Ethics of Animal Use
courses.description: Scientific assessment of animal well-being, ethical concepts applied to animal use, and animal welfare issues arising in agriculture, biomedical research and other areas.
courses.prerequisites: (At least third-year standing in any faculty.)

courses.name: FRST 449A Directed Studies in Forestry - DIRECTED STUDIES
courses.description: In special cases and with the approval of the instructor concerned, a student may carry on directed studies of specific problems in forestry.

courses.name: HIST 490G Seminar for Majors in History - SEM FOR HIST MAJ
courses.description: Selected problems in the theory and practice of historical work. Check with the department for course offerings. Restricted to fourth year students majoring in History or in the History and Philosophy of Science. Also open to History Honours students.

courses.name: ASIA 211 Sex, Sexual Ethics, and Asian Religions
courses.description: Sex and sexual ethics in the scriptures, monastic rules, rituals, and narratives of Asian religions, such as Sikhism, Hinduism, Buddhism, and Confucianism.

courses.name: BIOL 548L Advanced Topics in Biology - ADV TOPICS BIOL
VISA 470A Advanced Special Studies I - ADV SPCL STDY I

courses.name: ASIA 370 The Sanskrit Cosmopolis: India and the World, 200-1500 CE
courses.description: Languages, religions, art forms, and political structures of Asian societies shaped by creative encounters with Sanskrit.

courses.name: MATH 448A Directed Studies in Mathematics - DIRECTED STUDIES
courses.description: Introduction to the methods of mathematical research through an exploration of a mathematical topic under the supervision of a faculty member.  Written report required.
courses.prerequisites: (Third- or fourth-year standing and permission of the Department Head.)

courses.name: PCTH 548E Directed Studies in Pharmacology - DIRECTED STUDIES
courses.description: In special cases, with the approval of the department head, advanced courses may be arranged.

courses.name: MINE 590Z Special Advanced Topics - MINE PRJ ECN&FIN
courses.description: A special advanced course may be arranged upon the approval of the department head.

courses.name: VISA 370 Special Studies I
courses.description: Intermediate tutorial. Not offered every year.

courses.name: SOWK 440J Integrative Seminars in Social Work - INTGRTV SEM SOWK
courses.description: A series of seminars offered during the final term of studies which address salient issues in social policy and social work practice and draw upon combined knowledge from social work and related disciplines.

courses.name: MECH 410M Special Topics in Mechanical Engineering - INT MECHATRONICS
courses.description: Lectures and readings on specialized topics of current interest in Mechanical Engineering.

courses.name: EDUC 450A Inquiry Seminar I - INQUIRY SEMNR 1
courses.description: Pass/Fail.

courses.name: FNH 350 Fundamentals of Nutrition
courses.description: Fundamentals of energy and macronutrient metabolism.
courses.prerequisites: FNH  250 and one of BIOL 201, BIOC 202.

courses.name: CHBE 697 Ph.D. Thesis Proposal Development
courses.description: Techniques for preparation of a critical literature review and focussed research proposal for Ph.D. candidates. Students perform oral and written critiques of published research in their area of study, define research questions and hypotheses, and develop a focussed research proposal.

courses.name: PHYL 521 Advanced Topics in Renal Physiology
MUSC 415 Imagining Musical Performances
courses.description: How performance and analysis engage the musical imagination, as complementary activities; how analytical observations can stimulate performance, and vice versa. Selected topics, with special emphasis on temporal factors.

courses.name: MECH 533 Biofluids
courses.description: Principles, biorheology, circulatory biofluid mechanics, synovial fluid in joints, biofluid dynamics of the human brain, respiratory biofluid mechanics, flow and pressure measurement techniques in the human body. Credit will be granted for only one of MECH 433 or 533.

courses.name: VANT 140E Content and Language Enrichment Tutorials - CONTENT LANG TUT
courses.description: Sustained language support for linked content courses in International Program. Students develop strategies for self-directed learning.

courses.name: EOSC 212 Topics in the Earth and Planetary Sciences.
courses.description: Cutting edge problems in earth, ocean, atmospheric and planetary sciences.  Topics will be introduced through discussions of the current literature.

courses.name: ASIA 510B Monastic Biography and Hagiography in East Asian Buddhism - MON BIO&HAG BUDH
ARCL 203 Archaeological Methods
courses.description: Introduces the methods and principles applied in anthropological archaeology and cultural-historical research.

courses.name: POLI 464B Problems in International Relations - PROB INTRL RELTN
courses.description: Content varies from year to year. Consult the departmental website. One section (of 3 credits) is reserved for fourth-year students in the Major program in International Relations.

courses.name: CELL 501 Cell and Developmental Biology Research Literature
courses.description: Development of written communication and critical thinking skills.

courses.name: CEEN 503 Sustainable Energy Systems
courses.description: Planetary thermodynamics, energy system evolution, energy services, role of renewable energy sources. Alternative energy technologies. Solar, wind, small-scale hydro, tidal, geothermal, electrochemical (batteries, capacitors, and fuel cells), and biochemical energy, electromechanical conversion processes. Techno-economic assessment of alternative energy technologies.

courses.name: FRST 449F Directed Studies in Forestry - DIRECTED STUDIES
courses.description: In special cases and with the approval of the instructor concerned, a student may carry on directed studies of specific problems in forestry.

courses.name: GREK 351 Intermediate Ancient Greek: Prose
courses.description: Readings in the major authors in Greek Prose.

courses.name: MECH 529 Modelling of Dynamic Systems
courses.description: Advanced modeling of mechanical, electrical, fluid, thermal and multi-domain systems; inter-domain analogies; analytical models in time and frequency domains; modeling tools; response analysis; digital simulation; practical project.
courses.prerequisites: (Prior undergraduate coursework in dynamics, vibration, or electrical circuits.)

courses.name: LLED 391 Theory and Practice in Reading Instruction
courses.description: Credit may be obtained for only one of LLED 310, 391, 300.

courses.name: LAW 324A Topics in International Law and Transactions - TPCS INTL LAW&TR
courses.description: Not offered each year, consult Faculty.

courses.name: GERM 439C Fourth-Year Honours Seminar - 4 YR HONS TUT
PHAR 453B Directed Studies in Pharmacy Practice - DIR STDY PHAR PR
courses.description: Individual assignments involving library and field work investigations of problems associated with pharmacy practice. Enrolment restricted. Open to upper level students.
courses.prerequisites: (Successful completion of the first three years of required courses in the pharmacy curriculum.)

courses.name: BIOC 501C Advanced Biochemistry Laboratory - ADV BIOC LAB
courses.description: Practical applications of advanced biochemical techniques. Admission is limited and is by permission of the department head.

courses.name: EOSC 546 Advanced Field Methods in Earth Science
DENT 561B Directed Studies in Dental Sciences - DST DENTAL SCIE
PHAR 453C Directed Studies in Pharmacy Practice - DIR STDY PHAR PR
courses.description: Individual assignments involving library and field work investigations of problems associated with pharmacy practice. Enrolment restricted. Open to upper level students.
courses.prerequisites: (Successful completion of the first three years of required courses in the pharmacy curriculum.)

courses.name: CCST 503 Graduate Practicum and Major Paper in Curatorial Studies
courses.description: Practical on-site teamwork to produce exhibitions or other public displays in a museum, gallery, or alternative situation, offering opportunities for comparison, collaboration, and interdisciplinarity. Students concurrently produce a major paper from the ideas and research which generate the exhibition.

courses.name: MEDI 548C Directed Studies in Experimental Medicine - DST IN EXPTL MED
MATH 607E Topics in Numerical Analysis - TPCS NUMERIC ANL
MECH 576 Combustion
courses.description: Thermodynamics of combustion, stoichiometry, heat of formation and reaction. Equilibrium composition and adiabatic flame temperature. Chemical kinetics of combustion. Flames in premixed gases; laminar and turbulent flame propagation. Diffusion flames, pollutant emissions and combustion in IC engines.

courses.name: PLAN 509 Urbanism as a Global Way of Life
KIN 301 Co-operative Work Placement
courses.description: Supervised, technical work experience in an established company or organization for a minimum of three months. Technical report. Restricted to students meeting the requirements of the School of Kinesiology and the Co-operative Education Program.  Pass/Fail.

courses.name: PCTH 399 Co-operative Work Placement II
courses.description: Approved and supervised technical work experience in an industrial research setting for a minimum of 3.5 months. Technical report required. Restricted to students admitted to the Co-operative Education Program in Pharmacology.

courses.name: FRST 348 Co-operative Work Placement.
courses.description: Supervised work experience in an approved organization for a minimum of 15 weeks. Restricted to students in the Co-operative Education Program in the Faculty of Forestry. Final work term report required.

courses.name: BIOL 399 Co-operative Work Placement II
courses.description: Work experience in an industrial research setting, taken during Summer Session (Terms 1 and 2) following third year. Restricted to students admitted to the Co-operative Education Program in Biology.

courses.name: POLI 449A Topics in Political Theory - TPCS POLI THEORY
THTR 211 Drama: Forms and Ideas II
courses.description: Topics in comparative drama; drama and the other performing arts; dramaturgy.

courses.name: AUDI 516B Discourse Analysis - DISCOURSE ANYL
courses.description: May be taken more than once for credit.

courses.name: VANT 150 Sustainability and Engineering Design
courses.description: Topics in sustainability, including the impact of technology on the environment and society, and fundamentals of engineering design. Restricted to students in the UBC Vantage College Engineering Stream.

courses.name: STAT 461 Statistical Inference II
courses.description: Detailed development of the theory of testing hypotheses and confidence regions, Bayesian models and inference, elements of decision theory and additional topics. Intended for Honours students.

courses.name: ASTU 400P Interdisciplinary Studies in Arts - WHY UND WLK AMG
courses.description: For upper-division students in the Faculty of Arts. Topics announced annually.

courses.name: ENGL 210 An Introduction to English Honours
courses.description: For Honours students accepted by the English Honours Committee on the recommendation of the instructor. Students permitted to take this course must take ENGL 211 concurrently.
courses.prerequisites: Either (a) ARTS 001 or (b) two of ENGL 100, ENGL 110, ENGL 111, ENGL 112, ENGL 120, ENGL 121 or (c) ASTU 100 or (d) ASTU 150 and one of ENGL 110, ENGL 111, ENGL 120, ENGL 121;  or (e) WRDS 150 and one of ENGL 110, ENGL 111, ENGL 120, ENGL 121. (Or 6 credits of first-year English.)

courses.name: KIN 473 Neuroanatomy of Human Movement
courses.description: Neuroanatomy of human motion in healthy and clinical populations.

courses.name: EOSC 516 Teaching and Learning in Earth, Ocean and Atmospheric Sciences
EDUC 449C Supervised Research Investigation - SUPERVISED RSRCH
courses.description: Available only to outstanding students approved by the Associate Dean (Teacher Education).

courses.name: ITAL 201 Second-Year Italian I
courses.description: Reading, writing and oral practice, with constant and systematic reference to the grammatical structure of the language.

courses.name: GEOG 290 Introduction to the Geography of Canada
courses.description: Selected topics in human geography focusing on the regional distribution of natural resources, population, urban systems, and economic activities.

courses.name: HIST 585A Topics in Cultural History - TOP CUL HIST

courses.description: Physiological and/or acoustic phonetics. Focus on experimental methods and analysis techniques. Topics may include: source-filter theory; spectral and temporal acoustic analysis, inter-articulator timing and motor coordination.
courses.prerequisites: LING 313. (Recommended: All of LING 100, PSYC 100 (or PSYC 101 and 102), PSYC 217 and 218, PHYS 341.)

courses.name: MUSC 507C Composition - COMPOSITION
courses.description: The composition of original music for conventional instruments and/or electronic media.

courses.name: CRWR 411U Writing for Lyric Forms I - LYRIC FORMS 1
courses.description: A workshop class exploring the words that accompany music in varied forms including pop, art, musical theatre, and opera. Admission is restricted to B.F.A. Majors in Creative Writing.

courses.name: ECON 390 Introduction to Economic Research
courses.description: Selected topics in economic research.  Application of research methods to economic data.  Credit will be granted for only one of ECON 390, ECON 490, ECON 495, or ECON 499.

courses.name: EECE 571Q Electrical Engineering Seminar and Special Problems - ACTV SILICN PHTG
NURS 510 Advanced Health Assessment Across the Life Span
POLI 309 Canadian Perspectives on Human Rights
courses.description: Key issues in the theory and practice of human rights in Canada. Topics will vary from year to year.

courses.name: INDE 442 Senior Clerkship
courses.description: A senior clinical elective for fourth year students. Students will participate in all relevant clinical and academic activities associated with the particular rotation.

courses.name: MINE 592C Mining Industry Internship - MINE INTERNSHIP
courses.description: Mining or mineral processing engineering internship in which concepts, theory and practice of mining and mineral processing engineering are applied by working with industry on appropriate technical projects. Pass/fail.

courses.name: MECH 597 Project for M.Eng. Studies
courses.description: Project on assigned topic of specialization. For students registered in the M.Eng. program whose project is supervised by a faculty member in the department of Mechanical Engineering.

courses.name: MINE 524 Processing of Precious Metal Ores
courses.description: Advances in science and technology for recovering gold, silver, and platinum group elements. Credit will be granted for only one of MINE 524 or MINE 577.

courses.name: KIN 371 Introduction to Statistics in Kinesiology
courses.description: Basic concepts and principles of descriptive and inferential statistics, and distribution-free statistical techniques. Please consult the School of Kinesiology Credit Exclusion Lists: http://www.calendar.ubc.ca/vancouver/index.cfm?tree=12,205,253,1477.

courses.name: LFS 302A International Field Studies - INTERNL FLD STD
courses.description: Field studies carried out abroad under staff direction. Participating students are assessed a fee.

courses.name: LAW 423D Topics in Intellectual Property - TPCS INTELL PROP
courses.description: Not offered each year, consult Faculty.

courses.name: CAPS 448C Directed Studies in Physiology - DIRECTED STUDIES

courses.description: Understanding, assessing, and managing stress in farm, companion, captive wildlife, and research animals: sources of stress; behavioural, emotional, cognitive, and physiological responses; effects on growth, reproduction, health.
courses.prerequisites: (Third-year standing or higher. APBI 315 and courses in animal physiology and animal behavior recommended.)

courses.name: PHYS 319 Electronics Laboratory
courses.description: A project-oriented lab introducing the design and construction of microprocessor-controlled devices.

courses.name: PHYL 523 Advanced Topics in Gastrointestinal Physiology

courses.description: Concepts and processes for the strategic management of private sector, single and multi-business unit enterprises are analysed using the case method. Methodologies which draw on economic and organizational theory are integrated to form the foundations for strategic analyses.

courses.name: LATN 350 Latin Literature of the Classical Period (Prose)
courses.description: Readings in Latin Prose.

courses.name: MECH 329 Materials for Mechanical Design
courses.description: Selection of material properties and processing techniques for mechanical design. Properties of steel and other alloys. Heat treatment. Ceramics, composites, plastics.
courses.prerequisites: Either (a) MECH 224 or (b) all of APSC 278, MECH 260.

courses.name: EDST 570 Topics in Sociology of Education
BASM 523 Management Consulting and Corporate Decision Support
KIN 465 Interculturalism, Health and Physical Activity
courses.description: Examination of multiculturalism and interculturalism in the delivery of community-based physical activities for diverse populations; connections between physical activity and health in different cultural contexts.  Community service learning and participation in culturally unfamiliar physical activities are core elements.

courses.name: MTRL 359 Hydrometallurgy I Laboratory
courses.description: Laboratory exercises on aqueous extraction of metals from ores and concentrates.

courses.name: FIST 240 Media Industries
courses.description: Overview of today's film and media industries, and of the concepts governing their practices.

courses.name: ARCL 228 Forensic Anthropology
courses.description: The application of methods from biological anthropology and archaeology to the identification, recovery, and analysis of skeletal remains from crime scenes, mass disasters, and unexplained deaths.

courses.name: LAW 509 Administrative Law
courses.description: The system of legal control exercised through non-judicial agencies and the relationship of the courts to the administrative process.  Credit will be granted for only one of LAW 509, LAW 210 or LAW 372.

courses.name: AUDI 530B Research Methods - RESEARCH METHODS
courses.description: May be taken more than once for credit.

courses.name: PLAN 510 Environment and Sustainability Concepts for Planning Practice
KIN 191 Anatomy and Physiology II
courses.description: Structure and function of the digestive, endocrine, urinary, circulatory and respiratory systems. Special emphasis on effects of exercise. Please consult the School of Kinesiology Credit Exclusion Lists: http://www.calendar.ubc.ca/vancouver/index.cfm?tree=12,205,253,1477.

courses.name: FMED 423 Musculoskeletal and Locomotor
courses.description: The student is introduced to the basic science components which underlie common clinical conditions. Case-based themes involving normal and abnormal bone metabolism, rheumatoid and osteoarthritis, ligament and muscle contributions, and overall joint mechanics are highlighted.

courses.name: CPSC 449 Honours Thesis
courses.description: Under supervision of a faculty member, students investigate a research topic and prepare a thesis.

courses.name: CIVL 315 Fluid Mechanics II
courses.description: Two dimensional flow around immersed objects; velocity and pressure fields; lift and drag on cylinders and aerofoils; fluid loads on structures and structural response; pumps and turbines; analysis and design of pipeline systems; unsteady flow in pipes; frictionless waterhammer analysis.

courses.name: MINE 590L Special Advanced Topics - MIN MTL PHY CHAR
courses.description: A special advanced course may be arranged upon the approval of the department head.

courses.name: LAW 396D Fisheries Law - FISHERIES LAW
courses.description: Legal regimes for the exploitation and regulation of fisheries. Not offered each year, consult Faculty.

courses.name: KIN 567 Human Motor Performance
courses.description: Processes underlying the ability to learn and perform motor skills.

courses.name: CNPS 584 Program Development and Professional Practice in Counselling
courses.description: Designing, implementing and assessing counselling programs in schools, colleges, universities, and other counselling settings.
courses.prerequisites: One of EDUC 500, EPSE 481 and one of EPSE 482, EPSE 483.

courses.name: PHIL 461A Philosophy of Social Science - PHIL OF SOC SCIE
courses.description: Topics in the philosophy of science of special concern to the social and behavioural sciences; hypotheses and explanation; principles, theories, models; the formation of scientific concepts; the function of mathematics in social science.
courses.prerequisites: (9 credits at the 200-level or above from philosophy, anthropology, geography, economics, history, political science, psychology or sociology.)

courses.name: EDUC 211 Global Citizenship, Part 2: Community Service Learning and Capstone Conference
JAPN 408 Readings in Modern Japanese Literature
courses.description: An advanced course in the reading and analysis of literary texts in modern Japanese. Advanced conversation, translation into English and practice in the use of standard reference tools as preparation for advanced research in Japanese.

courses.name: JRNL 548 Final Research Project
courses.description: Pass/Fail.

courses.name: DENT 594 Endodontic Case Review and Treatment Planning I
courses.description: Student case presentations, treatment choice, and evaluation of prognosis.

courses.name: ELEC 421 Digital Signal and Image Processing
courses.description: DSP fundamentals; image processing; signal representation; digital filtering; statistical estimation; DSP applications.
courses.prerequisites: One of EECE 269, ELEC 221, EECE 359, EECE 369.

courses.name: ELEC 292 Biomedical Engineering Design Studio
courses.description: Design projects involving electronic devices and circuits, electromagnetics, signals and systems, microcomputers with applications in biomedical engineering. Final group project requiring oral presentation of student-prepared slides.

courses.name: CHIN 115 Basic Chinese II: Part 1 (Heritage)
courses.description: Skills in listening to and speaking Mandarin and reading and writing modern written Chinese. Emphasis on reading and writing.

courses.name: HIST 485 Asian Migrant Communities in Vancouver
courses.description: This course will examine the history of Asian migration to Vancouver and British Columbia, focusing on the development of local communities and provide a background in historical research methods that will enable the students to conduct research on the history of these communities.

courses.name: FIPR 534A Advanced Production for Film and Television - ADV PROD FILM&TV
MINE 432 Industrial Automation and Robotics
courses.description: Automatic control theory, PID control, Laplace and z-transforms, loop tuning, frequency response, stability analysis, control strategies in flotation, comminution, dewatering, reagent and bin/sump levels, automated load-haul-dump and drilling equipment, telerobotics in mining operations, instrumentation and soft sensors.

courses.name: ENDS 420 Technology and Technique
courses.description: Introduction to fundamental design principles and investigations of buildings, landscape, machines and furniture, including structure, enclosure, envelope and detailing.

courses.name: DENT 722 Clinical Endodontics, Year 2
courses.description: Endodontic treatment of patients in the clinic under the supervision of specialist instructors. Supervised endodontic treatment clinic.

courses.name: ELEC 402 Introduction to VLSI Systems
courses.description: Static CMOS combinational logic circuits. Standard cells design and layout. Memory element (flip-flop and latch) design. Dynamic logic families. Synchronous logic and timing analysis. Power, scaling, and industry trends. Verification. VHDL/Verilog design, layout and synthesis project using CAD tools.

courses.name: FREN 348 French Literatures in Translation I
courses.description: Literary works from the Middle Ages to the French Revolution. Not available for credit towards a Minor, Major or Honours program in French. May be taken up to two times for a total of 6 credits with different content.
courses.prerequisites: (6 credits of first-year English, ARTS 001, or Foundations, and at least second year standing.)

courses.name: HGSE 353 Rainforest Ecology and Management
courses.description: Ecology of the temperate rainforests of Haida Gwaii.  A core element of the Haida Gwaii Semester.

courses.name: FIPR 338 Motion Picture Sound
courses.description: An introduction to the technique and aesthetics of creating production and post-production sound for film and video.

courses.name: MUSC 539C Opera Production - OPERA PRODUCTION
courses.description: Stylistic and technical studies and participation in the production of opera performances. May be repeated for credit, in accordance with program requirements.

courses.name: EOSC 579 Dynamic Oceanography
courses.description: Consult the Credit Exclusion List in the Faculty of Science section of the Calendar.

courses.name: ANTH 351A Ethnography of the Pacific Islands: Melanesia - ETHNO: MELANESIA
courses.description: Major cultural groupings in Melanesia, emphasizing both traditional cultures and the incorporation of the region into modern international institutions.

courses.name: CHIN 205 Intermediate Chinese II: Part I (Non-Heritage)
courses.description: Skills in listening, speaking, reading, and writing, and better understanding of Chinese culture.

courses.name: ARCL 406A Analytical Techniques in Archaeology - LAB TECH ARCHEGY
courses.description: A survey of methods and techniques in the interpretation of archaeological data; practical experience in processing and analyzing archaeological materials by means of a research project. Students will prepare manuscripts, drawings and photographs for publication and will learn the basics of lithic and faunal analyses.

courses.name: THTR 530C Seminar: Relationships Between Theatre and the Other Arts - SEMINAR
courses.description: Studies in a selected area of theatre in relation to one or more of the other arts.

courses.name: CIVL 320 Civil Engineering Materials
courses.description: The structure and properties of common Civil Engineering materials: aggregates, Portland cement, concrete, asphalt, timber and metals. The emphasis is on the relationship between the structure of materials and their mechanical properties.

courses.name: HIST 419 Crime and Punishment in Canadian History
courses.description: The relationship between law and society; the development of legal institutions and the evolving character of crime in Canada.

courses.name: ELEC 281 Technical Communication
courses.description: Written and oral communication in engineering. Technical description, report preparation, business correspondence, and oral presentation of technical material. Restricted to students in second year of Electrical and Computer Engineering programs. Credit will be granted for only one of ELEC 281, CPEN 281, or APSC 201.
courses.prerequisites: One of APSC 176, ENGL 110, ENGL 111, ENGL 112, ENGL 120, ENGL 121.

courses.name: POLI 402A Law and Politics of the Canadian Constitution - CANADIAN CONSTIT
courses.description: Seminar on the origins and development of the Canadian Constitution: the political aspects of federalism and the legal consequences of the Charter of Rights.
courses.prerequisites: POLI 101 and one of POLI 301, POLI 302, POLI 303, POLI 304, POLI 305, POLI 306, POLI 307, POLI 308.

courses.name: EECE 566 Communication and Information Theory
courses.description: Coding for noisy channels, linear block codes, cyclic codes, convolutional codes, maximum likelihood decoding, trellis coded modulation, measure of information, source coding, channel capacity theorem.

courses.name: ANAT 392 Gross Anatomy of the Limbs and Trunk
courses.description: Lectures and laboratory sessions on the human gross and functional anatomy of the limbs and trunk. The course includes the study of predissected specimens. For credit only in the Department of Physical Therapy.

courses.name: FRST 503 Plant Molecular Biology Laboratory
courses.description: Techniques of purification, cloning, sequencing, restriction-hybridization analysis of plant nucleic acids, in-vitro labeling of plant nucleic acids and proteins, and electrophoresis and immunodetection of plant proteins. Offered by the Biotechnology Teaching Laboratory in cooperation with the Department of Forest and Conservation Sciences. Admission to the course is limited and requires recommendation from the department head.

courses.name: APBI 495 Principles of Wildlife Management in Forests and Agricultural Environments
courses.description: Impacts of wildlife on crop productivity in temperate and tropical environments, the resiliency of wildlife populations to conventional control methodology, adoption of innovative methods to reduce crop damage, and the impact of introduced species on native fauna.

courses.name: SOCI 302A Ethnic and Racial Inequality - ETHNIC & RACIAL
courses.description: A critical examination of classical and contemporary theories and research evidence concerning ethnic and racial inequality at the societal and interpersonal levels.

courses.name: GRSJ 505B Directed Reading in Advanced Feminist Studies - DIR READ FEMNST
GRSJ 310 Issues in Gender and Health
courses.description: Interdisciplinary introduction to gender and health issues using selected theoretical frameworks.
courses.prerequisites: Either (a) all of GRSJ 101, GRSJ 102 or (b) all of WMST 101, WMST 102. (or third-year standing.)

courses.name: RHSC 504A Directed Studies in Rehabilitation - DST REHABILIT'N
GERM 434 German for Reading Knowledge II (Languages for special purposes)
courses.description: Multimedia teaching of reading skills in German for special purposes. Students are expected to work largely independently. Focuses on specific topics of the student's choice in the humanities, the natural sciences, economics/business and music and enhances skills in technical reading.
courses.prerequisites: GERM 433. (or no more than one year of beginner's German.)

courses.name: VISA 210 Digital Arts
courses.description: Examination of current art practices and issues related to digital technologies and contemporary culture. Technical instruction in image and sound manipulation with an emphasis on the theoretical conceptualization of digital artistic media.
courses.prerequisites: A score of 72% or higher in VISA 110 and a score of 72% or higher in one of VISA 180, VISA 182 and a score of 72% or higher in VISA 183.

courses.name: CIVL 598A Topics in Civil Engineering - STRCT HLTH MNTOR
courses.description: Seminar or lecture.

courses.name: HGSE 357 Ecology and Management of Island Wildlife
courses.description: Unique biological attributes of island wildlife, such as subspecies, isolated populations, and distinct evolutionary pathways, with a focus on endemic species on Haida Gwaii.  Part of the Haida Gwaii Fall Semester.  Credit will be granted for only one of FRST 395 or CONS 357.
courses.corequisites: All of HGSE 355, HGSE 356, HGSE 358, HGSE 359.

courses.name: MATH 300 Introduction to Complex Variables
courses.description: Functions of a complex variable, Cauchy-Riemann equations, elementary functions, Cauchy's theorem and contour integration, Laurent series, poles and residues. Please consult the Faculty of Science Credit Exclusion List: www.students.ubc.ca/calendar/index.cfm?tree=12,215,410,414.
courses.prerequisites: One of MATH 200, MATH 217, MATH 226, MATH 253, MATH 263.
courses.corequisites: One of MATH 217, MATH 227, MATH 263, MATH 317.

courses.name: BIOC 521 Advanced Topics in Molecular Biology
courses.description: Discussions based on topics in the current literature.

courses.name: BOTA 546A Topics in Botany - TOPICS IN BOTANY
STAT 547P Topics in Statistics - TOPICS IN STAT
courses.description: Students should consult the Statistics Department for the particular advanced topics offered in a given year.

courses.name: CICS 500 Software Systems Internship
courses.description: Technological work experience in an approved company or organization for a four-month period. A required internship to be taken as part of the M.S.S. (Master of Software Systems) program.
courses.prerequisites: All of CICS 505, CICS 510, CICS 515, CICS 520, CICS 525.

courses.name: SPPH 533 Toxicology and Public Health
courses.description: Mechanism of action of commonly encountered occupational toxic agents; relevance of laboratory and epidemiological evidence.

courses.name: SOCI 515 Qualitative Data Analysis in Sociology
COMM 473 Business Finance
courses.description: Introduction to managerial finance, including the role and functioning of financial markets, procurement of funds and financing strategies, dividend policy, capital budgeting and financial analysis and planning. (For non-Commerce students only).
courses.prerequisites: Either (a) all of ECON 101, ECON 102 or (b) ECON 100 or (c) all of ECON 310, ECON 311 or (d) all of ECON 101, ECON 311 or (e) all of ECON 102, ECON 310;  and one of MATH 100, MATH 102, MATH 104, MATH 110, MATH 120, MATH 180, MATH 184.

courses.name: MECH 589 Computer Control of Multi-Axis Machines
courses.description: Digital control laws for servo drives; state space and transfer function models of feed drives; tracking errors; trajectory generation of multi-axis machines; contouring analysis of multi-axes servo drives; real time linear and circular interpolation methods supported by laboratory applications. Credit will be granted for only one of MECH 467 or MECH 589.

courses.name: ANTH 215 Japanese Popular Culture
courses.description: Television shows, dramas, movies, advertising, marketing, manga (Japanese style "comics"), anime (Japanese animation), theatrical forms, popular literature, popular music, fashion fads, tourism, toys, and sports.

courses.name: BA 530M Study Abroad and Exchange - STUDY ABR'D&EXCH
courses.description: Restricted to students in one of the following programs: M.B.A., LL.B./M.B.A., M.Sc.B., Ph.D. with B.A.D.M. specialization, or M.M. with either ECMS or ECMJ. M.M. ECMS or ECMJ students are limited to a maximum of 12 credits in this course.

courses.name: JAPN 250 Intensive Intermediate Japanese I
courses.description: Integrated coverage of topics on culture and  cross-cultural communication designed to develop competencies in speaking, listening, reading, and writing. Offered in Term 1. Equivalent to JAPN 210 and JAPN 211. Note: JAPN 250 and JAPN 251 are normally taken in the same year.

courses.name: EOSC 453 Physics of the Earth and Other Planets
courses.description: Identification and quantitative analysis of diverse physical problems in the earth, ocean, atmospheric, and planetary sciences.

courses.name: BIOC 420 Advanced Biochemical Techniques
courses.description: Multi-week experiments in areas of contemporary biochemistry research using classical and modern techniques.  Emphasis on experimental design, technique, critical analysis of data, and scientific communication skills.  Restricted to Honours students in Biochemistry and others with permission of the instructor.

courses.name: PSYC 102 Introduction to Developmental, Social, Personality, and Clinical Psychology
courses.description: Introduction to methods and statistics, motivation, assessment, developmental, personality, clinical, and social psychology. Credit will not be given for both PSYC 100 and PSYC 102.

courses.name: SPAN 202 Intermediate Spanish II
courses.description: Grammar, composition, translation, oral practice, readings.
courses.prerequisites: SPAN 201. (Students with Spanish 12 need permission from a department advisor to receive credits for this course.)

courses.name: BIOL 411 Insect Ecology
courses.description: Behavioural, population and community ecology of insects. Interactions between insects and plants and the application of the principles of insect ecology to biological control of insects and weeds.
courses.prerequisites: Either (a) BIOL 205 or (b) all of AGRO 327, BIOL 327.

courses.name: COMM 547A Major Essay/Industry Project - MAJOR ESSAY/PROJ
CIVL 598C Topics in Civil Engineering - TPCS SUST BUILD
courses.description: Seminar or lecture.

courses.name: MINE 590N Special Advanced Topics - GRND MODIFICTN
courses.description: A special advanced course may be arranged upon the approval of the department head.

courses.name: LAW 448 Sports Law
courses.description: Legal issues relating to the sports industry and those who participate in it. Not offered each year, consult Faculty.

courses.name: PERS 300 Advanced Persian I
courses.description: Graded reading, writing, exposure to the writing system, textual history, newspaper reading, and translation. Cultural materials presented as appropriate. The art of calligraphy introduced.

courses.name: CHEM 310 d- and f-Block Elements: Chemistry and Applications
courses.description: Representative chemistry of d- and f-block elements interpreted in terms of structure, mechanisms, and theoretical principles.  Applications discussed include: organometallic catalysis, bioinorganic chemistry and materials.

courses.name: LAW 419C Individual Employment Law - INDV EMPLYMT LAW
courses.description: Legal aspects of employment relationships other that those arising by collective bargaining. Not offered each year, consult Faculty.

courses.name: LIBR 534 Health Information Sources and Services
PATH 405 Seminars in Current Topics
courses.description: Oral and written presentation and critical appraisal of scientific papers.

courses.name: PSYC 321 Environmental Psychology
courses.description: Psychological theory and research on the interaction between organisms and the physical environment; emphasis on applications to the design and management of constructed and natural environments.
courses.prerequisites: Either (a) PSYC 100 or (b) all of PSYC 101, PSYC 102. (or (c) 6 credits of 200-level Psychology (but not 205 or 263).)

courses.name: FNH 325 Food Science Laboratory I
courses.description: Integrated laboratory introducing techniques used in food processing and analysis. Enrolment restricted to Food Science students.
courses.prerequisites: All of FNH  300, FNH  301, FNH  302. (These courses can be taken as corequisites.)

courses.name: KIN 215A Performance Analysis of Selected Team Sports and Activities - PERF ANYL STS&A
courses.description: Specific topics to be announced each year. KIN 115 and 215 can be taken in any order.

courses.name: ENGL 474F Studies in Contemporary Literature - CONTEMPORARY LIT
courses.prerequisites: (3rd year standing and 6 credits of first-year English, or Arts One, or 6 credits of ASTU 100 from CAP or 3 credits of first-year English and 3 credits of ASTU 150)

courses.name: ITAL 401 Advanced Studies in Italian Language and Style I
courses.description: Advanced reading, writing, speaking, comprehension. Special emphasis on oral practice. Alternates with ITAL 402.

courses.name: KIN 699 Doctoral Dissertation
courses.description: Pass/Fail.

courses.name: BIOL 448J Directed Studies in Biology - DIRECTED STUDIES
courses.description: A course designed to allow students to undertake an investigation on a specific topic as agreed upon by the faculty member and the student. Permission of the supervisor required. No more than six credits of BIOL 448 may be taken with the same supervisor.

courses.name: NURS 577A Graduate Practicum in Nursing - GRAD PRAC NURS
FRE 302 Small Business Management in Agri-food Industries
courses.description: Emphasizes the building of a business plan by exploring topics such as the planning process and financing, marketing and human resource concepts, as applied to an agri-food business, domestically and internationally.

courses.name: PHIL 388 Buddhist, Brahmanical and Jain Philosophers in Interaction.
courses.description: Debates on issues of epistemology, language and ontology among the philosophical schools or systems of classical India Nagarjuna, Bhartrhari, Uma-svati, Sankara and others.

courses.name: CHEM 203 Introduction to Organic Chemistry
courses.description: Structure, bonding and physical properties of aliphatic and aromatic compounds; mechanistic analysis of chemical reactivity of common functional groups with a focus on carbon-heteroatom bond formation; functional group interconversion and oxidation/reduction reactions. Only open to students in Chemistry or Biochemistry specializations.  Credit will be given for only one of CHEM 203 or CHEM 233, 235.

courses.name: MATH 184 Differential Calculus for Social Science and Commerce
courses.description: Topics as for Math 104; intended for students with no previous knowledge of Calculus. Please consult the Faculty of Science Credit Exclusion List: www.students.ubc.ca/calendar/index.cfm?tree=12,215,410,414.  Not for credit for students with AP Calculus AB, AP Calculus BC, or a passing score on the UBC-SFU-UVIC-UNBC Calculus Challenge Examination.
courses.prerequisites: (One of BC Principles of Mathematics 12 or Pre-calculus 12 and one of (a) a grade of 80% or higher in BC Principles of Mathematics 12 or Pre-calculus 12, or (b) a satisfactory score in the UBC Mathematics Basic Skills Test.)

courses.name: ECON 441 The Process of Economic Development
courses.description: Industrialization of an agrarian economy; how the West grew rich; history of Japanese development; technical progress and growth; evolution of the patterns of income distribution; role of international trade in development; environment and development.

courses.name: MIDW 102 Birth and its Meaning
courses.description: An interdisciplinary study of pregnancy and childbirth drawing on and integrating the disciplines of psychology, sociology, philosophy of science, anthropology, women's studies, and cultural studies.

courses.name: MINE 590S Special Advanced Topics - CARBN SEQUESTRTN
courses.description: A special advanced course may be arranged upon the approval of the department head.

courses.name: MUSC 150C Large Instrumental Ensemble - LRGE INST ENSEMB
courses.description: Symphony Orchestra or Wind Ensemble. May be repeated for credit in accordance with program requirements for B.Mus. or B.A. in Music. Open to other students by audition, with credit, as stipulated by their faculties.

courses.name: INDE 451 Clinical Skills IV
courses.description: Final examination for third year encompassing all clinical subjects.

courses.name: RUSS 400 Fourth-Year Russian
courses.description: Advanced oral practice, reading and composition.

courses.name: PSYC 365 Cognitive Neuroscience
courses.description: Brain mechanisms underlying cognitive processes such as perception, attention, consciousness, and memory.

courses.name: ARCH 544U Seminar in Architecture - TRANSP URBN FRM
courses.description: An exploration of selected topics in architecture. Enrolment is limited to facilitate discussion.

courses.name: ECON 255 Understanding Globalization
courses.description: Social and economic implications for both rich and poor countries of lowered barriers to the international flows of information, capital, labour and goods.  May not be taken for credit by students with fourth-year standing.

courses.name: CPSC 213 Introduction to Computer Systems
courses.description: Software architecture, operating systems, and I/O architectures.  Relationships between application software, operating systems, and computing hardware; critical sections, deadlock avoidance, and performance; principles and operation of disks and networks.
courses.prerequisites: Either (a) all of CPSC 121, CPSC 210 or (b) all of CPSC 210, CPSC 260, EECE 256. (CPSC 210 may be taken concurrently with case (b) only.)

courses.name: CRWR 416U Writing for Television I - WRT TELEVISION 1
courses.description: A workshop class in writing for television. Admission is restricted to B.F.A. Majors in Creative Writing.

courses.name: MUSC 207A Composition II - COMPOSITION 2
courses.description: Continuation of MUSC 107.
courses.prerequisites: MUSC 107. (and permission of Composition Division based on submission of scores.)

courses.name: SOIL 515 Integrated Watershed Management
