courses.description: Methods of watershed evaluation, land-water interactions, key aspects of hydrology, water quality and aquatic biota, land use impacts on water resources, community involvement, and integration of multiple land use activities and their cumulative impacts.  Credit will be given for only one of SOIL 515 or RMES 515.

courses.name: CELL 511 Cellular and Molecular Mechanisms of Human Disease
courses.description: Cell biology in the age of evidence-based medicine.

courses.name: EDUC 490M Special Studies in Education - SPEC STUDIES ED
courses.description: Topics not covered in a course. A pilot course may be offered under this name for only one year and with permission of the Associate Dean (Teacher Education).

courses.name: LLED 368 Multiliteracies in English Language Arts Classrooms
courses.description: Pass/Fail.

courses.name: MINE 597 Engineering Project
courses.description: A project involving laboratory, pilot plant or field work is to be completed in close collaboration with an academic adviser. For M.Eng. students only.

courses.name: MEDG 545 Current Topics in Medical Genetics Research
courses.description: Critical discussion of current primary research literature in medical genetics.

courses.name: BIOL 300 Fundamentals of Biostatistics
courses.description: Statistical procedures for biological research; estimation, hypothesis testing, goodness of fit, analysis of variance and regression; use of computers for statistical analysis. Please consult the Faculty of Science Credit Exclusion Lists: www.students.ubc.ca/calendar/index.cfm?tree=12,215,410,414.
courses.prerequisites: Either (a) BIOL 121 and one of MATH 101, MATH 103, MATH 105, MATH 121;  or (b) SCIE 001.

courses.name: STAT 200 Elementary Statistics for Applications
courses.description: Classical, nonparametric, and robust inferences about means, variances, and analysis of variance, using computers. Emphasis on problem formulation, assumptions, and interpretation. See the Faculty of Science Credit Exclusion Lists: www.calendar.ubc.ca/vancouver/index.cfm?tree=12,215,410,414.
courses.prerequisites: One of MATH 101, MATH 103, MATH 105, MATH 121, SCIE 001.

courses.name: ANAT 512 Functional Human Anatomy of Head and Neck Systems
FRST 548B Major Essay - MAJOR ESSAY
courses.description: For non-thesis master's degree programs.

courses.name: FIST 436 Seminar in American Cinema Since 1960
courses.description: Topics may include an analysis of a specific period.

courses.name: GEOG 412 Water Management: Theory, Policy, and Practice.
courses.description: Interdisciplinary analysis of critical water issues, in Canada and internationally.  Focus on social science perspectives.  Emphasis on presentation, research, and essay-writing skills.

courses.name: CELL 502 Current Topics in Developmental Biology
courses.description: Cellular and molecular mechanisms of development from the earliest stages of axis formation to organogenesis.

courses.name: FNH 302 Food Analysis
courses.description: Principles of and procedures for analysis of the chemical and physical properties of food; proximate analysis; introduction to instrumental analysis; reporting and analysis of data.
courses.prerequisites: Either (a) CHEM 201 or (b) CHEM 205;  and either (a) CHEM 203 or (b) CHEM 233.

courses.name: CHBE 243 Introduction to Chemical and Biological Engineering Process and Technology
courses.description: Processes used in chemical and biological industries, which emphasize underlying physical, chemical, and biological principles.

courses.name: EDCP 526A Theory and Principles of Music Education - THEOR&PRINC MUED
INDE 420 Clinical Skills Systems II
courses.description: Small group sessions may be supplemented by self-study resources. Students will further develop general and specific communications skills, while learning a systemic approach to the remaining body systems. Experience with both pediatric and adult patients will be provided.

courses.name: GEOG 495 Geographies of Social Movements in the Americas
courses.description: The politics of North-South solidarity in theory and practice through community service learning models.

courses.name: THTR 273 Beginning Voice and Movement I
courses.description: Open only to B.F.A. Acting students. An audition is required.

courses.name: MUSC 149 Collaborative Piano I
courses.description: Skills and performance practice with primary emphasis on voice/piano partnership principles and repertoire. Strong sight-reading skills essential. For Piano majors; open to others by audition.

courses.name: GEOG 374 Statistics in Geography
courses.description: Introduction to statistical techniques and their application to geographical problems. Priority enrolment for honours and major students in Geography. Consult the Faculty of Science Credit Exclusion Lists: www.students.ubc.ca/calendar/index.cfm?tree=12,215,410,414.

courses.name: HIST 333C Third-Year Honours Seminar - 3RD YR HONRS SEM
ASTU 400O Interdisciplinary Studies in Arts - RTRCNG QUR VC AD
courses.description: For upper-division students in the Faculty of Arts. Topics announced annually.

courses.name: MUSC 156E Vocal Chamber Ensembles - CHAMBER CHOIR
courses.description: May be repeated for credit in accordance with program requirements for B.Mus. or B.A. in Music. Open to other students by audition, with credit, as stipulated by their faculties.

courses.name: ETEC 512 Applications of Learning Theories to the Analysis of Instructional Settings
LING 530B Linguistic Problems in a Special Area - PROB IN SPC AREA
CSIS 490A Directed Topics - DIRECTED TOPICS
courses.description: Designed to allow a student to develop an individual course of study in a specific area as approved by a faculty member affiliated with the CSIS program.

courses.name: EOSC 331 Introduction to Mineral Deposits
courses.description: Introduction to economic geology and models related to mineral exploration. Study includes typical deposit types and their plate tectonic setting.

courses.name: PLAN 548S Current Issues in Planning - URBN SYST CLIMTE
courses.description: Each year the school may offer one or more courses on a topical issue covering recent advances in the field.

courses.name: LLED 350 Classroom Discourses: Elementary
courses.description: Pass/Fail.

courses.name: MUSC 201 Musical Forms
courses.description: Study of various forms in tonal music and the rhythmic, melodic, textural, and harmonic processes that create them on small and large scales. Compositional and analytical exercises.

courses.name: MUSC 554 University Choral Union
courses.description: Open only to graduate students.

courses.name: THTR 452 Scene Painting II
courses.description: Study of selected scene painting styles.

courses.name: ECON 421 Introduction to Game Theory and Applications.
courses.description: Principles of rational behaviour in strategic situations and various notions of equilibrium useful in predicting outcomes. Applications from economics, business, politics, law and biology.

courses.name: BIOL 230 Fundamentals of Ecology
courses.description: Dynamics of plant and animal populations, structure of ecological communities and functioning of ecosystems. Interpretation of research results and application to environmental issues. Labs meet once a month. Please consult the Faculty of Science Credit Exclusion Lists: www.students.ubc.ca/calendar/index.cfm?tree=12,215,410,414.

courses.name: ITAL 303 Italian Literature and Culture of the Medieval and Early Modern Period
courses.description: A thematic approach to Italian literary works from the origins to the end of the sixteenth century considered in a broad cultural context. Alternates with ITAL 304.

courses.name: PUNJ 102 Introductory Punjabi
courses.description: Spoken and written Punjabi. As of 2011W, credit will be granted for only one of PUNJ 100/101 or PUNJ 102. Students who have taken Punjabi 11 in high school cannot take PUNJ 102 for credit.

courses.name: SPPH 681A Selected Topics - SELECTED TOPICS
courses.description: By seminar and directed readings, certain topics of current interest are explored in depth.

courses.name: BUSI 112 Canadian Real Property Law and Real Estate Ethics
courses.description: Canadian legal system and contract law and detailed aspects of real estate law as it applies across Canada.

courses.name: EOSC 372 Introductory Oceanography: Circulation and Plankton
courses.description: Physical and chemical processes and their controls on the distribution of plankton in the ocean.
courses.prerequisites: Either (a) SCIE 001 or (b) one of CHEM 111, CHEM 121, CHEM 154 and one of MATH 101, MATH 103, MATH 105, MATH 121 and one of PHYS 101, PHYS 107, PHYS 117, PHYS 153, PHYS 157.

courses.name: SPPH 550 Public Health Approaches to Substance Use and Addictions
courses.description: Critical examination of strategies regarding addictive behaviours, substance use and related problems, in the context of a multidisciplinary approach.

courses.name: LAW 506 Taxation
courses.description: Law and practice of income and capital gains taxes. Credit will be granted for only one of LAW 506, LAW 220 or LAW 407.

courses.name: ENGL 307A Studies in Rhetoric - RHETORIC STUDIES
courses.description: Topics in rhetorical theories and their application.

courses.name: AUDI 550B Advanced Topics in Audiology - ADV TPCS AUDI
courses.description: May be taken more than once for credit.

courses.name: ELEC 204 Linear Circuits
courses.description: Basic concepts and analysis techniques in the context of electric and electronic circuits including Bode plots and the Laplace transform. Treatment of RLC circuits, phasors, op-amps. Introduction to nonlinear circuit elements, diodes, BJT, FET circuits.
courses.prerequisites: MATH 152 and one of PHYS 102, PHYS 158, PHYS 153.

courses.name: DENT 566 Biomechanics of Craniofacial Orthopedics and Orthodontics II
MATH 442 Optimization in Graphs and Networks
courses.description: Basic graph theory, emphasizing trees, tree growing algorithms, and proof techniques. Problems chosen from: shortest paths, maximum flows, minimum cost flows, matchings, graph colouring. Linear programming duality will be an important tool.

courses.name: ASIA 441A Masterworks of Chinese Fiction and Drama in Translation - CHIN FIC&DRAM TR
courses.description: Reading of a classic novel or play, with attention to intellectual, social, and political subtexts as well as aesthetic dimensions and problems of interpretation.

courses.name: CNRS 503E Studies in Literature, Art and Society - STUD LIT ART
SOCI 352A Organization of Work - ORGANIZ OF WORK
courses.description: The meaning of work and leisure. Properties of work organization: division of labour and specialization; technology and working knowledge; means of coordinating work, such as cooperation, authority, and exchange. Research problems concerning work in households, offices, and industry, division of labour by gender, industrial democracy and the relation of work and social inequality.

courses.name: MATH 342 Algebra and Coding Theory
courses.description: Error-correcting codes via abstract and linear algebra.  Emphasis on proofs and computation.  Finite fields, Hamming distance and error-correction, upper and lower bounds on the size of a code, linear codes, groups and cosets, encoding and decoding schemes.
courses.prerequisites: One of MATH 152, MATH 221, MATH 223 and one of MATH 220, MATH 226, CPSC 121.

courses.name: FNH 398 Research Methods in Human Nutrition
courses.description: Process of research; principles and processes in utilizing research. Restricted to students in majors in the FNH program.
courses.prerequisites: One of FNH  250, FNH  255 and either (a) one of AGSC 252, LFS  252 or (b) BIOL 300 or (c) EPSE 482 or (d) FRST 231 or (e) STAT 200.

courses.name: MUSC 512A Directed Individual Studies - INDIVDL STUDIES
courses.description: Approval by the Director, School of Music, is required.

courses.name: BASM 550 Strategic Management
courses.description: Not available to MBA students.

courses.name: MTRL 599 Thesis
courses.description: For M.A.Sc. Degree. Research studies in chemical metallurgy, physical metallurgy, or ceramics.

courses.name: PHIL 491A Seminar for Majors in Philosophy - SEM PHIL MAJORS
courses.description: Selected problems in philosophy, with attention to methods of research. Check with the department for specific topics. Primarily for fourth-year Philosophy Major students, but also open to Philosophy Honours.

courses.name: POLI 363A Canadian Foreign Policy - CANADIAN FOREIGN
courses.description: An analysis of Canadian foreign policy on important international issues since the 1960s and of the policy-making process. Issues may include defence commitments, economic relations, activities of international organizations, and relations with the US, Europe, USSR, Asia and the Third World.

courses.name: ISCI 433 Ethical Issues in Science
courses.description: Theoretical and practical consideration of ethics in the practice, reporting, public impact and accountability of science.

courses.name: IGEN 340 Technology Entrepreneurship
courses.description: Theory and skills needed for engineers to capitalize on the opportunities that exist in commercializing technology, including the relationships between ideas and opportunities, customers and competition, and products and solutions.

courses.name: ENGL 328 Metaphor, Language and Thought
courses.description: Exploration of the concepts underlying figurative language (in vocabulary as well as in grammar), using data from both colloquial and literary language.

courses.name: ASIA 348 Great Literary Works of Classical India in Translation
courses.description: Major Sanskrit and Prakrit literary genres as developed in the Brahmanical, Buddhist and Jaina traditions, including folktales of riddle, intrigue, etc. Ramayana, Mahabharata. Polished poems of the urbane. Plays. Learned novels and long poems.

courses.name: DHYG 433 Assessment and Treatment Planning for Advanced Periodontal Diseases
courses.description: Available in online distance education format only.

courses.name: PHRM 171 Introductory Pharmacy Practice Experience I
courses.description: Prescription processing, drug distribution systems, and select patient care activities in real world environments. Pass/Fail.

courses.name: FMST 238 Family Resource Management
courses.description: Conceptual models of resource management as related to families.

courses.name: EDCP 553 Mathematics Education: Beyond the Early Years
courses.description: Recent theories and research.

courses.name: SPPH 506 Quantitative Research Methods
courses.description: Major quantitative research designs, measurement reliability and validity, common data sources used, internal and external validity, research proposals, and peer review. Credit will be granted for only one of SPPH 506 or SPPH 548.

courses.name: EDCP 311A Music - Secondary: Curriculum and Pedagogy - MUS SEC CRC&PED
courses.description: Pass/Fail.

courses.name: CNPS 532B Psychological Assessment in Counselling - PSYC ASSESS CNSL
courses.description: The use of standardized measures of mental ability, achievement, aptitude, interest and personality.

courses.name: MEDG 421 Genetics and Cell Biology of Cancer
courses.description: Molecular mechanisms of oncogenes and tumor suppressors and the effects of oncogenic mutations on the biology of cancer cells.
courses.prerequisites: BIOL 335 and one of BIOC 300, BIOC 302, BIOC 303, BIOL 350.

courses.name: FNH 436 Integrated Functional Genomics
courses.description: Global transcript, protein and metabolite profiling technologies, their integration, application, and furtherance of our understanding of how higher organisms function in general.

courses.name: CAPS 421 Advanced Cellular and Molecular Physiology
courses.description: Recent advancements in cellular and molecular physiology that have revolutionized our understanding of cell function in health and disease.
courses.prerequisites: Either (a) all of ANAT 390, PHYL 301 or (b) all of CAPS 301, CAPS 390. (and third-year standing.)

courses.name: AUDI 581 Perceptual, Cognitive, and Social-affective Issues in Communication Development, Assessment and Intervention
APBI 498 Undergraduate Essay
courses.description: Preparation of a comprehensive and analytical review of an approved topic under the supervision of a faculty member. Consultation with a program adviser is required.

courses.name: PATH 548K Directed Studies - HMST, THRM, HMPH
CNTO 303 Basic Cantonese II
courses.description: Elementary level Cantonese for non-heritage learners. Continuation of CNTO 301.

courses.name: WOOD 449F Directed Studies in Wood Products Processing - DIR ST WD PR PRC
courses.description: In special cases and with the approval of the instructor concerned, a student may carry on directed studies of specific problems in wood products processing.

courses.name: LATN 401A Latin Prose - LATIN PROSE
courses.description: Studies in history, oratory and/or philosophy. May be repeated for up to 12 credits.

courses.name: SOWK 531 Social Work Practice in the Field of Aging
ECON 499 Honours Essay
courses.description: Essay on some theoretical, applied, or institutional problem. Open only to fourth-year Honours students.

courses.name: ORPA 718 Rheumatology Conference
courses.description: Patients with a variety of rheumatological disorders are presented for discussion and evaluation in this combined conference, which rheumatologists and orthopaedic surgeons who have a special interest in reconstructive surgery attend. During each weekly two hour session, patients with difficult management problems are presented for clinical evaluation and discussion of medical and orthopaedic treatment.

courses.name: THTR 399C Production II - PRODUCTION II
courses.description: Assigned projects in theatre design and production.

courses.name: NURS 333 Professional Nursing Practice with Childbearing Individuals and Families
courses.description: Analysis and application of theories, concepts, evidence and competencies guiding professional nursing practice with childbearing individuals and families during the transition to parenthood in a variety of practice settings and contexts.
courses.prerequisites: All of NURS 302, NURS 303, NURS 304, NURS 305, NURS 306.
courses.corequisites: Either (a) one of NURS 338, NURS 339, NURS 340 or (b) one of NURS 341, NURS 342, NURS 343.  ((depending on sequencing of NURS 333 with other professional practice courses.))

courses.name: ENGL 551A Studies in Literary Movements - ST'S LIT MOVEMNT
PHAR 371 Pathophysiology I
courses.description: Pathophysiology of selected disease states.

courses.name: APBI 200 Introduction to Soil Science
courses.description: Physical, chemical and biological properties of soils; soil formation, classification, use and conservation. There are no prerequisites for this course, but background in Biology 12, Chemistry 12, and Physics 12 (or first-year university-level) is strongly advised.

courses.name: CIVL 521 Construction Methods and Performance
courses.description: Case studies in construction methods and solutions to construction site operation problems. Construction productivity, performance measurement, safety, quality, and other production issues.

courses.name: ECON 546 Monetary Theory and Policy I
CHIN 111 Basic Chinese I: Part 1 (Heritage)
courses.description: Skills in listening to and speaking Mandarin and reading and writing modern written Chinese. Emphasis on reading and writing.

courses.name: ASIA 363 Fiction and Film from Modern Taiwan
courses.description: A reading-intensive survey of literary and cinematic culture in Taiwan since the early 20th century: colonialism, the national divide, nativism, trauma, cosmopolitanism, and utopian imaginings. In English.

courses.name: CENS 202 Great Works of Literature from Central, Eastern and Northern Europe (in English).
courses.description: Major works of Central, Eastern and Northern European literature from the eighteenth century to the present in their European context.

courses.name: ASIA 488 Religion, Society and State in Modern India
courses.description: History of secular and religious discourse in post-independent India. Partition, state policy of secularism, religious mobilization among Hindus and Muslims, communal violence and religious radicalism.

courses.name: BRDG 590 Internship
courses.description: 4 months for M.Sc.

courses.name: ENPH 352 Laboratory Techniques in Physics
courses.description: Some of the experiments will be based on the lecture material for PHYS 301. Other techniques and subjects will also be covered.

courses.name: COMM 307 Real Estate Investment
courses.description: Evaluation of investment in real estate assets; proforma analysis, property and asset management, equity securitization, appraisal, and international real estate investment.
courses.prerequisites: One of COMM 295, ECON 201, ECON 301 and one of COMM 297, COMM 298.

courses.name: FIPR 534C Advanced Production for Film and Television - ADV PROD FILM&TV
FRST 537C Topics in Forest Management - TPCS FRST MGMT
EDCP 471A Technological Practices in Education: Technical Problems - TECHNICAL PROB
CIVL 407 Environmental Laboratory Analysis
courses.description: Testing procedures used in water quality studies and in the operation of water and wastewater treatment plants.

courses.name: ASTU 100A 1st Year CAP Seminar - CAP SEMINAR
courses.description: CAP seminar focused on writing and reading, including both literature and introduction to academic scholarship. Topics vary each year. Credits count toward both the Faculty of Arts Writing and Research Requirement and the Literature Requirement (but the latter only when the course is offered for 6 credits).

courses.name: EPSE 598A Field Experiences - FIELD EXPERIENCE
courses.description: Pass/Fail.

courses.name: HIST 476 Law and Society in the Middle Ages
courses.description: The history of law in the Middle Ages, including English common law, civil (Roman) law, and canon law, and how changes in both medieval law and society affected the development of each.

courses.name: CHIN 431 Classical Chinese I (Heritage)
courses.description: The development of early Chinese from the classical period through the Six Dynasties (5th century BCE to 6th century CE). Not to be taken concurrently with any CHIN courses lower than 400-level. Beginning in 2010W, credit will be granted for only one of CHIN 331 or CHIN 431.
courses.prerequisites: One of CHIN 313, CHIN 314, CHIN 317, CHIN 318, CHIN 323.

courses.name: HIST 405 Diplomacy and Conflict in the Middle East, 1914 to the Present
courses.description: International relations in the Middle East in the aftermath of the Ottoman Empire, with special attention to the conflicts between Jews of Palestine/Israel and their Arab neighbours.

courses.name: CHIN 105 Basic Chinese II: Part 1 (Non-Heritage)
courses.description: Skills in listening, speaking, reading, and writing Mandarin Chinese, active vocabulary of about 750 Chinese words, and basic grammar.

courses.name: ARST 565 Administering Records under Freedom of Information and Protection of Privacy Legislation
POLI 310 Parliament and Party: The Strategy of Politics
courses.description: Parliamentary and party politics, showing how politicians in Canada and other countries strike bargains with allies, outmanoeuvre opponents in debates, and manipulate institutional rules.

courses.name: KIN 231 Sport and Exercise Psychology
courses.description: Psychological theories and research related to sport and exercise behaviour.

courses.name: VISA 401G Advanced Open Studio - ADV OPEN STUDIO
courses.description: Research-based studio with thematic or disciplinary focus.  Intended for senior Visual Art undergraduate students.
courses.prerequisites: Three of VISA 310, VISA 311, VISA 320, VISA 321, VISA 330, VISA 331, VISA 340, VISA 341, VISA 350, VISA 351, VISA 360, VISA 361, VISA 370, VISA 390.

courses.name: CNPS 524 Counselling Adults
courses.description: Major issues and problems of adult development. Selection of appropriate counselling interventions for use in education and other counselling settings.

courses.name: ASTU 311 Co-operative Work Placement II
courses.description: Approved and supervised work experience with a public or private organization for a minimum of 13 weeks full-time. Final work term report required.

courses.name: GRSJ 500 Intersectional Issues in Social Justice and Equality Studies
FNH 335 Introduction to Wine Science II
courses.description: Review of diverse styles of wine with consideration of classic wine-producing areas. Concepts in wine microbiology/chemistry; overview of steps in grape processing for diverse wine styles. Comparison of regulations for Canadian VQA systems with international systems. Wine sensory analysis.

courses.name: EDUC 490K Special Studies in Education - SPEC STUDIES ED
courses.description: Topics not covered in a course. A pilot course may be offered under this name for only one year and with permission of the Associate Dean (Teacher Education).

courses.name: RMES 510 Social Ecological Systems
courses.description: Dynamics of environmental issues across temporal and spatial scales using disciplinary and interdisciplinary approaches to integrating sociological, cultural, and ecological perspectives.

courses.name: SPAN 505B Studies in Peninsular and Latin-American Culture - STD PEN<-AM CL
ENGL 470B Canadian Studies - CANADIAN STUDIES
courses.prerequisites: (3rd year standing and 6 credits of first-year English, or Arts One, or 6 credits of ASTU 100 from CAP or 3 credits of first-year English and 3 credits of ASTU 150)

courses.name: ECON 210 Microeconomic Policy
courses.description: A survey of policy issues, such as regulation, taxation, environmental and resource policy, health care, education and income distribution.  May not be taken for credit by students with fourth-year standing.

courses.name: KIN 570 Research Methods in Kinesiology
courses.description: Research methods applied to the study of sport and physical activity, the nature of scientific inquiry, the design of experiments, the survey as a research medium, the historical and philosophical methods of inquiry, the writing of the research report.

courses.name: EPSE 580B Investigation and Report of a Problem in Education - INV&RPT PROBS ED
LLED 366 Teaching Reading and Literature
courses.description: Pass/Fail.

courses.name: ARST 555 The Preservation of Digital Records
ASTU 360 Community-Based Research and Knowledge Creation
courses.description: Principles and practice of conducting research in community partnership.

courses.name: GPP 505 Domestic and Global Policy Process
courses.description: Theories and frameworks related to policy-making processes at domestic and global level. Agenda setting, policy formulation, decision-making, policy implementation, and policy evaluation.

courses.name: APBI 402 Sustainable Soil Management
courses.description: Application of fundamental, unifying, soil science principles in sustainable ecosystem management.

courses.name: LAW 435C Topics in Tort Law - TPCS IN TORT LAW
courses.description: Not offered each year, consult Faculty.

courses.name: ORPA 716 Orthopaedic Bedside Clinic
courses.description: Evaluation of orthopaedic diseases and injuries in patients at bedside. A review of clinical features is correlated with relevant physiology and pathology.

courses.name: ANTH 528 Advanced Quantitative Methods
courses.description: Introduction to the anthropological application of a variety of quantitative techniques: sampling designs, analysis of variance and regression, multi-way contingency tables, multivariate analysis. A series of lectures will outline the logic and exhibit applications that have been made. Students will then generate their own application and presentation. Access to data files specific to the substantive field of cultural anthropology, archaeology, physical anthropology is provided.

courses.name: MUSC 693B Music Performance (Major) - VOICE
courses.description: Private instruction, vocal or instrumental.

courses.name: SCAN 333 Major Works of Scandinavian Literature (in English)
courses.description: Selected Danish, Swedish, Norwegian, and Icelandic texts ranging from Old Norse sagas to contemporary literary works against the background of literary, social, and political developments in Scandinavia.

courses.name: EOSC 555B Nonlinear Inverse Theory - NON-LINR INV THR
courses.description: Model construction, appraisal of nonuniqueness, and inference in nonlinear problems. Stochastic inverses, constrained optimization, joint inversions and image processing.

courses.name: APBI 410 Applied Animal Health and Physiology
courses.description: Application of physiology and pathology principles to health and disease of domestic animals.
courses.prerequisites: BIOL 201 and one of APBI 311, CAPS 301.

courses.name: EDCP 374A Design and Technology I - Secondary: Curriculum and Pedagogy - DSGN TEC I C&P
courses.description: Pass/Fail.

courses.name: ARCH 541 Professional Practice
courses.description: Ethical, legal and business context of professional practice, including contracts, project management.

courses.name: FOOD 529 Laboratory Methods in Sensory Evaluation
ECON 339 Economics of Technological Change
courses.description: Application of economic analysis to technological change; the impact of technological change on the growth and distribution of income; economic influences on the invention and diffusion of technology; the interaction between technology, work, skills, and education; public policy toward technological change.

courses.name: ELEC 491 Electrical Engineering Capstone Design Project
courses.description: Design, analysis, and implementation of solutions in response to a real world electrical engineering problem, provided by industry, research laboratories, or other suitable entities.  Includes coverage of topics such as project management.

courses.name: COMM 495 Business and Sustainable Development
courses.description: An overview of environmental issues, focusing on corporate strategy, government policy and interactions between these two sectors of the economy.

courses.name: MUSC 565C Asian Music Ensemble - KOREAN DRUMMING
courses.description: Study of Asian music, to include practical training in instrumental techniques and ensemble performance. The music of one major Asian civilization, often Chinese, will be emphasized.

courses.name: ARCH 549 Graduate Project Part II
courses.description: Design component, completion, and defense of the graduation design project.
courses.prerequisites: ARCH 548. (and no more than 18 credits outstanding beyond ARCH 549)

courses.name: CRWR 303A Intermediate Writing for Children and Young Adults - INTRMD WRIT CHIL
courses.description: The writing of work for children and young adults in various forms using a combination of workshopping and online modules. Manuscript submission not required for admission.

courses.name: CPEN 412 Microcomputer Systems Design
courses.description: Microprocessor and system buses; advanced I/O methods; priority interrupts; event/exception handling; serial I/O; computer networking; memory system design; interaction of hardware and software, microprocessor comparison, testability issues, safety critical systems.
courses.prerequisites: One of EECE 353, CPEN 311 and one of EECE 259, CPEN 211, EECE 355, CPEN 312.

courses.name: FIST 434A Studies in Film - STUDIES IN FILM
courses.description: A seminar devoted to a topic of current interest in film. Topic will change from year to year. May be repeated for credit when topics differ.

courses.name: ARCH 500 Architectural Design Studio I
courses.description: A series of projects focusing on conceptual development, design synthesis, principles of typology, organization and representation.

courses.name: BIOL 200 Fundamentals of Cell Biology
courses.description: Structure and function of plant and animal cells; membrane models, cytoplasmic organelles, biological information from gene to protein, the endomembrane system, secretion, intracellular digestion, endocytosis, transport processes, cytoskeleton and cell motility.
courses.prerequisites: Either (a) BIOL 112 and one of CHEM 123, CHEM 113;  or (b) SCIE 001. (or (c) 8 transfer credits of first-year BIOL and 6 credits of first-year CHEM or (d) one of BIOL 112 or BIOL 121 and a corequisite of CHEM 203.)

courses.name: COGS 303 Research Methods in Cognitive Systems
courses.description: Examination and comparison of the research methodologies of different disciplines relevant to cognitive systems.

courses.name: EDST 508D Review of Research in Educational Studies - REV RES ED STUDS
EPSE 687B Doctoral Practicum In School or Counselling Psychology - SCH CNS PSY PRAC
courses.description: Pass/Fail
courses.prerequisites: (Admission to the School Psychology or Counselling Psychology Ph.D. Program.)

courses.name: ARCH 523 Contemporary Theories in Architecture
courses.description: Theoretical propositions and their built manifestations.

courses.name: BIOL 209 Biodiversity of algae, fungi and bryophytes
courses.description: Diversity, ecology, cell biology and evolutionary origins of multicellular eukaryotes, illustrated through mosses and liverworts; fungi and slime molds; and fresh water and marine algae.
courses.prerequisites: Either (a) all of BIOL 121, BIOL 140 or (b) all of SCIE 001, BIOL 140. (or (c) 8 transfer credits of first-year biology.)

courses.name: CIVL 498A Topics in Civil Engineering - ENVRN STWSHP ENG
courses.description: Seminar or lecture. Registration will take place on the first day of class by the Instructor.

courses.name: LAW 316 International Law
courses.description: The history, sources and evidence of international law and its relation to municipal law; international personality; state jurisdiction; and treaties. Students who have taken POLI 465 cannot take this course.

courses.name: LAW 410 International Taxation
courses.description: The tax aspects of international transactions. Not offered each year; consult Faculty. Credit will be granted for only one of LAW 410 or LAW 565.

courses.name: BIOL 416 Principles of Conservation Biology
courses.description: Ecological basis of conserving biological diversity and ecosystem services; application of ecological theory to global and local conservation problems in the context of economic, legal, political, and social perspectives. Please consult the Faculty of Science Credit Exclusion List: www.students.ubc.ca/calendar/index.cfm?tree=12,215,410,414.
courses.prerequisites: One of BIOL 230, BIOL 303, BIOL 304, FRST 201.

courses.name: CHIN 311 Advanced Chinese Reading and Writing I (Heritage)
courses.description: Transition from language to literature. Can be taken concurrently with CHIN 315 and CHIN 341.

courses.name: ASTU 400X Interdisciplinary Studies in Arts - DSEMPD MOTHR
courses.description: For upper-division students in the Faculty of Arts. Topics announced annually.

courses.name: FOPR 261 Basic Geomatics for Natural Resources
courses.description: Techniques of measuring and surveying as they are applied in assessing and managing natural resources.

courses.name: ENGL 545A Studies in Canadian Literature - STUDIES CAN LIT
MATH 345 Applied Nonlinear Dynamics and Chaos
courses.description: Phase plane methods, bifurcation and stability theory, limit-cycle behavior and chaos for nonlinear differential equations with applications to the sciences.  Assignments involve the use of computers.
courses.prerequisites: A score of 68% or higher in one of MATH 215, MATH 255, MATH 256, MATH 265.

courses.name: GEOG 352 Urbanization in the Global South
courses.description: Urbanization in the developing countries of Latin America, Africa, and Asia; the role of cities in the development process and the features and problems of rapid urbanization.

courses.name: PATH 327 Bacteriology, Mycology, Virology and Parasitology
courses.description: Descriptions of each group of human microbial pathogens according to biological attributes, clinical features, pathogenesis and pathology, epidemiology, immunological reactions, laboratory diagnosis, principles of antimicrobial therapy, preventative measures. For students in the Faculty of Medicine B.M.L.Sc.

courses.name: POLI 461 Peace and Conflict Studies
courses.description: A seminar on a selected topic concerning the causes of war and strategies for the promotion of peace. For specific content in a given year, consult the departmental website.
courses.prerequisites: Two of POLI 260, POLI 360, POLI 361, POLI 362, POLI 363, POLI 364, POLI 365, POLI 366, POLI 367, POLI 368, POLI 369, POLI 370.

courses.name: FNH 477 Nutrition and Disease Prevention
courses.description: Evidence-based examination of the role of nutrition in the prevention of chronic disease. Restricted to students in majors in the FNH program.

courses.name: PLAN 548L Current Issues in Planning - CITIES BY CTZENS
courses.description: Each year the school may offer one or more courses on a topical issue covering recent advances in the field.

courses.name: BIOL 457 Comparative Environmental Physiology
courses.description: A survey of physiological adaptions of animals to different environments.

courses.name: MUSC 160A String Chamber Ensembles - STR CHAMB ENS
courses.description: May be repeated for credit in accordance with program requirements for B.Mus. or B.A. in Music. Open to other students by audition, with credit, as stipulated by their faculties.

courses.name: PHIL 375A Philosophy and Literature - PHILOSOPHY & LIT
courses.description: Philosophical issues in works of literature or arising from theories of literary interpretation. Topics include issues relating to relativism, the nature of morality, free will, personal identity, the nature of the emotions.

courses.name: POLI 420C Advanced Topics in Comparative Politics - ADV TPCS CMP PLI
courses.description: Seminar in comparative analysis of politics in democratic systems. For specific content in a given year, consult the departmental website.
courses.prerequisites: Two of POLI 220, POLI 320, POLI 321, POLI 322, POLI 323, POLI 324, POLI 325, POLI 326, POLI 327, POLI 328, POLI 329, POLI 330, POLI 331, POLI 332, POLI 333, POLI 350, POLI 351.

courses.name: CIVL 526 Virtual Design and Construction
courses.description: Creation and use of building information models (BIM) for managing the construction process. 3D parametric modeling, 4D modeling, design coordination, model-based cost estimating, BIM performance measurement, and integrated project delivery methods.

courses.name: CHEM 305 Biophysical Chemistry
courses.description: Diffusion and transport phenomena; interaction of radiation and matter. Methods for determining molecular weight, size, and shape of molecules in solution.
courses.prerequisites: One of MATH 200, MATH 217, MATH 226, MATH 253, MATH 263 and either (a) CHEM 201 or (b) a score of 76% or higher in CHEM 205 or (c) CHEM 304 or (d) PHYS 203.

courses.name: BIOC 548D Directed Studies - DIRECTED STUDIES
courses.description: In special cases, with approval of the department head, advanced courses may be arranged for graduate students in attendance.

courses.name: CIVL 520 Construction Planning and Control
courses.description: Planning of civil engineering projects using networking techniques and time space methods. Treatment of resources and cash flow. Activity planning. Concepts of control at the project and activity levels.

courses.name: CIVL 422 Project Based Learning in Civil Engineering Materials
courses.description: Some topical problems will be identified and students in groups will carry out experiments to study the materials involved. Site visits and external consultations are an integral requirement.

courses.name: GEOB 305 Introduction to Hydrology
courses.description: Principles of hydrology at site, watershed, and larger regional scales. Introduction to techniques of measurement and analysis. Emphasizes surface water hydrology of western North America.
courses.prerequisites: One of GEOB 200, GEOB 204, APBI 244, ATSC 201.

courses.name: FRST 386 Aquatic Ecosystems and Fish in Forested Watersheds
courses.description: Effects of forest management activities on fish and aquatic ecosystems.
courses.prerequisites: (Third- or fourth-year standing in Forestry, Science or Applied Science.)

courses.name: MUSC 550A Large Instrumental Ensemble - LARGE INST ENSEM
courses.description: Symphony Orchestra or Wind Ensemble. Open only to graduate students.

courses.name: COMM 320 Financial Accounting
courses.description: Preparation of financial statements and use of financial information contained in financial statements to make better decisions.

courses.name: EECE 535 Advanced Biophotonics
courses.description: Physical principles and design of optical microscopy, optical spectroscopy, and optical imaging devices and systems, and their applications in diagnostics and therapeutics.

courses.name: CHEM 514 Crystal Structures
courses.description: Crystal structures and structural analysis by the methods of X-ray diffraction and neutron diffraction. Credit will not be given for both CHEM 402 and CHEM 514.

courses.name: EECE 565 Communication Networks
courses.description: Analysis and design of communications networks; network architectures; Internet protocols; routing; scheduling algorithms; medium access control; congestion control; admission control; optimization techniques; network management.

courses.name: COMM 461 Sales Management
courses.description: Principles and practice of personal selling: strategy, tactics, and implementation.

courses.name: SPPH 543 Health Technology Assessment for Health Policy
courses.description: This course is an advanced program evaluation course.

courses.name: MECH 260 Introduction to Mechanics of Materials
courses.description: Statically determinate frames and trusses; normal and shear stresses and strains; shear force and bending moment diagrams; theory of beam bending, torsion of circular rods; transformation of stress and strain in two and three dimensions, Mohr's circle; yield and ultimate failure criteria.

courses.name: ASIA 411 Chinese Political Thought and Institutions
courses.description: Chinese theories and practices of government and administration from earliest times to 1949.

courses.name: SPAN 550B Studies in Peninsular and Latin-American Languages and Literatures - PEN&LAT AM L&LIT
LLED 212 Introduction to Language Communities and Variation in Language Practices
courses.description: Sociolinguistic analysis of language variation according to age, ethnicity, class, race, and gender, and how these variations function in both reflecting and constructing specific identities and memberships in society.

courses.name: VISA 230 Painting
courses.description: Development of a variety of techniques and approaches to painting. Emphasis on developing a strong paint vocabulary as well as acquiring knowledge of historical and contemporary issues in painting.
courses.prerequisites: A score of 72% or higher in VISA 110 and a score of 72% or higher in one of VISA 180, VISA 182 and a score of 72% or higher in VISA 183.

courses.name: CNPS 365 Introduction to Theories of Counselling
courses.description: An overview of selected theories of counselling.

courses.name: LAW 382 Law and Medicine
courses.description: Legal issues relating to medicine and the health care system.

courses.name: THTR 550 Studies in Historic Design
courses.description: Seminar in theatre scenery, costumes, and architecture of selected historical periods. Pre- or co-requisite: THTR 505 and THTR 506.

courses.name: MUSC 428F Topics in World Music - MUSIC-INDONESIA
courses.description: The history, theory, style, organology, and forms of the music of a particular culture in its aesthetic and cultural context. Students should consult the School as to which music culture will be covered in a particular year. May be repeated once for credit if different cultures are covered.

courses.name: CHEM 448A Directed Studies in Chemistry - T1 DST CHEMISTRY
courses.description: Students will undertake an investigation of a specific topic as agreed upon by the student and the faculty supervisor. Open to third- and fourth-year chemistry students.

courses.name: ENGL 301 Technical Writing
courses.description: Study of the principles of written communication in general business and professional activities, and practice in the preparation of abstracts, proposals, reports, and correspondence. This course is closed to first- and second-year students in Arts.  Not for credit towards the English Major or Minor.
courses.prerequisites: Either (a) ARTS 001 or (b) two of ENGL 100, ENGL 110, ENGL 111, ENGL 112, ENGL 120, ENGL 121 or (c) ASTU 100 or (d) ASTU 150 and one of ENGL 110, ENGL 111, ENGL 120, ENGL 121;  or (e) WRDS 150 and one of ENGL 110, ENGL 111, ENGL 120, ENGL 121. (Or 6 credits of first-year English.)

courses.name: ASTU 400U Interdisciplinary Studies in Arts - BILNGLM
courses.description: For upper-division students in the Faculty of Arts. Topics announced annually.

courses.name: HIST 547D Readings: Special Topics in History - SPEC TOPICS HIST
PLAN 524 Legal Concepts for Professional Planning
PHIL 434A Business and Professional Ethics - BUS & PROF ETHIC
courses.description: Moral problems in contemporary business and professional practice, general moral theory, the law, and policy formation. Corporate social and environmental responsibility, employee rights, preferential hiring and affirmative action programs, conflicts of interest, advertising, "whistle blowing" and self-regulation.

courses.name: EOSC 511 Numerical Techniques for Ocean, Atmosphere and Earth Scientists
courses.description: This course is Web-based. Credit will not be granted for both ATSC 409 and ATSC 506/EOSC 511.

courses.name: ASIA 378 Philosophical Wisdom of Early India
courses.description: Epistemological and ontological thought from the Vedic period to the period of the rise of philosophical schools or systems Philosophy in the Mahabharata, Gita; early Buddhist and Jain views on knowledge and reality; views on language.

courses.name: LARC 316 Trees and Shrubs in Landscape
courses.description: Culture and identification of landscape materials with emphasis on woody plants. Elementary principles of landscape composition.  Suitable for students of other faculties and departments interested in landscape materials and their uses, but priority given to  Agroecology and Landscape Architecture students.

courses.name: SPAN 364 Survey of Spanish-American Literature and Culture to the 1820s
courses.prerequisites: One of SPAN 220, SPAN 221 and SPAN 302.
courses.corequisites: (SPAN 302 may be taken as a corequisite, with the permission of the instructor or the Spanish Major Adviser.)

courses.name: MINE 303 Rock Mechanics Fundamentals
courses.description: The study of the mechanical and structural properties of rock materials at the laboratory and field level. The relevance of such studies to common mining, geological and civil engineering problems. Credit will be granted for only one of MINE 303 or MINE 305.
courses.prerequisites: One of CIVL 230, MECH 260. (MINE 290 is recommended.)

courses.name: HIST 313 Africa from Imperialism to Independence
courses.description: The history of Africa in the 19th and 20th Centuries: the growth of Islam and Christianity, the impact of European colonialism, the development of nationalism, and the variety of different political and social outcomes after independence.

courses.name: LATN 401C Latin Prose - LATIN PROSE
courses.description: Studies in history, oratory and/or philosophy. May be repeated for up to 12 credits.

courses.name: CPEN 421 Software Project Management
courses.description: Advanced project planning, cost estimation and scheduling. Project management tools. Factors influencing productivity and success. Productivity metrics. Analysis of options and risk. Tools. Case studies.

courses.name: MUSC 414 Counterpoint
courses.description: Analysis and comosition of pieces that rely on the control and development of imitative, polyphonic textures. Models to be taken from one or more European historical repertoires.

courses.name: MICB 448B Directed Research - DIRECTED RESRCH
courses.description: A library (3 credits) or laboratory (3 or 6 credits) project. Requires permission of the Undergraduate Advisor. The results are presented in a written report to be reviewed by oral examination.
courses.prerequisites: Either (a) MICB 323 or (b) all of MICB 322, MICB 399.

courses.name: FRST 529 Ecological Economics
courses.description: Emphasis on forested ecosystems.

courses.name: ITAL 301 Third-Year Italian I
courses.description: Reading, writing, speaking, comprehension. Special emphasis on oral practice and on composition.
courses.prerequisites: One of ITAL 202, ITAL 203. (Or permission of the department.)

courses.name: COMM 412 Negotiation
courses.description: Negotiation simulations to provide experience and confidence in the negotiation process and to develop effective skills for achieving objectives.

courses.name: PSYT 550B Directed Studies - DIRECTED STUDIES
courses.description: Reading and study in particular fields of study and research in psychiatry.

courses.name: AUDI 516C Discourse Analysis - DISCOURSE ANYL
courses.description: May be taken more than once for credit.

courses.name: SCIE 001 Science One
courses.description: An innovative first-year multidisciplinary course incorporating biology, chemistry, mathematics, and physics with a strong focus on the connections between these traditional disciplines.  See the Science One website (www.scienceone.ubc.ca)  for further information and the application process for admission to SCIE 001.
courses.prerequisites: Either (a) BIOL 11 or (b) BIOL 12;  and all of CHEM 12, CALC 12, PHYS 12, ENGL 12. (and Principles of Mathematics 12 or Pre-calculus 12.)

courses.name: ANTH 495A Advanced Studies in Anthropology - ADV STUDIES
courses.description: An intensive examination of selected topics in Anthropology. Consult the Department for this year's offerings.

courses.name: GEOG 419 Research in Environmental Geography
courses.description: Details available from Geography Undergraduate Advisor. Not necessarily offered each year.
courses.prerequisites: (Major or Honours in Geography with at least 75 credits, or permission of the instructor.)

courses.name: MINE 555 Mining and Society
courses.description: Discussion of social, political and technical topics concerning mining-related activities. Credit will be granted for only one of MINE 555 or MINE 583.

courses.name: CEEN 596 Project and Report
courses.description: For M.Eng. students. Carry out a project and prepare an engineering report under the supervision of a faculty member.

courses.name: PCTH 513 Pharmacology of Anaesthesia
courses.description: Pharmacology of drugs used in anaesthesia. Conferences, assigned reading and laboratory exercises demonstrating the actions of drugs as currently applied in the practice of anaesthesia.
courses.prerequisites: (Permission of the department head is required.)

courses.name: PHYS 158 Introductory Physics for Engineers II
courses.description: Electricity and magnetism, DC and AC circuits, optics. Please consult the Faculty of Science Credit Exclusion List: www.students.ubc.ca/calendar/index.cfm?tree=12,215,410,414.
courses.corequisites: One of MATH 101, MATH 103, MATH 105, MATH 121.

courses.name: ECON 590C Special Advanced Course - SPEC ADV CRSE
ECON 465 Market Structure
courses.description: Market structure and social welfare, theory of price discrimination, equilibrium in oligopolistic markets, entry and exit decisions, product differentiation and spatial models, theories of hierarchical organization, agency problem in the modern corporation, vertical integration and control, market structure and technical progress.

courses.name: COHR 305 Strategic Compensation
courses.description: Employee compensation, including pay systems, benefits systems, and rewards and recognition programs. Examination of the motivational underpinnings of compensation administration and the application of compensation principles to the achievement of employer strategic objectives.
courses.prerequisites: COMM 292 and one of COMM 203, COMM 392.

courses.name: LIBE 494B Supervised Study in Teacher Librarianship - SUPR ST TCH LIBR
SPPH 544 Socal Determinants of Health Across the Life Course
courses.description: The social determinants of health have profound impacts on inequities across the life course, as do population-level interventions. Builds on SPPH 527, with an emphasis on life course perspectives and vulnerable populations.

courses.name: MUSC 241 Class Piano II
courses.description: Continuation of MUSC 141.

courses.name: ARCH 545A Directed Studies in Architecture - DRECTD STDY ARCH
courses.description: Directed research and exploration of selected topics in architecture.

courses.name: EDCP 356 Earth and Space Science - Secondary: Curriculum and Pedagogy
courses.description: Pass/Fail.
courses.prerequisites: (A completed concentration in earth and space science or permission of the Head.)

courses.name: MTRL 250 Metallurgical Thermodynamics I
courses.description: Thermodynamic and electrochemical principles applied to metallurgical processes; phase rule, heat of reaction, free energy, activity, thermodynamic equilibrium; thermodynamics of aqueous solutions.

courses.name: KIN 489F Seminar - SEMINAR
courses.description: Current topics and research in specific areas.
courses.prerequisites: (Fourth-year standing. Consult with Advisor for specific prerequisites.)

courses.name: LAW 435D Topics in Tort Law - TPCS IN TORT LAW
courses.description: Not offered each year, consult Faculty.

courses.name: PSYC 333 Memory: Historical, Clinical and Cognitive Perspectives
courses.description: Classical and contemporary metaphors for memory and their impact on theory development.
courses.prerequisites: Either (a) PSYC 100 or (b) all of PSYC 101, PSYC 102. (or (c) 6 credits of 200-level Psychology (but not 205 or 263). Non-PSYC students may substitute LING 460 or LING 200 and 201 for the above prerequisite.)

courses.name: BIOL 203 Eukaryotic Microbiology
courses.description: Introduction to the origin and diversity of protists (protozoa and algae) at both cellular and genomic levels, including the role of endosymbiosis in evolution.
courses.prerequisites: BIOL 140 and one of BIOL 121, SCIE 001. (BIOL 200 recommended.)

courses.name: FIPR 233 Video Production I
courses.description: Camera operation, lighting, sounds, and editing for video production.

courses.name: MATH 498 Co-operative Work Placement III
courses.description: Approved and supervised technical work experience involving mathematics in industry for a minimum of 3 1/2 months. Technical report required. Restricted to students admitted to the Mathematics Co-operative Education Program.

courses.name: AUDI 520B Phonological Development, Assessment and Intervention - PHON DEV, AS, IN
CHEM 333 Spectroscopic Techniques in Organic Chemistry
courses.description: Application of mass spectrometry, and NMR, UV/visible, and IR spectroscopies to organic chemical problems.
courses.prerequisites: Either (a) all of CHEM 203, CHEM 204 or (b) all of CHEM 233, CHEM 205 or (c) CHEM 213.

courses.name: GRSJ 328 Feminist Theories of Subjectivity
courses.description: How feminist scholarship has shaped and reinterpreted accounts of the subject, drawing on such traditions as structuralism, poststructuralism, psychoanalysis, postcolonialism, postmodernism, and Queer Theory.
courses.prerequisites: Either (a) all of GRSJ 101, GRSJ 102 or (b) all of WMST 101, WMST 102. (or third-year standing.)

courses.name: COMM 547B Major Essay/Industry Project - MAJOR ESSAY/PROJ
LLED 223 Introduction to the Nature of World Englishes
courses.description: Exploration of the emergence of new English varieties, as well as a critical examination of main reasons linked to the rise of English worldwide and its proposed role as a neutral global language.

courses.name: ARCH 573D Seminar: Environmental Studies - REGENERATVE DSGN
courses.description: An investigation of specialized environmental topics concerning theory and the practice of architecture.

courses.name: CLST 318 Classical Comedy
courses.description: The plays of the Greek and Roman comic dramatists: Aristophanes, Menander, Plautus and Terence, in translation.

courses.name: ASTR 405 Astronomical Laboratory
courses.description: Experiments in the use of astronomical instrumentation and data analysis. Use of the 40-cm reflector, spectrograph and electronic detectors. Photometric and spectroscopic analysis of digital data.

courses.name: CHEM 449 Seminar and Thesis
courses.description: Original research work under the direction of a faculty member. Weekly seminar. Required of all Honours students. Open to Majors students with a satisfactory standing and permission of the department head.

courses.name: LIBR 559M Topics in Computer-Based Information Systems - TPCS CP-BSED INF
EDST 540B Locating Oneself in Global Learning - GLOB LEARN
CIVL 228 Introduction to Structural Engineering
courses.description: Static determinacy, stability, superposition, analysis and design of trusses, deflection of trusses by principles of virtual work, statically indeterminate trusses, beams and frames, cables and arches, design objectives, loads and load combinations, structural safety, load paths, design of simple steel, timber, and reinforced concrete members.

courses.name: CHEM 540C Seminar in Chemistry - INORGANIC SEMINR
courses.description: Compulsory for all graduate students in Chemistry. Pass/Fail.

courses.name: POLI 562B Topics in International Relations - TOP IN INTER REL
MATH 401 Green's Functions and Variational Methods
courses.description: Green's functions for partial differential equations. Calculus of variations. Eigenfunction expansions. Rayleigh-Ritz and finite element methods.  See Faculty of Science credit exclusion list: http://www.calendar.ubc.ca/vancouver/index.cfm?tree=12,215,410,414.
courses.prerequisites: Either (a) a score of 80% or higher in one of MATH 256, MATH 257, MATH 316 or (b) MATH 400.

courses.name: NURS 422 Clincial Nursing Focus: Childbearing Families
courses.description: Credit is given for one of NURS 420, 422, 423, 424, or 425.
courses.prerequisites: All of NURS 302, NURS 303, NURS 304, NURS 305, NURS 306, NURS 333, NURS 334, NURS 335, NURS 336, NURS 337, NURS 338, NURS 339, NURS 340, NURS 341, NURS 342, NURS 343.

courses.name: COMM 296 Introduction to Marketing
courses.description: Basic considerations affecting the domestic and international marketing of goods and services.

courses.name: LLED 441 Introduction to Teaching Children's Literature
APBI 416 Animal Welfare and Conservation Biology
courses.description: Evaluation of humane treatment of individual animals living in the wild and managed within conservation biology. Assessment of attitudes and viewpoints of the role of animal welfare in conservation biology.
courses.prerequisites: (Third-year standing or higher. APBI 315 and BIOL 416 or CONS 220/330 recommended.)

courses.name: NURS 424 Clincial Nursing Focus: Individuals and Families with  Mental Health Concerns
courses.description: Credit is given for one of NURS 420, 422, 423, 424, or 425.
courses.prerequisites: All of NURS 302, NURS 303, NURS 304, NURS 305, NURS 306, NURS 333, NURS 334, NURS 335, NURS 336, NURS 337, NURS 338, NURS 339, NURS 340, NURS 341, NURS 342, NURS 343.

courses.name: RUSS 207 Twentieth-Century Russian Writers in Translation
courses.description: The writings, lives, and thought of major Russian authors.

courses.name: CAPS 498 Cooperative Work Placement III
courses.description: Approved and supervised relevant work experience in an industrial, academic, or government setting for a minimum of 13 weeks full time. Work term report required. Restricted to students admitted to the Co-op Option in Honours Cellular, Anatomical and Physiological Sciences (B.Sc.).

courses.name: ITST 345 Italian Fascism in Interdisciplinary Perspective
courses.description: The cultural, literary, philosophical roots of Fascism and its evolution: its policies in literature, sports, cinema, architecture, racial legislation, and colonial adventures.

courses.name: MECH 225 Integration of Engineering Concepts II
courses.description: Integration of the theory and practice of Mechanical Engineering to illustrate the commonality and conceptual connectivity of seemingly different technical areas. Emphasis on thermodynamics, fluid mechanics, and mathematics.

courses.name: EOSC 250 Fields and Fluxes
courses.description: Application of classical theory of scalar and vector fields to geophysical sciences. Conductive, convective and radiative energy flux, gravitation, electrostatics, and magnetostatics. Gauss' and Stokes' theorems.
courses.prerequisites: One of PHYS 101, PHYS 107, PHYS 117, PHYS 157.

courses.name: CAPS 200 Biomedical Research: Essential Skills and Concepts
courses.description: Analysis of the underlying questions and assumptions, experimental approach, results and significance of work described in selected biomedical research presentations.
courses.prerequisites: BIOL 200. (Limited to students in second year.)

courses.name: BIOC 548A Directed Studies - DIRECTED STUDIES
courses.description: In special cases, with approval of the department head, advanced courses may be arranged for graduate students in attendance.

courses.name: COMM 477 Risk Management and Financial Engineering
courses.description: Principles of financial engineering and risk management. Use of derivatives in risk management. Valuation and hedging models for contingent claims.

courses.name: EOSC 478 Introduction to Fisheries Science
courses.description: An introduction to the ecology and management of freshwater and marine fisheries. Topics include: population dynamics, species interactions, communities, environmental influences, stock assessment, economics and sociology of fisheries. Laboratories will consist of numerical analyses and simulations.

courses.name: GEOB 448B Directed Studies in Geographical Biogeoscience - DS GEOGCL BIOSCI
courses.description: For fourth-year students in Geography to permit investigation of a topic to be agreed upon by a member of the faculty and the student. Permission of the department head and of a supervisory faculty member is required. Credit will be given for only one of GEOB 448 and GEOG 448.

courses.name: PSYC 401 Clinical Psychology
courses.description: Theoretical and research foundations of the processes of assessment and behaviour modification in clinical psychology. Credit will not be given for both PSYC 400 and PSYC 401.

courses.name: ORPA 725 Bone Tumour Registry
courses.description: A review of musculoskeletal oncology and related problems with presentation of clinical and laboratory information, radiographs and pathological materials. One and one-half hours monthly.

courses.name: INDS 530D Directed Studies - DIRECTED STUDIES
courses.description: A series of directed readings related to student's area of interdisciplinary studies. This advanced course may be taken upon approval of the Program head.

courses.name: EOSC 315 The Ocean Ecosystem
courses.description: An introduction to life in the oceans, its variety and evolution; primary producers and their links to the environment, zooplankton, marine communities, living marine resources and their role in today's world. Not for credit in the Faculties of Science or Applied Science.

courses.name: MECH 220 Technical Skills Practicum
courses.description: Engineering graphics, spatial visualization, CAD, equation solvers, machine shop practice, electronic circuit construction and troubleshooting, elements of engineering science.
courses.prerequisites: All of MATH 101, MATH 152, PHYS 170 and one of APSC 150, APSC 151 and either (a) PHYS 153 or (b) all of PHYS 157, PHYS 158, PHYS 159.

courses.name: EDCP 313A Choral Pedagogy: Secondary - CHORAL PDY: SEC

courses.description: Methods and applications of statistics in business; data analysis, descriptive regression; data generation; sampling distributions; hypothesis testing; confidence intervals; two sample problems; inference in regression.

courses.name: MINE 590V Special Advanced Topics - CLIMATE CHNG MNG
courses.description: A special advanced course may be arranged upon the approval of the department head.

courses.name: ARBC 201 Classical Arabic (Intermediate) I
courses.description: Increased reading ability as well as learning the further essentials of grammar.

courses.name: EDUC 496G Practicum (Secondary) for Previously Certified Teachers - TEACH PRACT SECD
courses.description: Pass/Fail.
courses.prerequisites: (Recent completion of secondary teaching methods courses in the subjects to be taught.)

courses.name: AUDI 570 Case Studies in Phonological Intervention and Aural (Re)habilitation
CNPS 588C Supervised Training in Counselling - SUPRVSD TRAINING
courses.description: Initial counselling experience under faculty supervision in department training centres.

courses.name: HIST 333B Third-Year Honours Seminar - 3RD YR HONRS SEM
FREN 123 Contemporary French Language and Literature II
courses.description: Continuation of FREN 122 with emphasis on literature, essay writing and textual analysis.
courses.prerequisites: FREN 122. (or assignment based on placement test.)

courses.name: EPSE 316 Learning Disabilities
courses.description: Identification, assessment and needs of children with learning disabilities.

courses.name: APSC 412 Co-operative Work Placement
courses.description: Supervised, technical work experience in an approved company or organization for a minimum of three months. Technical report. Restricted to students meeting the requirements of the Faculty of Applied Science and Co-operative Education Programs.

courses.name: ANTH 545A Graduate Research Seminar - GRAD RSRCH SEM
EPSE 519 Development of English Language Skills of Deaf and Hard of Hearing Students
CHEM 313 Advanced Organic Chemistry for the Life Sciences
courses.description: Chemistry of organic substances having particular relevance to the life sciences.

courses.name: RMST 234 Introduction to Romance Language Cinema
EOSC 474 Marine Pollution
courses.description: An interdisciplinary study of pollution, with examples drawn from coastal and oceanic environments, including areas of local interest. Intended for third and fourth year students with a background in the sciences.

courses.name: BIOC 399 Internship Work Placement II
courses.description: Approved and supervised technical work experience in an industrial or academic research setting for four months. Technical report required. Restricted to students admitted to the Internship Program in Biochemistry and Molecular Biology.

courses.name: WOOD 310 Co-operative Work Placement
courses.description: Approved and supervised work experience with a public or private organization for a minimum of 13 weeks full-time. Final work term assignment required. Restricted to students in the Co-operative Education Program in Wood Products Processing.

courses.name: PHYS 473 Applied Nuclear Physics
courses.description: Radioactive decay and radiations, nuclear properties, interactions of neutrons, physical principles of power reactors, nuclear fusion, radiation monitoring, and safety.

courses.name: SPPH 607 Ph.D. Research Seminar
courses.description: Required course in Ph.D. program. Topics of current interest will be presented and discussed by students and various faculty.

courses.name: NURS 590S Directed Studies in Nursing - DIRECTED STUDIES
FREN 112 Intermediate French II
courses.description: Not available for credit to students with FREN 12.

courses.name: MUSC 528A Seminar in Music Since 1900 - EARLY MODERNISM

courses.name: CNPS 598H Field Experiences - FIELD EXPERIENCE
courses.description: For students in the master's program. Pass/Fail.

courses.name: THTR 499A Production III - PRODUCTION III
courses.description: Assigned projects in Theatre or Film design and production.
courses.corequisites: One of THTR 405, THTR 406, THTR 407, THTR 408, THTR 450, THTR 452, THTR 454, THTR 456, THTR 470.

courses.name: PSYC 335 Gambling and Decision Making
courses.description: The psychology of gambling behaviour, with emphasis on relevant work from judgment and decision-making, the cognitive neuroscience of choice, and clinical perspectives on disordered gambling.
courses.prerequisites: Either (a) PSYC 100 or (b) all of PSYC 101, PSYC 102.

courses.name: APBI 496A Applied Animal Biology Practicum - APBI PRACTICUM
courses.description: Application of principles and concepts of Applied Animal Biology to experiential learning in the fields of wild, companion, lab, and farm animal welfare and management.
courses.prerequisites: (Third-year standing or higher. APBI 314 and/or APBI 315 are recommended.)

courses.name: BAMS 523 Managerial Decisions Modeling and Analytics
SOWK 601 Social Work Doctoral Seminar
courses.description: Critical examination of research, teaching, proposal writing and publication.

courses.name: ARST 592A Directed Research Project - DIRECTED RES PRJ

courses.prerequisites: Either (a) CPSC 221 or (b) all of CPSC 260, EECE 320. (In addition to above pre-requisites: either (a) 6 credits of 2nd Yr. MATH or STAT or (b) 3 credits of 2nd Yr. MATH or STAT with a grade of 72% or better.)

courses.name: LAW 400 Advanced Criminal Procedure
courses.description: Selected topics relating to procedural law and practice in criminal matters. Credit will be granted for only one of LAW 260 or LAW 400.

courses.name: ANTH 213 Sex, Gender, and Culture
courses.description: An anthropological exploration of how understandings of sex and gender are culturally and historically shaped.

courses.name: AUDI 579 Practicum in Audiology for Speech-Language Pathology Majors
LLED 556A Theory and Research in Early Literacy - TH&RES EARLY LIT

courses.description: Research-based studio with thematic or disciplinary focus.  Intended for senior Visual Art undergraduate students.
courses.prerequisites: Three of VISA 310, VISA 311, VISA 320, VISA 321, VISA 330, VISA 331, VISA 340, VISA 341, VISA 350, VISA 351, VISA 360, VISA 361, VISA 370, VISA 390.

courses.name: MINE 224 Mineralogy for Mining Engineering
courses.description: Fundamentals of the main techniques used by the industry to characterize raw materials and troubleshoot processing plants.

courses.name: WOOD 225 Communications Strategies
courses.description: Strategies for thinking critically and writing effectively about topics that engage practitioners in Forestry, particularly in Wood Products Processing.  Planning, drafting and editing of professional-quality documents for specialists and other stakeholders. Developing oral presentation skills.

courses.name: LAW 343C Topics in Public Law - TPCS PUBLIC LAW
courses.description: Not offered each year, consult Faculty.

courses.name: LLED 454 Adolescent Literacies: Processes and Practices
courses.prerequisites: (or corequisite: an introductory-level reading, language arts, or English education course.)

courses.name: PLAN 592 Urban Restructuring

courses.name: LIBR 574 Project Management in Information Organizations

courses.prerequisites: A score of 68% or higher in all of ECON 101, ECON 102, MATH 104, MATH 105.

courses.name: CCFI 580B Problems in Education - PROB IN EDUC
courses.description: Investigation and report of a problem.

courses.name: SPHA 532 Health Economics
courses.description: Economic strengths and weaknesses of current arrangements, and the prospects and objectives of various proposals for reform.

courses.name: SOWK 524A Social Services Management - SO SRV MGMT

courses.description: Indicators of maternal/newborn well-being across population subgroups, changing trends in obstetrical intervention, perinatal morbidity, and the analysis of perinatal data.

courses.name: HIST 403K Seminar in the History of International Relations - INTRNATNL RELTNS
courses.description: Selected topics in the history of international relations. Priority for registration will be given to fourth-year majors in the International Relations and History programs.

courses.name: ARTH 339 19th-Century Art and Social Space
courses.description: Ideologies of gender, class, race, ethnicity, and economics in 19th-century European and American visual culture.

courses.name: LAW 386 Sustainable Development Law
courses.description: The linkages, intersections, and tensions between the legal regulation of the environment and competing social and economic priorities.

courses.name: HIST 305 British Columbia

Topics will emphasize changes in the economic, social, and institutional structures of the province. Credit will only be granted for one of HIST 305 or 404, if 404 was taken before 2007W.

courses.name: PSYC 301 Brain Dysfunction and Recovery

courses.prerequisites: Either (a) PSYC 100 or (b) all of PSYC 101, PSYC 102. (Or 6 credits of 200-level PSYC (but not PSYC 205 or PSYC 263).)

courses.name: BA 507 Integration and Professional Development: Global
FIPR 337 Cinematography and Lighting I
courses.description: Introductory cinematography and lighting techniques and aesthetics for 16mm film and video.

courses.name: ETEC 531 Curriculum Issues in Cultural and New Media Studies
NURS 542 Social Epidemiology: Special Populations

courses.name: CLST 503B Studies in Greek Architecture - GREEK ARCH
courses.description: Selected topics in Greek architecture, e.g., religious, secular, and military architecture.

courses.name: DHYG 402 Dental Hygiene Practice I

courses.name: CLST 110 Golden Age of Athens

courses.description: Sociological perspectives on property, resource industries (such as agriculture, fishing, forestry and mining), resource development, and resource communities. May also include examination of social aspects of resource development in the Third World.

courses.name: MUSC 593A Music Performance (Major) - KEYBOARD INST'S
courses.description: Private instruction, vocal or instrumental. May be repeated for credit, in accordance with program requirements.

courses.name: PHAR 409 Renal Pharmacotherapeutics
courses.description: Case-based approach to the pathophysiology, pharmacology, clinical pharmacokinetics, and pharmacotherapy in nephrology with emphasis on the integration and application of fundamental principles to clinical situations in class and during their experiential component.
courses.prerequisites: (Successful completion of all required courses in the first three years of the pharmacy curriculum.)

courses.name: BIOL 140 Laboratory Investigations in Life Science
courses.description: Guided experimental investigations of biological questions.

courses.name: MTRL 392 Engineering Technical Communication
courses.description: Written and oral technical communication. Report preparation and oral presentation of technical information.

courses.name: MUSC 235 Opera Repertoire II
courses.description: See MUSC 135.

courses.name: COMM 204 Logistics and Operations Management

courses.name: THTR 407 Lighting Design II

Velocity and flow rate measurement techniques. Flow visualization. Case studies of industrial and research experimental practice. Credit will not be given for both MECH 489 and MECH 582.

courses.name: STAT 305 Introduction to Statistical Inference
courses.description: Review of probability theory. Sampling distribution theory, large sample theory and methods of estimation and hypothesis testing, including maximum likelihood estimation, likelihood ratio testing and confidence interval construction.
courses.prerequisites: Either (a) one of STAT 200, BIOL 300 and one of MATH 302, STAT 302;  or (b) a score of 65% or higher in one of MATH 302, STAT 302. (STAT 200 or BIOL 300 is recommended.)

courses.name: GERM 402 Words and Music in German Literature (in English)
courses.description: Study of individual works and genres in which words and music together form a whole. Possible topics include the Lutheran Hymn, the Volkslied, the Romantic Lied and Brecht songs, operas by Mozart, Wagner and Strauss, and music and the musician as a subject in literature. No musical training is necessary to take this course.

courses.name: ARTH 345 History of Photography: Archive, Spectacle, Reality
courses.description: History and theory of photography, from the competitive context of invention in the 1830s to contemporary uses in social media.

courses.name: ENGL 364A Nineteenth-Century Studies - 19TH CENT STDY
courses.prerequisites: (3rd year standing and 6 credits of first-year English, or Arts One, or 6 credits of ASTU 100 from CAP or 3 credits of first-year English and 3 credits of ASTU 150)

courses.name: POLI 352A Comparative Politics of Public Policy - COMP POLI & PP
courses.description: Policy making across industrialized democracies, with a focus on North America and Europe.

courses.name: LIBE 477B Special Topics in Teacher Librarianship - SP TPCS TCH LIBR
courses.description: In-depth study of selected topics in library education.

courses.name: PSYC 546B Seminar in Psychological Problems - ANLY OF VARIANCE
ISCI 320 Research Development Project
courses.description: Retreat to develop skills in writing scientific research proposals.  Emphasis on formulating and testing hypotheses to explain observations.  Course location will vary; fee payable prior to retreat.
courses.prerequisites: (Third-year standing in the Faculty of Science.)

courses.name: FRST 516 Tree Physiology
courses.description: Growth and development of woody plants; physiological responses to abiotic and biotic environmental factors; consequences of silvicultural practices on physiological processes.

courses.name: MINE 590M Special Advanced Topics - INTRO ROCK MECH
courses.description: A special advanced course may be arranged upon the approval of the department head.

courses.name: EDUC 490E Special Studies in Education - SPEC STUDIES ED
