courses.name: EECE 534 Green Nanoelectronic Devices
courses.description: The fundamentals for operation, fabrication of green electronic devices using nanomaterials for generation, storage and management of clean electrical energy are presented. Examples include photovoltaic devices, light-emitting diodes, piezoelectric scavengers, thermoelectric devices, and batteries.

courses.name: LLED 572A Theory and Research in Teaching English as a Second Language - RESEARCH IN ESL
courses.prerequisites: (Admission into the TESL Graduate Program or permission of instructor.)

courses.name: ELEC 343 Electromechanics
courses.description: Electromechanical energy conversion; linear actuators; torque/speed of rotating devices; reluctance, stepper, permanent-magnet, induction, brushless-DC motors and DC motors; actuator/motor drive circuits/controllers. Credit will be granted for only one of EECE 365, ELEC 344, EECE 370, EECE 373, ELEC 342, EECE 374, EECE 376, or ELEC 343.
courses.prerequisites: One of EECE 253, ELEC 202, EECE 363, ELEC 302.

courses.name: ARTH 561A Studies in the Indigenous Arts of the Americas - AMER INDIG ART
SANS 200 Intermediate Sanskrit
courses.description: Advanced grammar and selected readings. As of 2011W, credit will be granted for only one of SANS 201/202 or SANS 200.

courses.name: LLED 211 Field Research in Social Processes of Inclusion and Exclusion: Discourse Perspectives
courses.description: Roles that social discourses of inclusion and exclusion play in intercultural integration.

courses.name: FNEL 281 Sounds of Endangered Languages: Conservation and Revitalization
courses.description: Development of skills in the perception and transcription of speech sounds in endangered languages, focusing on the diversity within BC Aboriginal languages. Capacity-building techniques for digital recording, editing, analysis, and archiving; guided by community-based ethical protocols and conservation/revitalization goals.

courses.name: CHEM 335 Chemistry Integrated Laboratory II
courses.description: Further development of principles and techniques of modern chemistry applied by integrating experiments chosen from organic, inorganic, physical, and analytical chemistry.

courses.name: PATH 306 Laboratory Safety for Medical Laboratory Scientists
courses.description: Control processes for workplace hazards of radiological, chemical, and biological origin.

courses.name: ENGL 321 English Grammar and Usage
courses.description: Descriptive approaches to the English Language

courses.name: SURG 502 Surgical Core - POS Series
courses.description: The basic principles of surgery common to all branches of surgery.

courses.name: LING 200 Linguistic Theory and Analysis I
courses.description: Introduction to phonetics and phonology; training in the identification and production of speech sounds; principles and methods for describing and writing the sound system of a language; phonological theory with reference to selected languages; the interface between phonology and morphology. Analytical practice and seminar discussion.

courses.name: BAEN 580A Topics in Entrepreneurship - TPCS ENTREPR'SHP
COMM 634 Empirical Research Methods in Information Systems
SPPH 505 Scientific Basis for Epidemiological Thinking
courses.description: The course will provide a framework for students to use epidemiological and other scientific evidence to make decisions about causation and to recommend policy actions.

courses.name: GREK 502A Greek Verse - GREEK VERSE
courses.description: Epic, tragedy and/or comedy.  Credit will not be given for both GREK 402 and GREK 502.

courses.name: AUDI 547B Directed Reading in Audiology and Speech Sciences - DIR READ AUDI&SP
courses.description: May be taken more than once.

courses.name: LAW 483C Competitive Moots and Advocacy Credit A - COMP MOOTSA
courses.description: Appellate and related forms of advocacy. Restricted to students representing the Faculty for the first time in an approved advocacy competition.

courses.name: SOWK 405 Social Work Practice II
courses.description: This course examines the principles of optimal social work process with individuals, small groups, families and larger collectivities.

courses.name: ASTR 310 Exploring the Universe I: The Solar System
courses.description: A survey of recent discoveries about the planets and other objects in the solar system, without the use of advanced mathematics. The Sun, the existence of planetary systems around other stars, and the search for life. Not open to first year students and not for credit in the Faculties of Science and Applied Science.

courses.name: LLED 210 Introduction to Analyzing Meanings of Images in Texts
courses.description: Systematic analysis of visual and verbal modalities in academic and professional registers through a "grammar" designed for this purpose.

courses.name: CHBE 493 Thesis Proposal-Environmental Topic
courses.description: Literature search, planning, equipment design for an individual research project leading to a written proposal and oral presentation. Topic to be chosen from a selection of environmental topics offered by the department.

courses.name: ECON 567 Organization Theory and Non-market Allocation
LLED 450 Teaching and Learning Language and Literacy: Kindergarten and Primary Grades
courses.prerequisites: (An introductory-level reading or language arts education course)

courses.name: MATH 104 Differential Calculus with Applications to Commerce and Social Sciences
courses.description: Derivatives and rates of change, exponential and trigonometric functions, Newton's method, Taylor polynomials, maxima and minima, and graphing. Please consult the Faculty of Science Credit Exclusion List: www.calendar.ubc.ca/vancouver/index.cfm?tree=12,215,410,414.
courses.prerequisites: (High-school calculus and one of (a) a grade of 80% or higher in BC Principles of Mathematics 12  or Pre-calculus 12, or (b) a satisfactory score in the UBC Mathematics Basic Skills Test.)

courses.name: BIOL 352 Plant Physiology II: Plant Development
courses.description: Introduction to the processes involved in growth and development: cell division, tissue culture, meristems, differentiation, and the action of major growth regulators, and photomorphogenesis. Emphasis on experimental approaches.
courses.prerequisites: Either (a) BIOL 200 and one of BIOL 233, BIOL 234;  or (b) one of BIOL 334, FRST 302. (CHEM 233 is recommended.)

courses.name: ATSC 448B Directed Studies - DIR STUDY
courses.description: Investigation of a topic to be agreed upon by a member of the faculty and the student.  Permission of the undergraduate advisor and of the supervising faculty member is required before registration.

courses.name: SOCI 217A Research Methods - RESEARCH METHODS
courses.description: Introduction to research designs and methodologies.

courses.name: ANAT 550 Current Topics in the Morphological Sciences
courses.description: Lectures, demonstrations, discussions and student seminars on selected and current topics in cell biology and the anatomical sciences. Attendance is required of all M.Sc. and Ph.D. students in Anatomy and Cell Biology.
courses.prerequisites: (Students must be registered in graduate-level studies in Anatomy & Cell Biology.)

courses.name: PHYS 306 Mechanics
courses.description: Newtonian mechanics, non-inertial frames, central potentials, Kepler's laws, variational calculus, Lagrangian dynamics, rigid body motion, Hamiltonian mechanics, Poisson brackets, canonical, Hamilton-Jacobi theory, action angle variables.
courses.prerequisites: One of MATH 200, MATH 217, MATH 226 and one of MATH 221, MATH 223, MATH 152 and either (a) SCIE 001 or (b) one of PHYS 12, PHYS 107, PHYS 157, PHYS 170, PHYS 216 and one of PHYS 102, PHYS 108, PHYS 158.

courses.name: WOOD 499 Wood Products Capstone
courses.description: Development of a wood products manufacturing start-up company.  Development of comprehensive business plan, marketing strategy, product design, equipment selection and justification, manufacturing plant layout, and economic analyses.
courses.prerequisites: All of WOOD 440, WOOD 465. (and fourth-year standing in Wood Products Processing.)

courses.name: COMM 407 Real Estate Economics
courses.description: The economics of real estate markets. Topics include real estate cycles and bubbles, search models and vacancy, the relationship between real estate and the economy, housing demand, and models of housing supply.

courses.name: CHEM 573 Application of Spectroscopy to Organic Structural Determinations
courses.description: A problem solving course to illustrate the application of NMR, mass spectrometry, ORD, CD, etc. to elucidation of structures of organic and organometallic compounds.

courses.name: ISCI 448D Directed Studies - DIRECTED STUDIES
courses.description: Permission of the Director is required.

courses.name: EDCP 598B Field Experiences - FIELD EXPERIENCE
courses.description: Field experiences in community-based or museum contexts. Focus on curriculum design and evaluation.

courses.name: MUSC 562C Wind and Percussion Chamber Ensembles - WIND CHAM ENS SX
courses.description: Open only to graduate students.

courses.name: MUSC 593E Music Performance (Major) - GUITAR,ETHN&HIST
courses.description: Private instruction, vocal or instrumental. May be repeated for credit, in accordance with program requirements.

courses.name: FIST 338 Asian and Australasian Cinema
courses.description: Topics may include an analysis of a national cinema, such as that of China, India, or Australia.

courses.name: FOOD 512 Hazard Analysis and Critical Control Point and Food Safety Management
GRSJ 450A Directed Studies - DIRECTED STUDIES
courses.description: General reading and/or a research undertaking, with the agreement, and under supervision of, a faculty member selected by the student and approved by the GRSJ Undergraduate Advisor. A written paper or equivalent will be required. Open to GRSJ majors or minors.

courses.name: WOOD 474 Wood Properties and Products Manufacturing
courses.description: Wood moisture, density and strength properties; manufacturing processes for major forest products.

courses.name: MTRL 578 Microstructural Evolution of Deformed Materials
courses.description: Physical mechanisms of microstructure evolution; structure, energy and mobilities of grain boundaries, grain boundary segregation, precipitation, recovery, recrystallization, grain growth; microstructure engineering of steels.

courses.name: SPHA 531 Economic Evaluation
courses.description: Maximizing health benefits from health care budgets.

courses.name: DHYG 108 Oral Health Sciences I
courses.description: An introduction to normal, healthy facial, oral, and dental structures; oral health records, and charting terminology and symbols.

courses.name: EDCP 471E Technological Practices in Education: Technical Problems - TECHNICAL PROB
PHAR 315 Pharmacokinetics
courses.description: Pharmacokinetics and clinical applications of pharmacokinetic principles.

courses.name: APBI 324 Introduction to Seed Plant Taxonomy
courses.description: Introduction to seed plant taxonomy emphasizing descriptive morphology and identification. Each student will be required to submit a plant collection.

courses.name: POLI 366 International Political Economy
courses.description: An analysis of governmental policies and international political bargaining in regard to such issues as international investment, trade, and monetary relations. Pre-requisite: ECON 100 or 309 are recommended.

courses.name: VISA 183 Studio Two: Meanings and Materials
courses.description: Contemporary art practices, emphasizing the relationship between meanings and materials, art historical contexts and concepts, and non-traditional materials. (This course is open to all UBC students, regardless of prior experience.)

courses.name: EDUC 451B Inquiry Seminar II - INQUIRY SEMNR 2
courses.description: Pass/Fail.

courses.name: EDST 507D Topics in the History of Education - TPC HIST OF EDUC
PSYC 314 Health Psychology
courses.description: Health-related behaviours such as smoking and drug use; effects of stressful events on health; methods for coping with stress; impact of chronic illness on the family; social support systems.
courses.prerequisites: Either (a) PSYC 100 or (b) all of PSYC 101, PSYC 102. (Or (c) 6 credits of 200-level Psychology (but not 205 or 263).)

courses.name: MINE 304 Rock Fragmentation
courses.description: Theory and practice of rock fragmentation by drilling and blasting; introduction to explosives and initiation systems; design of surface and underground blasts; machine excavation systems for tunneling and stoping; environmental impacts, safety, and risk assessment.

courses.name: ASIA 515B Topics in Early Vernacular Modern Chinese Literature - TPCS EARLY V CHN
ENDS 320 Design, Media and Representation
courses.description: Theories, histories and techniques of design representation; geometry, design and expression are principle areas of focus.

courses.name: ANTH 431C Museum Practice and Curatorship - MUS PRC&CURATRSH
courses.description: Management of museum collections and their public presentation, addressing questions of access, collaboration, and cultural property. The public interpretation of anthropological concepts and materials utilizing the programs and facilities of the Museum of Anthropology.

courses.name: ELEC 331 Computer Communications
courses.description: Analysis, design and implementation of computer networks and their protocols. Application layer protocols, transmission control protocol (TCP), Internet protocol (IP), routing algorithms, reliable data transfer, multiple access, Ethernet.
courses.prerequisites: One of EECE 269, ELEC 221, CPSC 261, EECE 359, EECE 315, CPEN 331.

courses.name: CRWR 405W Writing Creative Nonfiction I - CREATIV NONFIC I
courses.description: A workshop class in writing creative nonfiction, focused on some of the more popular forms of creative nonfiction: autobiography, rhetoric (commentary), literary journalism, and the personal essay. Admission is restricted to B.F.A. Majors in Creative Writing.

courses.name: LING 432 Field Methods II
courses.description: Elicitation, transcription, organization, and analysis of linguistic data from a native speaker of a language not commonly studied.  Practical experience in the use of fieldwork equipment.

courses.name: ECON 310 Principles of Microeconomics
courses.description: The scope of this course is approximately the same as that of ECON101. The course is intended for upper-level students only. Credit will be given for only one of ECON 310 and ECON 101.

courses.name: PATH 408 Laboratory Administration
courses.description: Personnel management, staff management relationships, stock control, record keeping, etc. Medicolegal aspects of medical laboratory science. Theory and practice of quality control. Use of computers in the medical laboratory.

courses.name: CHIN 481 Modern Chinese Literature I (Heritage)
courses.description: Selected readings from the May Fourth Era to present. Not to be taken concurrently with any CHIN courses lower than 400-level. Credit will be granted for only one of CHIN 381 or CHIN 481.
courses.prerequisites: One of CHIN 313, CHIN 314, CHIN 317, CHIN 318, CHIN 323.

courses.name: ECED 440 Supporting Social and Communication Development in Infants and Young Children with Special Needs
courses.description: (Formerly EPSE 440).

courses.name: PHYS 501 Quantum Mechanics II
courses.description: Time-dependent perturbation theory, density matrix formalism, NMR, emission and absorption of radiation. Elementary field theory techniques for many body systems. Quasiparticles, phonons, magnons, holes. Relativistic Klein-Gordon and Dirac equations.

courses.name: CHIN 104 Intensive Basic Chinese I (Non-Heritage)
courses.description: Skills in listening, speaking, reading, and writing in Mandarin Chinese, an active vocabulary of about 500 Chinese words, and basic grammar.

courses.name: CIVL 311 Soil Mechanics II
courses.description: Consolidation and shear strength of soils, with application to settlement and stability analysis of embankments, retaining walls, shallow footing and pile foundations.

courses.name: MTRL 559 Advanced Hydrometallurgy
courses.description: Advanced thermochemical modeling of hydrometallurgical unit operations to include extraction, separation, and recovery of base metals.  Application to flow-sheet analysis.

courses.name: ECED 416 Kindergarten Curriculum
courses.description: The development of kindergarten programs with reference to recent research, theories of early learning, curriculum trends and practices, and the place of kindergarten in contemporary education.

courses.name: ASTU 400A Interdisciplinary Studies in Arts - KNOWLEDGE MAKING
courses.description: For upper-division students in the Faculty of Arts. Topics announced annually.

courses.name: CAPS 448A Directed Studies in Physiology - DIRECTED STUDIES
MUSC 607C Composition - COMPOSITION
courses.description: Further study for doctoral candidates in Composition.

courses.name: CSIS 490C Directed Topics - DIRECTED TOPICS
courses.description: Designed to allow a student to develop an individual course of study in a specific area as approved by a faculty member affiliated with the CSIS program.

courses.name: CHIN 108 Intensive Basic Chinese II (Non-Heritage)
courses.description: Skills in listening, speaking, reading, and writing in Mandarin Chinese, an active vocabulary of about 1000 Chinese words, and basic grammar.

courses.name: EOSC 424 Advanced Mineral Deposits
courses.description: Advanced concepts in the processes that lead to the formation of mineral deposits. Introduction to the study of ore minerals using reflected light microscopy.

courses.name: CPEN 442 Introduction to Computer Security
courses.description: Security risks, threats, and vulnerabilities from technical perspectives; confidentiality, integrity, and hybrid policies; cryptography, access control, assurance, accountability, and engineering of secure systems.
courses.prerequisites: One of EECE 314, CPEN 333, EECE 315, CPEN 331, CPSC 313.

courses.name: PHIL 514A Early Modern Philosophy - ERLY MODERN PHIL
GEOB 300 Microscale Weather and Climate
courses.description: Meteorology and climatology at the micro-, local, and meso-scales. Interactions between land surfaces and atmosphere. Basics of atmospheric turbulence and transfer processes. Microclimates on scales of a leaf to those of a large valley.

courses.name: SOCI 200 Sociology of the Family
courses.description: An introduction to contemporary family forms and relations.

courses.name: SPPH 562 Chemical and Biological Hazard Measurement
courses.description: Industrial hygiene and environmental exposure monitoring, methods, and instrumentation, and theory. Laboratories demonstrate workplace sampling and analysis techniques.

courses.name: GSAT 502 Advanced Concepts in Genome Science and Technology
courses.description: Current approaches to high-throughput, system-wide analysis, and manipulation of biological systems.

courses.name: SOWK 523A Advanced Analysis of Culture and Race in Social Work Practice - CLTR & RACE SOWK
CENS 303A Representations of the Holocaust (in English) - REPRESENTNS HOLO
courses.description: The Nazi Holocaust in film and literature from Central, Eastern, and Northern European Countries.

courses.name: MATH 253 Multivariable Calculus
courses.description: Partial and directional derivatives; maxima and minima; Lagrange multipliers and second derivative test; multiple integrals and applications. Please consult the Faculty of Science Credit Exclusion List: www.students.ubc.ca/calendar/index.cfm?tree=12,215,410,414.
courses.prerequisites: One of MATH 101, MATH 103, MATH 105, MATH 121, SCIE 001.

courses.name: ENGL 309 Rhetoric of Science, Technology, and Medicine
courses.description: Exploration of the persuasive dimension of discourse practices in science, technology, and medicine.

courses.name: SPHA 552 Design and Measurement 2
courses.description: Clinical Epidemiology, trials and the evaluation of diagnostic tools and therapeutic interventions.

courses.name: HGSE 352 First Nations and Natural Resources
courses.description: Overview of the relationship of First Nations with natural resources, with emphasis on First Nations involvement in forest management, past and present.  A core element of the Haida Gwaii Semester.

courses.name: CCST 500 Seminar in Interdisciplinary Frameworks in Museum and Curatorial Studies
courses.description: Theoretical and historical foundations of visual representations and expressive culture. It explores the history of museums and galleries, and changes in the meaning of art and material culture as debates about cultural property intensify.

courses.name: ITAL 302 Third-Year Italian II
courses.description: Reading, writing, speaking, comprehension. Special emphasis on oral practice and on composition.

courses.name: MINE 497N Directed Studies - MN RSC DEV & CDN
courses.description: Requires approval of the department head.

courses.name: ENGL 462E Twentieth-Century British and Irish Studies - 20CENT BRIT & IR
courses.prerequisites: (3rd year standing and 6 credits of first-year English, or Arts One, or 6 credits of ASTU 100 from CAP or 3 credits of first-year English and 3 credits of ASTU 150)

courses.name: ASTU 204A Topics in Interdisciplinary Studies in the Humanities - TPC INTERD STUDY
LING 333 Research Methods for Linguistics
courses.description: Research methods used in linguistics and speech science. Emphasis on scientific reasoning, critical thinking, experimental design, and the ethics and methods of linguistic data-collection.

courses.name: EDUC 419D School-based Extended Practicum: Middle Years - EXT PRACT MID YR
courses.description: Pass/Fail.
courses.prerequisites: (Normally all requirements set to precede this practicum.)

courses.name: RGLA 372A Topics in Religion, Literature, and the Arts - TPC RELG LIT ART
courses.description: The topic is selected and announced annually by the RGLA Committee.

courses.name: NURS 591 Ethical and Professional Issues in NP Practice
ASIA 398 Narrative Literature in Premodern India
courses.description: Stories of gods, goddesses and religious heroes from the Ramayana, Mahabharata, Puranas, Avadanas and in classical poetry and drama.

courses.name: JAPN 102 Beginning Japanese II A
courses.description: Continuation of JAPN 101 (Non-intensive).

courses.name: POLI 332 Politics and Government of Latin America
courses.description: A comparative examination of democracy and authoritarianism in Latin America: populism, corporatism, bureaucratic authoritarianism, transitions from authoritarianism, and contemporary debates on the quality and diversity of democratic institutions.

courses.name: SOWK 430A Special Studies in Social Work - SPEC STDS SOWK
courses.description: Lectures, seminars and/or individual tutorials to develop knowledge and skills in relation to a defined theory, policy or practice problem or client population. Enrolment is limited to students in the B.S.W. program, except by permission of the School.

courses.name: ARTH 322 Early Modern Italian Art and Culture (ca. 1550-1700)
courses.description: Focus primarily on Rome as the center of artistic, cultural, economic, and religious power in the seventeenth century.

courses.name: MDVL 210 Introduction to Medieval Studies
courses.description: A survey of the study of the medieval period in Western Europe (400-1550), integrating history, literature, and the arts; topics vary from year to year; interested students should consult the Medieval Studies Advisor.

courses.name: EOSC 422 Structural Geology II
courses.description: Studies of natural deformation using advanced techniques.

courses.name: SPPH 540 Program Planning and Evaluation
courses.description: Examines the concept of evaluation in health services and how various methodological approaches can be used in evaluative studies.
courses.prerequisites: Either (a) all of HCEP 400, HCEP 502 or (b) all of SPPH 400, SPPH 502.

courses.name: HIST 490H Seminar for Majors in History - SEM FOR HIST MAJ
courses.description: Selected problems in the theory and practice of historical work. Check with the department for course offerings. Restricted to fourth year students majoring in History or in the History and Philosophy of Science. Also open to History Honours students.

courses.name: PCTH 398 Co-operative Work Placement I
courses.description: Approved and supervised technical work experience in an industrial research setting for a minimum of 3.5 months. Technical report required. Restricted to students admitted to the Co-operative Education Program in Pharmacology.

courses.name: ENGL 509A Studies in Rhetoric and Theory of Composition - RHET & THRY COMP
KIN 330 Human Motor Behaviour II
courses.description: Acquisition, performance, and control of skilled movements. Processes and underlying mechanisms involved in learning and performing motor skills. Credit will be granted for only one of KIN 330 or KIN 468.

courses.name: KIN 568 Seminar in Human Motor Performance
courses.description: Reports and discussions of research literature concerning theories and findings in human performance. Special emphasis is given to understanding the basic mechanisms underlying motor performance within the framework of man as a component system.

courses.name: CIVL 598F Topics in Civil Engineering - CONSTRUCTN PROJ
courses.description: Seminar or lecture.

courses.name: MECH 280 Introduction to Fluid Mechanics
courses.description: Fluid properties; statics; kinematics, dynamics, energy, and momentum principles for one-dimensional flow; dimensional analysis and similarity; laminar and turbulent flow; pipe flow; principles of turbo-machine flow; forces on bodies in flow.
courses.prerequisites: All of MATH 152, PHYS 170 and one of MATH 217, MATH 253 and either (a) all of PHYS 101, PHYS 102 or (b) PHYS 153.

courses.name: BIOL 432 Research Strategies and Techniques in Cell Biology
courses.description: Major physiological mechanisms that define eukaryotic cells, explored through student visits to UBC research laboratories and discussion of recent scientific literature, with emphasis on the techniques and strategies that enable researchers to test hypotheses and advance new concepts.
courses.prerequisites: All of BIOL 200, BIOL 362 and one of BIOL 233, BIOL 234. (And fourth-year standing.)

courses.name: ECON 457 Seminar in International Economic Relations
courses.description: Selected topics focusing upon various issues arising in international economic relations. Open only to fourth-year students in the Major program in International Relations.

courses.name: APSC 486 New Venture Design
courses.description: Teams comprising students in APSC 486 and COMM 486 create a business plan and a prototype or engineering solution of a novel product, process, or process component.

courses.name: LAW 486 Law Review Credit
courses.description: Study and practice of law journal editing and business operations. For students acting as senior editors or the business manager for the UBC Law Review, the Canadian Journal of Family Law or any other equivalent legal journal based in the Faculty of Law.

courses.name: LARC 582B Seminar: Special Topics - ADV TPCS IN SUST
WOOD 330 Industrial Engineering
courses.description: Use of industrial engineering concepts and methods to analyze and improve organizations, including operations strategy and competitiveness, quality control, work measurement, inventory management, linear programming, sensitivity analysis, transportation problems, and capacity planning.
